fields.headline: Charisma alone cannot revive Spurs
fields.trailText: Life could hardly look better for Tottenham Hotspur. The problem at White Hart Lane these days is that every silver lining seems to have a cloud.
fields.body:
Life could hardly look better for Tottenham Hotspur. Figures issued earlier this month show a club in improving, healthy financial condition and last season's Worthington Cup winners go into today's north London derby at Arsenal, whom they defeated at home in November, in seventh place in the Premiership on the back of a record 7-2 win last weekend. The problem at White Hart Lane these days is that every silver lining seems to have a cloud.

Few Spurs supporters, and probably few inside the club - with the possible exception of the chairman Sir Alan Sugar - are fooled by the superficial gloss of the plc's report that showed turnover up 34 per cent to £29.8 million. Nor does the demolition of Southampton's flimsy defence amount to convincing evidence that the club can bridge a growing chasm and claim an all-important top-three position in the Premiership.

Football always involves comparison and expectation, for Tottenham more than most. Chelsea are Johnny-come-latelies, they believe; Manchester United should be more the benchmark, though Liverpool, granted, also have a shout at the top table. Arsenal? Winners, but not with the charisma that Spurs possess.

For charisma, read cloud cuckoo land. While they may be financially a much more attractive proposition than when Sugar got his hands on them for a few million quid, their valuation is probably around a tenth of Manchester United's £1 billion. And, as George Graham pointed out when he took over as manager 18 months ago: 'All that stuff about the Spurs tradition for attractive football is just a crutch. They haven't been playing like that for ages.'

To top the insults, the Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger - whose side easily eclipse Spurs for flair - even ventured earlier this season that though he was aware of the importance and rivalry with Spurs, the derby against Chelsea was the more significant these days in terms of the top of the table.

For the current regime of Sugar, Graham and director of football David Pleat, this is a crucial time in their redevelopment of the club. The Worthington Cup win bought Graham time, but doubts and questions still abound, for all his skill at plucking out results like Southampton at delicate times - before last Saturday, they had scored only six goals in nine previous games.

Is the mistrusted Sugar willing to take the necessary financial gamble to lift the club to the next level or is it all just a vehicle for his ego, profit-seeking and other business interests? Does Graham still have the drive and judgment to assemble a top-three squad playing entertaining football? Will patience extend to waiting for the blossoming of some of the promising young players that Pleat has acquired, such as Simon Davies, Matthew Etherington and the Swedish under-17 captain Jon Jonssen?

Next year will be the fortieth since Spurs last won the title, the tenth since they won the FA Cup. The closest they have come to being champions since was in 1987 when the then manager, Pleat, assembled the exciting Hoddle-Waddle side and finished third. He also took them to the FA Cup final.

Pleat now laments what happened in the decade afterwards. 'We got landed with a lot of mercenaries and foreign players because previous managers panicked and bought mediocrity,' he says. 'It's taking us a while to recover.'

Graham's indulgence by Tottenham fans was hardly helped recently, however, by the abortive attempt to sign John Hartson for £6 million from Wimbledon; his muscular manner is not what Spurs fans expect. It may be recalled that Sir Alex Ferguson began to doubt his assistant Brian Kidd's judgment when he suggested Hartson before United bought Dwight Yorke.

Though some £17 million has already been spent, on such solid performers as Chris Perry, Tim Sherwood and Oyvind Leonhardsen, there is still no sign of the quality striker like Yorke or midfield player with guile that N17 craves, and both Sugar and Graham are apparently reluctant to shell out £10 million and more for one player.

Graham seems to want to build in the way he did at Arsenal at the time he began to eclipse Pleat's Tottenham; in prudent stages on the transfer front and by hard work on the training ground. One wonders, however, whether the same policy will work, with the game having moved on since then.

Gérard Houllier, for example, has instigated an expensive revolution at Anfield to accompany the work ethic. In addition, at Arsenal they have recognised the need to speculate to accumulate, while Arsène Wenger also believes in working smarter, not harder. His scientific training sessions often last only 45 minutes.

'If I was a young player today, I would still sign for George because he would definitely make me a better player,' says Paul Merson, a leading Gunner in the Graham era now enjoying a twinkling twilight at Aston Villa. 'But because of his physical demands, I'd have to think twice as an older player.'

Word is that Graham is more reluctant these days to scour the world for players. Perhaps it is a waste of time since selling the Spurs name may be akin to that of Rover cars abroad. 'It's still a great name,' Pleat insists. 'I believe overseas players are aware of the standards and traditions.'

Perhaps Graham also feels that he has a real job on to keep those at home happy. Spurs fans may no longer lament the probable departure of Darren Anderton, but should Sol Campbell decide that the club is not progressing sufficiently quickly and seek a move, then the White Hart Lane worm would turn.

Graham is a shrewd man. He knew the value of Tony Adams to Arsenal and kept him; so should he with Campbell. Sugar clearly needs to bankroll the wages and signings necessary to send signals of ambition. Graham has also learned from some mistakes and his retention of David Ginola, despite his misgivings, shows political and practical sense; there is no other player at the club capable of creating so much.

There are other echoes that Graham will need to ponder. At Arsenal, he left it too late to spend money to reinvigorate a declining side; at Leeds we are now seeing the flowering of young players that David O'Leary has been willing to throw in more readily than a cautious Graham.

And there are concerns that Sugar should be aware of. His PR exercise in pegging ticket prices next season, currently among the highest in the country, will count for little should other clubs continue to pull away, leaving a remarkable Tottenham support of more than 35,000 growing disillusioned all over again. Chelsea's success may be transient but three years in the Champions League will mean, like Manchester United and Arsenal, that they are £50 million ahead of Spurs.

Graham can still organise cleverly a team for a one-off task against superior opponents but beyond that, today's game at Highbury should tell us more about how much further Sugar needs to go to fund fulfilment, and how capable Graham is of delivering it. If they don't in the next year or so, then Spurs could well end up as a club with a great future behind them.

webTitle: Chelsea may prove a Silvio lining

fields.headline: Chelsea may prove a Silvio lining
fields.standfirst: Jon Henderson
fields.trailText: If you think this week's draw for the quarter-finals of the Champions League means each of the eight teams could be paired with any one of the other seven you probably haven't heard Tom Finney's been dropped by England. TV-driven modern football lost its innocence many sendings-off ago and although the draw in Geneva on Friday will not be fixed it will be - how to say this? - heavily manipulated.
fields.body:
If you think this week's draw for the quarter-finals of the Champions League means each of the eight teams could be paired with any one of the other seven you probably haven't heard Tom Finney's been dropped by England. TV-driven modern football lost its innocence many sendings-off ago and although the draw in Geneva on Friday will not be fixed it will be - how to say this? - heavily manipulated.

The winners of the four second-phase groups will be kept apart as will the two teams that finished first and runner-up in the same group. In other words, instead of starting with the possibility of playing any of one of the other seven, a team will know it must be drawn against one of only three opponents. At least this has the virtue of meaning there is plenty of incentive for Manchester United and Chelsea to perform well in the final round of second-phase matches this week even though they are already through to the last eight. If they win their groups they will not only avoid each other, they will be kept apart from Barcelona and Bayern Munich. ITV and ONdigital, who show the Champions League, will - of course - also be hoping United and Chelsea manage to avoid each other in the draw. ITV had their best viewing figure of the competition last Wednesday when 10 million viewers - or 43 per cent of the national audience - watched United's win over Fiorentina. It was also the biggest audience anywhere in Europe for one of last week's Champions League matches. Now things are set to get even better for the two broad casters. 'It's at the quarter-finals that our big investment in the Champions League really starts to pay off,' says Jeff Farmer, ITV's head of football.

All this contrasts with the fortunes of Silvio Berlusconi in Italy. Not only did the president of AC Milan see his club knocked out of the Champions League in the first group stage, now his media empire could be left without any Italian action at all in the competition. Berlusconi's Mediaset group have the rights to Lazio and Fiorentina's Champions League games in Italy and have been broadcasting them on his Canale 5 station. But if results don't go well for Fiorentina on Tuesday and Lazio fail to win at Stamford Bridge on Wednesday, the man who badgered Uefa into expanding the Champions League will be left with the hard task of selling games with no local interest in them. Italian viewers should prepare themselves for an onslaught of ads featuring Gianluca Vialli and Gianfranco Zola as the azzurri from west London are lined up to save Silvio's budget.

jon.henderson@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Silent hero enjoying life
fields.standfirst: Duncan Ferguson returns to Goodison Park this afternoon - and he's better than ever
fields.trailText: Fair warning: this is not an interview with Duncan Ferguson. Anyone looking for one of those should track down some old Scottish newspapers or the odd Newcastle United programme. The striker formerly known as Duncan Disorderly no longer speaks to the media, partly because they come up with such unflattering nicknames, and any resemblance between what follows and actual contact between Ferguson and this newspaper is entirely coincidental.
fields.body:
Fair warning: this is not an interview with Duncan Ferguson. Anyone looking for one of those should track down some old Scottish newspapers or the odd Newcastle United programme. The striker formerly known as Duncan Disorderly no longer speaks to the media, partly because they come up with such unflattering nicknames, and any resemblance between what follows and actual contact between Ferguson and this newspaper is entirely coincidental.

Ferguson has been called the Greta Garbo of football, although his horror of any kind of exposure makes the reclusive actress look like Posh Spice. The BBC cannot get him to appear on A Question of Sport, despite the fact that John Parrott is now his brother-in-law. After several rebuffs, the programme took the unusual step of asking Parrott to make a personal request, to which Ferguson replied politely but firmly in the negative, and this time he was only being asked to be a mystery guest.

The Scot can occasionally be prevailed upon to make public appearances to thank supporters, but was furious when Sky TV cameras turned up and took over a player of the month award last year. Similarly, when Everton visited St James's Park last November, a rare interview with Ferguson in the programme was predictably plundered by a succession of quote-starved newspapers, even though it contained nothing more startling than an admission that he was pleased to see the club climb out of the bottom three and a promise that he felt 'fitter and stronger' and was 'dying to show the Geordies something of the real Duncan Ferguson'. Over the course of the next couple of weeks, Ferguson became so fed up with seeing the same quotes rehashed in different articles he asked the club if it was possible to put a stop to it.

Ferguson is not the only footballer who does not understand how the media work, but he ought to be able to work out that it is his own reticence that gives his occasional utterances a value they scarcely deserve. He could learn from Alan Shearer, who does not talk much either, but says enough to confirm he has mastered the art of the anodyne interview. Ferguson's self-imposed silence dates fairly precisely from the sequence of events in Scotland that led to a six-week stay in Barlinnie Prison for a butt on Raith's John McStay while playing for Rangers in 1994. It is reasonable to assume he either blames the press for what happened (even though he was on probation at the time of the McStay incident), or does not want to give inquisitors the chance to bring it up. Never the most relaxed of interviewees even in the carefree days of his youth, Ferguson is positively hostile now. 'If there was any justice in this world those people who wrote all that rubbish about a great, great player [Shearer] who has since rammed every daft word down their throats should have been thrown out of their jobs on newspapers, radio and television,' he recently concluded.

Shearer's response to this vote of confidence was to follow Ferguson's lead and announce his international retirement. Scotland have practically no strikers, certainly none of Ferguson's physical presence, so it is assumed his non-availability is harming his country, though since he has never added to the solitary goal he scored at under-21 level in seven full internationals there is room for debate on the subject. Goalscoring has never been Ferguson's forte, but failing to impose himself against the might of Estonia in his last appearance in a dismal 0-0 draw in Monaco in 1997 convinced many Scots they were not missing out on much. Craig Brown remains diplomatically receptive to a Ferguson change of heart, but usually stresses he would like the 6ft 4in striker as an option. The Scottish manager will be aware that one or two of his players believe Ferguson switches teams into involuntary long-ball mode. 'You can't help it,' one former team-mate explained. 'You look up and he's the first thing you see. The easiest thing is always to just hit it to him.'

Bobby Robson does not appear to have any problems with that, neither does Shearer, and neither did Ruud Gullit, who bought Ferguson as a target man after initially inquiring after Dion Dublin. What you get with Ferguson is surprising ability on the ground for such a big man, and the occasional awesome display of strength and aggression when he is pumped up for big matches. 'Unplayable' is Alan Hansen's verdict. What you don't get is a regular supply of goals, and you tend not to get consistency either, since some part of Ferguson's extraordinary physique is usually under strain and he never seems far from his next injury.

Yet if Fenerbahce really have £12 million to wave under Newcastle's nose for Ferguson, Robson can be credited with a transformation even more startling than his celebrated rejuvenation of Shearer. Getting the England captain back to the top of the Premiership scoring charts is nothing compared to showing a profit on a player who was merely an £8 million adornment to the treatment room under Gullit. It is possible the Turkish club's alleged interest stems from the misapprehension that Ferguson scores goals like last month's screamer against Manchester United all the time, but Robson is not about to let the facts get in the way of a good story.

'Ferguson fought Jaap Stam in the air, he fought him on the touchline,' said a splendidly over-the-top Newcastle manager in full Churchillian flow. 'He gave him a torrid time, and I don't think Stam enjoyed it one bit. He probably found Ferguson the toughest, most awkward striker he has played against this season, and that includes the Champions League. Big Duncan is beginning to enjoy his football again, that's the change in him. He likes what he's doing so now he's doing it better. It shows in matches and it shows in training. He's not missing training like he was doing when I first came here.'

Ferguson credits Robson for the correct diagnosis. 'He took the time and trouble to really examine my situation, and told me I was trying to come back too early from injuries,' he said (yes, in a club magazine). 'He was right. I have tended to do that throughout my career, and there have been occasions when I have had an injection and played when I shouldn't.' The newly restored Ferguson has again rejected Scotland, which Robson thinks is a pity, since they do not have another player like him. 'Mind you, there's no one like him in England either,' he said. 'Kevin Phillips isn't like him, neither is Andy Cole or Teddy Sheringham. He's unique.' And his partnership with Shearer? 'The most lethal in the Premiership,' according to fellow Scot Kevin Gallacher, who incidentally believes Ferguson is 'too big' to coerce back into a Scotland shirt.

The respect in Gallacher's tribute is revealing. At both his English clubs, Ferguson has been hugely popular with supporters, fellow players, and hospital wards, which witnessed his impromptu visits and unheralded generosity. He is sure of a rapturous welcome at Everton today. Ferguson might have made a few mistakes when fame and fortune descended upon him too quickly in Scotland, but all you hear about now is a player who tips apprentices on boot duty with £20 notes, buys presents for team-mates' babies, and makes sizeable donations to local charities as long as the press don't find out.

You have to go back a few years to find anyone with a bad word to say about Ferguson, but one Karen Young, a topless dancer from his bachelor days on Merseyside, complained in the Sunday Mirror that he only had three topics of conversation: 'Football, prison, or his damned pigeons.' There's just no pleasing some girls. Ferguson may not find his way on to many chat shows, but three subjects is well above average. Too many players these days can't even talk about football.

You have to go back a few years to find anyone with a bad word to say about Ferguson, but one Karen Young, a topless dancer from his bachelor days on Merseyside, complained in the Sunday Mirror that he only had three topics of conversation: 'Football, prison, or his damned pigeons.' There's just no pleasing some girls. Ferguson may not find his way on to many chat shows, but three subjects is well above average. Too many players these days can't even talk about football.

webTitle: Players' age and experience are not to be scoffed at

fields.headline: Players' age and experience are not to be scoffed at
fields.trailText: One of my most cherished distinctions is that I am the oldest outfield player to have appeared in the Premiership. However, after seeing Richard Gough and Mark Hughes in action for Everton at Coventry last week, it occurs to me that I should savour my position while I can - it is unlikely to last much longer.
fields.body:
One of my most cherished distinctions is that I am the oldest outfield player to have appeared in the Premiership. However, after seeing Richard Gough and Mark Hughes in action for Everton at Coventry last week, it occurs to me that I should savour my position while I can - it is unlikely to last much longer.

Of all the players at this level who are in their late thirties, one obvious contender to take my record - achieved when I appeared in the Coventry-Derby match in May 1997 at the age of 40 and four months - has been West Ham's Stuart Pearce. Now, with Pearce's chances of doing so having been undermined by two leg fractures, Gough and Hughes must be the best bets.

Gough, my former Scotland colleague, will be 38 on 5 April, while Hughes, a team-mate at Manchester United, reached that age last month. But they hardly seem to have changed at all physically - and the same applies to their ability.

Richard has the same lean body shape that he had some 20 years ago, when he was at the start of his career with Dundee United and I was at Aberdeen. He produced a superb performance against us on Wednesday. His anticipation, particularly with regards to the number of good crosses we produced, was as good as that of any Premiership central defender I have seen this season.

The misgivings about the decision by Everton's manager, Walter Smith, to bring Richard to Everton at the start of the season - because of his age and limited top-flight football experience in recent seasons - have been proved to be misplaced. I feel it will be the same story with Mark, who made his Everton debut against Coventry after being given a free transfer by Southampton.

True, he did not score many goals for Southampton. But the other way of looking at Everton's decision to sign him concerns his ability as a target man. Even today, I would say that his strength in gaining possession of the ball under pressure, and retaining it long enough to allow the other members of his team to to get organised, is unrivalled.

The cases of Richard and Mark, as with those of most players who are still going strong at the top level in their thirties, contain a number of common denominators.

Apart from their avoidance of serious injuries, the most important of these is their enthusiasm for the game and the extent to which they are prepared to push themselves in training and look after themselves physically.

In that respect, for players who have been less committed than others, it is never too late to change. It is a bit like giving up smoking.

As you get older, the inevitable decline in physical power can be offset to a great extent by your knowledge of the game. When I reached the so-called 'veteran' stage in my own career, I found that while I had lost perhaps 10 per cent of my fitness and stamina, my football intelligence had improved by 25 per cent. But that does not mean you can afford not to keep training flat out. The body has to be accustomed to the tempo at which it is expected to perform on a Saturday.

Therefore, although an older player might train for an hour a day, as opposed to an hour and a half, the effort he puts into it must be 100 per cent.

A number of players are sceptical about the advantages of doing a lot of physical work. In pre-season training, when there is a particular emphasis on this, one often hears complaints such as: 'We are footballers, not Olympic athletes.' But one thing they overlook is that the greater their fitness and stamina, the better their concentration becomes. When it comes to matches, it is the players who are the most tired who make the most mistakes.

In terms of footballers adopting the mentalities of athletes, Richard Gough is as good an example as any. He has always driven himself to the extent where outsiders might well have looked upon him as some kind of masochist. One vivid illustration of his approach was when the Scotland squad were undergoing altitude training in Santa Fe before the 1986 World Cup finals in Mexico.

At times when the players might have been expected to be relaxing. Richard could often be found working out in the sports centre adjoining our hotel. He was even spotted taking part in some public aerobics sessions there.

The other reason why I am not sur prised by his present success concerns his relationship with Smith, who was also his manager at Rangers.

As players get older, I feel that managers need to treat them differently from others. To get the best out of them, I personally think it is important for managers to show that they trust players to take on the responsibility of looking after themselves, and, in some cases, to consult them.

Richard himself has said that towards the end of his career as Rangers captain his self-esteem, and therefore his enjoyment of playing, was boosted by the fact that Smith would often discuss his ideas or thoughts with him. The comment certainly struck a chord with me because I was treated in the same way by Howard Wilkinson when I joined Leeds from Manchester United, and there is no doubt that it was a major factor in enabling me to extend my playing career as long as I did.

I have been very conscious of this in my dealings with the 'veteran' pros I have worked with as Coventry manager. While I am the one who ultimately makes all the football decisions, I have no compunctions about seeking advice or guidance occasionally from our captain, Gary McAllister, or any of our other leading senior pros.

Players with Gary's personal pride and dedication are a joy to work with. I have enormous respect and admiration for him, and all the other thirtysomethings who are currently pushing back the clock and doing well in the Premiership. If and when my record goes, nobody will applaud the player more enthusiastically than me.

webTitle: FA set to revolutionise English football

fields.headline: FA set to revolutionise English football
fields.trailText: English football is about to undergo a revolution designed to ensure Michael Owen, Emile Heskey and Kieron Dyer lift the World Cup in 2006 - ideally at the new Wembley.
fields.body:
English football is about to undergo a revolution designed to ensure Michael Owen, Emile Heskey and Kieron Dyer lift the World Cup in 2006 - ideally at the new Wembley.

The Football Association is making a decisive break with its troubled recent past - the mire of bungs, Hoddlegate and stifling inertia - by pushing through far-reaching changes to almost every aspect of the game, both on and off the pitch.

The Football Association's new 12-man governing board has approved a radical three-year action plan drawn up by Adam Crozier, its recently arrived, ultra-reformist chief executive. There will be dramatic steps to improve the quality of play on the field and a raft of measures to restore the Football Association's tarnished credibility.

New 'financial police' will scrutinise clubs' financial affairs, all transfers will have to be recorded at Lancaster Gate and thousands of Ajax-style 'superclubs' will be introduced to raise skill standards. Crucially, the FA Cup will be given special attention to help it regain its central place in both the football calendar and the affections of supporters everywhere.

It is almost certain that the Cup will, after 2001, be played on only two days at a weekend rather than the three or four that have been commonplace this season. The third round will go back to January and replays will be preserved. The Football Association's tender guidelines for broadcasters hoping to screen the competition being finalised tomorrow will make clear that whichever station(s) show the Cup will have to transmit it with imagination and due regard for its glorious tradition.

A new domestic football calendar is on the cards too, if the competing interests of the Football Association, Premier League and Football League can somehow be reconciled - and if both Uefa and Fifa agree. That could mean summer football, a winter break and a smaller Premiership.

Winning the game's ultimate prize, preferably on English soil, is the key target. 'Everything we do from now on will be geared to trying to fulfil that objective,' said Crozier. 'Kevin Keegan runs the national team, which is at the apex. He must have the raw material in the form of the best young players we can produce with which to challenge for 2006.'

However, regaining the Football Association's authority - a casualty of mismanagement, the Premier League's growing power and the re-emergence of an influential elite of top clubs - is both the explicit and implicit purpose of much of the shake-up. The English game's governing body realises it must urgently reinvent itself if it is to continue to play a meaningful role in the sport nationally and internationally.

Crozier, a Scotsman with a background in advertising, has secured the backing of the Football Association's new streamlined board for his wide-ranging blueprint, despite having only been there for two months.

'The FA has never had a plan before about how it was going to take football forward. Now we have a three-year plan which starts literally on Monday [tomorrow],' he said.

Crozier's 80-page document, which will go a long way to determining whether the recent green shoots of English football recovery - especially the emergence of many exciting young talents - actually bloom. He will need to maintain the whirlwind pace of change he has set since 10 January for the next three years to implement what is, by Football Association standards, an astonishingly ambitious plan.

Much of Crozier's manifesto for change borrows heavily on his former job at Saatchi & Saatchi. Under the heading 'regaining the leadership of the people's game', he lists 'vision, purpose and values' as the three areas in which, if the Football Association get things right, they can again boast authority.

Key changes include:

* Introducing a new domestic football calendar. Senior Football Association personnel will attend a two-day summit with the Premier League and Football League next month to start throwing around ideas for the possible shape, rhythm and content of a new season. However, the parties' conflicting interests - such as the League's attachment to the Worthington Cup and the majority of the Premiership's desire to stick with a 20-club top flight - will make agreement difficult.

* Creating a new financial compliance unit to oversee all 92 English clubs' financial dealings. Intended to work as an 'early warning system' to problems that might occur. Will be staffed by at least six top accountants. However, while every club will have its books inspected annually, they will only be visited if problems arise. In addition both its powers and the punishments that may follow an FCU inquiry are still unclear.

* Restoring the FA Cup's pre-eminence and avoiding this season's pitfalls that have seen holders Manchester United be allowed to withdraw, low crowds at the first-ever third round games staged before Christmas and confusion among fans about what stage it had reached.

* Establishing 3,000 grassroots 'superclubs' within three years. Already common in Holland and Germany, they run up to 20 teams each and use their good facilities to draw together a huge number of participants. County Football Associations will have a key role in this.

* Details of all transfers involving English clubs, both domestic and foreign, will have to be given to Lancaster Gate, including the exact fee paid and any cut given to an agent or any other third party, as part of a crackdown on bungs.

* Setting up a customer relations unit at the Football Association to deal with fans' queries and concerns. But what could it do to help a fan disgruntled about a huge season-ticket hike? Crozier says a new good practice charter at every club should prevent that.

* All coaches and managers in English professional football will have to have a Football Association pro licence before they can start working with players. Intended to drive up coaching standards.

* A women's professional league will be created in 2003 to reflect the booming interest in females playing football here and worldwide.

fields.headline: The club
fields.trailText: For a few seconds in Madrid last Tuesday, I thought Nicolas Anelka might really be mad. Sitting by the lake in the Buen Retiro park on a perfect summer's day in mid-March, I felt that only a loony would want to leave this city. Anelka, suspended by Real Madrid for 45 days for missing training sessions, will probably be off soon.
fields.body:
For a few seconds in Madrid last Tuesday, I thought Nicolas Anelka might really be mad. Sitting by the lake in the Buen Retiro park on a perfect summer's day in mid-March, I felt that only a loony would want to leave this city. Anelka, suspended by Real Madrid for 45 days for missing training sessions, will probably be off soon.

Tuesday was the French striker's twenty-first birthday. Surely there are better ways of spending it than fighting with Real Madrid, but he coped.

He played golf and tennis, socialised with his brothers and the neighbourhood pets, went to Real for punishment training, but was sent home for not calling in advance, and then served birthday cake and Coca-Cola to the journalists waiting outside his house.

That night, Real played Dynamo Kiev in the Champions League. Some of the 40,000 fans who bothered to turn up were polled by the sports daily Marca on whether the Frenchman should be pardoned. 'No,' said 88 per cent. The club agrees. A spokesman said: 'If we had known all this before, we wouldn't have signed him. To have done otherwise would be masochistic.' Vicente del Bosque, the caretaker manager, added: 'This is not a school.'

Yet Real have much in common with a boarding school of the Greyfriars variety. You could see this even as they took the field, led, as always, by the trio of Raul, Fernando Hierro, and Fernando Redondo. Raul (good at games) is the most popular boy in the class. Hierro is school captain: he has been around forever, is challenged by no one, and so has become a bit of a bully. Redondo is their crony. Roberto Carlos, Steve McManaman and Fernando Morientes tag along, good enough and sociable enough to have gained acceptance. But Anelka is the boy who gets bullied: the Billy Bunter of Real Madrid.

The chaotic game against Dynamo ended in a 2-2 draw, leaving Real best placed to reach the knockout stages of the Champions League. Afterwards, as journalists waited for players outside the changing-rooms, the latest issue of France Football was passed around. Anelka treats the magazine as his newspaper of record, like a 1950s prime minister talking to The Times, and he had granted an interview in which he told all.

Sadly, it only added to the impression that he is indeed a paranoid loner. 'I am alone against the rest of the team,' he said. He possessed, he claimed, a video showing his team-mates looking gloomy after he had scored his first goal for Real after six months at the club. He had tried to give this video to Del Bosque, but Del Bosque didn't want to see it. Also, the other black Francophone players had told him that the others wouldn't pass to him.

This sounds extraordinary. But as the old joke says: sure he's paranoid, but what if everyone really is out to get him? None of the popular boys at Real have made Anelka feel at home. Hierro has attacked him in public, and the Frenchman says the sweeper even went to Lorenzo Sanz, the club president, to dissuade him from signing him. In Anelka's phrase, 'They threw me into the changing room, and said "Look after yourself".'

When the Real squad emerged from the showers after the Dynamo game, everyone asked about Anelka. Christian Karembeu, one of his friends, shrugged. Sanz shrugged. The general view in Spain, as it was in England last year, is that Anelka should shut up and do what he is paid for.

That is a peculiarly materialistic view: as if your salary should determine your behaviour. But even in materialistic terms, Real are being foolish. If you pay £23 million for a player, it is bad management to make him fend for himself.

There is a leading kit brand in the game today that assigns a minder to each footballer it signs. The minder gives the player occasional presents, acts as his secretary, friend and shrink, and remembers his wife's birthday. To most players, this comes as a bonus in a stressful life. To a few, it is essential. If you are a 21-year-old paranoid loner living in a country where you don't speak the language, you need help.

Some clubs understand. Arsenal helped Tony Adams and Paul Merson fight addiction, kept Emmanuel Petit in England, restored the confidence of Dennis Bergkamp and Nwankwo Kanu, and had Anelka on the pitch scoring goals.

Conversely, the collapse of Paul Gascoigne and Stan Collymore reflects badly on Middlesbrough and Aston Villa respectively. So Real must ask themselves how they failed Anelka.

He has a point when he says no one wants him to succeed. The manager who signed him, John Toshack, has since been sacked, the seventh manager to go in Sanz's four years in charge. Sanz, who sanctioned Anelka's purchase, is obviously a changeable character. At the moment he is preoccupied with trying to buy back his son Fernando, who was sold to Malaga after failing to make the grade at Real.

Del Bosque is a marginal figure, with none of the Louis XIV-style powers accorded to British managers. Viewed for years as an eternal assistant, this uncharismatic man is known chiefly for his Groucho Marx moustache. He keeps his head down.

Jorge Valdano, one of Sanz's seven victims, says the current Real squad remind him of Frankenstein's monster: a mishmash of various managers' minds - 'this man's ear, that one's nose, someone else's mouth'. From the diverse materials Del Bosque has constructed a side. Anelka does not fit into it, geared as it is to a forward line of Raul and Morientes.

Real ran up a debt of about £130 million in putting together this side. We knew you could buy a winning team, but Real have shown you can also buy a losing one.

Sanz, who sanctioned Anelka's purchase, is obviously a changeable character. At the moment he is preoccupied with trying to buy back his son Fernando, who was sold to Malaga after failing to make the grade at Real. Del Bosque is a marginal figure, with none of the Louis XIV-style powers accorded to British managers. Viewed for years as an eternal assistant, this uncharismatic man is known chiefly for his Groucho Marx moustache. He keeps his head down. Jorge Valdano, one of Sanz's seven victims, says the current Real squad remind him of Frankenstein's monster: a mishmash of various managers' minds - 'this man's ear, that one's nose, someone else's mouth'. From the diverse materials Del Bosque has constructed a side. Anelka does not fit into it, geared as it is to a forward line of Raul and Morientes. Real ran up a debt of about £130 million in putting together this side. We knew you could buy a winning team, but Real have shown you can also buy a losing one.

fields.headline: Freddie finds his feet
fields.standfirst: Amy Lawrence talks to Arsenal's improving Swede about his desire to succeed in N5
fields.trailText: Having beaten Werder Bremen on Thursday by a respectable European scoreline, warmed down, showered and changed into pristine navy-and-bright-yellow track suits, Arsenal's players faced just one more little job before the night was over. On their way out through the marble halls they were asked to solve a fiendish dilemma: given the choice, would you prefer to win the Uefa Cup or qualify for the Champions League? Oh, what a tease. What an abominable poser. That's the trickiest task all evening.
fields.body:
Having beaten Werder Bremen on Thursday by a respectable European scoreline, warmed down, showered and changed into pristine navy-and-bright-yellow track suits, Arsenal's players faced just one more little job before the night was over. On their way out through the marble halls they were asked to solve a fiendish dilemma: given the choice, would you prefer to win the Uefa Cup or qualify for the Champions League? Oh, what a tease. What an abominable poser. That's the trickiest task all evening.

The instant gratification of glory versus sating the longer term hunger to belong among the cream. So what's it to be? Kanu was unequivocal. 'The Uefa Cup,' he said, grinning mischievously, with the air of a man who is simply enchanted by the thrill of the triumph. Patrick Vieira parked himself diplomatically on the fence. Freddie Ljungberg, fresh from poaching the second goal which provides Arsenal with a crucial degree of breathing space for Thursday's trip to Germany, thought about it for a moment, was struck by a jolt of defiance, and declared there was no reason his team couldn't go for both.

Actually there is a pretty good reason. Seeing as the devil of inconsistency has so far scorched their Premiership, FA Cup, Worthington Cup and Champions League aspirations it's logical to assume another untimely descent or two might finish their season off altogether. Nobody can ever guarantee in which guise the men from Highbury will show up for any given game - the swaggering Arsenal who dominated Deportivo La Coruna 5-1 or the stuttering Arsenal left staring at their boots in shame after capitulating at Bradford. For all his painstaking analysis not even Arsène Wenger can work it out.

Harping optimistically on about how much there is still to play for doesn't camouflage the real mood in London N5. New enthusiasm for the Uefa Cup or a top-three finish is like politely drinking fizzy white when you crave champagne. Beneath the crinkled smiles, the season can't end quickly enough so they can put this annus inconsistentis behind them and start afresh. An inquest is expected this summer. Rumours of an exodus hang densely in the air. When Wenger sits down to assess his squad he takes heart from the nucleus of driven, settled, gifted young players who are the foundation for the future. Vieira, Kanu, Ljungberg and Thierry Henry, with Alex Manninger and Matthew Upson waiting in the wings.

That Swedish international Ljungberg has imposed himself in this group is testament to his tenacious character. Having made the kind of impact on his debut that made you think he'd fit in just fine at Arsenal - looking like some kind of mutant version of Johnny Rotten meets Boyzone with his electric-shock hair and cute features, he came on as a late sub and claimed a cheeky goal and a booking against Manchester United - he struggled for a while. A little homesickness and a lot of fatigue after 18 months of uninterrupted football took its toll on his game.

Now, adaptation completed, he has transformed himself into one of the club's most valuable players. It is significant that nobody has played more games for Arsenal this campaign than he. 'In his first season he was lost,' says Wenger, 'and this season his improvement has been one of the satisfactions of the year.' Fortunately for Arsenal Ljungberg appears to be as pleased with life at Highbury as they are with him. 'My contract is for two more years and obviously I will stay until then but I don't see any reason to move anyway. At the moment I am really happy with the club. I have a lot of friends in England and a good social life, I think we have a great team, and I'm playing as well, which is important. Of course we could win some more games - then I would be even happier.

'I've heard everyone say that when Arsenal have their backs against the wall they play well and I think that's true,' adds Ljungberg. 'That's what we're hoping for. We have 10 more games in the league and we'll try to take as many points as we can and see where we finish. We need to get some consistency and a lot of points in a row and we can get in the top three, absolutely. And winning the Uefa Cup would be a great thing for me personally because I have never won a European trophy. Winning is a nice feeling and it drives you every day in training.'

Back home they are watching his progress with interest. Ljungberg is revered as the best player in Sweden. For the national side he is the playmaker, the creator, the wand that can change a game. They reckon we will only see the best of him when he is free to roam in his favourite central role rather than positioned out wide as he is at the moment. 'If his finishing and final ball improves and when he has more experience that's where I think his future will lie,' hinted Wenger. 'And he has a big future, because he is good going forward, he works hard and he's a winner. He has the fighting spirit of an English side.'

The Arsenal tradition of absolute refusal to accept defeat has been in short supply this season. Ljungberg, though, has never been a shrinking violet when it comes to rallying to the cause. He admits he used to get angry but is learning to channel his energy differently. 'It distracts your concentration,' he says. 'Now if opponents try to kick me down instead of shouting at them I try to dribble round them instead.' He has tried to move on from the experience against today's opponents at White Hart Lane, when he was sent off harshly and responded with a reckless gesture that earned him a suspension.

It also brought cult hero status. At least, thought the Arsenal faithful, it symbolised passion. They are used to their players caring in these parts and it's gone awol too often for comfort lately. It's the missing ingredient that can be summed up in two words: George Graham. The former Highbury overlord, who once banished a brilliant Swedish winger, Anders Limpar, for being too fragile a talent, would probably approve of Freddie Ljungberg.

fields.headline: The brothers
fields.standfirst: Are his brothers to blame, have Real Madrid failed him, or is Frenchman's plight all his own fault?
fields.trailText: One professional footballer lies in a hospital bed, his liver teetering on the brink of failure. There's widespread concern. Another lies in his own bed, £38,000 a week still not enough to rouse him for light shooting practice at the Real Madrid training ground. Nobody gives a damn.
fields.body:
One professional footballer lies in a hospital bed, his liver teetering on the brink of failure. There's widespread concern. Another lies in his own bed, £38,000 a week still not enough to rouse him for light shooting practice at the Real Madrid training ground. Nobody gives a damn.

This is a modern mortality tale of two footballers, George Best and Nicolas Anelka. Two players from different generations of professional football but with one thing in common. They are both sick.

The pairing of Best, a lifetime alcoholic, with Anelka may seem grossly unfair and typically anti-French but on this occasion I defer to a Spaniard - the president of Real Madrid, Lorenzo Sanz, who signed Anelka from Arsenal last August.

When Anelka failed to turn up for training on three consecutive days last week Sanz suspended him, without pay, for 45 days. It will cost Anelka, a millionaire at 20, about £200,000. Sanz means business and, although not medically qualified, he has views on Anelka's central clinical difficulty.

'He is a man who has it all so there must be something wrong psychologically. Otherwise it doesn't make any sense.' Sanz believes Anelka is sick.

After spending almost three days with members of the Anelka family, namely brother-agents Claude and Didier, I think Senor Sanz is fairly close to diagnosing Anelka's ailment. The problem appears to be deep-seated, psychological and in need of urgent treatment. And, without wanting to win an award for insipid generalisations, it's a condition shared by his brothers.

When Nicolas Anelka refused to play for Arsenal last summer, despite signing a five-year contract, vice-chairman David Dein placed the blame for his sudden behavioural problems on his 'advisers' - his brothers. It was they who had secretly negotiated with six foreign clubs, behind the back of Dein and his fellow directors, before coercing Arsenal into the sale of a prized asset. Although Arsenal made a £23million profit on Anelka, both Dein and Wenger have maintained that they did not want to sell him.

In an effort to discover how they managed to move Nicolas, and to gain some insight into the family's mindset, I went to Anelka HQ in Edgware. A four-bedroom semi-detached 1960s property, bought for cash at the time of his signing for Arsenal, is Nicolas' only legal connection with the UK.

Within the space of 10 minutes Claude Anelka, Nicolas' elder brother, was at once welcoming, rude, surly, aggressive then friendly. He was plagued by extreme suspicion of anyone outside 'the family' and his grasp of reality seemed to swing from distortion to ignorance. But perhaps most significantly of all, he refused to observe any rules or conventions.

Claude Anelka was virtually incapable of deciding what he felt about Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger, perhaps because he wanted to show affection for a fellow Frenchman. But he was positively lyrical on David Dein.

'David Dein,' said Claude, 'he is devil, evil, merde, toilet.'

From a wild rage he then became suddenly jocular and genuinely hospitable. 'You want come to the Spot in Covent Garden? It's club. I play pure, nice good music. Yes, I am not joking.'

At this point two immensely fit and tall Moroccans descended the stairs. 'They are good defenders. We find club for them. We have trial with QPR. English managers is crazy. Never make up mind,' said Claude.

I asked him whether he, or his brother, were licensed agents. 'Non.' Would they be paying tax and VAT on any transfer they were responsible for? 'What VAT? Rubbish.' Did they pay council tax? 'What is this shit?' I thought it best to cut the questioning before things got uglier. Obeying the rules seems difficult for the brothers Anelka. The traffic lights are, in their eyes, a mere suggestion and nothing more.

And then there's the incomparable George Best, now recovering at a private hospital in London. His troubles are as well documented as Nicolas Anelka's and no less contemporary.

Who can forget his staggering performance under the spotlights on Wogan , in 1990, when one of television's most skilled and accommodating presenters was forced to cut him short and move on to a much less compelling item?

One could sense Terry Wogan's feelings of sadness and mounting despair that a sporting hero, who at one time danced around Old Trafford for 90 minutes, couldn't hold himself together for a nine-minute appearance on a mild-mannered chat show. He wasn't well.

Or what about his despair, in 1984, when a judge sentenced him to 12 weeks imprisonment for drink driving and assault on the police? The rules just didn't seem to agree with him. Yet despite all of this, the football-loving public has forgiven and revered him. The Cromwell Hospital has never received so many get-well cards for a patient.

And now, suddenly, at the dawning of a new millennium George Best, aged 53, must become a new person. He must display self-discipline and self-restraint. Out of somewhere, he must produce the characteristics that we spend years desperately trying to inculcate in our children. Critically, he must decline the inevitable offers of alcohol from friends and admirers.

But how can he? What reserves of self-control will he be able to draw upon? What experience of rule-keeping does he have? The next few weeks will be the most difficult he has ever faced.

Ditto Nicolas Anelka. Of course, some over-ambitious club president will offer Real Madrid good money for his signature. But what's his signature worth? A merchandising company will invest good money in printing his name on his new club shirt, but will he be wearing it in six months time? Probably not.

It is tempting to believe that if Best and Anelka had played under Alex Ferguson or George Graham, both players would have learnt to obey rules and abide by their obligations. But even Chris Tarrant wouldn't bother playing 'Who Wants to be a Different Person?' and he's seen the questions.

No, there's unlikely to be much of a change from Best or Anelka. They've made their sickbeds, and they'll lie on them. Sadly.

fields.headline: Let the battle begin again
fields.trailText: My best friend, who happens to be an Arsenal fan, bought me a copy of the Nick Hornby bestseller Fever Pitch for Christmas a few years ago. I thanked him and placed it on the bookshelf, where it has remained ever since. I simply refuse to read a book about Arsenal. But I have read The Pride of North London, the definitive history of Arsenal-Tottenham matches by Bob Goodwin.
fields.body:
My best friend, who happens to be an Arsenal fan, bought me a copy of the Nick Hornby bestseller Fever Pitch for Christmas a few years ago. I thanked him and placed it on the bookshelf, where it has remained ever since. I simply refuse to read a book about Arsenal. But I have read The Pride of North London, the definitive history of Arsenal-Tottenham matches by Bob Goodwin.

Arsenal, or Royal Arsenal as they were originally called, started life in south London and their move north to Highbury caused much resentment in Tottenham, who thought the club would compete with them for spectators (there was no TV money then, just gate money). The owner of Arsenal had wanted to merge with Fulham but was prevented from doing so by League rules. Indeed, after Arsenal's move north, the League did make a law forbidding clubs from moving without permission. But all this was too late to stop Arsenal's ambition of becoming number one in north London. It was not just Tottenham who objected to Arsenal's move. Local residents were also up in arms about their new tenants and formed the 'Highbury Defence Committee' to try to stop them coming, but in those days no planning permission was necessary and Arsenal got their way.

The unwelcome guests in north London would stand no chance of long-term success unless they were promoted into the First Division and as they were not a very good side there was little chance of making it on merit. But the outbreak of war would give them their chance and they took it. The 1914-15 League season was completed despite the outbreak of war and Spurs finished twentieth in the First Division, with Arsenal sixth in the Second Division.

When the war was over, it was decided that the First Division should be extended by two clubs; Spurs and Chelsea, who finished nineteenth, could expect to stay up and the top two from the Second Division be promoted.

Incredibly, what actually happened was that the League voted for the top two, Derby and Preston, to come up together with Arsenal. Chelsea kept their place and down went the Spurs. Although Spurs were promoted the next season, Arsenal were now established among the elite. The deal was almost certainly the result of bribery of other clubs by Arsenal's owner, Tory MP Sir Henry Norris. In fact Norris was banned from football in 1929 for persistently breaking FA rules.

It actually took an ex-Spurs player, Herbert Chapman, to really establish Arsenal as a great club and the Thirties saw the Gunners win no fewer than five League titles. They even managed to persuade London Transport to change the name of Gillespie Road tube station to Arsenal, thus becoming the first club to have a station named after them.

Apart from the Spurs 'Push and Run' side that won the League in 1951, Tottenham fans had to wait until the early Sixties before they could claim real dominance over Arsenal. Winning the League and cup 'double' was Spurs' greatest moment, but the last club that Spurs fans wanted to emulate that feat was Arsenal. I was at Tottenham on 3 May 1971 with more than 100,000 people, most of them Spurs fans hoping to get in the ground to see their team stop Arsenal from winning the League. I remember very little about the game except that Ray Kennedy scored in the Paxton Road end and I cried. When Charlie George went on to help them lift the Cup later in the week I was devastated.

Those young Spurs fans who thought that the end of the world had come when Alan Sugar appointed ex-Arsenal man George Graham as manager should have been around when ex-Arsenal man Terry Neill was appointed to take over from Bill Nicholson. At least under Graham Spurs are in the top half of the table. Terry Neill's leadership was a disaster that led to Spurs being relegated with many fans believing that it was an Arsenal conspiracy.

As Arsenal continued with their success the only consolation for Spurs fans was winning the odd cup and beating Arsenal in the first FA Cup semi-final at Wembley. But Arsenal's success didn't matter much so long as they were boring and Spurs remained true to the beliefs of Danny Blanchflower. The realisation that under Arsène Wenger Arsenal had actually become not just a great side, but one that played attractive football too, came as a great shock to Spurs fans.

But as they gather at Highbury today neither set of supporters will care about the style - they just want to win. I will be at home listening to the game on the radio, as, like thousands of others, I couldn't get a ticket for the game.

Those young Spurs fans who thought that the end of the world had come when Alan Sugar appointed ex-Arsenal man George Graham as manager should have been around when ex-Arsenal man Terry Neill was appointed to take over from Bill Nicholson. At least under Graham Spurs are in the top half of the table. Terry Neill's leadership was a disaster that led to Spurs being relegated with many fans believing that it was an Arsenal conspiracy. As Arsenal continued with their success the only consolation for Spurs fans was winning the odd cup and beating Arsenal in the first FA Cup semi-final at Wembley. But Arsenal's success didn't matter much so long as they were boring and Spurs remained true to the beliefs of Danny Blanchflower. The realisation that under Arsène Wenger Arsenal had actually become not just a great side, but one that played attractive football too, came as a great shock to Spurs fans. But as they gather at Highbury today neither set of supporters will care about the style - they just want to win. I will be at home listening to the game on the radio, as, like thousands of others, I couldn't get a ticket for the game.

fields.headline: Bernard's tale mirrors Dons decline
fields.trailText: Cup finals, like the Cheltenham Festival, have a peculiar way of causing the compilers of the form book to wonder if their work is worth continuing.
fields.body:
Cup finals, like the Cheltenham Festival, have a peculiar way of causing the compilers of the form book to wonder if their work is worth continuing.

Faced with the kind of obstacles they would, in the normal course of a season, step over as if avoiding a fallen twig, 'certainties' have an alarming tendency to capsize. It is a trend that should lend encouragement to Aberdeen and their supporters when they take the field against Celtic at Hampden Park this afternoon in the showdown for the CIS Insurance Cup.

If, on the other hand, they look for promising portents in the previous meetings between the teams this season, they are likely to feel like going off for a lie-down - on a railway line. Celtic's three league victories, by an aggregate score of 18-0, give the 2000 final of the competition formerly known as the Scottish League Cup the appearance of a catchweight contest, with the Parkhead side having at least a couple of stones in hand of their rivals. Yet the 9-2 freely available about the Pittodrie side is likely to bring willing takers to betting shops in the north-east, convinced that their team's resurgence since they lost 6-0 at home to Celtic on 11 December has somehow brought the protagonists much closer together.

That may be something of an illusion. While Aberdeen have enjoyed better results than they were able to muster before the turn of the year, their performances have yet to persuade more dispassionate observers that they have improved sufficiently to warrant high expectation or a flood of optimistic wagers. Even if they have increased productivity since the midwinter break with victories that have taken them to today's final as well as the semi-finals of the Tennents Scottish Cup, their 'run' also includes a 5-0 thrashing from Rangers at Ibrox on 22 January on the only occasion they have encountered opponents of real substance.

The last four words of the preceding paragraph indicate the other main source of hope for Aberdeen in today's final. While Celtic, even without the stricken Henrik Larsson, have frequently shown themselves to be capable of powerful performances - not only in their towering superiority over Aberdeen, but even in defeat against Rangers 11 days ago - they have, during the last few years of morale-sapping scuffling, demonstrated a singular inclination towards squandering opportunities.

Their defeat by Raith Rovers of the First Division in the 1994 League Cup final and their failure to dispose of Falkirk, also from the lower league, in the 1997 Scottish Cup semi-final, have been the most memorable examples of a self-destructiveness which has manifested itself regularly when they have been allowed a chance to reach or even overtake Rangers at the top of the Premier League.

Even so, failure is relative, and Celtic are made to look like all-conquering giants when their record in the last five years is set beside that of Aberdeen. Since the Pittodrie side won the 1995 renewal of the League Cup, they have lurched from one disappointment to the next, giving the impression of a club that has been mortally wounded. Paul Bernard is Aberdeen in microcosm, the midfielder's trials and tribulations coinciding precisely with the club's during this period. At £1 million from Oldham Athletic, he was and remains Aberdeen's costliest player, but has spent half of his time there demented by hamstring and ankle injuries that have prevented him from attaining the standard expected by a crowd who have often been merciless in their disparagement.

Having been signed by Roy Aitken in '95 and made the most promising start by playing in the League Cup winning team, Bernard has spent most of the years since as a target for derision, culminating in his being booed when substituted during the 5-0 defeat from Celtic at Pittodrie on the opening day of the season. 'I had taken a leg knock and had to go off and they booed me off the pitch,' said Bernard. 'I have been through quite a lot. I had only one season, the first, injury-free and it seems an eternity ago. It took a long time to get to the root of what was wrong with me and John Sharp, our physiotherapist, finally sat me down one day and told me it was going to take a full year to get me properly fit.

'I was in a restaurant one day and a supporter shouted at me that I was happy just to take the wages and that I wasn't interested in getting fit. It's the deepest insult any player can hear. You just love playing and it's no fun being injured. But I knew where I had to go and if that's what I had to go through to get there, so be it.'

Bernard is convinced that Roy Aitken should not have been dismissed at the end of 1997 and makes no secret of his belief that Aitken's successor, Alex Miller, helped to accelerate the decline. 'I think Alex Miller has a lot to account for, in terms of letting people go. When I joined, we had a strong squad, a good mix of youth and experience. I believe that, had the club stuck by Roy, he would have turned it around, but it's all just taken a nosedive since then.'

Under Ebbe Skovdahl, the squad have been redrawn with a Scandinavian bias with the intention of running some steel through the core, but even that is unlikely to send shivers down the backs of the Celtic players.

With Kenny Dalglish in charge, Celtic have a much less romantic, more pragmatic self-opinion and it is difficult to escape the impression that, if they give a performance, Aberdeen could once again be subjected to the treatment.

fields.headline: Liverpool swoop
fields.trailText: Liverpool are planning to steal a march on their Premiership rivals today by completing the signing of football's latest teenage superstar.
fields.body:
Liverpool are planning to steal a march on their Premiership rivals today by completing the signing of football's latest teenage superstar.

Andres D'Alessandro, 18, attracted interest from a host of clubs in England, Italy and Spain after starring for Argentina's under-21s against England at Fulham last month. Tottenham, Chelsea, Aston Villa and Leeds all made inquiries - but Liverpool have two men in Buenos Aires and are confident of signing him today. They have agreed a £3.5 million fee with his club, River Plate, and will talk personal terms tonight.

While the others dithered, Gerard Houllier decided to move immediately for D'Alessandro, who is keen to play in the Premiership. Liverpool officials have already been in contact with D'Alessandro's agent and River Plate. The deal would take Houllier's spending to £14.5 million in the past two weeks, after the capture of Emile Heskey from Leicester.

Chief scout Alec Miller and chief executive Rick Parry flew out to Buenos Aires on Friday to watch the midfielder - who has been dubbed 'the new Maradona' by the sports press in Argentina - for River Plate against Independiente today.

They're hoping to bring the player back to Merseyside within a fortnight. A Liverpool source revealed: 'A deal was almost done last weekend but it was decided to watch him in a domestic game. He is very impressive.'

His arrival would place further question marks over the Anfield career of Jamie Redknapp, who might tempt Arsenal or Tottenham.

D'Alessandro's arrival will underline England's growing status in the world game. It has been unusual for Latin talent to move directly to England rather than Italy or Spain. The Feyenoord coach, Leo Beenhakker, one of European football's most respected figures, last week predicted English football would be at the forefront of the game over the next decade because of its commercial success.

fields.headline: Women's football to turn pro
fields.trailText: For decades women in football were either streakers, programme sellers or players' glamorous girlfriends. Then a few females began appearing on terraces, in boardrooms and even as officials at matches. But now women's soccer is about to record its biggest victory. Move over David Beckham, look out Michael Owen: female football is finally going professional.
fields.body:
For decades women in football were either streakers, programme sellers or players' glamorous girlfriends. Then a few females began appearing on terraces, in boardrooms and even as officials at matches. But now women's soccer is about to record its biggest victory. Move over David Beckham, look out Michael Owen: female football is finally going professional.

The Football Association has pledged to set up a full-time professional league of women's teams within three years to capitalise on the sport's booming popularity. Millions of pounds will be spent, television will screen fixtures and dozens of women will be able to give up their day job to concentrate on proving they are as skilful as Alan Shearer or Ryan Giggs.

The move is a dramatic confirmation that the male-dominated FA has finally abandoned the last traces of its historic hostility to women playing 'a man's game'. Rocked by a recent series of controversies, the English game's governing body sees the league's formation as a vital part of its new campaign to ditch its 'old farts' image.

The FA's reformist new regime has been made aware that women's football is the UK's fastest-growing sport. Thousands of girls are learning how to pass and shoot, the number of female teams has jumped from 500 in 1993 to 4,500 today and more women than ever are becoming hooked on the national sport. In school playgrounds across the country these days, girls are as likely as boys to spend their break-time kicking a football.

England's female league will be established by 2003. It is likely to be based on the existing 10-team FA Women's Premier League National Division, which includes teams such as Arsenal Ladies, the Millwall Lionesses and Doncaster Belles, the inspiration for the television drama Playing the Field . America, the existing women's football world champions, plans to put its own professional set-up in place next year.

The FA's Katherine Knight said: 'Women's football has exploded in popularity in the last decade. England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland all have their own national teams, England ladies have their first full-time coach and 1,000 players attend 30 regional centres of excellence.'

The FA, which already puts £2 million a year into developing women's football, will secure television coverage by refusing to allow broadcasters to screen England games or FA Cup matches unless they also show clashes from the new league.

The United States' victory over China in last year's women's World Cup Final gave the sport a huge boost even in England, which did not qualify. The 90,185 crowd was the largest audience for a women's sporting event and tens of millions more watched on television. While the US team's players are unknown here, most are household names across the Atlantic.

Mia Hamm, the side's biggest star, earns $1 million a year, has inspired a footballing Barbie doll and endorses Nike sports shoes bearing her name. On the field she has scored 116 international goals - far more than any other player in history, male or female.

Hamm said: 'To have women's professional soccer in England is a great step forward for our sport considering the incredible tradition of soccer in England. The creation of pro-leagues for women worldwide is a natural progression from last year's World Cup.'

Sepp Blatter, president of world football's ruling body Fifa, has already declared that 'the future of football is feminine'. Fifa regards female players as better ambassadors for the sport because they offer a refreshing antidote to the game's money-obsessed big-name male stars.

The FA's new-found enthusiasm for the women's game contrasts starkly with its previous attempt to kill off female football altogether. In 1921, alarmed that teams made up of women who had worked in factories during the war were drawing large crowds, the game's rulers barred them from playing on FA-affiliated pitches for 50 years. The FA decreed that in its 'strong opinion the game of football is quite unsuitable for females and ought not to be encouraged'. FA chiefs, worried that the popularity of the men's game might be affected, encouraged doctors to warn that football was too dangerous for women. Some 'medical experts' even suggested that females would be left sterile if they persisted in this 'unladylike' activity.

Ex-Spurs and Manchester United star Garth Crooks said the women's game going professional was 'first-class news. The women have worked very hard for this breakthrough and now that it's come people will decide just how popular women's football is. If sponsors and advertisers show the same sort of imagination as the Americans, it can be hugely popular over here too.'

Sports Minister Kate Hoey urged Premiership clubs to follow Arsenal and Everton in running successful women's teams. 'If they do, the potential growth is huge.'

But Yal Bekar of women's football magazine On The Ball warned that poor crowds which women's football attracts could be as big an obstacle to the new league's success as ingrained male cynicism. Premier League games attract between 50 and 500 fans, but England ladies' last two games both drew more than 5,000 paying spectators.

fields.headline: 2006: the big decision
fields.trailText: Alan Rothenberg should know everything there is to know about World Cups. As America's soccer supremo since 1990, he organised the most successful World Cup ever (if you don't count the standard of the football) in 1994.
fields.body:
Alan Rothenberg should know everything there is to know about World Cups. As America's soccer supremo since 1990, he organised the most successful World Cup ever (if you don't count the standard of the football) in 1994.

Over the past six months, Rothenberg has been utilising his knowledge, leading a team of Fifa inspectors round the five countries competing for the right to host the 2006 World Cup. His trip to South Africa ended on Tuesday. Local sports minister Ngconde Balfour was predictably bullish, boasting that 'we have 98 per cent of the votes in the bag' at the end-of-tour press conference. His morale had no doubt been boosted by Rothenberg's own comments. 'Outstanding' and 'very impressive' were the words he used. 'We were very pleased with what we saw. We were impressed by the sheer breadth of people committed to this bid.'

To those who had been following Rothenberg's progress around the world, it was a familiar refrain (so long as you don't count Brazil, which was a bit of a flop). Contrast those comments, for example, to those he made after his visit to England back in October. 'Outstanding', 'excellent', and 'very impressive' were the words on his lips that time. In particular, 'the stadiums were outstanding. The commitment at all levels for hosting the World Cup is very impressive'.

Then there was Germany, the week before he arrived in England: 'Outstanding. The depth and the quality of the commitment has been made clear at all levels.' Or Morocco: 'Very, very impressive. We were impressed by the official commitment to organise the cup. That feeling is something we are very interested in.' You don't say. Or Brazil: 'The stadia were built before the creation of Fifa recommendations. All the stadia need important reforms.' Well, I did warn you about Brazil.

Rothenberg will now report to Fifa's 24-member executive committee, who meet in Zurich on 5 and 6 July to make the big decision. It will be their job to work out which is the best bid - even if Rothenberg's recommendations are all exactly the same.

webTitle: But will anyone want to watch?

fields.headline: But will anyone want to watch?
fields.standfirst: Not unless football's male rulers put their money behind it, says  Sarah Hughes
fields.trailText: Picture the scene: It's 2003 and Arsenal are playing to a packed crowd of 38,000; the Sky camera crews are at the ground and the now traditional hyperbole is going on back in the studio as Andy Gray et al discuss the finer points of the game. Except that there is one big difference - the team playing are not Arsene Wenger's Arsenal, but Arsenal Ladies, the most successful female team in the English Premier Women's League.
fields.body:
Picture the scene: It's 2003 and Arsenal are playing to a packed crowd of 38,000; the Sky camera crews are at the ground and the now traditional hyperbole is going on back in the studio as Andy Gray et al discuss the finer points of the game. Except that there is one big difference - the team playing are not Arsene Wenger's Arsenal, but Arsenal Ladies, the most successful female team in the English Premier Women's League.

But why would women who like football necessarily want to watch women's football? It's true that the Premier League has seen traditional football supporters squeezed out as it becomes both more family and more female oriented but while the girls in their Zola and Beckham replica shirts might well play the game, would they necessarily pay to watch other girls play?

There is a sense in which, for all their good intentions, the FA are trying to run before they can walk.

A women's football league would have the advantage of keeping young talent like Kelly Smith in England while bolstering the chances of promising youngsters like England Under-16 goalkeeper Aman Dosanj, but there is no point in building the structure without first laying the foundations.

More girls than ever before are playing football but there are few established training centres for them to learn at.

Southampton, which has an outstanding school of excellence run by former England player Sue Lopez, is one of the few places to nurture young female talent and in London Arsenal run a similarly successful scheme. But these centres are few and far between.

If Crozier and the FA are serious about the women's game then surely the money needs to start at the bottom, to encourage girls to play football at school and to put in place the sort of network currently available for boys.
