webTitle: Owen sparkles as Reds hold out

fields.headline: Owen sparkles as Reds hold out
fields.trailText: The formula is simple enough: absorb the pressure with a resilient defence and break out to score with a ruthless finisher. Simple enough but not easy, as Liverpool have discovered in trying over the past decade to repeat the success of the previous two.
fields.body:
The formula is simple enough: absorb the pressure with a resilient defence and break out to score with a ruthless finisher. Simple enough but not easy, as Liverpool have discovered in trying over the past decade to repeat the success of the previous two.

Yesterday at Pride Park offered more evidence, though, that they are getting back to their old selves. Having withstood all that Derby County could throw at them, they countered with a typically predatory goal by Michael Owen to change the balance of the game, then held on to a place in the top three thanks to a late strike by his substitute Titi Camara that condemned Derby to more anxiety at the foot of the Premiership.

There was a time last season, the Liverpool manager Gerard Houllier admits, when he feared for his side in the first quarter of a game, so unsure was he of a potentially fragile defence. This campaign the difference is clear. Derby came at Liverpool with a confidence born of a change in fortunes since the turn of the year, but the visitors kept them at bay with their new-found resilience.

First, Georgi Kinkladze - and what a pleasure it was to see the little Georgian weaving his spell back in English football - ran at Liverpool, Emile Heskey having given the ball away in midfield. Unfortunately the shot from 20 yards was a few feet wide.

Then, from a cross by Darryl Powell, Derby welcoming back their captain after a hamstring injury, Rory Delap headed towards goal and the 20-year-old prospect Malcolm Christie just failed to connect for a goal to celebrate his new four-year contract.

From that platform of reasonably comfortable early survival, Liverpool could break out with confidence. Their captain, Sami Hyypia, on whose broad shoulders much rests these days, changed from attack stopper to attack maker by finding Owen with a 40-yard ball and the England prodigy shimmied around Jacob Laursen and drilled home a low cross shot from 20 yards.

Now when Derby went forward there was less conviction to them, two attempts by Branko Strupar typical. First he allowed Sander Westerveld to tip the ball away from his feet then shot tamely at the goalkeeper when well placed. Indeed by half time, Liverpool might have increased their lead with Owen, relishing his developing return, curling a shot just wide then forcing Mart Poom into a sharp save with a low effort.

Liverpool looked largely content to protect the lead after the break, though they continued to be dangerous on the counter-attack. They should have doubled their advantage when Patrik Berger seized on Steve Elliott's wayward header and sent Owen clear, but this time his shot was sliced wide.

You wondered if such wastefulness would cost Liverpool and had Strupar been sharper, they would have been made to pay. Derby stretched the visitors first with Delap's cross from the right, then Johnson's from the left. But the Belgian, six yards out, headed meekly into Westerveld's arms. He also nodded a perceptive chip by Stefano Eranio over the bar.

Finally Liverpool sealed the game. Heskey laid the ball off to Dominic Matteo on the left and his crossfield pass found Camara, who cut inside Delap and calmly sidefooted the ball past Poom.

fields.headline: Rangers go out of sight
fields.trailText: With Celtic preparing for today's Scottish Cup final, Rangers took full advantage to move 12 points clear at the top of the Scottish Premier with a comfortable 6-2 win over Motherwell.
fields.body:
With Celtic preparing for today's Scottish Cup final, Rangers took full advantage to move 12 points clear at the top of the Scottish Premier with a comfortable 6-2 win over Motherwell.

The visitors had arrived at Ibrox with an eye on third spot and the UEFA Cup place that brings. And early on their aspirations seemed to have been justified.

With Arthur Numan, Tony Vidmar and Claudio Reyna sidelined, the Rangers manager, Dick Advocaat, had switched to a three-man back line as Scott Wilson was recalled in a side with no recognised full-backs. The reshuffled defence was tested for the first time after 17 minutes when Lee McCulloch's cross from the right picked out debutante Sasa Curcic. The former Aston Villa and Bolton midfielder had time and space in the centre, enabling him to fire a right-footed shot that Stefan Klos had to tip over the bar one-handed. A minute later Motherwell had the lead, when Kevin Twaddle's corner was headed in by the unmarked Ben Kemble.

But Rangers were behind for only three minutes. Giovanni van Bronckhorst's corner was met at the far post by a Lorenzo Amoruso header.

The Chilean Seb Rozental then gave Rangers the lead from the penalty spot on the half-hour mark after Motherwell's Ged Brannan handled inside the area. Rangers moved 3-1 ahead after 36 minutes when Albertz shot low past Andy Goram from a Craig Moore cross.

Motherwell had every right to feel deflated, but Curcic's trickery was offering them something extra in midfield and his pass set up Derek Adams for a snap shot Klos saved expertly. And within seconds Motherwell had pulled it back to 3-2 when Stephen McMillan's free-kick was headed in by an acrobatic McCulloch. Rangers' response was ruthless and within a minute they were 4-2 ahead. Neil McCann streaked clear on the left for Rod Wallace to net at the far post with a looping header.

Although Motherwell had the ball in the back of the net minutes after the restart, McCulloch's header was disallowed for offside, it was Rangers who were to dominate the second period. After 70 minutes, Rangers eased any lingering fears by extending their advantage to 5-2 when a searching McCann cross was headed in smartly by Wallace with Goram static. Kerimoglu Tugay added a sixth in the final minute from the penalty spot.

fields.headline: Blues run on empty
fields.trailText: The Champions League is like a drug - as soon as you have enjoyed a hit, you need the next fix. For all the sense of achievement blossoming after last week's effervescent victory at Feyenoord, Chelsea know the importance of qualifying next year. And to be sure, they crave that top three position. Liverpool's win makes this point a half-empty glass, especially as Chelsea didn't have enough in the tank to overcome a West Ham side reduced to 10 men for the last 20 minutes. Having said that, anything less than a draw would have been dreadfully harsh on Harry Redknapp's men. They were much the better side.
fields.body:
The Champions League is like a drug - as soon as you have enjoyed a hit, you need the next fix. For all the sense of achievement blossoming after last week's effervescent victory at Feyenoord, Chelsea know the importance of qualifying next year. And to be sure, they crave that top three position. Liverpool's win makes this point a half-empty glass, especially as Chelsea didn't have enough in the tank to overcome a West Ham side reduced to 10 men for the last 20 minutes. Having said that, anything less than a draw would have been dreadfully harsh on Harry Redknapp's men. They were much the better side.

The European Cup quarter-finalists could hardly rest on their laurels when confronted by simmering local hostility from the capital's most effective team in London derbies this season. The tone was set when the giant frame of Marc Vivien Foe virtually leapfrogged over Jody Morris to win a header in the centre circle.

Paolo Di Canio sparkled, lifting the game from the mundane midfield congestion. He produced a sublime moment of skill, charging down Albert Ferrer's casual clearance before dancing half the length of the field. Off he swerved past Didier Deschamps and Frank Leboeuf, but he could only scuff tamely into Ed de Goey's arms.

Igor Stimac was in imperious form marshalling the home defence, aided by an impressive Rio Ferdinand. They mopped up with such commanding aplomb it was almost half an hour before Chelsea's first real chance.

Gianluca Vialli had tinkered with his tactics, bringing in Dan Petrescu to roam in front of a midfield trio of Deschamps, Morris and Dennis Wise. Ominously for West Ham, the Romanian ghosted into the six-yard box. The man who became Chelsea's first foreign player to reach 200 appearances has a habit of clinical finishing. This time, though, he was thwarted by Craig Forrest's outstretched hand.

De Goey, not to be outdone, conjured an equally important save a minute later. It was havoc in the Chelsea area: John Moncur's shot was blocked, and when Di Canio's follow-up ricocheted off Marcel Desailly, the Dutch keeper somehow managed to tip the ball on to the top of the bar and out to safety.

Tore Andre Flo might have opened the scoring after Petrescu's cute threaded pass for once exposed the home rearguard. The Norwegian steered his shot low and hard past Forrest only to watch it sneak wide of the upright.

With half time approaching tempers began to boil. West Ham's arch-scrapper John Moncur, who had already been booked for following through on Wise, came in with another late tackle which briefly lit the blue touchpaper. His victim, Flo, reacted and was duly set upon by Ferdinand, with Stimac in close attendance. After long consultation with his linesman, referee Steve Dunn cautioned the Norwegian and the Croat.

West Ham raised the tempo after the break, launching raid after dangerous raid. But the majority of chances fell to the wayward, wasteful Paulo Wanchope, who ballooned his opportunities high and away from goal. His replacement on the hour, Paul Kitson, looked a hungrier and livelier option.

Chelsea, understandably considering their current schedule, began to tire, while West Ham were so much brighter than in last weekend's lacklustre loss at Sheffield Wednesday. With Joe Cole consigned to the bench until a late cameo appearance, they missed the guile to take full advantage.

Anyway, by this time their cause had been dealt a mighty blow. The influential Stimac was dismissed 20 minutes from time for sliding through Wise, his second bookable offence. The unfortunate Kitson, involved for a mere 17 minutes, made way for Neil Ruddock to restore the full complement of defenders. The Hammers faithful were not amused. They sensed a game that was there to be won, regardless of numbers, turned into an invitation for pressure. Chelsea, though, couldn't capitalise. Roll on the quarter-final?

fields.headline: Hibs find late form
fields.trailText: In the kind of derby that was never likely to slow the pulse rate, resilience was the most significant factor as Hibs overcame their early feebleness to give manager Alex McLeish the gratification that comes from an unbeaten record in the fixture.
fields.body:
In the kind of derby that was never likely to slow the pulse rate, resilience was the most significant factor as Hibs overcame their early feebleness to give manager Alex McLeish the gratification that comes from an unbeaten record in the fixture.

The probability of Hibs repeating their extraordinary 3-0 victory at Tynecastle had been seriously reduced by a revived Hearts, who had won five and drawn the other of their preceding six league matches. A win of any kind seemed virtually impossible the moment Jackson gave the visitors the lead.

Even the least flexible of the home fans would have had difficulty in denying that, by that 25th minute, Hearts had looked the more promising side, composed in defence, compact and tidy in midfield, and quick and threatening in attack.

Much of the menace came from Jackson, who is clearly distinguishable in most of the matches he plays as the one who is barracked by both sets of supporters. This derives partly from the fact that he has played for many of the clubs in opposition - including Hibs - and partly from his difficulty in establishing rapprochement with those in maroon.

But, as a veteran international who has played in numerous derbies in Glasgow, Edinburgh and the North-East of England during his time with Newcastle, Jackson is not easily intimidated. He put a temporary end to the haranguing - dumbfounding the home crowd and converting the visitors - with a goal of exceptional quality.

Latapy, who would atone later with the equaliser, inadvertently began the move that led to Hearts' goal by complacently losing possession on the edge of the Hearts penalty area. Gary McSwegan broke quickly down the left and, after Colin Cameron had taken over, he played the square pass to Jackson.

As Jackson received the pass, Franck Sauzee inexplicably retreated from the challenge. Jackson killed the pass, played the ball from right foot to left and sent a magnificent drive from 20 yards high to the left of Nick Colgan.

Latapy had seemed an unlikely nominee for the glory of bringing the home side level, for long periods too easily kept from making an impression on the match by opponents who relegated him to the periphery of the action.

When he sprang into prominence, it was all the more breathtaking. As the ball was played in from the right and Latapy brought it under control with his back to goal just outside the penalty box, Sauzee made a decoy run down the left which seemed to bewilder the Hearts defenders.

Latapy seized the opportunity to push the ball past Steven Pressley and Gordan Petric on to his own right foot, then sent a low shot to the left of Antti Niemi from 16 yards. Hearts' regret at wasting two excellent scoring opportunities before the interval - McSwegan and Wales both choosing the wrong options when shooting off target - deepened after the break, when a transformed Hibs not only produced the goals that secured the points, but improved the level of their overall performance emphatically.

Hibs would have led earlier than they did, had not Pressley effected a wonderful clearance off the toe of John Hughes as the home defender tried to make contact on the line with a header from Martin McIntosh.

The second goal came when Mixu Paatelainen switched the play intelligently with a measured pass to Tom Smith on the left. The full-back's deep cross was met by Sauzee 10 yards out to the right of goal, and his looping header cleared Niemi and his defence before dropping under the bar. Paatelainen's confirming goal was an unmissable tap-in after Latapy's shot had been pushed to his feet by the helpless Niemi.

fields.headline: Sky Blues on cruise control
fields.trailText: It will probably not prevent Gordon Strachan from continuing in his inimitable role as a footballing Energizer Bunny, patrolling Premiership sidelines like a man possessed, but for the first time in what seems like living memory, his team's supporters can breathe easily.
fields.body:
It will probably not prevent Gordon Strachan from continuing in his inimitable role as a footballing Energizer Bunny, patrolling Premiership sidelines like a man possessed, but for the first time in what seems like living memory, his team's supporters can breathe easily.

Coventry's annual flirtation with relegation has this season been little more than a one-month fling.

A run of four consecutive defeats has been followed by two home victories in four days. And while Strachan will not forsake his high-energy management style - which yesterday featured an ugly slanging match with Dean Windass after a late challenge on Paul Telfer - his players can at least relax.

After Bradford unleashed an overweight and over-the-hill Neville Southall on the Premiership last weekend, his replacement Aidan Davison was required to gather the ball from the back of his own goal twice inside the opening 21 minutes.

It could have been an even more traumatic opening for Davison, as Coventry showed emphatically that they have recovered from a worrying loss of form.

It took only seven minutes for their midfield dominance, the result of energetic running and the clever orchestration of Gary McAllister, to have an effect.

A strong challenge from John Eustace won the ball, his pass found Noel Whelan whose shot was deflected weakly by Davison into the path of the waiting Cedric Roussel for the opening goal.

Davison would soon be offered, and accept, opportunities to make up for that questionable piece of goalkeeping. A vicious, low shot was well saved at the foot of the Bradford post, Davison proved alert to a McAllister shot, then did even better to deny Eustace's right-foot attempt.

It mattered not. In the 21st minute Whelan, looking particularly sharp and hungry, struck from the edge of the area and Roussel's presence distracted the keeper, as well as possibly deflecting the shot, to leave Davison wrong-footed and the ball in the bottom corner of the goal.

Bradford manager Paul Jewell then sent on the enigmatic Portuguese forward Jorge Cadete as a replacement for midfielder Gareth Whalley with only 30 minutes gone.

By the time he also threw on Robbie Blake as a half time replacement for full-back Gunnar Halle, Jewell had four strikers on the field, a tactic which finally led to chances but was ultimately destined to end in failure.

It came in the form of Peruvian substitute Ysrael Zuniga who, in the 84th minute, charged down a Lee Sharpe clearance and was brought down by the same player for a penalty Eustace converted.

Two minutes later Zuniga scored his first goal for the club with a swift volley into the right-hand corner of the goal after his initial run had been blocked by Jamie Lawrence.

fields.headline: Davies back to his best
fields.trailText: Southampton exorcised the demons of their 7-2 thrashing at Tottenham last week by inflicting a first defeat of the year on an out-of-sorts Villa.
fields.body:
Southampton exorcised the demons of their 7-2 thrashing at Tottenham last week by inflicting a first defeat of the year on an out-of-sorts Villa.

Southampton scored twice for the second week running, Kevin Davies scoring either side of half time, but this time their defence came away with their goal and pride intact.

Indeed Paul Jones, the goalkeeper who was the most overworked man at White Hart Lane last week as he picked the ball out of the net seven times, did not have a save to make against a Villa side who succumbed to their first defeat in 13 games.

Not surprisingly, Southampton's manager Glenn Hoddle put caution first after losing at Tottenham, and dropped the error-prone Francis Benali.

Villa were without inspirational but injured captain Gareth Southgate, who was replaced by midfielder Ian Taylor in the heart of defence, and dropped striker Julian Joachim to the substitutes' bench.

That meant a place for Paul Merson, but the former England man was far less influential than in his more customary midfield role.

fields.headline: Ziege rewarded
fields.trailText: Honours finished even in this scrappy North-East derby with a goal from Niall Quinn matched late in the game by one from Christian Ziege. And Sunderland could count themselves lucky because in the last minute of normal time Juninho missed with just the keeper to beat.
fields.byline: John Wilford at The Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Honours finished even in this scrappy North-East derby with a goal from Niall Quinn matched late in the game by one from Christian Ziege. And Sunderland could count themselves lucky because in the last minute of normal time Juninho missed with just the keeper to beat.

Sunderland have been suffering one of the worst runs in their history. Before this game they hadn't won in League or cup since mid-December. Although skipper Steve Bould was fit again, he started on the bench, as did Nicky Summerbee, who has fallen victim to manager Peter Reid's chopping and changing as he struggles to find a winning combination.

Boro, by their normal standards, are enjoying a mini-revival having now gone five games without defeat. Juninho started among the substitutes for the second week running, but Bryan Robson welcomed back Gary Pallister at the centre of the defence.

It was typical of a scrappy opening period that when Paul Ince fired in the game's first direct shot he hit it so high that it didn't even reach Tomas Sorensen's goal, catching the wind and spinning back into play.

Boro's line-up suggested containment, with three central defenders and five in midfield. This put the onus on Hamilton Ricard and Brian Deane to create something up front and Deane did just that in meeting Fleming's accurate cross with a header that was just a yard wide.

Christian Ziege showed flourishes of class in an otherwise niggly game, but Sunderland made little impression, with Niall Quinn stifled by Pallister and Kevin Phillips chasing shadows.

One of Boro's best moments came when Ricard met a Neil Maddison corner with a powerful header, which Alex Rae chested down on the line before Sorensen completed the save. The question was: Did Rae handle the ball? Ricard thought so and a few minutes later he and Rae were involved in a spat that led to both players being booked.

Sunderland came to life in the second half when Darren Holloway opened up the Boro defence with a 40-yard pass to Phillips, which found the England striker unmarked. He hit his shot well enough, but it struck the inside of the post and rebounded into the arms of Schwarzer.

With Boro forced to play 11 men in their own half, Sunderland pushed forward and took the lead when the ever-willing Phillips chased a loose ball to the left-hand corner and put across a perfect centre that Quinn, rising unmarked at the far post, headed stylishly past Schwarzer from five yards.

But eight minutes from time Ziege equalised when he profited from good work by substitute Juninho and then Deane before lifting the ball over Sorensen, who had rushed to the edge of the area.

fields.headline: Watford too Smart
fields.trailText: The living dead who inhabit Watford's Vicarage Road looked to have dragged Sheffield Wednesday down into the dark world of First Division football after Allan Smart's 88th-minute winner inflicted defeat in a game Wednesday really had to win. Though it is mathematically possible for both clubs to avoid relegation this match was really a wooden spoon affair.
fields.body:
The living dead who inhabit Watford's Vicarage Road looked to have dragged Sheffield Wednesday down into the dark world of First Division football after Allan Smart's 88th-minute winner inflicted defeat in a game Wednesday really had to win. Though it is mathematically possible for both clubs to avoid relegation this match was really a wooden spoon affair.

A draw would have been something for Wednesday on a day their closest rivals lost, but when substitute Tommy Smith broke clear on the right and centred for Smart to slide in from six yards all was lost.

The fact that a win just might lead to their Premiership survival seemed to escape Wednesday early on as they started with the urgency of a sloth on a day off. Watford made all the running and though lacking the guile to benefit from their posession they were always willing to show for the ball.

While Wednesday manager Danny Wilson hopped from dug-out to pitchside, Watford recorded five shots on target in the first 15 minutes alone. The best of that bunch came from Nordin Wooter, who danced into the Wednesday area to hit a shot which Pavel Srnicek fumbled before he sustaining an arm injury in blocking Heidar Helguson's follow-up effort.

Wednesday's best assets were their band driven fans behind the goal they were supposed to be attacking.

Watford, meanwhile were missing chances at the other end and Micah Hyde was guilty of some poor finishing when he completed a great one-two with Smart before lifting his shot over Srnicek and the crossbar from 10 yards out.

Srnicek, having taken another knock to his right arm, was replaced by Kevin Pressman in the 32nd minute and, for no obvious reason, it coincided with a brief improvement in Wednesday's play going into half-time.

They even hit the target for the first time when an Andy Hinchcliffe cross was met unconvincingly by Richard Cresswell's head, but it still needed a goalline clearance from Richard Johnson's chest to prevent the ball going in.

Cresswell also had the first chance of the second half when a Neil Cox error allowed the Wednesday forward to run at goal. His shot was powerful too, but went inches wide as it flew into the roof of the side netting.

At least Wednesday now had some fight to match Watford's bite, but the overall quality of this game remained far below what could be described as value for money entertainment.

This was like the old days when people had to make their own entertainment on the terraces; it's just that they didn't always have to pay up to 24 quid for the privilege.

webTitle: Beckham a cut above the rest

fields.headline: Beckham a cut above the rest
fields.trailText: David Beckham scored his third goal of the season and Dwight Yorke his fifth in eight days as Manchester United restored their seven-point lead over Leeds United, leaving Leicester City relieved to have caught the champions on a relative off day.
fields.body:
David Beckham scored his third goal of the season and Dwight Yorke his fifth in eight days as Manchester United restored their seven-point lead over Leeds United, leaving Leicester City relieved to have caught the champions on a relative off day.

The inequalities within even the upper section of the Premiership have seldom been so sharply displayed. This was Leicester's biggest home match of the season, yet for Manchester United it was merely a game to get out of the way after hitting the heights of which they are capable in midweek against Fiorentina.

Naturally here their performance did not approach Wednesday's excellence, it would have been unfair to expect it, yet it was too good for Leicester's spirited but workmanlike challenge.

United simply worked off their stiffness for the first half-hour, letting the home side huff and puff without ever threatening Mark Bosnich's goal, then took the lead through the combined class of Ryan Giggs and David Beckham. 'One-nil in your cup final,' United's travelling support chanted mercilessly, before going on to make the not entirely false accusation that Leicester fans had only come to see the champions.

Certainly one doubts whether the rooftops of factories and tower blocks across Leicester's tiny East Stand and beyond a row of terrace houses are quite so dotted with spectators claiming a free view for every home match. But that's the big difference between United and Leicester. At Old Trafford they have thousands of people sitting just as far away paying full price.

At least United did not disappoint, even if the match was eminently forgettable. Beckham turned up with a drastic new haircut, but after failing to find the target with his first free-kick on the half- hour he managed to prove his shorn locks have not cost him any of his powers five minutes later. As Beckham free-kicks go, it was not one of the most spectacular but it took Tim Flowers by surprise, possibly because it went between Stefan Oakes and Neil Lennon rather than over them, and the ball was in the back of the net before the goalkeeper made a move.

Even that description does Beckham rather less than justice, however, since United's right winger had actually started the move, five yards from his own goal-line on the left side of the field, by helping out Jaap Stam in defence and unerringly finding Giggs on half-way.

Giggs needs no persuading to run at people in his present vein of form, and duly tore up the middle, forcing Leicester back until Frank Sinclair ended his run with a blatant trip. Referee Rob Harris, returning to the Premiership after the Tranmere-Sunderland fiasco, did not distinguish himself by awarding a free-kick without cautioning Sinclair. It is one thing to cut down on unnecessary booking for petty or accidental offences, but cynical fouls by defenders with no intention of playing the ball were the reason referees were asked to get tough in the first place. In the circumstances, Leicester could hardly complain when Beckham supplied a punishment of his own.

Leicester barely troubled United in the first half, apart from an early opportunity for Darren Eadie which Bosnich came out smartly to smother. Stan Collymore began the second half by sending a shot fizzing over Bosnich's bar. Collymore ran his channels and showed the occasional neat touch, but failed to cause Stam or United any alarm and had to endure a few sniggers when he was beaten in the air by the diminutive Paul Scholes. United should really have wrapped the game up in the 53rd minute, when Giggs found Denis Irwin on the overlap and the full-back created a shooting chance for himself with a deft flick inside. But Flowers was equal to his thunderous drive.

Leicester threw on Ian Marshall shortly after Scholes had gone close with a a long shot, and United responded with the introduction of the rather more elegant Sheringham. But the last word went to the player who has suddenly rediscovered his scoring touch. Again Giggs was involved, and his centre from the left wing left little work for Yorke to do, just one touch to control, and a second to beat Flowers.

Still, Leicester did beat Tranmere at Wembley to win the Worthington Cup. 'Come along to our open day and touch the magic trophy,' ran a public address announcement at half time. At least the United supporters had the good grace not to burst out laughing.

fields.headline: Cancer funding 'must be doubled'
fields.standfirst: Province needs 100%in cancer doctors
fields.trailText: Cancer victims throughout Northern Ireland have no doubt what Gordon Brown should be spending any spare cash on in the Province. The shortage of oncologists and intensive-care beds in Belfast is causing severe hardship to those already suffering life-threatening illnesses.
fields.body:
Cancer victims throughout Northern Ireland have no doubt what Gordon Brown should be spending any spare cash on in the Province. The shortage of oncologists and intensive-care beds in Belfast is causing severe hardship to those already suffering life-threatening illnesses.

Cancer care workers believe that funding must be more than doubled to bring Northern Ireland's survival rate from the disease up to the best European Union levels.

In the past few months 66-year-old Tommy Ferris has fasted on four separate occasions in preparation for a life-saving operation to remove the tumour in his oesophagus.

Each time, as he was ready to be wheeled into the operating theatre, his operation was cancelled because Belfast's Royal Victoria Hospital did not have any intensive-care beds. The flu epidemic combined with a chronic lack of NHS funds was to blame.

His tumour was first spotted in early December, but a more thorough examination was delayed due to the beds crisis at the RVH. His test finally took place on 25 January. However, the operation to remove the tumour itself was then scheduled for four separate dates - 8, 9, 10 and 16 February - and on every occasion was cancelled because intensive-care beds were not available.

Recovering last week at his home in Carrickfergus after the operation he finally had in late February, Ferris was in no doubt what the Chancellor should do. Those on the frontline of the fight against cancer in Northern Ireland believe the Government needs to double its cancer treatment spending to £30 million per annum.

Ferris said: 'Eventually everything worked out but the delay was very distressing. Every time I was built up for the operation they said there were no beds in intensive-care and that they would try again tomorrow.

'I was diagnosed as having cancer in the oesophagus in early December but I also suffer from severe colitis which was made worse by the stress I was under due to the cancellations.

'I don't blame the nurses, the surgeons or any of the medical staff, it was not their fault. They just didn't have the beds to cope. I'm speaking out now in order to help other people in the future and maybe there'll be more money for beds for cancer patients.'

His daughter-in-law Vivienne Ferris is a counselling nurse at the Ulster Cancer Foundation. For five years she has been dealing with complaints from cancer patients and their families about the sometimes fatal delays in vital operations.

Mrs Ferris deals with queries from the sufferers and their relatives, but never thought she would find herself in the same situation.

'Every time I inquired about the cancellations, the same reason was given. They did not have beds in intensive care. Pyschologically and physically it has taken its toll on him. I think it's a disgrace that he has worked all his life and yet can be left in this terrible situation for an unnecessarily long period.'

The Ulster Cancer Foundation points out that Northern Ireland has only 10 oncologists to cope with an ever rising number of cancer patients. An estimated 4,000 people will die of the disease every year.

Arlene Spires, the deputy-chief executive of the UCF, said they concurred with the recent Campbell report on the future of cancer services in the UK. But to reach the report's goal of reducing cancer deaths in Northern Ireland required a doubling of the number of oncologists to 20, she said.

'At present around £12.3m is being spent here on cancer services but, in order to achieve the vision of the Campbell report, we need that figure to be around £30m in order to bring our survival rates up to the best standards in other parts of the EU,' Spires added.

'A lot of people suffering serious illnesses like cancer are afraid to speak out because they don't want to upset the doctors and nurses or affect the care they are to get. But it's time people did speak out.'

webTitle: It's the way he tells it...

fields.headline: It's the way he tells it...
fields.standfirst: Kazuo Ishiguro's new novel, When We Were Orphans, is architecturally sound but curiously furnished
fields.trailText: Kazuo Ishiguro's new novel, When We Were Orphans, is architecturally sound but curiously furnished
fields.body:
When We Were Orphans
Kazuo Ishiguro
Faber £16.99, pp313
Buy it at BOL

All in all, Kazuo Ishiguro is a pretty odd novelist. His voice is studiedly anonymous, unfailingly formal and polite, even under the most dramatic circumstances. He resists and, I think, dislikes what most novelists relish, the particular concrete detail which pins down a scene to a locality and a time. He resists, too, that other most concrete element of writing - the metaphor.

Towards the end of When We Were Orphans, it reveals itself to be a variation on Great Expectations, but a less Dickensian novelist can hardly be imagined. Dickens only constructs a plot, one feels, so that he can write about the characters' shoes, the particular colour of someone's shirt, the particular smell of a full larder.

For Ishiguro, the particular detail is impeding and irrelevant, and, even in a costume drama like this one, the events pass in a smooth, weightless movement, undistinguished by the gritty marks of the particular fact.

His virtues are all architectural ones. His timing and orchestration of events is practically unrivalled; in The Remains of the Day, the circling repetition of the narrator's narrow interests and the thin tone of voice are all designed to build up a weight which only cracks at the very end, when the narrator is reported as breaking down in tears. Cunningly, it is the one thing he doesn't tell us, and sets the reader off on a hunt backwards through the book, looking for other things he hasn't told us.

The Unconsoled, his sublime and strange last novel, was an even more daring exploration of repetition and delay, a circle of frustration which only broke towards the end, with a truly overwhelming sensation of relieved grief. It was an annoying novel; what also made it a great one were the architectural uses to which it put the reader's annoyance, frustration and even boredom.

In his previous two books, the weightless and unspecifying tone of voice was not a problem; he had carefully chosen the arena, and it would have been inappropriate to worry about the unyielding, unemotional formality of the sentences. The unreliable narrator of The Remains of the Day spoke like that because he was not quite educated and did not trust himself outside his chosen methods of expression. The beautiful, little hanging discord of the split infinitive in the last sentence is a model of expressive usage.

The Unconsoled reads like a dream, in which the normal rules of time and space are suspended, and no dream is filled with intensely felt objects, intensely experienced physical facts. The calm reporting of the prose seemed entirely appropriate to the strange events of the book; it could not fully respond to the events, so it would set down what had happened with the simplest manner possible.

In When We Were Orphans, the manner has, I think, become a problem. Again, the book has many virtues: it is surely developed and extended; it is full of ingenious variation; it builds to an admirable and satisfying climax. Its virtues, in short, are all architectural ones. It starts to present a problem when we look at the voice, the sentences, which, in the context, will not do at all.

Christopher Banks is a fashionable society detective, solving fashionably ghastly crimes in 1930s England. In his past, however, there is an unsolved and traumatic crime which continues to torment him. He was brought up in Shanghai, with a father heavily involved in Western complicity in the importation of opium and a mother who campaigned fiercely against the trade. His parents crossed a major warlord, Wang Ku, and disappeared. Banks travels back to Shanghai, now riven by the Sino-Japanese war, and descends into the ruins of the city, searching hopelessly for the place where his parents might, just, still be held captive.

Personal trauma as the world falls apart is classic Ishiguro territory, and in many ways he seizes the drama with both hands. It is striking how the ghastly 1930s shocker at the beginning moves into something altogether deeper as the book progresses.

The single problem with the book is the prose, which, for the first time, is so lacking in local colour as to be entirely inappropriate to the task in hand. One can't only admire a book's structure.

There is something troubling about Ishiguro's prose style that took me a while to pin down, and it's this - he hardly ever uses a phrasal verb. He is a writer who always prefers to say 'depart' rather than 'set off', 'discover' rather than 'find out'. Phrasal verbs are, in a way, at the heart of English; they are a part of the language which presents peculiar difficulty to the learner, since there is no logic whatever in their meaning, and they hardly ever resemble anything in another language.

A Frenchman, learning English, would soon see the connection between 'discover' and 'découvrir'; 'find out', on the other hand, would seem to him like an exotic and irrational expression, which, despite its being more idiomatic, he might well choose to avoid. There is no logic to them; why 'get on with' and 'get off with' should mean what they do, rather than the other way round, cannot be justified, and yet they are at the heart of the spoken language.

Ishiguro's avoidance of phrasal verbs is a major problem here - it gives his narrator a circumlocutious, cautious air which isn't really very helpful. More than that, it gives him a particular tone of voice which is not that of his social setting. It is bizarrely unconvincing as an idea of upper-middle-class London in the 1930s - I think Ishiguro will find that society beauties did not say 'pardon' then and do not now - and the inadequacy can be pinned down to the narrator's voice, and his choice of verbs, as much as the details. Here he is on his new digs:

'Although at that point I had yet to receive a single visitor in my rooms, I issued my invitation with confidence, having chosen the premises with some care. The rent was not high, but my landlady had furnished the place in a tasteful manner that evoked an unhurried Victorian past.'

Receive, issue, furnish, evoke; Christopher Banks tells us that he is a 'society detective', but he sounds exactly like a policeman. Or, to be unkind, like a butler.

Of course, there are splendid things in it; the games and huge terrors of a Shanghai childhood. Or the horrific descent into the lawless slums as Banks searches for his kidnapped parents, only partly marred by the way the prose will not budge an inch from its superb, unfeeling immaculacy: 'Most annoyingly, my right shoe had split apart, and my foot was badly gashed, causing a searing pain to rise with each step.'

The resolution is moving and graceful, but the problem of the voice is a universal one, present and incredible in every sentence.

He resists and, I think, dislikes what most novelists relish, the particular concrete detail which pins down a scene to a locality and a time. He resists, too, that other most concrete element of writing - the metaphor. Towards the end of When We Were Orphans, it reveals itself to be a variation on Great Expectations, but a less Dickensian novelist can hardly be imagined. Dickens only constructs a plot, one feels, so that he can write about the characters' shoes, the particular colour of someone's shirt, the particular smell of a full larder. For Ishiguro, the particular detail is impeding and irrelevant, and, even in a costume drama like this one, the events pass in a smooth, weightless movement, undistinguished by the gritty marks of the particular fact. His virtues are all architectural ones. Cunningly, it is the one thing he doesn't tell us, and sets the reader off on a hunt backwards through the book, looking for other things he hasn't told us. It was an annoying novel; what also made it a great one were the architectural uses to which it put the reader's annoyance, frustration and even boredom. fields.headline: Videos
fields.standfirst: American Perfekt | The General's Daughter | Analyse This | Groundhog Day | Instinct | Go
fields.trailText:
American Perfekt
(1997, 18, Blue Dolphin/Third Millennium, VHS Rental, DVD Retail)
fields.body:
American Perfekt
(1997, 18, Blue Dolphin/Third Millennium, VHS Rental, DVD Retail)

Highly imperfect but consistently intriguing, very scary road movie thriller set in the desert around the California-Nevada border where the lives of two disturbed sisters (Amanda Plummer and Fairuza Balk) criss-cross with a disarmingly charming shrink (Robert Forster), whose every action is determined by the toss of a coin, an itinerant English conman (David Thewlis) and a rural sheriff (Paul Sorvino). Writer Paul Chart's directorial debut is (by design or desperation) edited in an unnervingly elliptical fashion and the strong cast hold our attention. The producer is Irvin Kershner, the veteran cult filmmaker who briefly entered the bigtime with The Empire Strikes Back and Never Say Never Again .

The General's Daughter
(1999, 18, Paramount, VHS Rental)

Slick psychological thriller indicting the sexist military machine starring John Travolta as an army policeman given 24 hours to track down the man (or men) who raped and murdered a female captain on an Deep South base. Factitious stuff, in the style of A Soldier's Story and A Few Good Men , but eminently watchable, with knockout performances from James Woods and James Cromwell.

Analyse This
(1999, 15, Warner, VHS Rental, DVD Retail)

Harold Ramis, writer-director of Groundhog Day , comes up with a hugely enjoyable, if less original, comedy that gives bespoke roles to Billy Crystal and Robert De Niro as a Jewish shrink and a Mafia capo who meet cute in Manhattan and discover they're both in thrall to overbearing immigrant fathers. It's a crude film about crudity, played with considerable finesse and far superior to the similar Mickey Blue Eyes .

Groundhog Day
1993, PG, Columbia-TriStar, DVD Retail)

Bill Murray played a modern Scrooge in Scrooged , and in this further variation on A Christmas Carol , he's a smug, misanthropic Pittsburgh weather-forecaster doomed to recapitulate a single winter day in a small Pennsylvanian town until he has transformed himself. This funny, challenging movie is one of the best comedies of the Nineties.

Instinct
(1999, 15, Buena Vista, VHS Rental)

This ambitious eco-drama, directed by Jon Turteltaub (who had a surprise success with the sports comedy Cool Runnings ), disappeared without trace within days of its release. Anthony Hopkins plays a brilliant primatologist, incarcerated for abandoning society for the company of Rwandan gorillas after murdering two game wardens. Cuba Gooding Jr is the ambitious University of Florida psychiatrist given 10 days to penetrate Hopkins's wall of silence. This is Equus -Lite.

Go
(1998, 18, Col-TriStar, VHS Rental, DVD Retail)

Doug Liman's follow-up to his engaging Swingers , is constantly on the move as it follows the lives of a bunch of desperate young citizens of Los Angeles over 24 hours before Christmas. This is a deliberately down-market Pulp Fiction , in which each overlapping episode in LA and Vegas illuminates the one that went before. Its moral position is expressed in the defensive line: 'We did the right thing - OK, in a half-assed sort of way.'

fields.headline: Is that you, Clarice?
fields.standfirst: Hannibal, the long awaited sequel to  The Silence Of The Lambs, has finally been cast -  without Jodie Foster. Instead, Julianne Moore is to play FBI agent Clarice Starling.  Damon Wise explains the politics of casting and wonders how Moore will fare against Anthony Hopkins' Hannibal Lecter
fields.trailText: Hannibal, the long awaited sequel to The Silence Of The Lambs, has finally been cast - without Jodie Foster. Instead, Julianne Moore is to play FBI agent Clarice Starling. Damon Wise explains the politics of casting and wonders how Moore will fare against Anthony Hopkins' Hannibal Lecter
fields.body:
It's Valentine's Day and Julianne Moore is running late. At 1.14pm, after a press conference for Paul Thomas Anderson's Magnolia was due to begin, the scowling head of the Berlin Film Festival made a solemn announcement to waiting reporters. Ms Moore, he said, was still in her hotel room and wouldn't be with us for some time. She was having her hair done, he sighed.

But why was our German friend surprised? Moore is no longer just a performer, nor even an artist. She is a movie star . (With all the necessary hair care which that entails.) This transition has happened almost imperceptibly. One minute she was a repertory player in arty ensemble films such as Robert Altman's Short Cuts, Paul Thomas Anderson's Boogie Nights and her partner Bart Freundlich's The Myth Of Fingerprints; then suddenly she went overground, playing opposite Ralph Fiennes in The End Of The Affair and gathering an impressive best actress Oscar nomination for her efforts. A barometer of her appeal is that Moore's 'beauty regime' warranted a two-page spread in a recent issue of the National Enquirer.

When she finally made her entrance in Berlin, Moore was rapturously received and her hair, of course, was perfect. Midway through, a smartly dressed European took the microphone - but he didn't have a question. 'Julianne? Mrs Julianne Moore?' he began in faltering English. 'You know today is the Valentine's Day, no? I have a present for you - because you are so nice .' Approaching the podium, he handed her a giant, heart-shaped red balloon. There was laughter, applause, and the actress blushed.

Because, for now, Julianne Moore is one of America's sweethearts. So when Jodie Foster announced her decision to bow out of Hannibal , the long-awaited sequel to The Silence of The Lambs, to be directed by Ridley Scott, it seemed perfectly logical that Moore would make the short list. And it also reflects our rather perverse fascination with serious crime. Looking at the other names considered for the role of FBI agent Clarice Starling, the plucky young hick who develops a dangerous empathy with jailed murderer Hannibal 'The Cannibal' Lecter, there's a curious consistency. Gillian Anderson, Hilary Swank. Angelina Jolie, Cate Blanchett, Ashley Judd, Gwyneth Paltrow. The keywords here seem to be intelligent, vulnerable, fearless and - most important of all - beautiful.

Foster's decision to drop out, ostensibly to direct the more personal Flora's Plum, has prompted a lot of rumours about the production. First, that she was asking too much (some where in the Travolta league of $20 million plus). Then it was said she found the novel too disturbing and wanted to change Harris's surreal ending (in which Clarice goes native, so to speak), supposedly to the writer's annoyance. Then there was the matter of the script, finished last autumn by playwright David Mamet, in the gap between directing The Winslow Boy and State Of Maine, and given a subsequent polish by Schindler's List writer Steve Zail lian. Reports suggest that Foster perhaps felt the balance of power had shifted, and that the actress wasn't about to let Clarice take a back seat to the now-showboating Lecter.

Moore, who announced she was 'very, very excited' about the role while negotiations were being finalised during her time in Berlin, does not seem fazed by following in Foster's footsteps. Which is brave, because there really doesn't seem to be much of a precedent. Sequels are usually commissioned for their stars, not their characters, as a quick glance at the roster of movie franchises shows: Lethal Weapon, Die Hard, Scream. One of the rare exceptions is RoboCop, which found a new star for its third instalment, though few saw beyond the leading man's full-face helmet to realise it wasn't Peter Weller. In fact, the only recent examples of actors given the challenge of facing comparison with their predecessors is in the world of the prequel: for example, Robert De Niro succeeding Marlon Brando as the young Don Vito Corleone in The Godfather Part II, or Ewan McGregor donning Alec Guiness's mantle to play the young Obi Wan Kenobi in Star Wars Episode 1.

On second glance, it would seem the Hannibal cycle has more in common with the Bond franchise; indeed, when Jonathan Demme's adaptation of The Silence Of The Lambs swept the 1991 Oscars, nobody seemed too concerned that Lecter had already made his big-screen debut some five years before in Michael Mann's Manhunter, an adaptation of Harris's second book, Red Dragon. Here, Lecter was played by Brian Cox, a bigger, arguably more masculine alternative to Anthony Hopkins's gentrified performance. The two Lecters both have their fans, both very different in their attitudes to the two films, but - interestingly - their success is simply a matter of preference.

Because, going back to Harris's original novels, there really is no blueprint for the definitive Lecter. Refer to chapter seven of Red Dragon , in which Detective Will Graham first visits Lecter (Mann inexplicably changed the name to Lecktor for the film adaptation) in the Chesapeake State Hospital For The Criminally Insane. Harris tells us little or nothing about Lecter, except that 'his eyes are maroon and they reflect the light redly in tiny points'. His only elaboration is that he 'is a small, lithe man. Very neat.' Compare this with chapter two of The Silence Of The Lambs : '[Clarice] could see that he was small, sleek; in his hands and arms she saw wiry strength like her own.' And a paragraph later: 'Dr Lecter's eyes are maroon and they reflect the light in pinpoints of red.'

Which brings us to Clarice Starling. When the young FBI agent makes her entrance, all we know is that she has 'grass in her hair and grass stains on her FBI Academy windbreaker from diving to the ground under fire in an arrest problem on the range'. Harris deliberately doesn't give us too many physical clues as to Clarice's identity - this he leaves to Lecter, who famously dissects her personality during their first, tense meeting. Instead, we get a mental image of Clarice in which only her strengths and weaknesses really register, and if Moore is smart, she presumably understands that Clarice and Dr Lecter have a life beyond their actors.

Put simply, Harris's trilogy is an archetypal modern fable, a timeless beauty and the beast saga. And just as Hannibal's physical attributes are irrelevant to this intellectual King Kong, so are Clarice Starling's. It's her mind that matters and her mind we care about, so it's no accident that only a certain type of actress could fit the bill. By way of illustration, the Hannibal short list was a select and prestigious elite - a far cry from the hullabaloo surrounding the casting of Charlie's Angels , in which every actress in Hollywood, from Jennifer Lopez to Catherine Zeta Jones, was said to be joining Drew Barrymore and Cameron Diaz for the camp action romp.

That the part went to the relatively smalltime TV star Lucy Liu speaks volumes. In the hands of Ridley Scott, Hannibal was never going to go that far downmarket. Because Scott, director of post-feminist Western Thelma And Louise , would undoubtedly know that the part of Hannibal Lecter's bloody valentine would be a magnet to some of Hollywood's most sophisticated actresses.

'Good roles for women are very hard to come by,' Moore told reporters in Berlin, 'because obviously the film business is based on economics. It's not interested in making movies about people and ideas, it's usually about things exploding and spending lots of money.'

When the $70m Hannibal starts shooting in May, Moore will pick up her biggest pay-cheque yet, said to be around the $3m mark (but still only a fraction of Hopkins's salary). With Clarice Starling she may have found the perfect balance between commerce and art. The part is intelligent, accessible and, best of all, lucrative. Just right for any actress who wants to have her cake - or should that be pound of flesh? - and eat it.

Foster and Moore: a tale of two Starlings

Jodie Foster

Age: 37

Number of films made: 32

Awards: Best actress Oscars for The Accused and The Silence of The Lambs . Also nominated for Nell and Taxi Driver (best supporting actress).

Career breakthrough: Playing streetwise teenage prostitute in Taxi Driver.

On Clarice Starling: 'I don't feel like I own her, but I know everything about her. She's the most specific character I've ever played. She's the kind of person if you said, "Would she wear an orange miniskirt?" I know exactly what the answer is.'

Others on Foster: 'If God had designed a perfect acting machine it would be pretty close to Jodie,' says Jon Amiel who directed her in Sommersby .

Also known as: BLT - 'Bossy Little Thing'. The nickname was devised by Jonathan Kaplan, director of The Accused .

Julianne Moore

Age: 39

Number of films made: 23

Awards: Current best actress Oscar nominee for role in The End of the Affair, previously nominated for supporting role in Boogie Nights.

Career breakthrough : As Annabella Sciorra's acerbic best friend in The Hand That Rocks the Cradle.

On Clarice Starling: 'I'm not going to do what Jodie did. She's a great actor, it was a magnificent performance, there's no way I'm going to duplicate it. There's no sense in even thinking about it.'

Others on Moore: 'She does it all. She's an artist. When one speaks of Julianne Moore, it's like speaking of Bette Davis,' says Robert Altman who directed her in Short Cuts .

Also known as: The Hardest Working Woman in Hollywood. Last year she starred in five films: Cookie's Fortune, An Ideal Husband, A Map of the World, Magnolia and The End of the Affair.

By way of illustration, the Hannibal short list was a select and prestigious elite - a far cry from the hullabaloo surrounding the casting of Charlie's Angels , in which every actress in Hollywood, from Jennifer Lopez to Catherine Zeta Jones, was said to be joining Drew Barrymore and Cameron Diaz for the camp action romp. That the part went to the relatively smalltime TV star Lucy Liu speaks volumes. In the hands of Ridley Scott, Hannibal was never going to go that far downmarket. Because Scott, director of post-feminist Western Thelma And Louise , would undoubtedly know that the part of Hannibal Lecter's bloody valentine would be a magnet to some of Hollywood's most sophisticated actresses. 'Good roles for women are very hard to come by,' Moore told reporters in Berlin, 'because obviously the film business is based on economics. It's not interested in making movies about people and ideas, it's usually about things exploding and spending lots of money.' When the $70m Hannibal starts shooting in May, Moore will pick up her biggest pay-cheque yet, said to be around the $3m mark (but still only a fraction of Hopkins's salary). With Clarice Starling she may have found the perfect balance between commerce and art. The part is intelligent, accessible and, best of all, lucrative. Just right for any actress who wants to have her cake - or should that be pound of flesh? - and eat it. Foster and Moore: a tale of two Starlings Jodie Foster Age: 37 Number of films made: 32 Awards: Best actress Oscars for The Accused and The Silence of The Lambs . Also nominated for Nell and Taxi Driver (best supporting actress). Career breakthrough: Playing streetwise teenage prostitute in Taxi Driver. On Clarice Starling: 'I don't feel like I own her, but I know everything about her. She's the most specific character I've ever played. She's the kind of person if you said, "Would she wear an orange miniskirt?" I know exactly what the answer is.' Others on Foster: 'If God had designed a perfect acting machine it would be pretty close to Jodie,' says Jon Amiel who directed her in Sommersby . Also known as: BLT - 'Bossy Little Thing'. The nickname was devised by Jonathan Kaplan, director of The Accused . Julianne Moore Age: 39 Number of films made: 23 Awards: Current best actress Oscar nominee for role in The End of the Affair, previously nominated for supporting role in Boogie Nights. Career breakthrough : As Annabella Sciorra's acerbic best friend in The Hand That Rocks the Cradle. On Clarice Starling: 'I'm not going to do what Jodie did. She's a great actor, it was a magnificent performance, there's no way I'm going to duplicate it. There's no sense in even thinking about it.' Others on Moore: 'She does it all. She's an artist. When one speaks of Julianne Moore, it's like speaking of Bette Davis,' says Robert Altman who directed her in Short Cuts . Also known as: The Hardest Working Woman in Hollywood. Last year she starred in five films: Cookie's Fortune, An Ideal Husband, A Map of the World, Magnolia and The End of the Affair.

fields.headline: It's the big title fight
fields.standfirst: Directors and writers are at war over who gets top billing
fields.trailText: Directors and writers are at war over who gets top billing
fields.body:
There is something reassuring about the credit 'A film by Michael Mann' at the start of The Insider . It suggests you haven't mis-spent £7.50 and are not about to waste the next two-and-a-half hours of your life.

Of course, if you take a wrong turn and arrive to see 'A Michael Winner film' flash on to the screen, there's still time to flee before it starts.

However, the so-called 'vanity credit' is at the centre of a ill-tempered row between Hollywood directors and screenwriters, which could lead to a writer's strike. The dispute harks back to the traditional stand-off between these groups. The scribes are angry at the popular practice which confers auteur status on 70 per cent of Hollywood movies and down-sizes their contribution. In short, they say, it keeps directors happy and doesn't cost studio execs a penny.

Only a handful of A-list writers, mostly novelists, have the clout to insist their names appear first among unequals on the screen. They include Neil Simon, John Grisham and Stephen King. The rest will get their recognition in hack heaven. 'We don't want to take the director's power away,' says writer-director Phil Alden Robinson ( Field of Dreams ) but directors really need to understand that the possessory credit is a real thumb in the eye to us.'

The directors argue that, unlike writers, they are involved in the project at all stages, often penning major sections of the film without credit. They view the dispute as the first skirmish in a battle to preserve their directorial authority. 'They'll get rid of the possessory credit over my dead body,' says Richard Donner, the auteur responsible the Lethal Weapon series. Michael Bay (Armageddon), has joined in, saying he writes his own action sequences. There is no Oscar for Best Choreographed Scene of Mass Destruction yet, but when there is Bay will accept the statuette - alone.

webTitle: It's not only MPs who need  News at Ten

fields.headline: It's not only MPs who need  News at Ten
fields.trailText: It is faintly ironic that amid the interminable twentyfirst-century predictions of an on-demand, interactive, non-linear, dot.com (fill in your choice of futuristic jargon) world, we are captivated by a good old twentieth-century tussle between the twin evils of nanny state in one corner and unfettered capitalism in the other.
fields.body:
All has gone temporarily quiet on the News at Ten front since ITV's bigwigs had their grilling from Gerald Kaufman and his travelling select committee sideshow two weeks ago. The issue is being aired again at a Voice of the Listener and Viewer seminar next week, where hopefully ideas will be a little less preconceived and questions a little more open than those managed by our MPs.

Meanwhile, the Independent Television Commission is weighing up the regulatory evidence on whether to instruct ITV to reinstate the Prime Minister's favourite programme.

It is faintly ironic that amid the interminable twentyfirst-century predictions of an on-demand, interactive, non-linear, dot.com (fill in your choice of futuristic jargon) world, we are captivated by a good old twentieth-century tussle between the twin evils of nanny state in one corner and unfettered capitalism in the other.

It is also reassuring. Cynics may believe that MPs' concern is driven by the sudden removal of their mugs from peak-time television at a time when they can most conveniently watch themselves, but some are genuinely concerned by the public interest argument. For a democracy to work effectively, it needs an informed electorate; televi sion is the most widely used source of national and international news; News at Ten added to the mix of high quality television information by reaching 6 million citizens a day; ergo... You may not be convinced by the reasoning, but the fact that we can still debate how television can best fulfil a vital democratic function - and the real policy decisions that flow from that - ought to be comforting.

Critics can point to a hidden assumption here that TV news actually makes a tangible difference to political literacy. Thankfully, there is American research to prove it. In 1994, a study asked five straightforward information questions (example: who is the president of Russia?) to people in five European countries plus America and Canada. Performances differed wildly: more than half of all Americans could answer no more than one question correctly, while most Germans got at least four questions right.

More importantly, the authors also carried out various statistical analyses to isolate the media's signifi cance, and concluded that 'being a regular TV news viewer makes an additional contribution to political information in only two countries - the UK and Germany'. QED.

Unfortunately, there is no study that tells us about the contribution of one channel sticking to a bulletin scheduled at one particular time. ITV can argue quite reasonably that by moving its main bulletin to 6.30, it not only reaches a million more people than its original early evening bulletin but actually makes the flagship bulletin available to more people at a more convenient time.

This, of course, is laughable to most London viewers. At 6.30, the average metropolis dweller is usually strap- hanging on a delayed underground/commuter train at the end of a 10-hour day. After staggering through the front door, he or she has barely time to down a Scotch, read the kids a story, feed the hamster, bung a Waitrose meal in the microwave and phone the wrinklies before it's 9.55 and time to catch up on the day's news. What is sometimes hard for the average Londoner - and the average MP - to understand is that daily life lived by normal people outside the city has a rather different rhythm and timetable.

My own reservations on this move have less to do with regulating for the benefit of the consumer than regulating to preserve the strength and integrity of a prestigious broadcast news provider. ITN has a rich history and a brand name - in terms of authority and trustworthiness - on a par with the BBC.

News at Ten may have been an indulgence for politicians, but it was also an important shop window for a serious, high-quality journalistic operation that kept the BBC on its toes. Removing the brand name from programme titles as well as the shop window to opinion formers has dealt a double blow to an important journalistic institution. And that has implications for an informed democracy.

You have to pity the ITC. Either its members stick to their decision to back ITV and are accused of being spineless toadies in thrall to greedy profiteers who wouldn't recognise the public interest if it bit them in the corporate bum. Or they reverse their decision and are accused of being spineless toadies incapable of standing up to a powerful Government which is about to reinvent the whole regulatory structure for broadcasting, and may well do to the ITC what the ITC did to News at Ten .

In the end, they will confirm their original decision. It would be nice if, in doing so, they could somehow convey to their regulatory charges that ITN is an important national asset which is slowly but fatally being undermined. And then instruct them to do something about it.

 Steven Barnett is senior lecturer in communications at the University of Westminster. S.Barnett@wmin.ac.uk

webTitle: High-techs brought low as old economy rises

fields.headline: High-techs brought low as old economy rises
fields.standfirst:
Is normal service resumed? Markets surge as the blue chips bite back - and dot.coms dwindle
E-finance: special report
Floating the net: special report
fields.trailText: Is normal service resumed? Markets surge as the blue chips bite back - and dot.coms dwindle
fields.body:
It is a corporate remake of The Empire Strikes Back. Just 10 days ago a clutch of new technology stars soared into the élite of the FTSE 100 index. Since then, the shares of Freeserve, Psion and Kingston Communications have plummeted by more than a third, and even Baltimore Technology has lost more than 10 per cent of its value.

That has been mirrored by a revival in the fortunes of those who made way for the upstarts - bastions of the old economy such as Imperial Tobacco, Hanson and even bread and sugar producer Associated British Foods, whose shares recovered by as much as 15 per cent.

That trend was repeated across the markets in both Britain and the US. In London, the Techmark 100 index of leading technology stocks is more than 15 per cent down on its peak, while Nasdaq, its US equivalent, has dropped more than 5 per cent. The FTSE 100 - which does not officially welcome the new entrants until tomorrow - and the Dow Jones surged.

So far, the decline in technology shares is little more than a puff of air escaping from the balloon: even after last week's fall, the Nasdaq has doubled in little over a year; Techmark has done the same in less than six months.

But is it a portent of a bigger shake-out to come? There are still few commentators prepared to predict that a technology crash will happen, let alone when it will come - although practically everyone agrees they look dramatically over-valued. Likewise, although everyone agrees there are real bargains among shares in the old economy, no one is expecting them to power ahead.

Statistics from Warburg Dillon Reed illustrate how the new economy has come to dominate the market: stripping out technology stocks, the FTSE 100 index has fallen by more than 20 per cent in the past decade, most of that decline in the past three years.

'The gap between old and new economy stocks is now too stretched,' said Steve Russell, strategist with HSBC. 'But remember that the technology revolution is for real. We recommend that people switch from the broad-brush approach of thinking, if its technology you have got to have it, and get into the winners and out of the losers.'He admits that, like everyone else, he has no idea who these will be - and even if he did, they would already be on stratospheric valuations.

'The best guide is to look for companies with barriers to entry. On the Internet, there are none. In software and telecoms, there are strong barriers.'

'Vodafone and perhaps Sema do have a chance of justifying their valuations.'

Ian Scott of Lehman Brothers thinks these stratospheric valuations have put the British market out of line with the US. 'Nasdaq is up 16 per cent so far this year, while the [similar] European Neuermarkt has risen 76 per cent. It has not been appreciated how much bigger the rotation [from old to new economy stocks] has been in Europe compared with the US.'

He points to specific sectors, such as telecoms - where European shares have jumped by 26.5 per cent so far this year, compared with a 7.1 per cent fall in the US - and media, which has almost doubled here but fallen by a quarter in the US. He believes there could be some selling of new economy stock, such as Reuters, which has risen 70 per cent this year, far faster than any of its US peers. Some attribute the decline in technology stocks to the flotation of lastminute.com. Despite scepticism in the City, it was comfortably subscribed, but those who bought hoping for a quick profit were disappointed as the shares fell sharply during the week.

'It is unlikely that either institutions or private investors will see it as a one -way bet any longer,' said HSBC's Russell.

Dissatisfaction with the lastminute.com flotation, coupled with share price weakness, has already produced casualties. Financial Objects, another technology company, has scrapped a flotation planned for next week.

Last week's flurry of interest in old-economy stocks went only a little way to reversing more than year of declines in their shares. But analysts warn that not all cheap stocks are bargains.

Michael O'Sullivan of Warburg Dillon Reed points to companies with consistently good results and strong positions in their markets, such as GKN, the engineer, CRH and BAe.

He likes technology stocks but says: 'As for Freeserve and lastminute.com, we say waitaminute.com.'

HSBC's Russell looks for industries unlikely to be changed by the Internet , such as life assurance, drinks and food firms: 'It is difficult to see how the Internet can stop people eating and drinking.'

webTitle: If you want to get a head...

fields.headline: If you want to get a head...
fields.trailText: Philip French: The movie is breathtakingly inventive... [and] for all its surreality, is never whimsical and each development has its own peculiar logic
fields.body:
The first feature film of both its screenwriter, Charlie Kaufman, and its director, the music video producer Spike Jonze, Being John Malkovich is a film of great wit and confidence that grabs our attention with its opening image.

A wooden puppet, dancing mournfully alone in a barely furnished room, looks in the mirror and, observing his strings, becomes aware of his dependent life. He destroys the mirror and collapses in despair to thunderous applause.

The sequence affectionately sends up portentous avant-garde art and takes us into the mind of the movie's humourless hero, for this is the dream of Craig Schwartz, a dedicated New York puppeteer, played with his customary air of self-interrogating unease by John Cusack.

Craig is an eccentric outsider down on his luck because 'no one's looking for a puppeteer in this wintry economic climate'. In a painfully funny early scene, he mounts his erotic puppet version of Abélard and Héloïse in a Manhattan street, only to be punched in the face by the irate father of a little girl spectator.

His wife Lotte (Cameron Diaz), who has turned their small flat into a menagerie, urges him to seek gainful employment and we're drawn further into a fantasy world when Craig finds a job as a filing clerk with a company located on floor seven-and-a-half of a skyscraper. He has to get out of a lift between floors and stoop because the ceilings are so low. This special floor, it's said, was designed by the owner to please his diminutive wife.

By now, we are more than halfway to Wonderland, and we finally reach it when Craig discovers a secret door opening on to a precipitous tunnel down which he falls, Alice-like, to enter the body of the actor John Malkovich. After a Warholian 15 minutes in the star's skin, Craig is ejected, or ejaculated, on to a patch of wasteland beside the New Jersey turnpike like something blown out of a volcano.

The movie is breathtakingly inventive. And in Craig's encounters with a provocative co-worker, Maxine (Catherine Keener), his lecherous, elderly boss Dr Lester (Orson Bean) and a receptionist with a bewildering speech disorder (Mary Kay Place), it's also verbally complex in a manner reminiscent of Lewis Carroll.

What happens after the discovery of the tunnel as Craig, his wife and others go down the tunnel to experience life as Malkovich, is neatly summed up by the puppeteer himself: 'Do you realise what a metaphysical can of worms this portal is?'

The movie, for all its surreality, is never whimsical and each development has its own peculiar logic. Being John Malkovich is a film of ideas about identity, celebrity, manipulation, mortality, immortality, vicarious experience and free will. It draws on and invokes a variety of sources from Kafka to those Thirties musicals Dames and Shall We Dance?, in which masks of the film's heroine are worn by the whole chorus line.

Malkovich quite brilliantly plays a version of himself, Charlie Sheen plays a parody of his raunchy public persona, and Orson Bean, a charming old actor and comedian, has no doubt been cast as Dr Lester because he is forever associated in the States with the long-running television panel game To Tell The Truth, source of the catchphrase: 'Will the real John So-and-So please stand up?'

The movie flags slightly towards the end, dipping briefly into a pastiche of the geriatric comedy Cocoon, but it picks up to conclude on a bizarre high note.

webTitle: Budgets: The who, what and why

fields.headline: Budgets: The who, what and why
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the Budget.
fields.body:
What is the Budget?

It is the speech in which the Chancellor of the Exchequer tells the Commons how he will balance the amount he wants to spend with the money he receives in taxes. He charts the country's financial state of health, makes predictions for the economy and reveals how he wants to change taxes.

Is it a tradition?

Budgets have been around since 1362, during Edward III's reign, although they were not called budgets until 1733. 'Budget' probably stems from the Old French word 'bougette' which means a little bag. Exchequer comes from the Latin scaccarium, meaning a chequered board, because money was counted out on a squared tablecloth.

Why is it annual?

Income tax is an annual tax. Since a challenge to the governments' powers in 1912, they have had to renew the legislation every year or lose the power to collect the tax. There can be more than one Budget in a year if, say, there is a new government or a crisis.

Is the Budget always in March?

It always used to be held in March or April because that was the start of the agricultural year, and most taxes came from land ownership.

In 1993 the Conservatives changed the date to the previous December, so it fell when the Government published its spending plans. Brown made a pre-Budget statement in November. but took the Big Day back to March.

Why are the speeches so long?

The longest was Gladstone's 1853 Budget speech: he prattled on for 4 hours 45 minutes. The shortest was Disraeli's in 1867, which lasted 45 minutes. The average is one hour 14 minutes. You can bet on how long you believe Brown's speech will last: his first lasted one hour; the next two were fractionally shorter.

What's Brown's Budget tipple?

To date, Brown has drunk water, as did Norman Lamont and John Major. But Geoffrey Howe drank gin and tonic, and Denis Healey liked brandy and water.

When do the changes start?

Customs and Excise changes usually kick in at midnight on Budget Day to prevent anyone stockpiling petrol and cigarettes. Income tax, capital gains tax and inheritance tax changes take effect on 6 April, which usually affects people's May pay packets.
