And the fear - a lot of being drunk is to do with being frightened all the time.' At last, when he was 30 and already yellow with hepatitis, he agreed to go to a drying-out clinic. He took his last drink - Moët et Chandon - on the train to Clouds, on 1 April 1984. 'I was quite close to dying. I was on the edge of cirrhosis. I had the highest liver count of anyone there. I was on a 24-hour watch with a nurse because you can die - in fact, I watched someone die - from alcoholic withdrawal. You have fits, and they were very worried that that might happen to me.' He was in the clinic for six weeks and came out sober. He has not touched alcohol since. 'But the important thing is, I was 30 when I stopped, and you're given this incredible clean sheet and that is a fabulous gift.' Of course, he didn't immediately leap from being AA Gill the drunk to AA Gill the successful writer. There were several years of just enjoying being sober, free of the fear. These were his cooking years, when he worked in restaurants (his younger brother, Nicholas, was a chef) and taught a cookery course in Scotland. But in his mid-thirties he discovered that he could write, and he wrote art reviews for little magazines. And in 1990 he married a venture capitalist, Amber Rudd, and had two children, Flora, now eight, and Hector, now six. Then someone asked him to write a piece for Tatler on what it was like being in a detox clinic. He wrote it under the pseudonym Blair Baillie for the September 1991 Tatler and Jane Procter, the then-editor, recalls: 'It was a brutally honest description. It combined the most compelling imagery with an exquisite use of English. At the risk of sounding overdramatic, I remember sitting in my office sobbing as I read it.' She asked to meet this Blair Baillie and suggested he should do interviews (thank God he didn't) - but, instead, he opted to do a cookery column with his own illustrations. He was shocked when an editor told him that he was a funny writer - he wanted to be Bernard Levin - but he accepted his fate. In 1993 he was poached by The Sunday Times, where he quickly established himself as their shiniest star. He said if he told me his salary, he would have to kill me, but the best guesstimates put it at over £200,000. He has given his editor some hairy moments, being reported to the Racial Equality and Press Complaints Commissions about his frequent attacks on the Welsh and last year's 'Hunforgiven' about the Germans. He was also once physically attacked by Robert Kilroy-Silk, to whom he'd given a 'firm but fair' TV review. But he is completely fearless. His mother and Nicola sometimes tell him to be careful. 'But I think you absolutely can't, because the moment you start thinking that there might be consequences, you've stopped doing your job and you may as well just rewrite PR handouts.' Hear hear. He writes all day, every day, fuelled by cigarettes and coffee; he doesn't even pause to eat till the evening. But, unfortunately, what he most enjoys writing is novels - he believes that 'Journalism is success, writing books is achievement.' Yet even his friends are stumped to find anything good to say about his novels. Why does he bother? The money must be negligible compared to his salary. He bangs on about the sense of achievement, and the pleasure of creating characters - 'It's just the most fun I have writing' - but I suspect he writes novels because the Tatler crowd he moves in considers it OK to be a novelist and not OK to be a journalist. But he is far too intelligent to make any such admission to me. His novels are characterised by poor structure, hysterical over-writing and truly terrible sex scenes. These are terrible, first, because there are so many of them - especially in Sap Rising, where he can't stop babbling on like a schoolboy, saying every rude word he knows - and second, because they are often so disgusting. He has a sort of Hogarthian relish for revolting couplings - there is one with a dog in Sap Rising, and an unspeakable scene in Starcrossed where the hero has to have sex with an ugly woman, which seems to be Gill's idea of a fate worse than death. There is something compulsive, almost unhinged, about his sex writing, as if he actually can't stop himself. And indeed he told me that writing for a Sunday newspaper, with no opportunity to write about sex, 'I built up this sort of well of unwritten sex. I would play endless jokes with the subs, trying to get rude bits in - I invented a restaurant called the Pork Trombone - but they always took it out.' His Style editor, Jeremy Langmead, confirms that 'he's always trying to slip filthy words into his copy'. There is something so off-key about his descriptions of women, and his fixation with genitalia, that I can't be the first person to think he's a closet bisexual. Actually he says everyone thinks it, has done all his life, probably because of his 'feyness', or his camp way of speaking. He doesn't mind - on the contrary, he was 'really chuffed' recently when a gay magazine nominated him as one of the 50 sexiest men in the world. He has a gay friend who tells him, 'You're a gay trapped in a straight body,' but, in fact, he says, his entire homosexual experience amounts to 'a little mutual masturbation' at school and it certainly didn't convert him. He has always had girlfriends, even in his drinking years, and was briefly married in his twenties to Cressida Connolly, and then to Amber Rudd in his thirties. That second marriage seemed to be happy and he was and is besotted with his two children - but he walked out on them in 1995 for Nicola Formby, 'the Blonde'. At the time, she was a model and girl-about-town, mainly known for having gone out with Viscount Linley. They met when Nicola went to consult Adrian about starting a restaurant - she had done a cookery course at La Varenne and is by all accounts a brilliant cook - and she was dazzled by his knowledge. He was presumably dazzled by her beauty - he once wrote a nauseating article in which he described her as 'drop-dead, table-banging, foot-stomping, forehead-corrugating, eyeball-inflating, hubba-hubba, wolf-whistling sensational' and it was at that point that many of my colleagues took against him. I winced for his ex-wife when I read that piece - but apparently she bears him no ill will; on the contrary, she has told friends that Adrian is a far better ex-husband than he ever was husband. He is always advertising 'the Blonde' in his columns, drooling over her beauty, hinting at their fantastic sex life. According to Nicholas Coleridge, they make love twice a day. But when I checked this with Nicola she said, quick as a flash, 'Only once a day with me!' I would have thought it was fairly irritating to be known as the Blonde, but she says, no, she likes it - in fact she writes a column called 'Blonde Date' in Tatler. She is officially editor at large for Tatler, and style editor of The Telegraph magazine. She is an extremely nice, polite girl, who seems to have quite a cool head on her shoulders. When I asked if she hoped to marry Adrian one day, she said she never particularly wanted to be married, and didn't fancy being 'the third Mrs Gill'. What about children? 'I'll cross that bridge when I come to it.' Adrian says he would love to have more children and hopes that Nicola will want them, too. 'It would be a terrible shame, I think, for her not to have children, and if she does have children I sincerely hope that they're mine.' But when I asked Adrian what she was like - apart from being beautiful - he gave what sounded more like a job reference. 'She's immensely organised. She's got a fantastically good eye for detail. I mean, she'll sit in a restaurant and say, "Have you noticed that you never see courgettes on menus any more?" And a lot of that is the essence of what I write anyway - so we tend to do stories together, and she's very good for travelling with.' (Nicola says he's a nightmare to travel with because he wants to be at the airport hours early. But once they arrive, he's fine.) Marcelle d'Argy Smith, the former editor of Cosmopolitan, who is probably their closest joint friend, describes them as 'two terribly successful, attractive alpha people having the most wonderful time - and they're both extraordinarily nice and generous, very kind'. But they are both very, very work-oriented - and almost everything they do is work. They dine out six nights a week so he can keep an eye on restaurants, and on the seventh night they stay in and watch television, so he can write his television review. He loathes dinner parties, but will go to almost any drinks party - 'It's true I absolutely would go to the opening of a fridge' - and yet he admits he is very bad at parties, always a wallflower, and of course always sober. I must say, whenever I've seen him and Nicola at parties they don't seem to be having much fun. But he explains, 'Usually, for one or other of us, it's work. If I read something in someone else's copy and I don't know what they're talking about, I just get this sudden froideur [presumably he means panic] about what am I not noticing. But then I worry that I might start taking it seriously, that I might start caring about not getting the right invitation. It hasn't happened yet, touch wood.' But he says Nicola is always complaining that they don't have any friends, just endless acquaintances, and, 'I worry that in the end I see the same 200 or 300 people over and over again, and I would hate to think that that actually ended up being what my social life was. There are lots of people I think of as being old, dear friends, but I maybe only speak to them once or twice a year, because they constantly go to the back of the queue, behind all the things which are to do with work, with deadlines. I'm continually saddened when I look through my address book, at how patchy it is, at how many people drop off the edge of my life.' One person who has shockingly dropped off the edge of his life is his younger brother Nick, his only sibling. Not knowing, I asked a casual question about whether he was still working as a chef and Adrian's eyes filled with tears. 'I don't know. My brother sort of disappeared, just over a year ago. He wasn't working. He's divorced, got three children. He came to see me and said, "I'm having a miserable time. I'm going to disappear for a bit." I think there comes a point for some people where you look at the totality of your life and say, "This is not what I want. There's not anything worth salvaging. So I'll go off and start again." In a sense, I had that forced on me, and Nick never did. And he's just gone and done it. I'm sure he'll turn up - but it will be when he wants to. It must be everybody's right to do that - to just chuck in the hand and say, "Deal me a whole new set of cards." I mean, on one level I think he's very courageous. On another level - I miss him a lot. I miss him terribly. I love him, Nick.' Gill obviously believes that the heart has its reasons. He made an equally abrupt departure when he left his wife and two small children for Nicola and has never regretted it - he says he is a great believer in 'positive divorce'. And yet he claims to be a Christian, which doesn't normally entail belief in positive divorce. 'Well, then the alternative is that I'm a great believer in really miserable marriages. That doesn't seem to be particularly Christian either!' he snaps. He says the great advantage of being a low-church Protestant, which he is, is that you don't have to get your religion through priests or pastors, because 'everyone has a direct line to God'. He spends time in churches, though not usually during services, and says that in his drinking years he used to cry a lot in the back of churches. None of his friends seem to know that he's a Christian. Jeremy Clarkson was quite amazed when I told him: 'Adrian? Christian? What - as in milk of human kindness, goodwill to all men? He's having you on.' His Style editor, Jeremy Langmead, was equally dismissive - 'I've never met someone so un-Christian - I thought the only person he worshipped was himself.' I find it very hard to square the beliefs expressed in his novels and his columns with Christianity, or indeed with any moral overview. Starcrossed in particular is almost Thatcherite in its contempt for 'losers' (and I wonder what his brother Nicholas made of it). Its message seems to be that rich, beautiful, famous people are actually better than poor, ugly, unsuccessful ones - better as in more deserving of space on the planet. It may be that because he despises himself for being poor and unsuccessful in his drinking years, he assumes that everyone who is poor and unsuccessful merely needs to get a grip and sign into Clouds. Although that's not fair either - he once wrote a very moving piece about poverty in the Sudan. Part of the trouble with AA Gill is that he can argue almost any case so eloquently you can't really tell which case he believes in. My more earnest colleagues complain that he 'always goes for the soft targets', but given that he's writing for a magazine called Style, you wouldn't seriously expect him to offer a critique of capitalism. Nevertheless, there is a sort of a missing middle in his writing - he swings between gushing sentimentality and withering contempt with no rational argument in between. And his fiercest contempt is usually directed at people who commit the crime of being ugly - reverence for beauty is the one consistent value in his oeuvre. Perhaps that is why he spends all the hours at Doug Haywood's, faffing over his execrable suits. Nicola says it's harmless: 'He loves clothes, and I think that's great. He goes off and sits with Doug Haywood and twinks and twanks about whether the stitching should go here, and the lining should be like this - that's his kind of game of golf in the afternoon. I don't think he's obsessively vain, but he likes the business of looking well turned out.' I asked Adrian if he wished he were more handsome, and a strange, puzzled frown darkened his brow, so I quickly amended the question to more devastatlingly handsome, which seemed to go down better. 'I'm no more secure in my appearance than I think anyone else is. I'm 45, I'm going bald, I stoop, I've got terrible teeth. I don't really worry about those things, but I'm aware of them. I happened to fall in love with someone who is very beautiful and I think it's totally captivating, beauty. I can take any amount of it - I never walk into a room and think, ho hum, more beautiful girls. What I really despise is the people who say it's only skin deep, it means nothing.' But it makes for a perilous future, surely - he and Nicola can't always be hot, can't always be beautiful, can't always be successful (though perhaps I'm indulging in a little wish fulfilment here). He admits that he worries sometimes about what happens to old columnists - he knows he can't go on forever. But, he explains, 'It comes back again to what I was saying about getting this clean sheet. The person I am now is the person that, at 29, I would have wanted to be. Somehow I did turn into someone that, in another life, I would have hated and envied. I was at a dinner party once with a whole lot of bankers and lawyers, and someone said, "Where do you want to be in 10 years' time?" And every single person round the table had a life plan, a goal, and it finally got to me and I said, "Please God, I can be doing exactly what I'm doing now. If I can write a book a year, and get paid a really absurd amount of money to eat in restaurants and watch television, and to be read but not to be famous - I couldn't really better that."' Dontcha hate him?  Starcrossed by AA Gill is published by Black Swan in May, price £6.99

fields.headline: Families set for bumpy ride
fields.standfirst: Don't trust your employer to get it right on Working Families Tax Credit, warns  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: One of the hot tips for Tuesday's Budget is the introduction of more incentives for mothers to get back to work. A rise in statutory maternity pay is one possibility; an extension to Working Families Tax Credit is another.
fields.body:
One of the hot tips for Tuesday's Budget is the introduction of more incentives for mothers to get back to work. A rise in statutory maternity pay is one possibility; an extension to Working Families Tax Credit is another.

But WFTC - although joyously welcomed by lone parents' charities and other groups - could still have its problems in practice. So if you are one of the 700,000 families claiming WFTC, expect a bumpy ride from next month, when employers take over from the Inland Revenue the task of paying out the money.

WFTC was introduced last October as the beefed-up, more generous successor to Family Credit - paying over £100 a week to some families. For the first six months, the Inland Revenue has been administering the payments - but responsibility passes to employers for claims starting after 4 April.

With more efficient companies there will, doubtless, be a seamless transition. But tax experts and welfare rights advisers are predicting major difficulties elsewhere. 'This is the first time that employers have been payers of benefits,' says Paul Falvey of accountant Grant Thornton. 'Employers representing only 2 per cent of the workforce have undergone Inland Revenue training on how to deal with it. Employers aren't geared up at all.'

Nick Burkitt of the Low Pay Unit worries that low-paid people - who are quite likely to be working in small businesses - may not get the benefit on time or may get the wrong amount. Liberal Democrat shadow chancellor Matthew Taylor, fears that WFTC 'imposes unneces sary burdens on small business, and encourages fraud'.

The new Disabled Person's Tax Credit is also being administered in the same way - through employers for claims starting after 4 April.

When he unveiled the credits, Chancellor Gordon Brown was adamant that WFTC should escape the stigma of being a benefit paid by the Benefits Agency - but should instead be added to the pay packet and seen as a 'credit'.

The complexity of dealing with the credits has sparked rumours that some employers will be less willing to employ WFTC recipients.

A small minority of WFTC recipients will still be paid by the Inland Revenue - those who are self-employed and those in a couple where the partner claiming is either self-employed or not working.

So, if you are an employed claimant, what should you be expecting? If you are already claiming, you will have made your first claim to the Inland Revenue (which now runs the Benefits Agency). When your claim was granted, it was agreed for a six-month period. As that period comes to an end, you need to make another claim for the next six months. This should be fairly straightforward - unless your circumstances have changed considerably.

When the Inland Revenue agrees the claim, it will write to your employer telling them how much you should be paid. You will not need to give your employer details of your partner's earnings or the number and ages of your children: these details are kept confidentially by the Revenue. You may, however, want to speak to your employer to check that they are ready to sort out your claim.

Accountant Grant Thornton believes that some employers will find it difficult to bolt WFTC on to their existing systems - not least because WFTC is calculated by the day, whereas most payroll systems work by the month. Falvey adds: 'I have heard of one case where a large employer was told that the new software might not be ready until the end of May. In the meantime, they could perhaps calculate it manually and make cheque payments. This should be possible if they are alive to the situation.'

Some employers think they will not need to deal with the issue because none of their staff has a low enough salary to qualify for WFTC. But they will need to think again. A working couple with a joint income of £34,000 and four children could be entitled to WFTC of £56.30 per week. A single parent on £30,000 could also qualify.

The Low Pay Unit says that at the other end of the spectrum, 'there are a lot of people who don't have written contracts or payslips'. Their employers have payroll systems which do not comply with the law as it is - let alone with the new complexities. Burkitt says: 'A lot of these people are used to having weekly benefits payments. They can't be kept waiting while it is sorted out.'

There is an Inland Revenue helpline. And there are provisions for the Revenue to pay the money to the claimant if the employer does not. Tardy employers can be fined up to £3,000 by the Revenue for failing to fulfil their obligations.

Other concerns about the WFTC include the fact that it could be easy to make mistakes - and therefore to be penalised by the Revenue for making those errors. The Low Incomes Tax Reform Group is urging the Government to smooth out the system. The definition of income for Income Tax purposes is not the same as the definition for WFTC - even though both areas are handled by the same government department.

For instance, the tax-efficient Individual Savings Accounts (Isas) are excluded from Income Tax calculations - but are included for WFTC. Benefits in kind - from the company car to the free yoga classes - are included in your taxable income, but excluded when your WFTC income is calculated.

Confused? Well, be careful if you ask your employer for help on what exactly your earnings are. They may get it wrong too. Check your income with a specialist adviser from a Citizens Advice Bureau, welfare rights unit, Gingerbread or another specialist charity.

John Andrews, chair of the Low Incomes Tax Reform Group, believes that employers could soon start to find significance in the fact that benefits in kind are excluded from WFTC: 'When the penny drops, they may start giving some of their pay in childcare vouchers, perhaps. Then we have a new avoidance industry again.'

That would be ironic. One of the tax themes of the last decade has been the Government's relentless pursuit of tax dodges through benefit in kind schemes. In the 1980s, wealthy workers in the City sometimes got partly paid in gold bars to avoid the tax. It would be bizarre if working parents soon start getting partly paid in childcare vouchers.

 Inland Revenue helplines: (for claimants) 0845 609 5000; (for employers) 0845 714 3143.

 Gingerbread advice line: 0800 018 4318; Lone parent helpline: 0800 018 5026 (run by the National Council for One Parent Families).

 Low Pay Unit helpline: 020-7713 7583

fields.headline: Inheritance set for a hit
fields.standfirst:
Neasa MacErlean on a tax loophole that Brown may be ready to close
Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: The chancellor was expected to tackle inheritance tax a year ago but only raised the individual personal threshold to £231,000. He may duck the issue again, but if he follows through on his earlier concerns, he will try to make it harder for the very wealthy to escape the tax.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown may be in purdah over Tuesday's Budget - but the writing is on the wall - or on the press release to be more exact.

Back in 1994, soon after he became Shadow Chancellor, Brown oversaw a publication called 'Tackling tax abuses - tackling unemployment'. This listed 25 'tax loopholes, abuses and areas for action'.

Most of the 25 items have already been dealt with. But one area stands out: Inheritance Tax (IHT), the tax on your estate when you die. Brown was expected to tackle this a year ago but only raised the individual personal threshold to £231,000. He may duck the issue again, but if he follows through on his earlier concerns, he will try to make it harder for the very wealthy to escape the tax.

Many people who are potentially liable will be unaware of it. For instance, if you own a semi-detached house in London, the chances are your estate will be liable for the tax under cur rent rules. The price of the average semi in London is around £300,000, according to the Halifax. On a £300,000 property, the taxable part would be £69,000. Taxed at 40 per cent, this produces a bill of £27,600.

Mike Warburton of accountant Grant Thornton suggests various ways that Brown could protect moderately wealthy people whose homes have soared in value and who may have Isas, and other taxable assets. 'He could consider a substantial increase in the threshold or, perhaps, a 20 per cent tax rate on the first chunk of chargeable wealth.'

Brown may feel more inclined to have a go at very wealthy people. One way of doing this is to change the system of 'potentially exempt transfers' (Pets). Many families avoid tax by parents giving assets to their children. If the parent survives seven years after the gift is made, there is no tax charge. The extension of this period by another three years would make that harder.

Whether Brown acts on his 1994 document this week or not, it is certainly an insight into the Labour approach - and far more detailed than the 1997 election manifesto when it comes to tax.

fields.headline: Getting hammered
fields.standfirst: These days, to bid at a live wine auction all you have to do is click your mouse
fields.trailText: These days, to bid at a live wine auction all you have to do is click your mouse
fields.body:
Call me a man with a short attention span, but I've always regarded live wine auctions as a contradiction in terms. I'm not talking about the occasional high-profile sale, where someone spends £105,000 on a bottle of 1787 Château Lafitte (sic) or the appalling Lord Lloyd Webber sells half his cellar to raise a few million quid. No sir, I'm talking about the run-of-the-mill wine auctions held at places like Christie's and Sotheby's. Unless crown green bowling quickens your pulse, these are the very distillation of dullness.

There are a few amusing, and no doubt apocryphal stories about wine auctions. My favourite is the one about the tramp who wandered in and bought most of the lots at a sale of miniatures, thereby wrecking it. But that's about as thrilling as it gets in the salesroom. Perhaps auctioneers should wear period costume or smash the odd bottle of claret with a hammer to keep people awake. Or maybe they should just recognise the fact that traditional wine auctions belong to another era, when everyone wore pinstripes and was a member of the same London club. At an average sale these days, roughly 70 per cent of the bids come from people who are not in the room, either because they live in another country or have an important date with their sock drawer.

If you think this sounds like an opportunity for an internet business, you'd be quite right. Winebid.com, a successful American on-line auction venture, has just launched its first UK sale, running until 26 March, and leading independent merchant Berry Brothers & Rudd is conducting enterprising daily auctions on the web until the end of the month in conjunction with icollector.com. Both sites are a lot more fun than sitting in a salesroom in South Kensington or New Bond Street waiting for your lot number to come up.

For readers who want a giggle, qxl.com includes wine on its auction site. Wine is listed, for some reason, under Home and Gardens, where you can find a case of 1995 Château Pichon-Lalande next to an office golf game or an 84-piece stainless-steel cutlery set with gold inlay. Wine drinkers have broad minds, but we're not all passionate about DIY and grow bags.

Will these sites take business away from the big auction houses? David Elswood of winebid.com, who worked for Christie's for 16 years, says: 'We're a small company, we've got lower overheads and we're a lot more flexible than the big two.' Buying from winebid, icollector or qxl means the punter doesn't have to make a snap decision under pressure. (One auctioneer told me that neophytes find bidding so terrifying that their ears go red before they wave their paddle in the air.) It also means you can follow the bidding while doing something else. Elswood is looking to make the whole business more consumer-friendly, and good luck to him.

If the idea of on- or even off-line bidding appeals, do a bit of research first, particularly if you're buying fine wine. You should also have a good idea of market prices (get hold of a catalogue from Farr Vintners on 020 7821 2000 or Bibendum on 020 7722 5577), and how much you want to spend before you connect your mouse. Also, have a look at things like commission rates. Should you be interested in a particular wine, check where the stuff has been stored, by whom and for how long: some wines have crossed the Atlantic only slightly less often than the QEII. The golden rule of buying at auction - caveat emptor - still applies in cyberspace. Whatever happens to the salesrooms, that much will never change.

fields.headline: Jupiter reaches for the stars
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The winner of the Money Observer unit trust/Oeics category, Jupiter Unit Trust Managers, has turned £100 invested in its funds into an average of £361 over the past five years - and achieved better returns than its rivals over all intervening periods.
fields.body:
The winner of the Money Observer unit trust/Oeics category, Jupiter Unit Trust Managers, has turned £100 invested in its funds into an average of £361 over the past five years - and achieved better returns than its rivals over all intervening periods.

Jupiter's fund management skills have won growing recognition in recent years among professionals and private investors alike. While it is best known for its large flagship funds - Income, UK Growth and European - its strengths are not restricted to these areas.

Its range of funds has become increasingly diversified in recent years, but this has not diluted the returns.

The secret of the group's success does not lie in a strict management discipline. On the contrary, investment director Edward Bonham Carter is scathing about anything that resembles a committee approach to investment, or stifles individual managers' initiative. 'That is not how you get performance,' he says.

Jupiter is now almost a household name among investors, and it is hard to believe that just five years ago its parent company, Jupiter Asset Management, was barely known except to the cognoscenti.

Even more surprising perhaps is that a group that celebrates its 13th birthday only this year should now be selling more individual savings accounts (Isas) than most of its older rivals put together.

But take a look at its performance record, and the reason becomes clear. Jupiter Asset Management, an independent investment management group, was founded by John Duffield in 1985. He chose a rather inauspicious time to launch its first unit trusts - July 1987, just three months before Black Monday - and initial progress was rather slow.

The group started with two funds, adding another three the following year. After that, things remained quiet as Britain struggled with a recession.

It was not until the second half of the Nineties that more funds were launched. By that time the performance of Jupiter's three flagship funds - Income, UK Growth and European - was being noticed by investment advisers. As sales rocketed, new funds were added. By the end of the decade, there were 16.

Jupiter started its distinctive advertising campaign in 1996. Blessed with a strong brand name - apparently chosen because of its founder's interest in the planets rather than any thought of how good it would look on posters - it has gone from strength to strength.

It has climbed the fund managers' league table, leaving weaker unit trust rivals such as Virgin Direct well behind. It is currently in 17th position with some £4.4 billion under management, and there seems little to stop it reaching the superleague alongside Fidelity and M&G within a few years.

Behind this progress lies Jupiter's stunning investment performance record. Even its rapid expansion in the past few years seems to have done little harm: 85 per cent of its funds have been in the top quartile of their sectors since launch.

Bonham Carter makes this achievement sound deceptively simple. 'The key factors have been attracting and keeping talented people, making sure one person is closely associated with the performance of a fund and still providing a team environment so that those talented individuals can discuss ideas constantly.'

One of the ways the group gets the best out of all its fund managers is its policy of seeing people from as many companies as possible in its offices, rather than going on the road to visit them. Several fund managers sit down together to grill them.

Bonham Carter explains: 'This approach is more time- efficient. It means we can sometimes see three or four companies in a day.

'More importantly, because everybody sees things in a different way, it means people will ask questions about what they are interested in - the financial side, the management and so on - and can then debate these matters with their colleagues.'

Although an agreed position may be reached, whether or not individual managers decide to put a company in their funds is up to them. They are not left entirely to their own devices, however. Every two months, as a risk control mechanism, fund portfolios are monitored to ensure that they do not have too many unquoted companies or one big hold ing that is getting out of proportion. Another aspect of the Jupiter approach is its flexible and pragmatic investment culture. Bonham Carter says: 'We don't focus rigidly on large or small companies, or pursue a growth or value approach; we invest in what we think is right at the time. We look at where a company's growth is coming from, what the risks are and whether there are barriers to entry which will enable them to defend their profits.'

In the end, though, he adds: 'Fund management is an art. It is a subjective process.' And this, of course, is where individual managers' talents come in.

fields.headline: Worlds apart
fields.standfirst: Himalayan magnolias and Tasmanian tree ferns feel quite at home in a Cornish valley
fields.trailText: Himalayan magnolias and Tasmanian tree ferns feel quite at home in a Cornish valley
fields.body:
I've just returned from Cornwall where I've spent the past week filming. You'll have to wait until November to see the programme (Lost Gardens, Channel 4), so it would be premature to tell its story, but it was my first visit to a Cornish valley garden. (I drove past the entrance to Heligan about six years ago when the restoration was in full flow, but it was the end of the day and I had a long journey ahead I've regretted it ever since.)

The essential components of these gardens - rhododendrons, ferns, magnolias, azaleas, camellias, bamboos - are not plants that I feel any empathy with. Just as the first five years of your life influences everything about the rest of your days, so the landscape you first knew and loved imprints itself on you and becomes the geology of the bone. The alkaline chalkland of north Hampshire was ideal for beech, yew, box, irises, carnations and summer flowering deciduous shrubs, but hopeless for rhododendrons and camellias. Apart from the soil conditions, it is on a frost line which meant we could not grow anything remotely tender.

So these Cornish gardens with their mild climate, high rainfall and careful siting in valleys protected by massive tree planting along the rims (creating an even milder micro-climate) are a foreign country. Any self-respecting Cornish person would point out that Cornwall always has been another country, but the strangeness is measured in foliage and light, not in custom.

I visited Glendurgan, which was created in the early years of the 19th century. This means that it has had time to evolve a sustainable ecology based upon this intelligent combination of manmade environment and uncontrollable climate. The result, like the Gulf-Streamed south-west corner of Ireland and the west coast of Scotland, is effectively temperate rainforest with a constant mild temperature and a rainfall of about 45 inches spread evenly across the year. It never dries out, never gets too hot and hardly drops below freezing more than once or twice a year. This means that plants from Australia, New Zealand, Japan, China and the lower slopes of the Himalayas feel more at home there than anywhere else in England.

The most obvious beneficiary of this environment is the Tasmanian tree fern, Dicksonia antartica, which, despite having become wildly trendy over the past few years, is still outlandishly prehistoric. These are the 6ft fronds that dinosaurs pushed past. They sprout on top of tall 'trunks' which are actually a thick matted cord of root. There are few stained-glass windows in this world as lovely as gazing up through these interlocking fronds, backlit by a blue sky. The conventional account of the tree fern's arrival in this country is that the stems were used as ballast by cargo ships returning from Australasia and one was thrown overboard in Falmouth harbour. Someone noticed that it began to sprout and planted it in their garden, where it thrived.

Given the right conditions, tree ferns do very well. In the wrong climate, they are almost impossible to grow. They ask only for some light (although not too much - dappled shade is the perfect prescription), moist soil, moist air, summer temperatures that are not too hot and mild winters (although most of the Cornish tree ferns survived the terrible winters of 1948 and 1963) and to be kept free from ivy which suckers on to their fibrous stem and which would eventually clog up the centre of the fronds which acts as a sump for rainwater, rather like a bromeliad. The theory is that the dying fronds hang down like a faded curtain, shading out potentially threatening climbers, but it doesn't seem to work against ivy.

The tree ferns look wonderful all year round, but in spring the flowering trees in these Cornish gardens are startlingly brilliant. My favourite is the Magnolia campbellii, the flowers of which open from plum-pink, avocado-sized buds into fat-petalled water lilies on the end of naked branches. That is extraordinary enough, but it dips into fantasy when you see how big these trees can become. Magnolias were such a fixture of interwar suburban planting - with 100 M x soulangeanas planted for one of any other type - that our gardens have domesticated them. A visit to these Cornish gardens blows away all these preconceptions. In its native Himalayas, the magnolia can reach 150ft, although it does well to reach a third of that in this country. But that is still staggering. Imagine a massive ash or beech suddenly exploding into huge flower and you are on the right track. The steep-sided valleys mean you can gaze up at the flowers 60ft above you, and then climb the hillside and look down on to them. Astonishment is the only just response. They must be planted for your dotage and your grandchildren, because they are very slow to come into flower, taking 25 years to produce a single flower. Not makeover material. They like an acidic soil and spring frosts would reduce the flowers to used tissue, so they must be in a sheltered and/or mild spot. An even bigger tree is M x veitchii which is a cross between M campbellii and M denudata, and this has reached 85ft in Cornwall.

The acidic soil is a prerequisite for rhododendrons and their flowers run amok from early February until late spring. Like tree ferns, they prosper best in high humidity and low heat. I hardly know what to think of rhododendrons. Yet I noticed last week that they made me smile. Perhaps this is their secret. They are not serious plants. They do not have the wonder of the magnolias or the mystery of tree ferns. The combination of glossy green leaves and shocking pastels is something to do with this, like a 1950s print of a starlet determined to make a splash at her first premiere; but also the way that they flower so profusely, the bushes bobbled all over like a glossy bathing cap. But, despite myself, I think that I am learning to like them, even though I cannot grow them on my neutral clay.

Even Hillier's Guide to Trees and Shrubs, which is my first point of reference in all matters dendrological, with Hugh Johnson's Encyclopaedia of Trees hard on its heels, admits that 'Rhododendron leaves can be extremely dull' and once they have flowered they create a backdrop as ungiving as a banker's smile. We have all come to see R ponticum as a rampant weed, choking whole hillsides with that flat glossy stare, but until my Cornish visit I had not realised that laurel can be equally invasive. I saw one garden where both the cherry laurel, Prunus laurocerasus, and the Portuguese laurel, P lusitanica, with lateral growth as thick and as long as trees, created an impenetrable jungle. Both were innocently planted as cover for plants and game birds, but in that climate they grow like triffids.

The maze at Glendurgan is of laurel and the head gardener told me that they cut it five times a year to keep it reasonably crisp. The main problem with this, he said, was not so much the cutting, but getting the clippings out. Every basket of laurel clippings had to be carried right round the maze of paths to the entrance to be emptied. It's a lovely image.

 Dicksonia antartica is available from £29 per plant upwards at Fern Express, 81 Bridle Road, Burton Joyce, Nottingham NG14 5FS (0115 931 2212; fax 0115 931 4114)

webTitle: Can you mint it from a mouse?

fields.headline: Can you mint it from a mouse?
fields.standfirst:
As the cost of surfing falls, Heather Connon asks how firms expect to make money online
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: As the cost of surfing falls, Heather Connon asks how firms expect to make money online.
fields.body:
How do businesses make money? The answer is usually obvious, whether the company is Marks & Spencer, Merrill Lynch or Manchester United. They sell things - sweaters, dealing and advisory services, the chance to watch live football - for more than it costs to make or provide them. Log on to the Web, however, and the picture becomes blurred.

For a start, no one seems to be charging for anything. Browsers can read anything from The Observer to Pride and Prejudice; receive news and sports information as it happens; find out the location of speed cameras in their local authority; download music for free; get instant medical advice; find out the weather in Miami; check share prices, even deal in shares for free...

But where does the money to support this web of information come from? Who is paying for it and, as important, who is making profits from it? To answer that question you have to look at the types of businesses and information available on the Net.

First, there are conventional businesses such as retailers, banks, insurance companies, travel agents and auction houses. These are simply using the Web as a shopfront or branch through which to offer goods or services. Some are online subsidiaries of conventional companies - Waterstones, Tesco, Toys'R'Us, the Co-op's Smile. Others have been established purely as Web businesses - Amazon, e-toys, egg, QXL. But all operate on the conventional economic model of selling something for more than it costs to produce it.

Then there are the organisations that supply information on the Web as a public service. That includes: government and other statutory bodies such as the Competition Commission; many universities; schools who have to make their inspection reports available online; some companies; pressure groups; even the National Health Service.

At the other end of the scale, and in a category few of us searching the Web at home will even see, are business-to-business sites such as Goindustry, an online auction house that helps companies dispose of unwanted assets such as machine tools from decommissioned plants, or trading hubs like those being established by Carrefour or Ford.

In between, are thousands of other businesses and websites, all hoping to make at least some money by using the Web as a business tool but without looking like conventional businesses. Until earlier this month, many would have relied on taking a share of the telephone charges paid by surfers: for example, half of last year's revenues for Freeserve, the Internet Service Provider, came from call charges. But following the move towards unmetered access - pioneered by Alta Vista and now widely emulated - these revenues will disappear. In their place are two sources of revenue still at the heart of most Internet business plans: advertising and commission.

Advertising is big business on the Web. Virtually every site you click on will have at least one advert. Some estimate that as much as 80 per cent of all venture capital money raised by Internet business is spent on advertising. Some of that goes on conventional media, television and billboards, for example, but a lot of it is spent on the Web itself. Every time you use one of the major search engines to look for a subject, an advert claiming you can find books on the subject at Amazon pops up. Small wonder, then, that its marketing and sales spend last year was more than $400 million, or a quarter of its total sales.

First, there are businesses such as lastminute.com, which is effectively a travel agent taking a cut of the cost of a flight, holiday or hotel room in exchange for helping the supplier fill it. Or it can be dressed up as an introduction or tip-off fee. An Internet service provider such as AOL or Freeserve, or a search engine such as Yahoo will direct surfers to particular sites, for shopping, investment advice, share dealing, financial management, sports results, music downloads or whatever.

The chances are it will have agreed a deal with everyone on that list to take at least a share of any sales they make - if not also an introduction fee for simply directing the surfer their way. Indeed, some take it further and will try to take a commission on every subsequent purchase made by someone who was first introduced to a retailer through their portal.

Not every company will be able to command lucrative commission deals. Internet excitement is cooling; those who control the budgets are starting to be more discriminating about where and how they spend their money. One financial services business describes being asked by one of the smaller search engines to agree to pay a commission of 2p every time it was included in a list of possible mortgage lenders. It finally agreed a flat fee of £7,000.

It is not impossible to make money from adverts: there are plenty of free newspapers which do just that, and even paid-for titles make around 70 per cent of their money from adverts. But while there are a limited number of newspapers, the Web sometimes appears infinite. Will there be enough money to go round?

webTitle: Pope's mission to halt exodus in Holy Land

fields.headline: Pope's mission to halt exodus in Holy Land
fields.trailText: When Pope John Paul II arrives next week to celebrate Mass in the home town of the Holy Family, local Christians hope he will overlook the green plastic flags and Muslim prayer mats of the makeshift mosque nestled beneath the Basilica of the Annunciation.
fields.body:
When Pope John Paul II arrives next week to celebrate Mass in the home town of the Holy Family, local Christians hope he will overlook the green plastic flags and Muslim prayer mats of the makeshift mosque nestled beneath the Basilica of the Annunciation.

The Muslim preacher who officiates at the parking lot prayer area hopes the pontiff will stop by. 'We invited him to come here to symbolise peace between Christians and Muslims all over the world,' says Sheikh Nazim Abu Saleem. 'We even asked him to come and put the cornerstone in our mosque.'

The sheikh is being disingenuous. Islamist activists occupied the lot in 1998, infuriating the Church, which has been unable to get them to leave, and defying municipal plans to build a parking garage and plaza for tourists. Now the dispute has come to symbolise the eclipse of Christian influence in the land where Jesus was born. At the dawn of the third millennium of Christianity, his followers have abandoned the Holy Land in such numbers that the Pope's six-day visit will combine pilgrimage with a boost in morale for a shrinking community.

'He will bring a message of hope and encouragement to local Christians - not only Catholics,' says Wadie Abu Nassar, executive director of the Assembly of Catholic Bishops of the Holy Land. A Roman Catholic whose family traces its roots in Galilee for 400 years, he has stayed behind as his cousins scattered around the globe. The exodus, which began 100 years ago, has gathered pace during the upheavals of the last 50 years: the creation of the Jewish state in 1948, which saw a third of the Palestinian Christians forced from their homes, the Arab-Israeli wars and the rise in Islamic militancy during the intifada of the 1980s.

In Israel and the West Bank, the Christian communities have dwindled to about 2 per cent of the population, or 180,000 souls, from 13 per cent 50 years ago. In Nazareth and Bethlehem, once almost exclusively Christian, they make up about a third of the population.

Such demographic shifts inflamed the land dispute at the Church of the Annunciation. In the last municipal elections in this town of 60,000, the largest Arab town in Israel, the Islamic Movement won a share of the council seats for the first time.

In 1998, they staked their claim to the land beside the church, where there is the modest tomb of a military leader who fought against the Crusaders, and said they would erect a grand mosque.

Church activists claim the Islamists were abetted in their land-grab by the Israeli authorities, who use religion to divide the population in Arab towns. Within Israel, Christians say they are treated no better - or worse - than Muslim Arabs. However, faced with paltry job prospects and enjoying an edge in education and contacts abroad, they have decamped for the United States, Latin America, Australia and Europe. That confluence of economic and social pressures also lies behind emigration from areas controlled for the last six years by the Palestinian Authority. Although its draft constitution declares Islam as the official religion, Yasser Arafat frequently strives to include the Christian community. His wife, Sulia, is Christian.

But, despite efforts by churches, which include practical measures such as building low-cost housing and creating jobs at church institutions, the flight has gone unarrested. In Jerusalem, Christians number only 10,000 in a city of 600,000.

So depleted are the numbers of Christians, that when the Pope addresses 100,000 people next Friday from the hillside in Galilee where Jesus is said to have delivered the Sermon on the Mount half of the teenagers in the 'youth Mass' will have been flown in from abroad.

While the progress of the Pope as he follows in the footsteps of Jesus will be captured on television, it will take more than a media extravaganza to turn round the Christians' fortunes. 'A tiny community that is endangered is going to be on the stage of the world for a week. But whether it is going to have any lasting impact on retarding the flight of Christians - that I cannot tell you,' says Father Jerome Murphy-O'Connor, professor of New Testament Studies at the Ecole Biblique in Jerusalem.

webTitle: Lastminute.com hit with German law suit

fields.headline: Lastminute.com hit with German law suit
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Floating the net: special report
fields.trailText: Everything went wrong for lastminute.com in the opening moments of the game. High-profile Internet entrepreneurs Martha Lane Fox and Brent Hoberman are not only watching their share price fall, they are also being taken to court for anti-competitive behaviour.
fields.body:
Everything went wrong for lastminute.com in the opening moments of the game. High-profile Internet entrepreneurs Martha Lane Fox and Brent Hoberman are not only watching their share price fall, they are also being taken to court for anti-competitive behaviour.

A German travel agent has started legal proceedings against the pair's company, which floated last week for more than £500 million, alleging the lastminute name is misleading and breaches trade laws.

Silicon.com, the online IT industry news bible, unearthed the story to coincide with the company's first day on the stock market. Details of the impending court case were written into lastminute's revised company prospectus. John Bernstein, editor-in-chief of Silicon, said the case signalled the problems the company will face in trying to roll out its brand across the world, a vital move if lastminute is to justify its incredible value.

'This is a local difficulty for lastminute, but it illustrates some of the problems you have doing business across the globe,' Bernstein said.

Lastminute says it doesn't believe the legal proceedings, brought by travel agent L'tur Tourismus against its German subsidiary earlier this month will have a significant effect on its financial performance.

The German agent alleges that lastminute's marketing claims are misleading; the company has built its brand around portraying itself as an eleventh-hour bucket shop provider of discount services, whereas travellers can in fact book flights and holidays more than 14 days in advance.

Lane Fox, 27, and Hoberman, 31, attracted huge amounts of interest in Lastminute, and the price at which shares were sold was upped to 380p last weekend. On their debut, the shares rocketed to 555p, but fell steadily over the week. By Friday evening, brokers were offering 380p.

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.standfirst: Websites to help you manage your money
fields.trailText: Websites to help you manage your money
fields.body:
Nearly a million Egg customers now have access to an 'online investment supermarket' - due to be made accessible to non-customers in April.

The new facility allows people to choose from up to 169 funds, some at reduced prices. Customers can enter details of savings, investments and mortgages, to build up a 'personal balance sheet' which is automatically updated daily as the price of investments change.

As part of a launch offer Egg is, until 27 April, giving a '1 per cent cashback bonus', paid into customers' savings accounts, when they invest money in an Isa.

Other features of www.egg.com include 'fantasy portfolios', allowing beginners to 'try before they buy', and information from independent sources on money subjects.

In the competition for Isa customers, Interactive Investor (www.III.co.uk ) is offering an online 'advice function' free until 5 April. Users 'complete an online consultation in which they are asked a series of questions about their situation, objectives, attitudes towards risk', and receive a short report, including specific fund recommendations.

Norwich Union is another Isa provider taking advantage of the fact that a written signature is not needed to buy an Isa. On www.norwich-union.co.uk you can buy an NU Isa in 10 minutes and get information on performance, value and service. A similar Isa-buying service is being offered by Gartmore on www.gartmore.com.

Screentrade, the online 'insurance supermarket' launched in 1997, is launching a digital TV quotation service on motor insurance to complement www.screentrade.co.uk.

The service is launched tomorrow for Cable & Wireless customers in Manchester, and will be rolled out to other regions and through other TV companies during the year. It will also be expanded to cover home and travel insurance.

One of a growing number of general financial information websites is fish4.co.uk - a source of used cars, residential properties and job vacancies as well as a directory of businesses and a listing of news and sports items.

At the other end of the spectrum, www.hpicheck.com allows buyers of second hand cars to check the status of possible purchases. The HPI E-Check register charges £12.50 to check up to three vehicle registration numbers to see if any are registered stolen, written off by an insurance company or have money still owing on the original purchase. One in seven checks results in an 'outstanding finance' alert, according to Equifax, which runs the service.

webTitle: The poet who died so well

fields.headline: The poet who died so well
fields.standfirst: Long-lost diaries promise to reveal her darkest  secrets. But is this macabre industry ignoring her work?
fields.trailText: Long-lost diaries promise to reveal her darkest secrets. But is this macabre industry ignoring her work?
fields.body:
Sylvia Plath gassed herself, aged 30, in the cold London flat she had moved into after separating from her husband, Ted Hughes. She shut the door and put out bread and milk for her baby son and three-year-old daughter. Her death, in 1963, is the most famous thing about her, as impossible to erase from the memory as any line of her poetry. And since her death, her life has become a minefield.

The Plath estate - managed by Olwyn Hughes - has fought to guard her image and to protect her children. Plath has become the siren who never lost the power to seduce, the sphinx that five biographers have tried to unriddle.Ted Hughes' miraculous final volume of poetry Birthday Letters, published in 1998 months before his death, seemed like the last words on the subject.

But now Plath's unedited journals, notebook and diaries - whose serialisation continues in the Guardian on Monday and Tuesday - are to appear in a single volume for the first time.

And of course we will read on, like detectives, greedy for clues. Advance publicity promises that Plath will be 'explained' (as if such a thing were possible).

They will reveal, we are told, that Plath's worst enemy was not Ted Hughes - as feminists have claimed - but herself. No one who has read Plath's autobiographical novel The Bell Jar - let alone her poetry - will regard this as news.

But as the train of literature about Plath and Hughes thunders on, as often as not Plath's poetry is left behind. No one stops to ask how good it was. Is it Plath's doomed life we care about most? Was death her best poem? Are her poems anything more than anguished poetic diaries? And can they be separated from her life?

When I was at school, girls who would not read anything else were often to be discovered, 'mixed-up kids in long trailing skirts,' with slim volumes of Plath under their arms.

She touched a nerve, made ordinary adolescent gloom sensational. Her suicide threw her poetry into relief, gave it glamour. Death seemed to be her co-author. She was a guide to the depths: despair, madness, the wish to die. I read Plath, too, avidly. But I have never felt drawn back to her. I felt I had outgrown her - that one needed to outgrow her, for one's own sanity.

Literature is full of madness: Virgina Woolf, John Clare, Selima Hill. But Sylvia Plath stands out in modern mythology as Ophelia - with Hughes, her husband poet, her Hamlet.

For sheer pain no one outclasses Plath. It is, above all, an astonishing performance, intensely theatrical. Plath is a star turn, scooping herself out of darkness. I find the theatricality dazzling - but disabling too.

The poems Plath is most famous for are her last ones (1962-3) written before her death and published as Ariel in 1965. 'Daddy' and 'Lady Lazarus' are quoted so often, you could be forgiven for thinking she had written nothing else. 'Daddy', a poem I've always loathed, is none the less a technical tour de force. 'Daddy' has stepped straight out of a malign cabaret. The poem is seen as a rant against father and husband: 'If I've killed one man, I've killed two/Daddy, daddy, you bastard, I'm through.'

'Lady Lazarus' is a far better poem, though also histrionic. What a line for a seductress: 'And I eat men like air.' (Is there any teenage girl who would not enjoy quoting such a line to herself as she set out to a party?) But it is the other boast from the same poem - 'Dying/Is an art, like everything else. I do it exceptionally well' that has become Plath's epitaph.

She had a need to be a femme fatale, even if she always knew she was most likely to prove fatal to herself.

Her husband Ted Hughes described her as an 'unusual' poet. He said she could be 'intensely artificial' but added that even in her weaker poems she had a 'unique excitement'. There was, he said, a 'sense of a deep mathematical inevitability in the sound and texture of her lines'. It is more than inevitability, it is fatalism.

The landscape of Plath's poems is depressed: it is black and white, 'mica silver' or steel, only occasionally interrupted by an assault of scarlet. Emotions, too, are black and white, as if in X-ray: the bones are always on show. Plath did not gild the lily, she blackened it.

When other colours appear in her work they are almost hallucinogenic: a green field too radiant to be true; brilliant blue cornflowers; visionary blackberries; blood red poppies that remind her of a woman in an ambulance.

Hers is the poetry of damage and of emergency. Over and again bandages appear: 'The wind stops my breath like a bandage,' and 'mother to myself I wake swaddled in gauze...' There is always a sense of a face beneath the skin, endlessly reconstructed, an in-patient. Even the moon is in casualty: 'The moon's crook whitens, thin as the skin seaming a scar.' The moon chaperones Plath indifferently right up to her final poem: 'The moon has nothing to be sad about/Staring from her hood of bone/... She is used to this sort of thing/Her blacks crackle and drag.'

And Plath knew she was writing into a void. Her poems were about containment, but they failed her. It is painful to read Ted Hughes, in the introduction to the Collected Poems, describing how Plath told him the first poem in Ariel began with 'love' and the last poem ended with 'Spring'. It is as if there were other, more affirmative poems she wished she could write, just as she wished to be free of herself.

Sometimes she writes like a mother, sometimes like an electrified child. But the mother rarely makes it to the end of a poem. 'Child' starts entrancingly: 'Your clear eye is the one absolutely beautiful thing./I want to fill it with colour and ducks,/The zoo of the new...' but the wish doesn't work. The final verse consumes the rest with a 'wringing of hands' and a dark, starless ceiling. It does make her a lesser poet that she occupies one terrifying dimension. Re-reading her now I am distracted by pity.

But as the train of literature about Plath and Hughes thunders on, as often as not Plath's poetry is left behind. No one stops to ask how good it was. Is it Plath's doomed life we care about most? Was death her best poem? Are her poems anything more than anguished poetic diaries? And can they be separated from her life? When I was at school, girls who would not read anything else were often to be discovered, 'mixed-up kids in long trailing skirts,' with slim volumes of Plath under their arms. She touched a nerve, made ordinary adolescent gloom sensational. Her suicide threw her poetry into relief, gave it glamour. Death seemed to be her co-author. She was a guide to the depths: despair, madness, the wish to die. I read Plath, too, avidly. But I have never felt drawn back to her. I felt I had outgrown her - that one needed to outgrow her, for one's own sanity. Literature is full of madness: Virgina Woolf, John Clare, Selima Hill. But Sylvia Plath stands out in modern mythology as Ophelia - with Hughes, her husband poet, her Hamlet. For sheer pain no one outclasses Plath. It is, above all, an astonishing performance, intensely theatrical. Plath is a star turn, scooping herself out of darkness. I find the theatricality dazzling - but disabling too. The poems Plath is most famous for are her last ones (1962-3) written before her death and published as Ariel in 1965. 'Daddy' and 'Lady Lazarus' are quoted so often, you could be forgiven for thinking she had written nothing else. 'Daddy', a poem I've always loathed, is none the less a technical tour de force. 'Daddy' has stepped straight out of a malign cabaret. The poem is seen as a rant against father and husband: 'If I've killed one man, I've killed two/Daddy, daddy, you bastard, I'm through.' 'Lady Lazarus' is a far better poem, though also histrionic. What a line for a seductress: 'And I eat men like air.' (Is there any teenage girl who would not enjoy quoting such a line to herself as she set out to a party?) But it is the other boast from the same poem - 'Dying/Is an art, like everything else. I do it exceptionally well' that has become Plath's epitaph. She had a need to be a femme fatale, even if she always knew she was most likely to prove fatal to herself. Her husband Ted Hughes described her as an 'unusual' poet. He said she could be 'intensely artificial' but added that even in her weaker poems she had a 'unique excitement'. There was, he said, a 'sense of a deep mathematical inevitability in the sound and texture of her lines'. It is more than inevitability, it is fatalism. The landscape of Plath's poems is depressed: it is black and white, 'mica silver' or steel, only occasionally interrupted by an assault of scarlet. Emotions, too, are black and white, as if in X-ray: the bones are always on show. Plath did not gild the lily, she blackened it. When other colours appear in her work they are almost hallucinogenic: a green field too radiant to be true; brilliant blue cornflowers; visionary blackberries; blood red poppies that remind her of a woman in an ambulance. Hers is the poetry of damage and of emergency. Over and again bandages appear: 'The wind stops my breath like a bandage,' and 'mother to myself I wake swaddled in gauze...' There is always a sense of a face beneath the skin, endlessly reconstructed, an in-patient. Even the moon is in casualty: 'The moon's crook whitens, thin as the skin seaming a scar.' The moon chaperones Plath indifferently right up to her final poem: 'The moon has nothing to be sad about/Staring from her hood of bone/... She is used to this sort of thing/Her blacks crackle and drag.' And Plath knew she was writing into a void. Her poems were about containment, but they failed her. It is painful to read Ted Hughes, in the introduction to the Collected Poems, describing how Plath told him the first poem in Ariel began with 'love' and the last poem ended with 'Spring'. It is as if there were other, more affirmative poems she wished she could write, just as she wished to be free of herself. Sometimes she writes like a mother, sometimes like an electrified child. But the mother rarely makes it to the end of a poem. 'Child' starts entrancingly: 'Your clear eye is the one absolutely beautiful thing./I want to fill it with colour and ducks,/The zoo of the new...' but the wish doesn't work. The final verse consumes the rest with a 'wringing of hands' and a dark, starless ceiling. It does make her a lesser poet that she occupies one terrifying dimension. Re-reading her now I am distracted by pity.

webTitle: 'I failed her. I was 30 and stupid'

fields.headline: 'I failed her. I was 30 and stupid'
fields.standfirst: A. L. Alvarez who championed Plath's last poems in The Observer speaks out about his failure to help her, writes Vanessa Thorpe
fields.trailText: A. L. Alvarez who championed Plath's last poems in The Observer speaks out about his failure to help her, writes Vanessa Thorpe
fields.body:
Still the Plath/Hughes industry rolls on, fed by an apparently insatiable interest in the lives of the two most famous post-war poets who worked in Britain. This week we have the insights of Plath's journals. Last year came the shock of Emma Tennant's controversial Burnt Diaries, describing her affair with Ted Hughes in 1977.

This morning on Radio 4 the poet Al Alvarez, former poetry editor of this newspaper and a great champion of both late poets, will speak openly about his failure to recognise Plath's misery and his decision not to have a relationship with her.

Although Alvarez did not know it at the time, Plath was in the last days of her life when she came to him and asked for help. As a guest on Desert Island Discs, Alvarez admits his inability to offer emotional support to Plath and says he was blinded by her poetry itself.

'I failed her on that level. I was 30 years old and stupid. What did I know about chronic clinical depression?' he tells Sue Lawley. 'I had been clinically depressed, but I didn't know what it was when I was in it.

'And the more subtle reason is that her poems were so good and there was such liveliness. I mean, there was more life and liveliness and appetite in Plath writing about death than there is in the collected works of Philip Larkin writing about what a bitch it is to be alive.'

'I had literally just started getting involved with my second wife and I could see that the kind of help Sylvia needed was not just someone to listen to her poems, although that was important, but she kind of needed someone to take care of her. And that was not something I could do. She was at any rate still married to a friend of mine.'

The friend was Ted Hughes, and Alvarez provided shelter for the future Poet Laureate when he left his two children and wife, Sylvia.

'I don't think it would have made a blind bit of difference if she and I had got together because I think she and Ted were absolutely eternally linked.'

Yet it was Alvarez who was fatefully with Plath for Christmas Eve 1962. She read him her poem Death & Co, with its plaintive lines 'The dead bell, the dead bell, somebody's done for.'

'At that point I realised where she was. She wanted me to stay, she wanted help. I ducked out. It is not a passage I am particularly proud of, but my life was complicated,' says Alvarez. A few weeks later, on 11 February 1963, Plath committed suicide.

Fascination with the pain at the core of these two writers' experience became, initially, a point of literary debate, with the publication in 1974 of The Savage God, Alvarez's investigation into the lure of suicide. It then became an issue of gender politics, as Plath was transformed into a feminist icon.

After the suicide of his second wife, Assia Wevill, theories about his domestic cruelty abounded. His name was struck from Plath's gravestone, and writers lined up for the defence or the prosecution. Hughes' decision to publish Birthday Letters in January 1998 was a literary landmark. From that moment on, the field has been open for conjecture about the relationship between Hughes and Plath.

Following Hughes's death the poet has become an institution. The Journals of Sylvia Plath 1950 - 1962 and Erica Wagner's Ariel's Gift: Ted Hughes, Sylvia Plath and the Story of Birthday Letters are published by Faber & Faber on 3 April.

fields.headline: 230 die in cult doomsday fire
fields.trailText: Up to 230 members of a Ugandan doomsday cult set themselves ablaze, police said yesterday, taking their lives in the world's second biggest ritual mass suicide. Followers of the Ten Commandments of God sect gathered in a church 200 miles southwest of the capital, Kampala, on Friday, and set themselves on fire after hours of chanting and singing.
fields.body:
Up to 230 members of a Ugandan doomsday cult set themselves ablaze, police said yesterday, taking their lives in the world's second biggest ritual mass suicide. Followers of the Ten Commandments of God sect gathered in a church 200 miles southwest of the capital, Kampala, on Friday, and set themselves on fire after hours of chanting and singing.

'Prior to this incident their leader told believers to sell off their possessions and prepare to go to Heaven,' the police said. The death toll was put between 100 and 230, many bodies being burnt beyond recognition.

Only a 1978 mass suicide had more victims. A US pastor, the Rev Jim Jones, led 914 followers to their deaths at Jonestown, Guyana, by drinking a cyanide-laced fruit drink. Cult members who refused to swallow the liquid were shot. Jones had a sign over his altar reading: 'Those who forget the past are doomed to repeat it.'

There have been smaller group suicides in Europe and North America, three involving the Solar Temple, a sect that believes death by ritual suicide leads to rebirth. Last year Ugandan police disbanded the 1,000-member World Message Last Warning sect, whose leaders were charged with rape, kidnapping and illegal confinement.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Women behaving badly, plus The Autcioneer, Voltaire's Coconuts, Serendipities, Mondo Desperado and The Heart-Shaped Bullet
fields.body:
Foreign Brides
Elena Lappin
Picador £6.99, pp208
Buy it at BOL

Transplanted from their homelands by marriage, Elena Lappin's protagonists in these 12 likeable stories take a wife-behaving-badly approach to exile. Prototypical is Noa, who falls for mild-mannered Noah when he visits Tel Aviv because, unlike her taciturn Israeli boyfriend, he talks incessantly in bed: 'She didn't understand half of what he was saying but it all sounded sweet, sexy and somehow mysterious.'

Relocated to East Finchley, and with a growing command of English, it transpires that Noah's saucy garrulousness is largely inspired by the fortunes of Tottenham Hotspur. So Noah concocts her devious revenge. A few illicit visits to a non-kosher butcher later, and the family's foodstuffs and footballing allegiances have been contaminated by a cunning double-blow: trayf chicken and the Arsenal.

The Auctioneer
Charles FernyhoughFourth Estate £6.99, pp344
Buy it at BOL

Finn Causley is an unorthodox auctioneer. He collects and catalogues objects that have been abandoned as their owners succumb to a mysterious mental illness called Bliss. Possibly caused by the widespread abuse of an ecstasy-like drug, Bliss robs its victims - who include Finn's wife - of the capacity to derive meaning from the world that surrounds them. The auctioneer's job, like the writer's, is concerned with the restoration of sense: objects significant to the narrative appear in the footnotes as numbered lots, part of the novel's play with the relationship between things and their meanings. At once social comedy, local history and love story, this is a crowded but ambitious and intriguing book.

Voltaire's Coconuts
Ian Buruma
Phoenix £7.99, pp326
Buy it at BOL

The title is the only dud thing about this brilliant book, although the idea it refers to - Voltaire's conviction that political ideas could be planted, like coconuts, in soils foreign to those in which they originate - reverberates throughout Buruma's exploration of European beliefs about Britain. His Anglophiles (and phobes) are marvellously drawn, from Voltaire, whose first impression of England was its 'fine sunny weather', to the Kaiser who, despite his efforts to be a 'super-Prussian', required a steady supply of tea and scones. Buruma's witty and insightful study is all the finer for its use of memoir - he includes his tweedy German grandparents for whom 'the idea of England as a place of refuge was not just propaganda'.

Serendipities: Language and Lunacy
Umberto Eco
Phoenix £6.99, pp164
Buy it at BOL

Five short essays in which Eco proposes that 'even errors can produce interesting side effects'. Thus Marco Polo, on meeting a rhino, thinks he has found a unicorn, and ruefully confesses that the mythical creature is not nearly as glamorous as he had been led to expect. Eco's prose is rightly described as 'learned', and as I struggled with some of the more abstruse passages, I tried to find comfort in the author's original thesis.

Mondo Desperado
Patrick McCabe
Picador £6.99, pp229
Buy it at BOL

Preconceptions confounded: Mondo Desperado is actually by one 'Phildy Hackball', a shameless hack whose major interests, according to his fraudulent biographical note, are 'having a few jars' and 'relaxing with friends', and who is currently working on a novel 'with plenty of shooting - and a shark!' So it's Hackball who is responsible for such lines as 'This Bruce Lee fellow! To kung fu what Elvis was to rock and roll or a chopsocky fraud in a warm-up suit?' Liberated from the tasteful constraints of quality fiction, McCabe/ Hackball's short-story collection is a cheerful riot of tacky prose and gratuitously surreal situations, like a fast-forward viewing of Father Ted.

 Sophie Harrison

The Heart-Shaped Bullet
Kathryn Flett
Picador £5.99, pp296
Buy it at BOL

Kathryn Flett's memoir, based on her Observer columns, is a shockingly honest - and often very funny - account of her 17-month marriage, and her attempt to rebuild her life after her husband's desertion. She recounts the familiar experience of falling in love - the doubts, the wild excitements, the surprises and disappointments - with wit and candour, largely succeeding in the difficult task of rendering a very personal experience compelling as a story.

It is not a book for those who feel squeamish about touchy-feely soul-baring, but anyone who has had their heart broken will find Flett a sympathetic and entertaining companion.

 Jane Perry

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: Michael Kitchen brings a gentle melancholy to Graham Greene's story of faith and chance, plus The Drowning People
fields.body:
The End of the Affair
Graham Greene
Read by Michael Kitchen Unabridged
Running time 6hrs 30mins
Chivers Audio Books £14.95

The Drowning People
Richard Mason
Read by Tim Pigott-Smith Unabridged
Running time 11hrs 35 mins
Chivers Audio Books £16.95

Read by Tony Britton Abridged; Running time 3hrs

Penguin Audiobooks £8.99
Buy it at BOL

There weren't just three people in Sarah's wartime marriage to Henry in The End of the Affair; as well as her lover, Maurice, there was a fourth player more dangerous than the falling bombs - God. Although Sarah ends the affair with Maurice, she continues to love him, and in her anguished journals - which he later reads - she wrestles with her Lord. In this unabridged version, Michael Kitchen is exactly the right reader. Through a voice tinged with gentle melancholy, he draws the listener into the minutiae of the pain suffered by them all.

Seventy-year-old James Farrell's statement that he has just killed his wife, which opens The Drowning People, immediately arrests the listener. To explain how he came to see 'a sort of justice done' in this way, he takes us back 50 years to Ella, the troubled woman he loved. The story involves jealousy and betrayal, the plot always intrigues, but the characters are neither likeable nor wholly convincing. However, Tony Britton's voice, older and gentler than Tim Pigott-Smith's, helps to make James more credible and sympathetic, and the abridgement does a service to the novel, highlighting its dramatic strengths and masking its shortcomings.
