fields.headline: Lowry's secret life
fields.standfirst: The artist formerly known as the painter of matchstick men and factory life had a hidden portfolio of erotic and sadistic images of women
fields.trailText: The artist formerly known as the painter of matchstick men and factory life had a hidden portfolio of erotic and sadistic images of women
fields.body:
The new £100 million Lowry arts centre on Salford Quays could seem an odd memorial to the local artist of redbrick factories and smoking chimneys. It is an irregular, stainless-steel oval rising at the side of the canal, and starkly reflects the flat light of the Manchester plain. As well as the paintings of Salford's most famous son, it will house two theatres, an interactive gallery and a series of restaurants and bars.

When I visited last week, armies of matchstick builders in fluorescent jackets and hard hats were working on an interior that will be painted a livid purple. Lowry you might guess - or at least the caricature flat-cap Lowry - would have preferred something, well, sturdier, more prosaic.

In some ways, though, the new building is an entirely appropriate home for the rehousing of the city's extensive collection of the artist's work. Its opening at the end of next month will coincide with a radical reappraisal of Lowry's art and life sparked by an illuminating and controversial new book.

The book - and the gallery - will do much to dispel the stubborn image of Lowry as a simple painter and reveal an artist alive to the existential temper of his times, the creator of private visions that concealed a repressed sexual violence and which were rooted in a profound sense of alienation.

Art historian Michael Howard's meticulously researched Lowry: a Visionary Artist, published by the new Lowry Press, shows how the painter's apparent naivety was not only hard won, but a deliberate mask to a disturbed and complex character. Howard was granted unique access to Lowry's estate, which was bequeathed to Carol Ann Lowry, the painter's 'adoptive goddaughter', one of the several young girls Lowry befriended, and who helped to fuel his artistic fantasies.

The archive contains Lowry's extensive library and some of the hoarded artefacts that filled his Victorian house on the edge of the Moors. It also includes a series of his obsessively reworked erotic paintings which begin to suggest a different artist to the northern heritage industry's favourite icon.

Talking of his book, Howard suggests that the principal challenge was to strip away the perception of Lowry as a marginal, colloquial figure and to re-examine the work. In his lifetime, Lowry was happy to play the uncultured amateur for the London papers as a form of self-protection. As a result, however, he was, early on, characterised as a Sunday painter, and the image has stuck - 'I'm a Sunday painter every day of the week,' he would later say, angrily.

Howard's belief was that far from being a unschooled naif, Lowry was closely attuned to contemporary painting and philosophy in Britain and Europe. His forensic study of the archive supported that hunch. Strongly influenced by Van Gogh early in his career Lowry later admired artists such as Magritte and Balthus and saw his own work in a similar private, visionary context.

He drew bleak inspiration from Pirandello's Six Characters in Search of an Author, which he returned to again and again, and was equally entranced by the Coppélia myth, apparently seeing in the ballet of a man who enjoyed the control of a young woman automaton a metaphor for his own methods. The 'old Lancashire saws' he was fond of quoting were often borrowed from Lowry's reading in European philosophy.

Far from being a simple social realist, sketching outside the mill gates, Lowry would paint into the early hours most nights, accompanied by the wilder arias of Donizetti or Bellini. 'I wanted to paint myself into what absorbed me,' Lowry was fond of saying. And what absorbed him, Howard shows, 'was an attempt to control that thing which he so feared: the mass of other people, particularly women; life itself'.

A large and clumsy boy, Lowry always saw himself as a misfit. 'I didn't like being a child,' he would say, and as an adult he seemed in restless search for his missing boyhood. He would paint a version of himself in crowds, always standing alone, or behind a fence, watching children play.

He worried continually about his mental state. In 1951, he confessed to a psychiatrist friend how he would stare for hours at 'empty houses with empty windows standing in isolation on derelict streets...' seeing in those desolate buildings an image of himself, 'yearning to recapture forgotten days of childhood happiness'. The friend characterised him as 'a severely depressed man... who, not knowing how he would get through the day, would find himself somehow, with a brush in his hand, before his easel and with no recollection of having painted what he now saw before him.'

Sometimes what he saw before him was very disturbing indeed. Shelley Rohde, whose excellent, updated biography of Lowry takes account of Howard's findings, examines the root of Lowry's depression in his relationship with his mother, a claustrophobic bond that seemed to prevent him developing intimacy with other women.

After his father died in 1932, Lowry nursed his 'bedfast' mother until her death seven years later. It was during this time that Lowry began painting what he called his 'horrible heads'. He claimed he had no idea where these images came from. They are anguished figures, bloodshot self-portraits, which bear a close relationship to the work of Edvard Munch.

Of one portrait of a wild staring man with crimson eyes, Lowry said that during his mother's illness he would look in his shaving mirror every morning and this was the image he saw staring back at him.

More disturbing still were the many paintings and drawings Lowry subsequently made of a recurring sexual fantasy, nearly all of which came to light after his death. The work returns to an image of a dark-haired woman with blackened eyes in fetishistic costume. These women have huge, sadistic collars cutting into their throats, breasts pushed up and out of torturous bodices.

In some of the images, the apparently lifeless figures are being manipulated by the hand of an unseen man, like the mannequin of Dr Coppelius. What struck Howard most, when he saw these pictures, he says, was how finished these were, some signed and dated, as if Lowry wanted to incorporate them in the main body of his work.

fields.headline: Oxford's global dictionary
fields.trailText: The second Gutenberg revolution gets underway with the online launch of the Oxford English Dictionary.
fields.body:
If you ever doubted that we are living through a second Gutenberg revolution consider two recent news items. First, the announcement that Stephen King is 'publishing' his latest horror story, Riding the Bullet, directly onto the Internet. And second, this week's launch of the Oxford English Dictionary's online edition. I have yet to peruse the former, but I have had the privilege of browsing the latter and I can report that, for anyone who loves to fossick through the pages of a great dictionary, the OED Online is a remarkable experience.

At the click of a mouse, you can summon up the etymology of any word that might interest you, from autochthonous to zeugma. You can ask for Shakespeare's usage of a word, or Wordsworth's. You can determine who coined what and when, and if you are used to computers you can do all this, and much more, at warp speed. In the history of the English language, then, 14 March 2000 deserves to be compared to 15 April 1755, the publication day of Dr Johnson's Dictionary. Henceforth, subscribers to this unique on-line dictionary will be able to retrieve the 60 million words the OED employs to describe the 750,000 terms used in English during the past thousand years just by logging on.

In its hardback format, the OED offered a truly astounding picture of the English language. In its new guise, it becomes the living archive of an extraordinary phenomenon: a language that is more widely spoken and more widely written than any other ever has been, everyone's second and the world's first global language.

The OED Online is of unique importance because it bridges a gap that had been threatening to render lexicography as meaningless as trainspotting - the gulf between the increasingly fluid expression of the language, its transience and modishness, and the outdated technology of its codification, its print, paper and hardcover binding.

The English language has always been characterised by its inventiveness and hospitality to innovation. Henceforth, the OED Online will be able to respond to linguistic novelty at the click of a button. No wonder, then, that the OED's promotional material should seem a trifle punch-drunk with examples of its range of sources, from Blackadder and the X-Files, to Seinfeld and EastEnders, and of the range of its creative literary reference, from Quentin Tarantino and Vikram Seth to Camille Paglia and Lou Reed.

Amid the facts thrown up by what will eventually become a colossal revision of the 1928 edition, some things haven't changed. William Shakespeare remains the most quoted author, and the King James Bible the most quoted work.

The OED's top 10 authors runs as follows: Shakespeare, Dryden, Milton, Walter Scott, Macaulay, Thackeray, Kipling, Jonson, Dickens and Pope. Over time, this will doubtless change. John Simpson, the editor of the OED Online, believes 'the revision could double the length of the text of the Dictionary, taking the number of words and phrases from 640,000 to 1.3 million, as the Dictionary tracks the development of World English as well as uncovering thousands of hitherto unrecorded terms from the history of English'.

The democratising genius of the Internet will make its presence felt in the evolution of the online OED. Where previously, the OED was the province of 'harmless drudges', Oxford graduates for the most part, the OED Online is welcoming contributions from 'word enthusiasts all over the world'.

This makes the point that the English language is no longer just British or American. The OED's head office will receive new words and meanings from branches in Toronto, Canada; in Canberra, Australia; in Wellington, New Zealand; and in Grahamstown, South Africa. The 'new Englishes' of the Caribbean, India, East Asia and South America will contribute words such as mafoo (a Chinese groom) and magsman (an Australian storyteller). For years, commentators have been saying that the English used in some form by about one-third of the earth's population should be known as World English. With the publication of the OED Online, that moment has arrived.

fields.headline: Grope springs eternal
fields.standfirst: Paul Golding explores gay sex with an almost religious fervour in The Abomination
fields.trailText: Paul Golding explores gay sex with an almost religious fervour in The Abomination
fields.body:
The Abomination
Paul Golding
Picador £16, pp500
Buy it at BOL

To fall in love with oneself, as Oscar Wilde insinuated, is the beginning of a life-long affair. Paul Golding's first novel blissfully consummates just such a relationship. It is a work about preening, poncing narcissism, and its style is suitably self-indulgent.

Paul Golding writes like an angel who has just recently fallen from grace, and he gorges on forbidden fruit for 500 ripe, aromatic pages. In fact, The Abomination is not so much written as wrought - or rather overwrought, like the fretted, curlicued iron of a Spanish balcony.

Its action is quickly summarised, since it mostly has to do with varieties of the eponymous abomination - sex between boys, between boys and men and between men. The hero grows up in Spain, cosseted by nannies and by a mummy whose dresses he covets. His hated daddy sends him away to a Catholic boarding school in the north of England, where he precociously beds two masters and attends a graduation dance attired in splendiferous drag. Settling in London, he does the rounds of rancid S&M cellars, and hires a hustler to preen for him at £70 a session.

The sex may be gay, but it's pretty joyless. One trick impolitely forgets to air his bollocks and the groin of another exudes a cheesy grot. Hunched above a lavatory bowl, a third overnight guest makes a double-jointed attempt to vomit and ejaculate in unison. Someone else who should never have been invited back for a coffee comes all over the kitchen floor.

The Abomination ends with the narrator tonguing the sphincter of a pick-up who identifies himself in the personal ads as 'Big Uncut Man, which nicely abbreviates as 'Bum'. The recipient, however, abruptly clenches that moist muscle and stomps out, leaving our hero once more ungratified. 'My music has come to an end,' he remarks as he struggles to his feet and reaches for the mouthwash; Golding's scatological rhapsody is over.

The style manages wonders of dandified transformation. Like the alchemists who claimed they could turn base metal into gold, Golding sets out to fantasticate faeces, to metamorphose bodily emissions into a pearlier and more precious milky way. The grungier the sex act, the more wittily elegant is the periphrasis with which he describes it. At school, the narrator does indiscriminate oral favours for his classmates: 'I brought their hectic zips,' he reports, 'to glutinous fruition.'

Nature succumbs to the fashionable edicts of culture. One character has himself circumcised in late adolescence for cosmetic reasons, and others conscientiously wax their buttocks. The hero's penis sports as much jewellery as the wrists or neck of a rich woman. He is also particular about the latex bonnets worn by his wooers: condoms must be devoid of nipples which, thanks to their incongruous femininity, turn a hard-on into an eyesore.

Because the sensibility with which we are closeted here is half-Spanish and therefore floridly baroque, The Abomination tries hard to be blasphemous. Sex is the celebration of a black mass. A pick-up 'blesses' the prissy narrator's sheet with a seminal dribble. As an apprentice fellator, Golding's hero wonders whether protocol permits him to lick the spillage from his fillings, 'which, even with the communion host, is just about allowed'.

Tussling with Bum, he slavishly offers his wrists to be gripped, 'ritually positioned as a cross'. He views the dilated anus of a man being fisted as 'a cathedral of mysteries'. Given all this decadent fervour, do we really need to be told that the back room of a sex club is 'the flower of its evil', especially since, like the most insistently naughty of altar boys, Golding goes on to call that lair a 'sanctum' and a 'tabernacle'?

Despite this determination to shock, The Abomination is about exhibitionism, not outrage. Golding and his hero are far too liberated to feel the force of the religious taboos which those metaphors defy. The novel is most enjoyable when acknowledging that its real erotomania is linguistic.

Bodily fetishes remind Golding of exotic diacritical marks: the faces of the cloned, studded, cowboy-chapped gods in the sex club are accessorised by 'the circumflex of a moustache'. On another occasion, he languidly comments: 'My loins are an open book.' Let that be a warning: if you read The Abomination, you will have browsed for hours in the author's nether regions.

To give him his due, Golding has done his best to make his customers welcome là-bas. The novel ends with its hero's day-long titivation as he gets ready for an appointment with Bum. I don't think there has been a more elaborate exemplification of human self-worship since Alexander Pope, another Catholic aesthete, described the 'rites of pride' at Belinda's toilet-table in The Rape of the Lock: Golding's vainglorious protagonist weeds his pubes with tweezers as if they were topiary, shaves his testicles and the underside of his shaft with a razor and finally 'anoints' - his word, cheekily priestly - the circumference of his anus with depilatory cream.

But despite his eager primping, the encounter concludes with another anti-climax. The Abomination, I fear, is an epic of onanism.

He is also particular about the latex bonnets worn by his wooers: condoms must be devoid of nipples which, thanks to their incongruous femininity, turn a hard-on into an eyesore. Because the sensibility with which we are closeted here is half-Spanish and therefore floridly baroque, The Abomination tries hard to be blasphemous. Sex is the celebration of a black mass. A pick-up 'blesses' the prissy narrator's sheet with a seminal dribble. As an apprentice fellator, Golding's hero wonders whether protocol permits him to lick the spillage from his fillings, 'which, even with the communion host, is just about allowed'. Tussling with Bum, he slavishly offers his wrists to be gripped, 'ritually positioned as a cross'. He views the dilated anus of a man being fisted as 'a cathedral of mysteries'. Given all this decadent fervour, do we really need to be told that the back room of a sex club is 'the flower of its evil', especially since, like the most insistently naughty of altar boys, Golding goes on to call that lair a 'sanctum' and a 'tabernacle'? Bodily fetishes remind Golding of exotic diacritical marks: the faces of the cloned, studded, cowboy-chapped gods in the sex club are accessorised by 'the circumflex of a moustache'. But despite his eager primping, the encounter concludes with another anti-climax. The Abomination, I fear, is an epic of onanism.

webTitle: Forget Lolita - let's hear it for lepidoptery...

fields.headline: Forget Lolita - let's hear it for lepidoptery...
fields.standfirst: Science doesn't quite meet literature in a collection of technical papers and butterfly inspired writing in Nabokov's Butterflies
fields.trailText: Science doesn't quite meet literature in a collection of technical papers and butterfly inspired writing in Nabokov's Butterflies
fields.body:
Nabokov's Butterflies
Annotated and edited by Brian Boyd and Robert Michael Pyle
Allen Lane £25, pp783
Buy it at BOL

Books Unlimited author page

Vladimir Nabokov was an expert on butterflies. He not only collected them obsessively but invented techniques to make their classification more precise. This volume brings together technical papers and butterfly-themed passages from his work. The closest comparable case of a major author having world eminence in another expertise would be A.E. Housman, who emended corrupt classical texts with the same analytical exquisiteness that Nabokov used to revise the classification of butterflies, according to the details of their dissected genitals.

Classical philology is hardly a more popular or accessible pursuit than lepidoptery, but the volume (edited by Christopher Ricks), which includes passages from Housman's technical writings as well as the poems, is an outstanding success.

The advantages of that book over this one were that it was wieldy, that it never left the domain of culture and that it showed a side of the writer absent from his verse. The slyly fatalistic persona of the poet made a fascinating contrast with the professor of Latin, who was a doughty if not brutal scrapper, and never split a hair in argument if there was a chance of splitting the person to whom it was attached.

When Nabokov wrote in 1947 that his scientific papers 'have no interest whatever for the layman', he was expressing pride as much as melancholy. Any reader would enjoy the passage reprinted here from his novel, The Gift, about the living arrangements of those large blues which have 'concluded a barbaric pact' with ants: 'I saw how an ant, greedily tickling a hind segment of that caterpillar's sluglike little body, forced it to excrete a drop of intoxicant juice, which it swallowed immediately. In compensation, it offered its own larvae as food; it was as if cows gave us Chartreuse and we gave them our infants to eat.'

His prose, though, is impenetrable even when there are touches of the same precise fancy dimly detectable: 'The most conspicuous thing about the upper portion is the presence of a pair of formidable semi-transparent hooks [the subunci or falces of a peculiar shape not found in allied genera], produced from the opposite side of the distally twinned uncus and facing each other in the manner of the stolidly raised fists of two pugilists [of the old school] with the uncus hoods adding a Ku Klux Klan touch to the picture.'

Nabokov's Butterflies is edited and annotated by Brian Boyd, a professor of English (and biographer of Nabokov) and Robert Michael Pyle, a lepidopterist, each of whom provides a substantial introduction. The editors find a harmony in Nabokov between artist and scientist - and it would be nice if there were traces of that virtue in their collaboration. There is overlap and contradiction in their opening remarks.

The literature man might usefully have advised the butterfly man to pitch his essay consistently. On one page, we are advanced students, not needing to be reminded of the meaning of 'phenology'. On another, we are back in primary school, struggling to understand the advantages of a system of classification, and asked to imagine 'running a big city without telephones'.

In return, Pyle could have suggested that Boyd not gloss over the crucial hostility towards evolutionary theory in Nabokov's scientific work.

Mimicry, about which Nabokov wanted to write an ambitious book, seemed to him impossible to explain in evolutionary terms. Boyd remarks only on the likelihood that 'had he begun serious work on mimicry, he would have found sufficient evidence of purely physical explanations to be forced to abandon his dearly-held metaphysical speculations'.

Pyle isn't so sure, or rather - bizarrely - he asserts (citing no source) that Brian Boyd 'is not so sure, suspecting Nabokov might well have counter-argued in ways no one would have guessed'. A writer who famously 'confessed' (Speak, Memory) that he did not believe in time was always going to resist an explanation of life that requires nothing else. What is striking in Nabokov's Butterflies is the consistency of his opposition to scientific orthodoxy.

He asserts that mimicry, by the gratuitous splendour of its imitations, disproves evolution, in fiction, memoir and scientific paper. In an essay on Lysandracormion, he uses such heretical phrases as 'the secret decrees of nature', while also giving that agency a whiff of Detroit by talking not of genetic variations but of 'bringing out' particular 'makes' of butterfly.

Nabokov seems to interpret mimicry as an artificial flaw in an aesthetic design, a clue left for those able to see it. The amount of emotion he invested in the metaphysics of lepidoptery - his special sense that mimicry proved an exemption from determinism - would be hard to underestimate. Temperamentally, he hated system as much as he loved pattern, and it would be shattering for him to find the enemy in the stronghold of his beloved system underlying pattern.

Nabokov ruled out of court any psychological reading of his life or work (and his critics largely oblige), but is it so surprising that the ambitious book on mimicry which would settle the matter never got written?

He visualised a 'high ridge', where the mountainside of scientific knowledge could join the opposite slope of artistic imagination, but the winds up there are high also, and no hiker, not even the most experienced, can guarantee to keep his footing.

fields.headline: Fanatic alphabet
fields.standfirst: Ahmed Rashid tells you all you ever wanted to know about the Taliban in 285 pages
fields.trailText: Ahmed Rashid tells you all you ever wanted to know about the Taliban in 285 pages
fields.body:
Taliban
Ahmed Rashid
IB Tauris £12.99, pp285

Buy it at BOL

James Bond films, as any media studies student knows, are good indicators of what are popularly held to be the major threats to world peace at any one historical moment. In the most recent Bond, the villain is a psychotic businesswoman set on securing the rights to pipe oil from the huge, untapped reserves under the steppes, mountains and deserts of central Asia.

Ahmed Rashid's book describes the sort of stuff that Bonds are made of. Warring tribes, clashing empires, fanatics with dreams of world domination, violence and sex, although in Afghanistan the latter hardly takes the form most favoured by 007.

Rashid is a Pakistani journalist with long experience of the Afghan war and the politics of the region. He knows as much about his subject as any other writer and one could not wish for a better guide to the fabulous complexities of what is one of the most tragic national stories of the past century.

He has written a genuine 'all you ever wanted to know about the Taliban', compressed into 285 pages. There is even a handy, six-page table listing the main leaders of the movements, their positions, ages, tribes, ethnic descent and recent career, perfect for nerdy Afghan propeller-heads. There is a chronology (from 1994 to October last year) that breaks down the hardline militia army history into almost hourly segments. The detail is impressive.

And detail is what Afghanistan is all about. The more you learn about the country, as a journalist, an aid worker, a diplomat or an interested armchair traveller, the more complex things become. Just when you think you are beginning to understand the broad patterns of allegiance, something turns up to remind you that you know nothing.

In the summer of 1998, I went up to the most forward frontline positions of the Taliban, a movement dominated by Sunni Muslims from the Pashtoon ethnic tribes in the south of Afghanistan - and found that the troops in the trenches were, in fact, Persian-speaking Shia Muslims from the Tajik tribes of the country's central highlands. Such people were meant to be the Taliban's sworn enemies yet here they were in battered bunkers merrily sending off salvoes of shells at their co-religionists and neighbours.

If anyone understands the place, Rashid does. He shows how the Taliban are different from anything that has come before in the region and how their values have been shaped by 20 years of violence and alienation. The 10-year struggle against the Soviets not only destroyed the landscape of their country but its values and cultures, too. Men who had spent their lives in refugee camps and then watched their country dissolve into anarchy were attracted by the clear, cool certainties of the Koran.

Crucial to the success of the Taliban was help given by Saudi Arabia, the US and, particularly, Pakistan. The Pakistanis, who hope to use the Taliban as a tool of their own policy in the region, still provide significant military and diplomatic support.

The history of US involvement is not happy. In the Seventies, the Americans poured development funds into Afghanistan to counter growing Russian influence; throughout the Eighties, they funded the Afghan resistance (particularly its hardline Islamist factions); in the Nineties, Washington's policy aim, Rashid says, was to isolate Russia and Iran by ensuring a stable environment to allow an oil pipeline to be built from central Asia to Pakistan through Afghanistan. Currently, they only care about Osama bin Laden, the Saudi-born terrorist being sheltered by the Taliban.

The most interesting thing about the Taliban is that they focus a complex ethical debate. How far does our Western liberal relativism go? Are we right in imposing our 'universal' values? In contemporary Afghanistan, the Taliban, a byword for human rights abuses in the West, are largely welcomed by the bulk of the population. As a Kabul resident told me last November - and forgive the loose translation - 'They are arseholes but they are better than all the other arseholes.'

Where does this leave the average, concerned Westerner? Our government appears to have made up its mind. HMG does not talk to the Taliban, other than when we want to boot out a few airborne asylum-seekers. Currently, diplomats and British aid workers, even if they are with the UN, are banned from going into Afghanistan. If this policy is designed to force a change in the Taliban's style of government, then it is ill-judged and naive. A better idea might be to engage with, and thus strengthen, the moderates within the Taliban.

Rashid's book is far from an easy read. After a paragraph of token description at the start of each chapter, the facts start advancing across the pages like waves of massed Taliban infantry. On one page, I counted 31 dates or statistics in 40 lines. It is not easy to make Afghanistan, one of the most colourful places on Earth, heavy going but Rashid has managed it. He is also not helped by some infelicitous editing.

There are also some bizarre spellings of places. One of the most wonderful names in Afghanistani is that of the arid wastes in the south-west of the country. They are known as the Dasht-e-Margo - the Desert of Death. The Dasht-e-Mango has a rather different ring to it.

fields.headline: Living the blues
fields.standfirst: Alice Echols moves beyond the rock'n'roll cautionary tale in her biography of Janis Joplin, Scars of Sweet Paradise
fields.trailText: Alice Echols moves beyond the rock'n'roll cautionary tale in her biography of Janis Joplin, Scars of Sweet Paradise
fields.body:
Scars of Sweet Paradise
Alice Echols
Virago £18.99, pp408
Buy it at BOL

This biography begins with one of the most vivid accounts of growing up awkward that I have ever read. Janis Joplin was born into a perfectly normal family in Port Arthur, Texas, in l943, with nice, ordinary parents and two nice, ordinary younger siblings.

She always said her childhood was idyllic until she 'lost her looks' at l4. Up to then, she was a pretty child who sang in the church choir. Then she developed terrible acne, failed to be selected for the school cheerleader squad and went spectacularly to the bad.

She became Port Arthur's first female beatnik, frizzed her hair by drying it in the oven, omitted to wear a bra (unheard of in the Fifties) and worked on her unique cackle of a laugh - a friend recalls her asking: 'Was it irritating enough?' Moreover, she deliberately cultivated a reputation as the school slut, although according to a classmate, she didn't actually lose her virginity until she graduated.

When she arrived at the University of Texas in Austin in l962, the campus newspaper profiled her with the headline - 'She Dares to be Different!' She drank, she swore, she hung out with bikers, she went to redneck bars. And soon she started singing with a folk group, not that that was particularly 'different' in the early Sixties.

But what was entirely different was her voice. She could sing like Joan Baez if she wanted to and sometimes did, for parodic effect, but in Austin she cultivated her Bessie Smith growl, and the trick whereby she would seemingly sing two notes at once.

In January l963, abandoning her course at Austin, she hitchhiked to San Francisco to join the Beats, but unfortunately the Beats had largely dispersed and the hippies had not yet arrived. She sang in coffee houses and lived on handouts, and everyone who heard her said they knew she would be huge. But of course in those days there weren't any record company talent scouts looking for ugly women singers with Bessie Smith voices. The folk scene was largely underground and commercially unexploited.

In Austin she was known as a drinker; in San Francisco she became a druggie. Speed was still legal and widely available but when speed became temporarily unavailable, she took to heroin. She later told a reporter: 'I wanted to smoke dope, take dope, lick dope, suck dope, fuck dope, anything I could lay my hands on I wanted to do it.'

She felt in some way that she had to earn her right to sing the blues by suffering the blues. But by the summer of l965 she was a wreck, and fled home to Port Arthur, weighing only six stone. She spent a year at home, cleaning up and seriously trying to be good. Her old classmates suddenly saw her wearing frocks and make-up, with her hair neatly tied in a bun, playing canasta and painting a Nativity mural for her parents' porch. Her little sister, Laura, six years younger, was deputed to take her clothes shopping, but Laura had to dash out of the changing-room to buy Janis some underpants.

She went into therapy, re-enrolled in college and talked seriously of becoming a secretary. But then a friend came to fetch her back to San Francisco, to sing with a new band called Big Brother and the Holding Company. In the year she'd been away, San Francisco had suddenly become the hippie capital of the world. Big Brother were a fairly chaotic band when she joined but she soon sharpened them up - she was entirely organised when it came to music.

In June l967, at the start of the Summer of Love, they were booked to play at the Monterey Pop Festival. Their set was in the afternoon, not normally peak time, but everyone who heard Janis went berserk, and the band were quickly booked to play again the next day. Albert Grossman, Bob Dylan's manager, offered to manage them, and Columbia Records signed them for $250,000. When she became successful she said: 'I'm not a warthog that nobody wants to climb in bed with. Everybody wants to climb in bed with me now.'

On stage, this dumpy, acne-pocked woman who was always complaining she couldn't get laid, became simply the sexiest woman alive and men and women practically queued to sleep with her. She got through men like Kleenex and made sure the press knew about it, boasting to Rolling Stone about her one-night stand with Joe Namath, the American football star.

But just as she used her boozing to cover her drugs use (she often carried a bottle of Southern Comfort onstage) so she used her much-publicised heterosexual promiscuity to cover her lesbian affairs.

She died in the Landmark Hotel, Los Angeles, on 4 October l970, aged 27. She had spent the day recording and seemed quite happy, though the boyfriend and girlfriend who were meant to be joining her for a threesome failed to show up. She went to her room, presumably shot up, went back down to the hotel lobby to buy some cigarettes, chatted cheerfully to the night porter - and was later found dead in her room, still clutching the cigarettes and change. The autopsy revealed that the heroin she had bought that night was exceptionally pure; in fact, it killed another eight users in Los Angeles that weekend.

Joplin's life could easily have been presented as a banal, cautionary tale of rock'n'roll victimhood but Alice Echols is too intelligent to do that. She resists making Joplin a symbol or a stereotype but presents her sympathetically as the awkward, brave, own-worst-enemy individual she was. The character portrayal is entirely convincing, and so, too, is the historical context.

Echols's previous book was Daring to be Bad: Radical Feminism in America, l967-75, and obviously her knowledge of the period informs this biography. Scars of Sweet Paradise is worth reading as a slice of cultural history, even if one has no particular interest in Joplin. Great stuff.

Their set was in the afternoon, not normally peak time, but everyone who heard Janis went berserk, and the band were quickly booked to play again the next day. Albert Grossman, Bob Dylan's manager, offered to manage them, and Columbia Records signed them for $250,000. When she became successful she said: 'I'm not a warthog that nobody wants to climb in bed with. Everybody wants to climb in bed with me now.' On stage, this dumpy, acne-pocked woman who was always complaining she couldn't get laid, became simply the sexiest woman alive and men and women practically queued to sleep with her. She got through men like Kleenex and made sure the press knew about it, boasting to Rolling Stone about her one-night stand with Joe Namath, the American football star. But just as she used her boozing to cover her drugs use (she often carried a bottle of Southern Comfort onstage) so she used her much-publicised heterosexual promiscuity to cover her lesbian affairs. She died in the Landmark Hotel, Los Angeles, on 4 October l970, aged 27. She had spent the day recording and seemed quite happy, though the boyfriend and girlfriend who were meant to be joining her for a threesome failed to show up. She went to her room, presumably shot up, went back down to the hotel lobby to buy some cigarettes, chatted cheerfully to the night porter - and was later found dead in her room, still clutching the cigarettes and change. The autopsy revealed that the heroin she had bought that night was exceptionally pure; in fact, it killed another eight users in Los Angeles that weekend. Joplin's life could easily have been presented as a banal, cautionary tale of rock'n'roll victimhood but Alice Echols is too intelligent to do that. She resists making Joplin a symbol or a stereotype but presents her sympathetically as the awkward, brave, own-worst-enemy individual she was. The character portrayal is entirely convincing, and so, too, is the historical context. Echols's previous book was Daring to be Bad: Radical Feminism in America, l967-75, and obviously her knowledge of the period informs this biography. Scars of Sweet Paradise is worth reading as a slice of cultural history, even if one has no particular interest in Joplin. Great stuff.

fields.headline: A heart of darkness
fields.standfirst: Adam Hochschild tells the story of the brutal subjugation of the Congo in King Leopold's Ghost
fields.trailText: Adam Hochschild tells the story of the brutal subjugation of the Congo in King Leopold's Ghost
fields.body:
King Leopold's Ghost
Adam Hochschild
Papermac £12, pp366
Buy it at BOL

Henry Morton Stanley has gone down in popular history as the nineteenth-century adventurer who mapped Central Africa, meeting a fellow explorer with that classic line: 'Dr Livingstone, I presume.' But one should presume nothing about Stanley. This Welshman who claimed to be an American was addicted to the cult of his own personality, and to the conquest of the people he claimed to be saving from the 'heart of darkness'.

This astonishing book, winner of the 1999 Duff Cooper prize, reveals that it was Stanley who began a systematic subjugation of the tribes of the Congo basin which was to lead to the deaths of between five and eight million people, a mass killing that is all but forgotten.

In the 1870s, 80 per cent of Africa was still under indigenous rulers and ripe for conquest or, as King Leopold II of Belgium preferred to call it, protection. He paid the explorer the equivalent of £250,000 a year to spend five years in the Congo, claiming that 'magnificent cake' for Belgium, buying up vast chunks of land and claiming the right to exploit the people.

Stanley left in 1884, but by 1897 a movement had been established to expose the cruelties of Belgian colonists to the world. Edmund Dene Morel, a British shipping company employee, realised that slavery was flourishing in the Congo and set about forming the first great human rights organisation of the twentieth century.

Adam Hochschild writes a compelling narrative in lucid prose, one that chronicles a conveniently forgotten atrocity that stains the pages of world history.

webTitle: The only Gaels in the world

fields.headline: The only Gaels in the world
fields.standfirst: Cole Moreton delves deeply into the rich river of the Irish diaspora in his history of the Blasket Islands, Hungry for Home
fields.trailText: Cole Moreton delves deeply into the rich river of the Irish diaspora in his history of the Blasket Islands, Hungry for Home
fields.body:
Hungry for Home
Cole Merton
Viking £14.99, pp288
Buy it at BOL

On Christmas Eve 1946, a young man collapsed and died of meningitis on a remote island off the west coast of Ireland. It was the beginning of the end for the famed Blasket Islands beloved of Gaelic poets and playwright John Millington Synge, who modelled his heroine of The Playboy of the Western World on an island character.

Generations of literary romantics may have come to sup at what they perceived to be a Homeric Gaelic fount of simplicity and rugged human endurance, but for the hapless islanders the death of Seánín Ó Cearna was the final straw in a pitiless battle against the raging elements.

On the edge of the world, the Blaskets were devoid of almost every human necessity; Ó Cearna's pallbearers had to risk their own lives in the face of a howling storm to row to the mainland to obtain his coffin. Within a few years, they had abandoned their island, their culture, their home, for perpetual exile.

The move to the mainland in 1953 signalled the fall of the last real indigenous Gaelic community. It was the end of the powerful but pernicious dream of an Ireland Gaelic and free.

Myth is never far away from the Blaskets but the real story of death of the islands would be unknown but for the efforts of Cole Moreton in Hungry for Home, who stunningly catalogues its final days and seeks out the testimony of remaining survivors in Ireland and the suburbs of Springfield, Massachusetts.

Moreton, who wonderfully is neither Irish or American, but an intriguing seeker after truth, delves deeply into the rich river of the Irish diaspora. The Michael Collinses and the Gerry Adamses come and go but the story of the diaspora is, rather than the easy myths of the bold Fenian men, the story of the Irish.

The fall of the Blasket Islands is emblematic of that far greater Irish chronicle of human sorrow, exile and transformation. In Cobh harbour, Moreton strolls around the leprechaun-bestrewn shops of the 'Harbour of Tears', the gateway through which three million Irish fled westward for generation after generation.

It is still an unimaginable number when you consider that the current population of the Republic is just four million. Rarely in human history can one country have so relentlessly bled and bled its young.

The reasons are not far to find. Across the sound from the Blasket Islands on the Dingle peninsula, Moreton visits two brothers, islandmen Seán and Muiris, still cooking on an open fire in a new millennium after refusing that new-fangled electricity, their lives run to nowhere by poverty and sterile loneliness. At night, the brothers - the round of their little world complete - fly the darkness for the local pub and furtive glances at dreary RTE on the bar television.

The best escape but only at a price. In Springfield, Massachusetts, Moreton finds Seánín Ó Cearna's brother Mícheál to have traded identity and poverty for a 27-inch television in the sitting-room and a 19-inch one in the bedroom. 'So we have come a long way,' expounds Mike Carney, after a lifetime spent vacantly fulfilling the American immigrant dream.

Carney takes Moreton on a tour of his new kingdom, the nearby ugly barn of an Irish club where the working-class Irish immigrants comfort themselves with dreams of the past even as their children slip away into the mainstream and the old neighbourhood is taken over by new despised Puerto Rican immigrants.

Moreton plays lightly with it but he is quite sharp enough not to be seduced by the cheery self-myths of those who leap from victim to racist in just one generation.

Moreton listens hard - these are not cultures easily penetrable by the written word because they lack self-consciousness - and teases out the unrequited longing beneath the glib stories.

In abandonment, the Blasket Islands are difficult to reach today. It took Moreton two summers before he stood in the ruins where the long-lost Ó Cearnas had played out their island lives. What he found there was not comforting, the detritus of an inescapably dead past.

Hungry for Home is a fine book by a gifted writer, though its conclusions are inescapable. There is no road of return for the exile, no possible life, nothing to return to. We leave home and are transformed forever. But that knowledge does not kill the hunger we carry around in our hearts.

webTitle: Accentuating the positive in a post-Aids world

fields.headline: Accentuating the positive in a post-Aids world
fields.standfirst: Edmund White conquers his reticence in a tender memorial that explores the possibility of monogamy in The Married Man
fields.trailText: Edmund White conquers his reticence in a tender memorial that explores the possibility of monogamy in The Married Man
fields.body:
The Married Man
Edmund White
Chatto & Windus £16.99, pp310
Buy it at BOL

Edmund White has always trawled his own intensely sexual life in his novels, and since that sexual life has charted the course of gay liberation, his books have been beautifully candid political acts. His last novel, The Farewell Symphony, was a vast valediction to his own promiscuity. Its narrator calculated that he had taken more than 3,000 lovers during the golden age of gay sex that began with Stonewall and ended with the onset of Aids, and White admitted that the tally was not far removed from his own.

There was, though, in that teeming homage to libido, a loose end. The novel contained a ghostly figure, called Brice, whose brief life the narrator challenged himself to detail along with all the one-night stands, noting at the outset: 'I may well fail. If I do fail, don't blame me. Understand that even writers, those professional exhibitionists, have their moments of reticence.' The ephemeral Brice was based on White's long-time lover Hubert Sorin, who died of Aids, aged 32, before White completed the book. And the author did fail in his efforts to delineate him, discovered his rare moment of reticence; Brice, always an insubstantial presence, simply disappears from view, without explanation, before its end.

The Married Man is an attempt, in White's distinctive, corporeal way, to flesh that story out, give it closure. It details the relationship between an American in Paris called Austin, and the younger married man he courts at his local gym, Julien. While writing the book, White explained in this paper how 'I am writing a novel loosely based on my years with Hubert... What shocks me about my response to him, however, is that my anger with him - for deserting me, for not releasing me, for not always being honest with me, as I discovered after his death - keeps seeping out on to the page. I thought I would show nothing except our growing isolation - and love - as he became more and more ill.'

The result bears witness to these tensions: this is a wonderfully poised and complex novel, in part a tender memorial, in part a kindly satire on the differences between Americans and the French, in part an examination of the possibilities of fidelity. It bears the imprint of lived experience, yet is set loose by White's precise ability to conjure a kind of flighty romance from the resolutely grim aspects of his story.

The Married Man is both an odyssey - we follow the lovers from Paris, out on day trips to the campagne, and then on to America, to New England and the Florida Keys, and finally to Morocco - and it is an elegy. White brings to the wasting of his lover's body the same forensic attention that he has always reserved for the physicality of his descriptions of lovemaking.

To begin with, though, it is the narrator, Austin, in whom our sympathies are rooted. Austin, who like White, has long been 'seriopositive' without developing Aids, has an apartment on the Île St Louis, and White uses the misty magic of that place as a touchstone for his sense of the 'posthumous, post-diagnosis, foreign days' that he spends among the camp banter of young circle of friends, mostly former lovers.

The sparkle of his past lust is pricked on summer evenings with the fairy-lit bateau-mouches passing his window, telling the story of the river in five languages; that life, however, has given way to dark nights crossing the Pont Marie 'with its empty statue niches looking down on the Seine, black and shiny as mined coal between tourist boats, more and more widely spaced as midnight and the winter solstice drew nearer'.

Meeting Julien changes all of this. The relationship seems to offer the chance of something that has never really made sense to him previously: monogamy, a state into which Austin, in his late fifties, finds himself born again. Julien has already experienced marriage - and his wife still hovers while he and his new lover explore each other 'above, below, behind' - but for Austin this is the first time, and 'he day-dreamed his way into the mind of a nineteenth-century bride who looked at those pale male hands beside her, and thought... that he'd explore her body with them for 50 years.'

That these daydreams are short-lived fuels the poignancy of a profound little novel that shows White, once the chronicler of 'golden lads', fully able to bring his distinctive kind of poetry to their coming to dust.

webTitle: Would you buy a used plotline from this man?

fields.headline: Would you buy a used plotline from this man?
fields.standfirst: Jeffrey Archer reveals his true colours in his new collection, To Cut A Long Story Short
fields.trailText: Jeffrey Archer reveals his true colours in his new collection, To Cut A Long Story Short
fields.body:
To Cut a Long Story Short
Jeffrey Archer
HarperCollins £16.99, pp272
Buy it at BOL

Jeffrey Archer's favourite political books
Books Unlimited author page

If you have not made up your mind yet about Jeffrey Archer, read To Cut a Long Story Short. By the end of it or by the time you fall asleep - whichever comes first - all your prejudices will have been deliciously confirmed.

Jeffrey Archer is living proof of the old adage that when people write fiction, they show their true colours. In this collection of 14 short stories, the disgraced former Conservative Party deputy chairman plunders his colourful past to reveal himself as a man obsessed with money, preferably in brown envelopes, deceit, champagne and other men's wives who dress up like Shepherd's Market whores.

He even helps the reader out by marking with asterisks those tales which 'I would like to acknowledge are based on true incidents'. This is more than half the stories. Thanks, Jeffrey.

Readers now know exactly what Archer's idea of a good time is. He goes out on a bright, crisp spring morning and runs into a woman he has admired from afar for years. She is called something girly like Susie and has 'long, fair hair, blue eyes, a captivating smile and slim figure'.

She 'greets me with a long hug, an "I feel I know you better already" hug.' The two agree to have lunch. He tries 'a chat-up line I've used many times in the past' - 'If you could do anything in the world right now, what would it be?' She says she wants to go to Paris.

'That's my perfect day, too,' our hero declares, before the two agree to pack and meet at Waterloo Station. On the Eurostar, she gives him 'a hug that was a definite step towards "I can't wait to get your clothes off".'

He takes her to a little restaurant 'that prides itself on not being in any of the tourist guides' and where the mâitre d' is an old friend. As the last legs of the champagne bubble down the flutes, the two leave for 'my favourite hotel'.

To please him, Archer's 'lady' dresses up in a see-through blouse, skintight leather skirt, fishnet stockings, stilettos and shocking pink lipstick. In bed, she is 'everything a man could ask - exciting, tender, provocative, teasing and, for an exquisite moment, a rampant whore'. He does not say how he performed but enjoys ridiculing her husband - Angus - as 'an old prune'.

Back in London, their 'lovemaking' continues apace. They do it in the back seat of his Mercedes in an NCP car-park in Mayfair, in the service lift in Harrods, the loo at Le Caprice and in a box in the dress circle at Covent Garden. On one occasion, he says: 'I want to be tied up to a four-poster bed, with you standing over me in a police sergeant's uniform: truncheon, whistle, handcuffs, wearing a tight black outfit with silver buttons down the front, which you will undo slowly to reveal a black bra.'

He savours his conquest: 'I have always considered it ignoble for any man to discuss a lady as if she were simply a trophy but I must confess... it had been well worth the waiting.'

If the asterisked plotlines in this collection of scammy tales - 'Crime Pays', 'Too Many Coincidences', 'Something for Nothing', 'The Endgame', 'The Reclining Woman' - are to be believed, Susie's husband, 'old prune' Angus, will conveniently keel over with a heart attack, leaving her the £20 million he has made tricking businesses into paying for phoney advertisements. Our hero will marry Susie, use her fortune to make even more money with a spot of insider trading, before forcing her into the arms of another, divorcing her and using his detailed knowledge of Channel Island laws to make off with a third of her estate.

Given his own career-destroying entanglements with women, the stock market and the legal system, it is extraordinary that before his downfall, Archer had intended this new collection to be published just weeks before the election for London major. You would think he would have expected readers to draw their own conclusions about his character and vote for almost anyone else.

To Cut a Long Story Short is embarrassingly bad and expensive. Neither Archer nor his publisher need the cash but it is a small price to pay to see a man who has fallen off his political perch so comprehensively destroy what is left of his creative reputation. As one of his creaking, corny characters would say: 'Enjoy!'

webTitle: Literary love is for girls and sissies

fields.headline: Literary love is for girls and sissies
fields.trailText: The battle lines between the sexes may have been breached when it comes to jobs, sport and even housework. But in the field of literature, men and women are still clearly at odds.
fields.body:
The battle lines between the sexes may have been breached when it comes to jobs, sport and even housework. But in the field of literature, men and women are still clearly at odds.

The first survey into the impact of gender on reading habits, published tomorrow, will show that men instinctively flinch from any book they consider a 'woman's read'.

Never mind what the book is about; male readers are unduly influenced by the sex of the author, by the look of the cover and by the use of emotional words in the title.

'Things don't seem to have changed much,' said Kate Mosse, co-founder of the £30,000 Orange Prize for Fiction, which is to release tomorrow the names of the 24 women writers who have made it on to its fifth annual long list, along with the full findings of a survey into gender prejudice among readers.

'It seems that male readers are still cutting themselves off from some wonderful literature because they are making the wrong assumptions. Great writing is above gender,' said Mosse.

In contrast to men, women are shown to read openly and widely. Although they do identify certain novels as being targeted at men, they are quite likely to read them anyway. Female readers, for instance, picked out Nick Hornby's High Fidelity as the most overtly male of all the 20 novels in the survey, yet more than half said they would 'seriously consider' reading it.

Overall, 40 per cent of women said they were interested in reading novels they suspected were 'male reads', while only 25 per cent of men were moved to pick up a book that they had already classified as a 'female read'.

This means that critically-acclaimed books by women writers such as A.S. Byatt, Anne Tyler and Margaret Atwood each appealed to only 2 per cent of male readers in the survey. What is more, men appear to be put off by book jackets and titles; both external signs that could belie the nature of the contents.

Ian McEwan's Enduring Love, despite being a dark, suspenseful tale, was categorised by three out of four men as a 'female read', partly because the word 'love' is in the title.

'It makes you think that you ought to put the word 'helicopter' or 'crash' in your title if you want to attract the male reader,' McEwan told The Observer.

'This survey is not based on responses of those who have actually read the books though, and it would be interesting to know whether these readers then changed their minds.'

Less than 30 per cent of surveyed men considered reading Enduring Love, while more than half of the women readers wanted to try it.

Similarly, the three women writers who made it into the survey's 'neutral zone' - books seen as neither male nor female - all had novels with titles and cover designs that looked more masculine. The qualifiers were Pat Barker's Regeneration, Beryl Bainbridge's Every Man for Himself and Ann Michaels's Fugitive Pieces.

The findings suggest that writers such as Anita Desai and newcomer Zadie Smith - both strongly tipped to make it on to the final runners for this year's Orange Prize with their novels, Fasting, Feasting and White Teeth - will never be read by as many men as women. Though the themes of these two new novels are not gender-specific and concern the struggle for cultural identity, they are in danger of being classified as women's books.

Mosse argues that the survey results underline the need for a prize for women writers only. 'We need to keep promoting women authors. Otherwise, a lot of male readers will misguidedly discount them,' she said.

'The survey also shows that women read as a part of social interaction and to stretch themselves. Men, on the other hand, were found rarely to talk about books and saw them as a way of relaxing or passing the time.'

The lighter-weight 'female' book has traditionally scored more highly with male readers, with the second Bridget Jones novel, The Edge of Reason, frequently spotted on men's bookshelves. The novel though, was not considered right for the Orange long list by its panel of five judges, which this year includes Ffion Hague and Bonnie Greer and is chaired by journalist Polly Toynbee.

Among the more established novels to suffer from a 'male turn-off factor' due to unappealing female associations is the George Eliot classic Middlemarch, which was overwhelmingly seen as a woman's book, despite the male pseudonym of the author. Less than 1 per cent of men wanted to read it.

Michale Ondaatje's The English Patient and John Fowles's The French Lieutenant's Woman were treated with suspicion by men too. Love, Again, by the pioneering feminist writer Doris Lessing, appealed to only 7 per cent of male readers.

Yet those novelists who inadvertently attract a majority of women readers are not really in trouble. Since the birth of the novel, fiction publishing has been supported by its female customers.

'The novel itself emerged because of the demand from women subscription readers in the eighteenth century, so it might fairly be seen as a female literary form. Fiction tends to deal with relationships and somehow this seems to tickle female antennae more than it does male.'

Bridging the literary divide

Written by a man, read by women

Enduring Love by Ian McEwan

A tense, black study in obsession, read largely by women and regarded by both sexes as a 'female read'.

The romantically evocative title and pastel-coloured jacket design led only 9 per cent of men to regard it as a book that would appeal to other men, even though it is by a male author with a well-established reputation.

About the boys

High Fidelity by Nick Hornby

The malest book on the block. Hornby's follow-up to his football-obsessive Fever Pitch deals chiefly with music and love, rather than sport, but is still only considered a 'female read' by 4 per cent of women. Nevertheless, 55 per cent of them would read it anyway, if only, perhaps, to learn about life on the other side of the gender divide.

One for all

Regeneration by Pat Barker

Although written by a woman, this semi-factual First World War story appeals to 62 per cent of men and 48 per cent of women.

Girl talk

Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason by Helen Fielding

Wicked return to the world of the singleton in search of love. A 'female read', but its humour makes it at least anecdotally well read by men.

webTitle: The world according to David Irving

fields.headline: The world according to David Irving
fields.standfirst:
The judge will soon give his verdict on one of the most bitter libel trials in recent memory. Last week David Irving took time off to give this revealing and forthright interview to celebrated American author Gerald Posner. He remains defiant, unapologetic and more outspoken than ever
The David Irving libel trial: special report
fields.trailText: The judge will soon give his verdict on one of the most bitter libel trials in recent memory. Last week David Irving took time off to give this revealing and forthright interview to celebrated American author Gerald Posner. He remains defiant, unapologetic and more outspoken than ever
fields.body:
'Those are Adolf Eichmann's personal papers and diaries, the ones the Israelis didn't find when they kidnapped him,' says David Irving, casually pointing to a stack of papers strewn on his kitchen table. His flat is overflowing with books, documents, files, as well as World War II memorabilia. 'They are more interesting than the Eichmann papers Israel just released to help the defence. They are desperate and clutching at straws.'

Irving, 62, relishes the limelight and tweaking his foes. He is thoroughly enjoying the fallout from his high-profile libel lawsuit against Penguin publishers and American Holocaust historian Deborah Lipstadt. After much prodding, he has agreed to a rare break in his round-the-clock trial work to see me in his sprawling Mayfair townhouse flat. 'After my closing argument in the trial,' he declares, 'I shall give no further interviews. This is probably the last one. I need to get back to my writing after a three-year hiatus.'

Irving remains unrepentant. In three weeks time he will discover if his libel action will salvage his reputation or mark him as permanently ruined. Following closing arguments last week, and while the the judge considers his verdict, one might expect Irving to be circumspect and politically correct. But that is not his style. Instead he seems determined to take on his foes and to reiterate his strident views.

He leads me into his study. There, he sat directly in front of a large colour overhead photograph of Crematorium Two at Auschwitz: 'That's the holy of holies,' says Irving, jabbing one of his pudgy fingers toward the photo. 'No one was gassed there. The stories from survivors where someone says they used to take off the manhole covers and then the gas poured in, it's all false.'

He enjoys, as he puts it, 'deglamorising and deromanticising' the Holocaust. 'The Poles have admitted that the only gas chamber at Auschwitz is a reconstruction built by them in 1948. It's only a damn tourist attraction.'

The charges start coming rapid fire. Although Irving relishes his status as a contrarian and historic mischief-maker, he desperately wants to be accepted as a serious historian. And he is anxious to demonstrate that instead of being cowed by the battery of legal talent defending Lipstadt, he is defiant and unbowed. For the next hour, he launches into a rather remarkable defence of his own conclusions as well as an extraordinary attack on the foundations of the Holocaust. In a virtual monologue, peppered occasionally with German phrases, he rattled off contentions almost faster than I could type them into my notebook computer.

'All Auschwitz survivors are now useless witnesses at any trial since they have all seen Spielberg's Schindler's List, and can recite from memory where the supposed shower heads with gas were.' When he says something he particularly likes, his yellow teeth flash as his thin lips part in a devilish grin.

And he does not back away from some of the extreme statements and acts attributed to him, although he often tries to deflect their importance by casting it as prankish humour. Yes, there were swizzle sticks adorned with little swastikas at his 1991 book party, but 'those were really nothing more than copies of Hitler's personal standard that my publisher had made up for the launch of my book.' (The late Alan Clark was according to Irving, 'a great admirer of Hitler. He sat in that very chair that you are in right before my party started and told me in depth about his admiration for Hitler.')

What about a little ditty found in the voluminous personal diaries produced in the trial:

'I am a Baby Aryan,
Not a Jewish or sectarian,
I have no plans to marry,
An Ape or Rastafarian.

'Yes, that was mine. But I wrote it because of the bounce of the words and they rhyme, not the content. They say it makes me a racist. Well, that is all they got from my diaries. There are 20 million words in those diaries, and these are 20. So that makes me what - 0.0001 per cent racist?' After a moment's hesitation, he adds, 'But I do now wish I had used vegetarian instead of Rastafarian.'

He comes alive when he talks about the trial, the forces he sees arrayed against him, and what he believes he is accomplishing in courtroom 73 of the High Court.

'I have been singled out,' Irving says as he sets forth a grand conspiracy he believes operates against him. 'There has been, for years, a co-ordinated effort to demolish my legitimacy as a historian. It is an international endeavour. It is the international network of the Anti-Defamation League, the Simon Wiesenthal Center, the Board of Deputies of British Jews, the South African Jewish Board of Deputies, the Austrian Jewish Congress, the American Jewish Committee, and a number of others.

'These are some of the traditional enemies of truth. These are all bodies that Lipstadt thanks in her book. They always use the slime defence against me. It is expensive for them, with so many lawyers and experts, but they mount it. In any case, Jews should be asking not who pulled the trigger, but why? When the Nazis asked the Slovaks, the Hungarians, the Czechs, and others to give over their Jews, everyone did so gladly. Why did the Americans and Roosevelt refuse to let the St. Louis dock? What is it about these people that no one wanted them?'

It it vintage Irving. He deflects the query about why many respected organisations have taken such a keen interest in his handling of history and instead turns the discussion into a rhetorical question about the nature of Jews, one that he is prepared to answer. Although he is adamant that he is not a racist or anti-Semite, no sooner had he posed the question than he provided an answer that is chillingly reminiscent of the anti-Semitic themes that have persisted for centuries. 'Greed.' He pauses, letting the word virtually hang in the room.

'Fifty years from now you might well have the same problem in the United States. The Jewish élite in America is filling the same positions they held in the Weimar republic during the 1920s and 1930s - controlling the big banks, the film business, media, and the like. The Jews disproportionately held all these big positions in Germany. It's a mirror image in the US. And it will evoke howls of rage from the ordinary citizens who are kept out of the power élite.'

Irving's charge about the 'Jewish élite in America' sounds remarkably similar to that made by the most extreme right-wing race baiters in the US, and it is surprising to hear him say it publicly, especially since his courtroom persona has been that of the measured historian who only has a difference of opinion with other historians.

Although he has been forced to admit at trial that he greatly underestimated the number of Jews killed in mobile gas vans (97,000 died that way), he finds solace in his belief - which almost no courtroom observer shares - that he has made great strides in demonstrating that Auschwitz's Crematorium Two, the site of half a million deaths, is 'a mere legend'.

'It is the geocentre of the supposed death factory,' says Irving, his voice rising slightly as he becomes more excited. 'But I have pictures that show there were no holes in the ceiling, so there was no place for the gas to come from.'

'What about the large quantities of Zyklon B gas that were shipped to Auschwitz?' I ask.

His answer is the classic defence of hardcore revisionists. 'Yes, huge quantities of Zyklon B were shipped there. The appropriate quantities for fumigation, especially with the camp's typhus epidemics and problems with pest control.'

My expression shows my scepticism.

'Look,' he continues. 'Zyklon B may have been used against prisoners. I don't know. But I know crematorium 2 was not an enormous gas chamber.' Although he says the debate over how many were killed by the Nazis is not important, he enjoys contending that 'only 100,000 Jews may have died at Auschwitz,' most from diseases, and the rest from shootings and hangings.

Then, as though his very minor concession about the possible use of gas ran against his spirit, he picked up again in a vitriolic mode.

'Jewish leaders have hijacked the word 'holocaust.' It's even spelt everywhere with a capital H. My Jewish editor in New York would not let me use the word in my book Hitler's War to describe the Allied bombing of Dresden. Another writer could not use it to describe the Irish potato famine. It's like it's a registered trademark. You can't open it or tamper with it. You either have to buy it or not, and if you don't buy it, what a headache.'

Now Irving's face is flushed red. His speech is rapid. There is an anger against the forces he thinks are operating against him. Now it seems to boil over as his rhetoric hits new highs. 'The factory of death legend,' he waves his hand dismissively. 'They have hijacked the entire media with their holocaust story. Nobody suffers from it except for me on who they pour their slime.'

He slumps back as though the outburst tired him.

'What if you are completely proven wrong one day?' I ask him. 'Proven wrong even to your satisfaction.'

He sits quietly for a moment. 'I've said it before, and will again - with a sheepish grin, I'll admit I was wrong, but you will have to give me credit for having given them a great run for 40 years. But I certainly don't expect that to happen.'

webTitle: How Alchemy transformed £50m into a solid gold £1bn

fields.headline: How Alchemy transformed £50m into a solid gold £1bn
fields.standfirst:
Paul Farrelly talks to Jon Moulton, the venture capitalist who bought the remains of Rover from BMW
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Paul Farrelly talks to Jon Moulton, the venture capitalist who bought the remains of Rover from BMW
fields.body:
The timing of the German-British Chamber of Industry & Commerce could hardly be more inept. Tomorrow, the august trade body hosts a grand City reception aimed at portraying German investment in Britain in the warmest light. But by the time the reminder was dropping on newsdesks last week, BMW - Germany's biggest UK investor by far - had been secretly negotiating its humiliating and bloody retreat for five long months.

The latest chapter in Rover's turbulent history was written in a modern, three- storey office block in London's fashionable Covent Garden. Last October, when Jon Moulton and colleagues from venture capital firm Alchemy flew to BMW's imposing Munich headquarters, they expected the meeting in the four cylinder-shaped building to be short but not especially sweet. But in Helmut Panke, BMW's finance director, the Alchemy team found an audience more than eager to listen to their plans.

'We expected to be shown the door. Instead, we spent two hours batting back and forth motor car strategy,' Moulton said this weekend in an interview with The Observer. 'Most of our deals walk in off the street. But the creative input for this one came from right here. We just thought, hell, BMW must have been really, really hurting with Rover just then.'

And no wonder. Since 1994, when BMW bought Rover for £800 million from British Aerospace, the Germans have invested £3 billion in the old British Leyland carmaker's sprawling plants at Longbridge, Cowley and Land Rover at Solihull. The audacious move was meant to spearhead BMW's attempted drive into the middle and mass markets to complement its upmarket, luxury marque. Instead, Rover visited nothing but tears, blood and peri odic bouts of fratricide on the BMW board.

Losses last year leapt to £725m, hit by sterling's strength and consumer resistance to a tarnished brand name. It was hard to forecast when Rover would ever make a profit. And so thoroughly disenchanted had BMW become by the end of the millennium that its infamously professional German managers had started to take their eyes off the ball.

At Rover's biggest plant, Longbridge, which employs 9,000 workers, the 140,000-car-a-year production is now running at one-and-a-half times annual sales. As a result, more than 50,000 Rover 25 and 45 models are lined up in fields waiting for a buyer, increasing Rover's losses - and BMW's grief - by the day. Precisely how many, however, no one at BMW or Alchemy seems to know: the venture capitalists are sending for satellite photos to count the stock this weekend.

'It's a mess. We know they've had stock control and production problems,' Moulton said. 'It's almost impossible to reconcile. They have a great German business [and] a great American business. He has since kept his idea alive: the launch of a new range of medium-volume British sports and saloon cars. The deal with BMW now realises the dream by another route: the MG brand.

'We spent a long time trying to buy Lotus,' Moulton said. 'We know this business well. We will be small and agile and ahead of the technology curve. Or the factory at Swindon, where another 2,500 staff make Rover body panels. But industry experts predict BMW may be storing up more problems for itself from its expensive British base. Over the next two years, Cowley's production of the Rover 75 will transfer to Longbridge, making more jobs vulnerable. Swindon, meanwhile, may be sold to Mayflower, the independent automotive engineering company which already produces panels for the MGF.

The world's best-known four-wheel drive brand had been one of the main attractions of Rover to the Germans. And, with worldwide sales of the Land Rover range reaching a record 178,000 last year, it was the one undoubted success story of BMW's British misadventure. Friday's £1.8bn sale of Land Rover to Ford, therefore, came as yet another shock to the public. But not to Alchemy. 'When we first discussed how they could do this months ago,' Moulton told The Observer, 'we said your write-off on Rover will be £2bn. But Land Rover's worth £2bn, so you're even.'

The timing of last week's dramatic events was in fact dictated by the deal with Ford, not by the one with Alchemy. Last Mon day, when Moulton was due in Munich again, he assumed it was for more routine negotiations. Instead, to his surprise, Panke pushed for a quick deal. The Americans were clearly ready. Alchemy's talks had gone from start to finish without a single appearance by by BMW's chairman, Professor Joachim Millberg.

BMW's secret negotiations with Ford started at the end of January - just after the board saw the full horror of Rover's 1999 results. By then, the powerful Quandt family, BMW's biggest shareholders, who previously had supported the pro-Rover faction on the board, had also seen enough.

Moulton hopes to complete the deal in six weeks, and is as coy on precise financial detail as he is on the likely job losses at Longbridge. The risk, though, to Alchemy will be strictly limited. The firm will invest no more than £50m, and will get the £1bn factory debt-free. BMW, meanwhile, has written off £1.9bn. webTitle: I'm sorry we lied, says Rover's German boss

fields.headline: I'm sorry we lied, says Rover's German boss
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Rover's German boss has apologised for lying to the British Government about the death sentence hanging over the Longbridge car plant. The Germans kept the Cabinet in the dark because they say their plans, leading to thousands of job losses, were 'market sensitive'.
fields.body:
Rover's German boss has apologised for lying to the British Government about the death sentence hanging over the Longbridge car plant. The Germans kept the Cabinet in the dark because they say their plans, leading to thousands of job losses, were 'market sensitive'.

The implied insult that Ministers and officials could not be trusted with a commercial secret has added to the Government's fury over BMW's handling of the Longbridge sale.

Tony Blair, who is said to have been shaking with anger when he heard the news, after the decision was made, is expected to have angry words with German Chancellor Gerhart Schroder, when they meet at an EU summit in Lisbon this week.

Rover chairman, Werner Saman, had a face-to-face meeting with Trade Secretary Stephen Byers less than a week before BMW's board decided to sell Rover Cars. He raised BMW's now familiar complaint about the strength of the pound, which is making it difficult to sell British cars on the Continent, but denied that anything that would affect UK car production was up for discussion.

When the two met again in Longbridge on Friday, Byers accused him of being deliberately misleading, and was given an apology. According to an eye witness: 'He said the reason he didn't give the information was that it was market sensitive at the time. But the Department is continually receiving market sensitive information so that any problems can be dealt with as they come up.'

The war of words between the British government and the car manufacturers reflect government fears of mass unemployment and political damage for Labour in the West Midlands.

Yesterday, Byers claimed it was not too late to find someone else who would take over car production at Longbridge. On his way into the first meeting of a government-backed task force to deal with the impact of the sale, Byers said: 'There is nothing to stop someone coming along and putting in a new offer with BMW.'

But officials and union leaders are resigned to the prospect that Longbridge will be taken over by Alchemy Partners, and that car production will be halved

Byers, who has come under fire over a series of problems, including last week's decision to site a £200 million science project in Oxfordshire rather than Warrington, is battling to show the Government is doing all that could be expected after being taken by surprise.

He has been backed by the head of the AEEU, Sir Ken Jackson, who blames the crisis entirely on BMW. But Bill Morris, head of the transport workers' union, the TGWU, which represents four-fifths of the Longbridge workforce, criticised the Government for not foreseeing the disaster.

Tory MP John Redwood, a former trade minister, said: 'Byers went to sleep on the job. It's no good him blaming BMW, because he was being negligent. If his job isn't on the line, it should be.'
