webTitle: Why the wheels fell off at Rover

fields.headline: Why the wheels fell off at Rover
fields.standfirst:
The blame for Rover's demise lies in generations of stagnant British management and antediluvian unions, not German duplicity
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The blame for Rover's demise lies in generations of stagnant British management and antediluvian unions, not German duplicity.
fields.body:
Euro-scepticism and BMW's unimaginative ownership may finally have killed Rover, but this calamity was longer in the making than the last few years. It is the culmination of decades of institutional failure, managerial incompetence, government inadequacy, poorly-lead unions and a naïve business culture. BMW made mistakes, certainly, particularly in overestimating the value of the Rover brand in a home market where Britishness counts for less and less, and the manner of its exit, leaving tens of thousands of jobs and a dealer network to swing in the wind with no prior warning, is disgraceful. But this remains a home-made tragedy.

At the bottom of Rover's long-term failure is a hopelessly crude conception of what constitutes enterprise and business success. The British have never accepted that an enterprising business is also an enterprising and intelligent organisation embedded in a network of other enterprising organisations, in which the quest for profit, while imperative, is not the sufficient condition for success alone. Creativity, employee commitment, investor patience and professional and trade skills are the other essential parts of the brew.

But the British view, embodied in company law and culture, is that business is solely about the pursuit of profit, in which the shareholder is sovereign and the market is held to be a fact of nature. Workers are essentially disposable commodities. Customers are pulp to be milched in the service of maximum dividends. At the heart of business success is not the time-consuming effort of organisation building, nurturing human capital and sustaining a brand - it is doing the big deal. Mr Blair, Mr Byers and the unions are right to protest at the secrecy with which Rover was sold to the venture capitalist Alchemy, but that was because in Britain the law requires that shareholders consult with no one when they do deals.

As for the state's relationship with industry, the century-long approach has been hands-off - markets must do what they will and business must live with the consequences. In particular, the exchange rate must be allowed to settle where the financial markets drive it. The long history of British incapacity to organise a competitive exchange rate for our industrial base is now acted out as opposition to membership of the euro.

A determined effort to keep sterling competitive has been abjured, because of political timidity, lack of policy innovation and a backward-looking cadre of economists and commentators who refuse to see how the dynamics of exchange-rate determination have been changed with the launch of the euro. Finance is again king, cemented by romanticism about retaining political sovereignty over the pound when it has long been lost and laced with not a little xenophobia.

For the decline of Rover is the story of all these weaknesses unfolding and recurring at different times over the entire postwar period. There were the absurd stock-market-driven bids and deals of the 1950s and 1960s as the car industry consolidated, with no management team getting hold of the emerging British Leyland and building it as a creative manufacturing organisation around long production runs and product innovation. The imperative was raising dividends. Union militancy, based on a wrong-headed analysis of capitalism, brought matters to a crisis in the 1970s. When the private BL failed and was bought by the National Enterprise Board, funds intended for product development were spent on delivering ridiculous pay deals to buy off threatened strikes.

There followed a failed sale to Ford and then British Aerospace's stewardship in 1988; a clever deal to buy Rover cheaply, cleverer asset-stripping and a cleverer-still sale to BMW. Cumulatively, the money invested in Rover may have seemed high; in fact, it was paltry, late and poorly targeted. And all the while the exchange rate reached astonishing highs, fell back briefly and then reached new peaks during the ERM débcle, making car manufacturing a task only for the congenitally stubborn.

When BMW intervened in 1994, it seemed to offer the management, commitment and deep pockets, but in reality the game was up. There is too much car-making capacity in the European car industry, German management tech niques did not travel and Rover was too far gone to be saved. The sale to Alchemy is the end. It acknowledges that within four years all that will be left - unless a Ford or a Volkswagen buy Longbridge, which is unlikely - is specialist sports car manufacture and even that is doubtful.

What we have to do is not try to save what is lost, but to learn - and build structures that mean the next wave of companies in the new information economy do not suffer the same fate. I would target four areas: the exchange rate, consultation procedures, corporate law and 'local' Keynesianism to support the stricken West Midlands.

First, Britain needs to commit to join the euro at a competitive exchange rate 20 per cent lower than today, somewhere around DM2.50. The Government should state this as its aim, then raise £20 billion through issuing long-term bonds, sell pounds and buy euros - and promise to do the same again until the pound has fallen to the target level. At current exchange rates, the Government will make a capital profit of £4bn on each £20bn intervention and alleviate the evisceration of manufacturing. Euro-scepticism costs money and jobs.

Second, no British government or trade union should be humiliated by a secret deal on such a scale again. The Industrial Society (I write as its incoming chief executive) has shown that under the 1981 Transfer of Undertakings Regulations, a company has no legal requirement to consult with anybody when a company transfers its employment responsibilities through a sale of its shares. Shareholder-driven deals, in short, require no consultation with the labour force whatsoever. This loophole should be closed immediately.

Third, we need to rethink corporate law and, in particular, the responsibilities of pension-fund trustees, directors of banks and boards of trading businesses. If we want companies to be more intelligent and creative, then the requirements we make of directors and financiers need to be less crude than at present. As a first step, the annual publication of a social, employment, investment and environmental audit should be made a condition of a stock-exchange listing, alongside the publication of the annual report.

And last, the West Midlands should become the venue for a new approach to economic development, what Frank Field calls local Keynesianism. The whole region should be designated as an 'employment zone' in which employers' national insurance contributions are abolished and where the Government directs a wave of public investment and procurement. We need to become serious about regional policy.

Mr Blair and his Cabinet feel betrayed and politically exposed. Finding a buyer for Rover has to be attempted, but nobody should hold their breath. Instead, this could be the opportunity for decisive change, not only in the name of jobs but to relegitimise government, which has been made to look incompetent. Don't get mad, Mr Blair. Get even.

fields.headline: 'We feel utterly betrayed'
fields.standfirst:
Joanna Walters reports from Longbridge on the anger of threatened employees and suppliers
Rover in crisis: special report
Rover Group
fields.trailText: Joanna Walters reports from Longbridge on the anger of threatened employees and suppliers
fields.body:
The joke on the shopfloor at Longbridge on Friday was: 'Where are the application forms for shelf stacking? Coz when there's a Tesco here, not a car factory, that's what we'll all be doing.'

The laughter is shrill and abrupt. As the afternoon shift poured out of the factory gates past the BMW sign on which, after dark, 'Stabbed in the back' was sprayed in large letters, they were spitting with rage. Everyone blamed BMW.

'Shafted. Treated despicably. Lied to from beginning to end. We won't trust anyone again.' These were typical comments called out as knots of grey-overalled assembly line workers trooped home from the vast plant.

'The Germans have sold us down the Swanee,' said Steve Nash. 'All those promises - they just lied. That's it for us now.' He puts together the middle-sized Rover 25 and 45 cars, whose quality has never been better, and sales never worse as confidence in the brand ebbs away.

Steve Bond, 38, lives 'just down the road' in a community almost entirely dependent on Rover. He is the only breadwinner in his household, and his £18,000 a year from driving a forklift truck at Longbridge supports a wife and six-year-old daughter.

'The first I knew was when I saw the newspaper headlines. Big shock - although I think BMW always intended to do something like this,' Bond says.

What jobs will there be if Longbridge shuts down? 'Nothing. The kind of stuff you see in the Jobcentre pays half what Rover does.'

Local suppliers are more inclined to blame the strength of sterling and Britain's reluctance to join the euro, although many cannot afford to criticise BMW, as they still supply components to its Oxford plant. Just yards from the main gate at Longbridge stands GPM engineering. It makes the machines that make the cars, fitting conveyor systems, pulleys and assembly line sections for Rover.

Managing director Geoff Crow started making the Austin A40 at Longbridge as a 16-year-old apprentice in 1956, when the factory buzzed with 28,000 workers.

He witnessed the industrial turmoil of the Sixties and Seventies, and left what was by then the Metro production line in 1982 to start GPM 'because my wife said there might be a better long-term future doing something else'.

He reckons his £12 million annual turnover, 'modest' profits and 130 staff will sur vive without Rover because he supplies the likes of Jaguar, Ford and Nissan, too.

'And we work harder than everyone else,' he says. The machines roll at GPM in the evenings and through weekends. Halfway through showing The Observer proudly round his plant, Crow takes a call from Honda.

'They say they can get their components more cheaply from Japan and they want me to drop my prices, again,' he said. Carmakers have forced 20 per cent price cuts on suppliers in the past two years, with 'violent pressure'.They consider 20 quotes before awarding contracts.

Does he have a choice? 'Yes. Drop my price or lose the job.'

He blames today's strife first on the Conservatives ('and I vote for them'), and now on Labour's reluctance to join the euro.

'If Longbridge were to close it would be a disaster for the West Midlands. It has had many owners in the past 30 years, but the current one seems the most dubious.' He also blames the failure of successive managements to 'get a grip' on workers.

Isn't it cruel that the young Longbridge workers of today pay the price for mistakes made 30 years ago? 'Life is cruel. No one has a divine right to be in this industry,' Crow says.

That is little comfort to Longbridge worker John. He has made his living at Rover for 10 years. His father-in-law works at components supplier Tucker Fasteners nearby, where a third of the work is for Rover.

John's brother works for a local subsidiary of GKN, which is equally dependent, and his wife is at the Lucas electronics factory in Kingstanding, where 40 per cent of the work is for Longbridge.

So many jobs will go. 'We feel utterly betrayed,' he says.

From penny-farthings to losses in the millions

1877: John Starley and William Sutton set up firm making penny-farthings.

1896: Company renamed Rover Cyle Company.

1904: Produced its first car.

1931: BMW built its first car - the 'Dixi', a model licensed from Rover.

1933: Moved to concentrate on medium-sized quality cars; adopted the advertising slogan 'Britain's finest car'.

1948: Launch of Land Rover.

1950: Rover produced the world's first car powered by a jet engine.

1963: Rover P6 2000 launched and named car of the year.

1968: Company absorbed into British Leyland. The group's constituent parts had around 40 per cent of the UK car market.

1970: tie-up with Honda for the launch of the Triumph Acclaim.

1975: Nationalised.

1984: Announced that it needed to take on more employees; Longbridge total already stood at 13,000.

1986: Whole group renamed Rover, dropping BL. Negotiations to sell the group to Ford halted by Government. Further negotiations - also blocked - to sell Land Rover to Ford.

1987: Company said it would trade profitably that year.

1988: Bought by British Aerospace, with the help of £250 million of government help.

1994: BMW bought Rover for £800 million - trumping an offer from Honda to lift its stake from 20 per cent to just under 50 per cent.

1995: Announced that the Rover 400 would be the last project on which Rover collaborated with Honda.

1998: Rover losses reached £647 million.

1999: Rover suffered 26 per cent sales decline, with UK market share falling below 5 per cent. Losses running at £600 million. Shed some 9,000 Rover jobs. BMW said it would invest £3 billion in Rover in the years up to 2005. Forecast that Rover would break even by 2002 - if sterling stayed at DM2.90. Government agreed £150m of aid - after BMW had threatened to shift some production to Hungary.

2000: Break-up announced.

fields.headline: After the flood
fields.standfirst:
As the waters start to recede from Mozambique, the award-winning photojournalist Tom Stoddart visits one of the worst-hit areas

Mozambique floods: A special report
fields.trailText: As the waters start to recede from Mozambique, the award-winning photojournalist Tom Stoddart visits one of the worst-hit areas
fields.body:
The bodies end up beached near Chokwe - shapeless tangles of limbs poking out of the water. Those rescued stand nearby and watch silently; scanning the victims pulled from the water. As aid workers row across the waters, methodically upending the dead into their boats, the mass of onlookers trebles in size - first 100, then 200, finally 300 strong. All of them watch in horrified silence.

The clearing of surrounding waters takes a little more than five hours. When it's completed, the nameless dead are pulled into body bags and left on one side of a makeshift airstrip. With only the heads poking out of their canvas coffins, flood survivors are called in an attempt to identify the dead. The crowd files past in a single line, the steady whirr of helicopter blades the only sound.

Words are a meagre commodity in Mozambique - and the silence has a supernatural aura. Victims stand silently, queuing for aid rations; a mother wordlessly watches for relatives by the roadside; a lorry driver speechlessly drives for 10 hours to deliver medical supplies to a refugee centre. The movements have a matter-of-fact nonchalance, but the silence of the displaced masses is truly unsettling.

Every day, relief workers and military machines strengthen their hold on the disaster areas. The Americans - short of any credible opposition elsewhere - speak of Mozambique as a 'fight against Mother Nature'. The rhetoric is duly fed back to word-hungry newspapers and image-starved satellite feeds - while the nation itself, wordlessly tries to piece itself back together.

Journalists in Mozambique have started referring to the 'stoicism' of the flood victims; aid organisation leaders and military leaders advocate other redundant portrayals of a 'resolute' and 'strong-willed' nation. All of the terms, on deeper investigation, carry misrepresentations and half-truths. If there is such a phenomenon as wide-walking collective shock, Mozambique carries it with unimaginable disbelief.

And to be truthful, the full extent of Mozambique's cruel geographical re-organisation has been better articulated through pictures, not words. Families clinging to treetops; helicopter crews struggling to winch up the inert living; villagers picking through the remnants of their homes - all have made for the kind of sympathetic photojournalism that separates itself from the usual mire of digital imagery. Many of the pictures need little explanation - and few journalists have been able to articulate the tragedy as well as any cameraman.

What happened in those trees, on those rooftops, and deep in those hillsides, in the nights before the world's media and aid planes scrambled to a small flood-ravaged country in Africa? Speaking to the casualties of Mozambique's natural disaster - trying to induce an interview - and journalists stumble against a conspiratorial silence. The helicopters may have rescued the needy from the trees, but only once the survivors had drowned their words and memories in the swirling waters below.

Survivors plucked from the waters routinely wave away media interviews - there seems to be a refusal to elaborate on any experiences. Journalists have mistaken the silence for solemn rectitude in the face of adversity, but the hushed tones sound too furtive and panicked to denote strength. This is a country waiting for its foreigners to depart; only then, will the grieving assume a more logical openness.

Fifty kilometres north of Vilangulu, a displaced people's camp houses around 2,000 refugees - families who survived the brunt of the flooding. Last Wednesday night, a group of them arranged a small campfire to cook food. Someone procured a radio, and tuned into a local pop station playing Portuguese dance music.

Looking at the inactive responses to the music elaborates the true extent of human suffering in Mozambique. As the acoustic beats blared from the tinny transistor, those gathered around the fire all seemed momentarily to escape their faculties, withdrawing into sullen looks that were later overcome by depressed shudders. But none of the survivors cried, neither did they share their experiences with each other, nor anyone else. The music played on until the battery ran out of power - yet no one stirred to move towards the tents.

How does one extrapolate the usual psychological terms to Mozambique - after providing food, water and shelter, does the West bandy such Americanised practices as 'closure'? At the moment, the locals are registering themselves in camps, soon the absolute cost of human lives will be apparent. Perhaps then, they will slowly relearn to speak. Only, by then, the foreign troops and writers will have decamped elsewhere: such is the nature of news.

Tape recorders and notebooks have proved powerless in Mozambique - the camera has proved the most effective weapon in drawing attention to the beleaguered country. The pictures articulate a myriad of contemplative realities - and a truth the written word has been unable to uncover.

 If you would like to make a donation, please call the Médecins Sans Frontières Mozambique Floods Appeal on 0800 200 253

fields.headline: A shot away from anarchy
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe faces civil war as black veterans vow to defy a court ruling against seizures of white land.

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe faces civil war as black veterans vow to defy a court ruling against seizures of white land.
fields.body:
The plastic trumpet tooted loudly over the park in Harare as more than 5,000 opponents of President Robert Mugabe's embattled administration chanted slogans and voiced their hatred of one of Africa's longest-serving leaders. 'The President is dead,' shouted one demonstrator, standing in a fountain. Behind him, the plastic trumpet continued its anarchic cacophony.

Zimbabwe is plunging headlong into chaos. Yesterday the demonstrators - backing anti-government moves by the opposition party, the Movement For Democratic Change - brought the capital to a standstill following a humiliating defeat for Mugabe in the High Court. Judges ruled on Friday that war veterans had 24 hours to vacate more than 400 white-owned farms they had seized over the previous month.

The veterans are soldiers from Zimbabwe's war of independence. Backed by Mugabe himself, they are protesting against land ownership by 'colonial' whites. The President says the veterans should remain on the farms until the government gives them their own plots. But most Zimbabweans believe Mugabe is merely promising free land in an effort to shore up support for his beleaguered government in next month's parliamentary elections.

But near yesterday's demonstrations another, more worrying rally was held by more than 1,000 of the veterans who had taken over the most profitable farms. They announced they will ignore the High Court ruling. 'No one, not the government nor the courts, can keep us off the land,' said one former soldier. 'It belongs to blacks.'

The veterans claim to possess arms caches which they would use to launch an uprising should the state try to evict them - though these weapons are mostly antique remnants of the war. Nevertheless, the spectre of full- scale civil war gets closer every day.

Two decades after Mugabe won Zimbabwe's first majority rule elections, his country lies in economic and political tatters. Unemployment is nearly 60 per cent and inflation around 70 per cent, and the President's plans for a new constitution have been firmly rejected by voters.

Anarchy is just a shot away, and the nation's white minority- sensing the coming crisis - are beginning to leave. The British High Commission has lodged a record number of applications for passports.

'This country is facing its worst economic crisis in 20 years,' says Ibbo Mandaza, editor-in-chief of the African Political and Economic Monthly . 'And Mugabe won't accept any share of the blame - neither for the corruption, nor the mismanagement. It's difficult to see how he can hang on to power.'

In his desperation, Mugabe has turned on the nation's white minority, accusing them of conspiring with his opponents to destabilise the country, returning to the anti-white axioms that were the mainstay of his early political career.

Mugabe formed his party, the Zimbabwe African National Union in 1963, and used it to advocate deposing the white government of Rhodesia (as the country was then known) by force. He was jailed for ten years in 1964, for speaking out against the Prime Minister Ian Smith. 'The time has come for African rule,' he said then.

After his election, Mugabe tempered his socialist leanings and finally deleted all references to Marxism-Leninism - his party's creed - from the nation's constitution in 1991. But much of Mugabe's latter years have been marred by massive party corruption that has left his legacy in ruins.

Last month's draft constitution was riddled with controversy, as opponents accused Mugabe of handpicking the Constitutional Commission's 400 members. At least 200 were politicians from Mugabe's party.

On top of this crass manipulation, Zimbabwe has been brought to a grinding halt by fuel shortages, while prices for basic commodities have rocketed. 'The corruption indicates a party too long in power,' says Ibbo Mandaza. 'The result of this corruption is a hugely devalued currency, and inflated prices.'

Mugabe's desperate political miscalculations are instantly apparent in the farm seizures that shocked wealthy whites. A total of 4,400 white farmers own more than half the country's productive land. War veterans captured 443 farms throughout the country, disrupting production and antagonising workers.

Mugabe has endorsed the attacks, citing the squatters' actions as a protest against Zimbabwe's colonial heritage.

Richard Brooker, 54, has lived in Zimbabwe his whole life. Until last week, he owned four farms 30 miles north of Harare. But 50 war veterans moved in a week ago yesterday. In the ensuing argument, Brooker was told to vacate his farm with only what he could carry. A security team of five veterans is installed in the farmhouse, as the remainder capture other farms in the area.

Brooker acknowledges that he knew land resettlement for black farmers was coming. 'I'm not against the idea of establishing black farms, even as a businessman,' he says.

'But there have to be parameters; you just can't have people charging in and taking control of all we've built. I don't know how much longer I can live in this country. This isn't an issue about land - it's Mugabe's way of clinging onto power.'

Standing on the balcony that now acts as a look-out post on Brooker's farm, the veterans' leader, Joshua Ndiweni, defends his soldiers' invasions with revolutionary rhetoric. 'This is African soil. This is Zimbabwean soil. We don't need whites here. Why should they be farming on our land? Why should they make the profits?'

These war veterans are proving unpopular allies for Mugabe, however. Last Thursday leaders of the Zimbabwe National Liberation War Veterans' Association said that, if Mugabe lost the April elections, they would rather the country be run by a military government than by the opposition. .

Such statements are likely to appal an electorate that still remembers Mugabe's long, weary bush war of the Seventies. And Mugabe's past resettlement schemes for black farmers have had disastrous results for the economy. Since 1980, the Zimbabwean government has purchased more than 8.3 million acres of land from white farmers, yet much of the land remains under-utilised. And Mugabe's populist gesture to shore up his flagging support has ignored the reality of poorly trained peasant farmers with little financial support.

'It's no good giving the land back to people who don't know what to do with it,' says Colin Cloete, of Zimbabwe's Commercial Farmers' Union. 'What could be more unproductive? This country is in deep financial crisis.'

Political pundits in Harare say Mugabe has twice been asked to step down in recent weeks by party members horrified by the economic disruptions caused by the invasions.

'His Cabinet is split,' says Masipula Sithole, Mugabe's opponent in the 1996 elections, and politics professor at the University of Zimbabwe. 'His Ministers know African nationalism is no substitute for food in the belly.'

fields.headline: Communists defect as Putin heads for triumph bandwagon
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: At a gathering in a stuffy Moscow basement early on Friday morning, the leaders of Russia's Communist youth movement had a revolutionary announcement to make.
fields.body:
At a gathering in a stuffy Moscow basement early on Friday morning, the leaders of Russia's Communist youth movement had a revolutionary announcement to make.

Komsomol members should vote against the only Communist candidate in next Sunday's presidential elections, the movement's leader declared. Instead, they should opt for acting President Vladimir Putin - a man who claims no affection for the Communist Party and de-scribes socialist ideology as a spent force.

Igor Malyarov, a pallid, middle-aged man squeezed into a tight-fitting Soviet-era suit, gazed fiercely through tinted glasses at his audience and, spitting with passion, proclaimed: 'I call on the patriotic Communist youth of our country not to vote for Gennady Zyuganov.'

Putin remained something of a dark horse, Malyarov conceded, but he had notched up numerous accomplishments, notably the war in Chechnya, which were 'precisely what modern Russian society needs'.

It was the most humiliating blow for Communist leader Zyuganov, who is doomed to take second place when Russia votes next week. Despite an arduous campaign, Zyuganov has lost crucial ground to Putin, who has shrewdly appealed to the same nationalist sympathies of the Communists' core voters. A poll last week suggested that 25 per cent of those who voted Communist in the December parliamentary elections were now preparing to vote for Putin.

The Komsomol movement, which at its prime boasted millions of members, was created to instill Communist values in Russians at an early age. One of its pioneers declared after the 1917 Revolution: 'Children, like soft wax, are very malleable and they should be moulded into good Communists.'

Today the dwindling organisation continues to unite the country's remaining Communist youth (aged from 13 to 35), but these modern young Communists, no longer as pliable as they were in the aftermath of the Revolution, have no qualms about abandoning their leader in favour of the amorphous figure of Putin.

Dmitry Dubovsky, 20, an engineering student and secretary of the Komsomol's Moscow branch, admitted Putin would get his vote. 'He is young, tough, energetic, educated and knows how to take decisions,' he said. 'Zyuganov represents the worst in our society. I don't like the way he looks, I don't like the way he talks. Every time I hear him on television I get irritated."

The Komsomol defection followed higher-profile desertions. The magnetism of Putin's guaranteed victory has attracted a rival party, the Union of Right Forces, to endorse him - abandoning one ofits own leaders who is standing against Putin. And Moscow's Mayor, Yury Luzhkov, announced that his Fatherland movement was also ready to support Putin - under certain conditions.

Last week Zyuganov travelled across Russia in a last-ditch attempt to boost his popularity. The latest stage of his panache-free campaign was a trip to a medical school in a radiation-polluted town in the Urals, where he tried to charm the women into voting for him - greeting every female student he met with an awkward grin, and the words: 'Hello, beautiful.'

It was not a success. Irina Sharupova, 22, said: 'I don't think I'll be voting for him. His ideas are dying ideas. We don't need more dying.'

Although he refuses publicly to admit defeat, Zyuganov knows he has no chance. Latest ratings put his support at about 20 per cent, way behind Putin's 58 per cent.

During the last presidential race in 1996, Boris Yeltsin's advisers paid Zyuganov the compliment of demonising him and his party to motivate the electorate, characterising the election as a battle of Red versus White - a fight between Communist revival and liberal principles. This time, however, Zyuganov's party has become an irrelevance in Putin's unstoppable charge for the Kremlin. The well-organised Communist Party cannot help Zyuganov. Even Putin admitted recently that the Communists were 'the only really strong, really big party with a firm social base'.

But Putin's appeal has flourished without such structural support - nurtured instead by the more powerful force of TV coverage. With Putin's every move as acting President guaranteed coverage, Zyuganov is unable to compete.

The policy statements of Putin and Zyuganov have little to distinguish them - both playing on the need to restore Russia's greatness. Instead, the race is increasingly about personalities. Pitched against the stumbling, slurring Yeltsin, Zyuganov, 56, could present himself in a youthful, relatively sane, energetic mould. But now, alongside the relatively dynamic Putin, 47, he appears bumbling and without charisma.

Communists will turn out to vote however foul the weather next Sunday, and Zyuganov may be able to comfort himself with the thought that Putin's supporters are seen as more complacent, and less likely to turn out on the day. But the comfort is a slim one.

fields.headline: Russia backs 'nurse killer' in Chechnya
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: One of the Kremlin's candidates to rule Chechnya is the man the Chechen government-in-exile holds responsible for the murder of six Red Cross nurses in 1996.
fields.body:
One of the Kremlin's candidates to rule Chechnya is the man the Chechen government-in-exile holds responsible for the murder of six Red Cross nurses in 1996.

Adam Deniyev, self-styled president of the Movement for Chechen Revival, is also singled out in a US State Department report last year as a suspect for the worst loss suffered by the world's oldest humanitarian organisation.

Andrei Babitsky, the Radio Liberty reporter who disappeared for a month after Russian troops handed him over to 'Chechen rebels' in a prisoner exchange widely held to be a fraud, also blames Deniyev for his imprisonment. He says Deniyev's forces detained him until international pressure forced Moscow to order his release.

The charges against Moscow's favourite Chechen - rumoured to be closely linked to the FSB, the new name for the KGB - will be an embarrassment to the Kremlin and to Tony Blair, who last week in St Petersburg defended acting President Vladimir Putin's war against what he called 'terrorism from Chechnya'.

No charges have been filed in the investigation into the atrocity, the worst in the 136 years of the Red Cross. Six nurses were found shot dead in their beds. Thierry Meyrat, head of the Red Cross delegation in Russia, described the killings as a 'professional assassination', but had no idea who was behind them.

One Chechen woman who worked for the Red Cross at Novye Atagi hospital, near the capital, Grozny, said: 'It never made sense to us that Chechens were responsible for these killings. They were helping our people.'

The State Department's 1998 report on human rights practices in Russia states: 'Chechen authorities named Adam Deniyev, who they said was an ethnic Chechen working as a colonel in the Russian army, as the individual who has organised the killings of the aid workers. Russia's Ministry of Interior had promised to surrender Deniyev, if his guilt could be proved.' The report added that the Chechens said they had sent to Moscow sufficient information to implicate Deniyev, but the Russians had failed to hand him over for questioning.

Deniyev, according to Chechen sources in Britain, Denmark and Georgia, is a man with an interesting past. Aged 40, he comes from the Chechen village of Avtoura in the foothills of the Black Mountains. In the 1980s he went to Baghdad. The Russians have long been friendly with the Iraqi regime, supplying men and material.

In the early 1990s, Deniyev was spotted by fellow Chechens in Russian uniform with the rank of colonel. He returned home, but was expelled from Avtoura, accused of being responsible for the murder of four Chechen villagers. Reportedly, he shot a rival dead, and while his family were preparing for the funeral his men attacked the house with a rocket-propelled grenade.

He returned to Iraq in 1993 and 1994, and then was based in Moscow, where he established a warehouse business. He is accompanied by armed Chechen bodyguards when he moves around Moscow, according to the Chechen sources.

Deniyev is not accused of carrying out the Red Cross murders personally, but ordering his pro-Moscow Chechen subordinates to do so.

Acting President Vladimir Putin has reacted to The Observer 's story last week, detailing suspicions that the FSB bombed Moscow last autumn to trigger public support for the Chechen war. He dismissed the allegations as 'delirious nonsense'.

fields.headline: @large
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Silicon.com | Dogzbollox.com
fields.body:
The commies are coming

Silicon.com, the online zine for the IT community, is causing eyebrows to move in a northerly direction. The Internet mag has published its e-economy Agenda Setters 2000 Top 50 list and some of the inclusions come from the far reaches of the left field. Chris Gent, boss of Vodafone, tops the table, followed by Steve Case, chairman of AOL. Fair enough. But Jiang Zemin, general secretary of the Chinese communist party's central committee is at number nine?

Northern zeal
Sign of the times? More than two in five people looking to change their mortgage will consider using the Internet to find the right deal according to E-loan, the online mortgage site. Apparently Scots and northerners are more enthusiastic about the idea than their southern counterparts.

Manx mecca
The current bidding war for the next generation of mobile phone licences - which allow wireless Internet access - may be heating up over here, but one part of the UK will be ready way before the rest of us. BT and Manx Telecom, its wholly owned subsidiary, are set to launch Europe's first commercial universal mobile telecommunications service on the Isle of Man. And you thought Finland was at the cutting edge of mobile technology.

All in a name
We await with interest the inevitable flotation of this week's featured e-business. Dogzbollox.com is a software and media house specialising in providing email and Wireless Application Protocol services. Its slogan is 'email with attitude'. Can't quite see Chris Gent putting it on his acquisitions hit list. Just think of the fun the headline writers would have. 'Vodafone eyes...'

webTitle: Now the Iron Chancellor  must show his mettle

fields.headline: Now the Iron Chancellor  must show his mettle
fields.standfirst:
Companies in the 'old' and 'new' economies are battling for the Chancellor's attention as he prepares to show his fiscal hand. Oliver Morgan, Emily Bell and Ben Laurance report
Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Companies in the 'old' and 'new' economies are battling for the Chancellor's attention as he prepares to show his fiscal hand.
fields.body:
When Gordon Brown rises to deliver his Budget speech on Tuesday, two distinct business constituencies will be hoping for his wholehearted - and more importantly his fiscal - support.

Newly minted dot.com executives will be keeping their fingers crossed that the Government's rallying cry for the weightless economy will translate into further tax breaks on their share options, tax credits for research and other routes to unfettered wealth. In contrast, captains of old British industry - the sort that employs hundreds of thousands of traditional Labour voters who see Brown as their champion in government - will be agonising over every word, scouring them for every penny of help he can offer. Will he notice them?

The signs for the old economy are not good. The Government seems infatuated by 'entrepreneurship', by 'new', 'knowledge-based', 'high-tech' companies and by business start-ups. BMW said as much as it abandoned ship at Rover.

Meanwhile 'old economy' companies - which wearily point out that they are the real seat of high--tech, knowledge-based Britain - groan that they are punished by the high pound, higher taxes, and inertia.

While Harland and Wolff, the 180-year old Belfast shipbuilder, goes to the wall complaining that the Government did not lend it enough support, Lastminute.com screeches on to the market with a dubious valuation model and a temporary market capitalisation of £750 million. Then it plummeted. Although it may only be a matter of perception, the importance of the enterprise economy seems to many to be overstated - and disproportionate in terms of the Government.

To be fair, it is not all one-way traffic from Westminster. Earlier this month Brown reinforced warnings from Howard Davies, head of the Financial Services Authority, about the danger of investing in dot.com stocks. But the Chancellor's rhetoric has been tilted unmistakably towards the new economy. In his Pre-Budget Report speech in Parliament last autumn, he stressed that in Britain the potential of new markets, new technologies and new skills had historically been 'squandered'.

He said Britain had only half the rate of business start- ups and share ownership of the US, and added: 'The British economy needs high levels of investment and entrepreneurship.'

Part of the Government's strategy has been to aim its new measures at the small businesses which it hopes will be the tomorrow's Microsofts. In his pre-Budget statement Brown said: 'Enterprise for all calls for a larger number of small businesses.'

However, as Lucy Chennels of the Institute for Fiscal Studies points out: 'Small does not mean new - you could be talking about bakers as well as Internet start-ups.'

Equally, as Martin Temple of the 'old economy' Engineering Employers Federation says: 'Rolls-Royce is an "old" company, but it is an extremely high-tech company. Companies like this are the true technology companies.'

This may be so. But whether small is a proxy for new does not alter the fact that new is where the effort is going.

Chennells says measures introduced since the last election which have impacted primarily on big business have been nasty. 'These measure have been broadly revenue raising, and so broadly negative,' she says.

For example, changes in taxation of dividend income introduced in the July 1997 Budget are estimated to bring in between £4 billion and £5bn a year, largely from shareholders in big businesses.

And the introduction in March 1998 of a new Corporation Tax system, requiring companies to pay the tax quarterly, increases the burden over the four-year introduction period. These payments outweigh the benefits of cuts in Corporation Tax rates, from 33 to 30 per cent since 1997.

At the same time Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) have been in luck since 1997. Cuts in Corporation Tax from 23 to 20 per cent for SMEs and to 10 per cent for the smallest companies, coupled with targeted boosts in capital allowances, produce a benefit of just over £1bn. There is more to come for small businesses. The 2000 package is likely to be the most New Economy-focused of all. The Budget is likely to include the following measures for small business:

 An all-employee share ownership scheme that gives tax relief on shares in small companies.

 An Enterprise Management Incentives Scheme giving tax relief on share options for 10 key employees of small companies;

 Reform of capital gains tax on business assets to shorten the period over which they have to be held to be free of tax when they are sold. At the moment assets have to be held for 10 years: this will be shortened to five;

 Tax relief for investment by large firms in small ones worth 20 per cent of the investment;

 An extension to research and development tax credits allowing small companies which invest more than £25,000 in R&D to deduct £150 from taxable profits for every £100 spent.

In addition, Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers has already introduced an enterprise initiative, with £245m of Government money, aimed at attracting a further £755m from the private sector to invest in small companies in deprived regions.

Two big questions arise from these initiatives. First, is the Government losing sight of the big picture by focusing on the new economy, which could be harmful? Second, will its strategy work?

Ian Brinkley, senior economist at the Trades Union Congress, is concerned that the focus on the new economy is unbalancing the Government's attempts to reform the whole economy - particularly the 'productivity gap' between the UK and US and European economies.

He says: 'The initiative behind the Government's productivity drive across the economy has given way to promoting the Internet and high-tech companies. The original debate - for example how do you encourage R&D and long-term investment in companies - has run out of steam. Now it is focusing on tax schemes for start-ups.'

In its respected Green Budget - which examines the Chancellor's policy options - the IFS finds that there is no clear-cut justification for taxing smaller companies differently from bigger ones.

But it also states: 'There are potential dangers in tilting the balance of the econ omy in favour of smaller firms. There is convincing evidence that, on average, small firms tend to provide lower productivity, lower wages and less secure jobs than larger companies.' This, it said, could have a 'perverse impact' on productivity.

Old-economy companies believe they are about to take a further tax hammering on top of missing out on perks limited to smaller companies. Temple, of the Engineering Employers' Federation, says: 'If you look at the burden of taxation on business since 1997, it has increased.'

The travails of industries in Britain's 'old' economy have only added to the pressure on Brown to retreat from the apparently green stance taken in the Budget a year ago.

Already, Brown has climbed down on several key issues on which his green credentials were founded. Last autumn, he bowed to pressure to limit the 'climate change levy' - the tax on industries' use of energy. He agreed to cut the levy by 80 per cent on industries deemed to be 'energy intensive'. The mere fact that he conceded the principle inevitably opened the floodgates; other industries which don't quite qualify for the rebate but are nevertheless heavy energy users are now pressing for inclusion in the rebate scheme.

Brown has also backtracked on his promise to raise fuel prices annually by at least 6 per cent more than inflation - a decision that followed a high-profile and populist campaign waged by the road haulage industry against heavier taxes.

From the Exchequer's point of view, petrol and diesel have the great virtue of not being vulnerable to large- scale smuggling: people may bring vans full of cheap cigarettes into the country, but they are less likely to try to smuggle a tankerload of petrol. The Freight Transport Association wants any increase in fuel costs to be offset by cuts in vehicle excise duty The FTA asserts that excise duty on a 40-tonne, five-axle articulated lorry is £5,750 in Britain, compared with £1,720 in Germany and just £450 in France.

The green argument for higher duty on fuel is hard to fault. Evidence over the past three decades suggests strongly that when people have to pay more for their fuel in real terms, they feel inclined to buy more fuel-efficient vehicles. In other words, high prices really do suppress demand for fuel; and that in turn suppresses emissions of greenhouse gases.

But the Treasury does not relish the prospect of a rerun of last year's campaign against increases in duty. Any increase is likely to be only 1 or 2 per cent in real terms. And it may be offset by a cut in the duty on trucks.

Fuel taxes and the climate change levy are the main battle grounds on which the environmental arguments have been played out. But the Government is also setting targets for electricity companies to increase the proportion of electricity they produce from renewable resources. And it wants a doubling of combined heat and power plants by 2010.

Beyond the Budget there are measures that will add to transport costs - such as company car parking taxes. Of course, it is true to say that petrol and parking taxes affect small companies as well as big. But they all erode the ability of 'old-economy' British businesses to compete.

Ironically, it is perhaps lack of action that is hurting most. Not only are all the goodies stacked towards new companies, but big business watches the inactivity on calming the hot spots of the economy - particularly the housing market - with dismay.

Traditional manufacturers, particularly those who are net exporters, are being hammered by the high value of sterling - which has averaged DM2.95 under Labour - about 10 per cent overvalued according to City economists. Companies from BMW, Rover's estranged parent, to Corus, the Anglo-Dutch company which includes former British Steel, have posed question marks over UK-sourced products and plants - such as Longbridge in Birmingham and the Llanwern strip steel mill in Wales.

Ian Rogers of the UK Steel Association says: 'The exchange rate has been a big problem since 1997. The Government says there is little it can do about it because responsibility for interest rates rests with the Monetary Policy Committee. But we have been arguing for some time the need for a balance between fis cal and monetary policy to ease pressure on sterling.'

Rogers and Temple agree that there are a series of measures that should be considered. These include calming the housing market by raising stamp duty on housing transactions - a possibility on Tuesday - or increasing capital gains tax on short-term property deals. Temple also thinks savings should be encouraged more by increasing the amounts that can be put into Individual Savings Accounts from £7,000 in the first year and £5,000 thereafter.

Big business might understand the Government's attention to small companies if it was clear that its policies were sure to work. But in the view of many experts, their validity is unproven. So, do the new economy measures add up to much?

The Institute of Fiscal Studies' analysis of proposed Budget 2000 measures is sceptical about the benefits. On employee share ownership, for example, it indicates that there are already two schemes in place, and says the evidence from these is that they are more popular with larger firms.

Employees of small companies who take part risk losing both salaries and savings if their company is hit. Evidence that schemes increase productivity is also thin.

On changes to capital gains tax it says that, because large financial investors don't pay CGT and individuals can avoid it through other Government schemes, 'it is not obvious that reducing capital gains tax rates on business assets will have a large impact on the level of investment'.

And on R&D tax credits the IFS says: 'Restricting the measure to small companies will lower the cost to the Gov ernment but will also reduce the additional R&D that is likely to be generated.'

All in all, Chennells is sceptical. 'What they are doing would seem to be targeted at small and new companies. That would be great if we could guarantee that a lot of small businesses could do what Microsoft has done. But it is hard to predict which companies will.'

On top of this, the limited resources being spent on the new/small business schemes are not really proportionate to the importance attached to them. There may be heat. But is there light?

Chennells says: 'The Government's response would be that we are targeting measures so they don't cost very much and focus on areas we want to develop. So it is spending small amounts of money on small companies when they account for a relatively small part of UK investment.'

Perhaps more perplexing for Brown is that despite wanting the Government to be seen as entrepreneur-friendly, there is a growing clamour from dot.com start-ups and other consultancy operators that in fact the weightless economy is being suppressed.

Barry Watson, a tax partner at PriceWaterhouseCoopers, says that the situation with regard to taxing share options is extremely grave.

'Most people considering leaving jobs for a start-up will go because, while the salary may be lower, they will pick up a large tranche of share options. But the problem is that first of all they will face a 40 per cent tax, and in addition a further 10 per cent in National Insurance Contributions. When you add up what this means for start-ups who have to use options as an incentive it is absolutely horrifying,' says Watson. In some cases, companies will face larger bills for NI contributions on share options than they have revenues.

In addition to this the employee faces a potential capital gains tax bill of a further 40 per cent when cashing out of their start-up. 'In the US this would be 20 per cent. The UK compares very unfavourably in terms of competing on the CGT front in Europe as well as the US,' says Watson.

Against this background, many exponents of the 'new economy' complain that they, or their businesses, would be better relocating offshore.

In addition, the introduction of the dreaded 'IR 35' is infuriating consultants - and in particular IT professionals, who are now not allowed to count themselves as self-employed and enjoy the tax benefits which traditionally went with them. 'This seems a very strange way to encourage the flexible labour market,' says one consultant.

The Treasury may argue that it is being prudent with taxpayers' money. But this really points to the paradox at the centre of the whole policy. We have a highly successful but risk-averse Chancellor trying to encourage essentially risky entrepreneurialism without placing significant public funds in jeopardy.

This strategy makes it impossible to help those most in need - old economy companies. But Brown will also be aware that his job is creating the right climate for growth - if certain plants fail it may be the head gardener, the DTI's Byers, who carries the can.

Will he notice them? The signs for the old economy are not good. The Government seems infatuated by 'entrepreneurship', by 'new', 'knowledge-based', 'high-tech' companies and by business start-ups. BMW said as much as it abandoned ship at Rover. Meanwhile 'old economy' companies - which wearily point out that they are the real seat of high--tech, knowledge-based Britain - groan that they are punished by the high pound, higher taxes, and inertia. While Harland and Wolff, the 180-year old Belfast shipbuilder, goes to the wall complaining that the Government did not lend it enough support, Lastminute.com screeches on to the market with a dubious valuation model and a temporary market capitalisation of £750 million. Then it plummeted. Although it may only be a matter of perception, the importance of the enterprise economy seems to many to be overstated - and disproportionate in terms of the Government. To be fair, it is not all one-way traffic from Westminster. Earlier this month Brown reinforced warnings from Howard Davies, head of the Financial Services Authority, about the danger of investing in dot.com stocks. But the Chancellor's rhetoric has been tilted unmistakably towards the new economy. In his Pre-Budget Report speech in Parliament last autumn, he stressed that in Britain the potential of new markets, new technologies and new skills had historically been 'squandered'. He said Britain had only half the rate of business start- ups and share ownership of the US, and added: 'The British economy needs high levels of investment and entrepreneurship.' Part of the Government's strategy has been to aim its new measures at the small businesses which it hopes will be the tomorrow's Microsofts. In his pre-Budget statement Brown said: 'Enterprise for all calls for a larger number of small businesses.' However, as Lucy Chennels of the Institute for Fiscal Studies points out: 'Small does not mean new - you could be talking about bakers as well as Internet start-ups.' Equally, as Martin Temple of the 'old economy' Engineering Employers Federation says: 'Rolls-Royce is an "old" company, but it is an extremely high-tech company. Companies like this are the true technology companies.' This may be so. But whether small is a proxy for new does not alter the fact that new is where the effort is going. Chennells says measures introduced since the last election which have impacted primarily on big business have been nasty. 'These measure have been broadly revenue raising, and so broadly negative,' she says. For example, changes in taxation of dividend income introduced in the July 1997 Budget are estimated to bring in between £4 billion and £5bn a year, largely from shareholders in big businesses. And the introduction in March 1998 of a new Corporation Tax system, requiring companies to pay the tax quarterly, increases the burden over the four-year introduction period. These payments outweigh the benefits of cuts in Corporation Tax rates, from 33 to 30 per cent since 1997. At the same time Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) have been in luck since 1997. Cuts in Corporation Tax from 23 to 20 per cent for SMEs and to 10 per cent for the smallest companies, coupled with targeted boosts in capital allowances, produce a benefit of just over £1bn. There is more to come for small businesses. The 2000 package is likely to be the most New Economy-focused of all. The Budget is likely to include the following measures for small business:  An all-employee share ownership scheme that gives tax relief on shares in small companies.  An Enterprise Management Incentives Scheme giving tax relief on share options for 10 key employees of small companies;  Reform of capital gains tax on business assets to shorten the period over which they have to be held to be free of tax when they are sold. At the moment assets have to be held for 10 years: this will be shortened to five;  Tax relief for investment by large firms in small ones worth 20 per cent of the investment;  An extension to research and development tax credits allowing small companies which invest more than £25,000 in R&D to deduct £150 from taxable profits for every £100 spent. In addition, Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers has already introduced an enterprise initiative, with £245m of Government money, aimed at attracting a further £755m from the private sector to invest in small companies in deprived regions. Two big questions arise from these initiatives. First, is the Government losing sight of the big picture by focusing on the new economy, which could be harmful? Second, will its strategy work? Ian Brinkley, senior economist at the Trades Union Congress, is concerned that the focus on the new economy is unbalancing the Government's attempts to reform the whole economy - particularly the 'productivity gap' between the UK and US and European economies. He says: 'The initiative behind the Government's productivity drive across the economy has given way to promoting the Internet and high-tech companies. The original debate - for example how do you encourage R&D and long-term investment in companies - has run out of steam. Now it is focusing on tax schemes for start-ups.' In its respected Green Budget - which examines the Chancellor's policy options - the IFS finds that there is no clear-cut justification for taxing smaller companies differently from bigger ones. But it also states: 'There are potential dangers in tilting the balance of the econ omy in favour of smaller firms. There is convincing evidence that, on average, small firms tend to provide lower productivity, lower wages and less secure jobs than larger companies.' This, it said, could have a 'perverse impact' on productivity. Old-economy companies believe they are about to take a further tax hammering on top of missing out on perks limited to smaller companies. Temple, of the Engineering Employers' Federation, says: 'If you look at the burden of taxation on business since 1997, it has increased.' The travails of industries in Britain's 'old' economy have only added to the pressure on Brown to retreat from the apparently green stance taken in the Budget a year ago. Already, Brown has climbed down on several key issues on which his green credentials were founded. Last autumn, he bowed to pressure to limit the 'climate change levy' - the tax on industries' use of energy. He agreed to cut the levy by 80 per cent on industries deemed to be 'energy intensive'. The mere fact that he conceded the principle inevitably opened the floodgates; other industries which don't quite qualify for the rebate but are nevertheless heavy energy users are now pressing for inclusion in the rebate scheme. Brown has also backtracked on his promise to raise fuel prices annually by at least 6 per cent more than inflation - a decision that followed a high-profile and populist campaign waged by the road haulage industry against heavier taxes. From the Exchequer's point of view, petrol and diesel have the great virtue of not being vulnerable to large- scale smuggling: people may bring vans full of cheap cigarettes into the country, but they are less likely to try to smuggle a tankerload of petrol. The Freight Transport Association wants any increase in fuel costs to be offset by cuts in vehicle excise duty The FTA asserts that excise duty on a 40-tonne, five-axle articulated lorry is £5,750 in Britain, compared with £1,720 in Germany and just £450 in France. The green argument for higher duty on fuel is hard to fault. Evidence over the past three decades suggests strongly that when people have to pay more for their fuel in real terms, they feel inclined to buy more fuel-efficient vehicles. In other words, high prices really do suppress demand for fuel; and that in turn suppresses emissions of greenhouse gases. But the Treasury does not relish the prospect of a rerun of last year's campaign against increases in duty. Any increase is likely to be only 1 or 2 per cent in real terms. And it may be offset by a cut in the duty on trucks. Fuel taxes and the climate change levy are the main battle grounds on which the environmental arguments have been played out. But the Government is also setting targets for electricity companies to increase the proportion of electricity they produce from renewable resources. And it wants a doubling of combined heat and power plants by 2010. Beyond the Budget there are measures that will add to transport costs - such as company car parking taxes. Of course, it is true to say that petrol and parking taxes affect small companies as well as big. But they all erode the ability of 'old-economy' British businesses to compete. Ironically, it is perhaps lack of action that is hurting most. Not only are all the goodies stacked towards new companies, but big business watches the inactivity on calming the hot spots of the economy - particularly the housing market - with dismay. Traditional manufacturers, particularly those who are net exporters, are being hammered by the high value of sterling - which has averaged DM2.95 under Labour - about 10 per cent overvalued according to City economists. Companies from BMW, Rover's estranged parent, to Corus, the Anglo-Dutch company which includes former British Steel, have posed question marks over UK-sourced products and plants - such as Longbridge in Birmingham and the Llanwern strip steel mill in Wales. Ian Rogers of the UK Steel Association says: 'The exchange rate has been a big problem since 1997. The Government says there is little it can do about it because responsibility for interest rates rests with the Monetary Policy Committee. But we have been arguing for some time the need for a balance between fis cal and monetary policy to ease pressure on sterling.' Rogers and Temple agree that there are a series of measures that should be considered. These include calming the housing market by raising stamp duty on housing transactions - a possibility on Tuesday - or increasing capital gains tax on short-term property deals. Temple also thinks savings should be encouraged more by increasing the amounts that can be put into Individual Savings Accounts from £7,000 in the first year and £5,000 thereafter. Big business might understand the Government's attention to small companies if it was clear that its policies were sure to work. But in the view of many experts, their validity is unproven. So, do the new economy measures add up to much? The Institute of Fiscal Studies' analysis of proposed Budget 2000 measures is sceptical about the benefits. On employee share ownership, for example, it indicates that there are already two schemes in place, and says the evidence from these is that they are more popular with larger firms. Employees of small companies who take part risk losing both salaries and savings if their company is hit. Evidence that schemes increase productivity is also thin. On changes to capital gains tax it says that, because large financial investors don't pay CGT and individuals can avoid it through other Government schemes, 'it is not obvious that reducing capital gains tax rates on business assets will have a large impact on the level of investment'. And on R&D tax credits the IFS says: 'Restricting the measure to small companies will lower the cost to the Gov ernment but will also reduce the additional R&D that is likely to be generated.' All in all, Chennells is sceptical. 'What they are doing would seem to be targeted at small and new companies. That would be great if we could guarantee that a lot of small businesses could do what Microsoft has done. But it is hard to predict which companies will.' On top of this, the limited resources being spent on the new/small business schemes are not really proportionate to the importance attached to them. There may be heat. But is there light? Chennells says: 'The Government's response would be that we are targeting measures so they don't cost very much and focus on areas we want to develop. So it is spending small amounts of money on small companies when they account for a relatively small part of UK investment.' Perhaps more perplexing for Brown is that despite wanting the Government to be seen as entrepreneur-friendly, there is a growing clamour from dot.com start-ups and other consultancy operators that in fact the weightless economy is being suppressed. Barry Watson, a tax partner at PriceWaterhouseCoopers, says that the situation with regard to taxing share options is extremely grave. 'Most people considering leaving jobs for a start-up will go because, while the salary may be lower, they will pick up a large tranche of share options. But the problem is that first of all they will face a 40 per cent tax, and in addition a further 10 per cent in National Insurance Contributions. When you add up what this means for start-ups who have to use options as an incentive it is absolutely horrifying,' says Watson. In some cases, companies will face larger bills for NI contributions on share options than they have revenues. In addition to this the employee faces a potential capital gains tax bill of a further 40 per cent when cashing out of their start-up. 'In the US this would be 20 per cent. The UK compares very unfavourably in terms of competing on the CGT front in Europe as well as the US,' says Watson. Against this background, many exponents of the 'new economy' complain that they, or their businesses, would be better relocating offshore. In addition, the introduction of the dreaded 'IR 35' is infuriating consultants - and in particular IT professionals, who are now not allowed to count themselves as self-employed and enjoy the tax benefits which traditionally went with them. 'This seems a very strange way to encourage the flexible labour market,' says one consultant. The Treasury may argue that it is being prudent with taxpayers' money. But this really points to the paradox at the centre of the whole policy. We have a highly successful but risk-averse Chancellor trying to encourage essentially risky entrepreneurialism without placing significant public funds in jeopardy. This strategy makes it impossible to help those most in need - old economy companies. But Brown will also be aware that his job is creating the right climate for growth - if certain plants fail it may be the head gardener, the DTI's Byers, who carries the can.

fields.headline: Gordon's a tonic for poor
fields.standfirst:
But is he all fizz? Oliver Morgan reports
Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: If you are a married man with children, with a job in a high-risk Internet company that pays a small wage and lots of shares but which could leave you penniless next month... If you don't care much about pollution and bought your house in the South-east in the early Nineties recession... If you don't smoke or drink, have no private health insurance and run an efficient car... then Gordon Brown's Budget will be for you.
fields.body:
If you are a married man with children, with a job in a high-risk Internet company that pays a small wage and lots of shares but which could leave you penniless next month... If you don't care much about pollution and bought your house in the South-east in the early Nineties recession... If you don't smoke or drink, have no private health insurance and run an efficient car... then Gordon Brown's Budget will be for you.

We have all heard that the Chancellor is a traditional old Labour wealth redistributor. So the sorts of people mentioned above are those towards whom the rest of our wealth has been redistributed in his two Budgets since 1997, and they are likely to benefit in his third on Tuesday.

If you are among them, you will have benefited from a raft of child-friendly policies. Your decision to take up your old school friend's offer to join him in dot.comland means that your £10,000 pay will be lightly taxed, thanks to a 10p starting rate of tax.

But from April the 20 per cent of the firm he gave you in shares won't be subject to income tax, capital gains tax or National Insurance contributions, if you keep them for five years, thanks to Brown.

If it does not work out and your wages are cut you will be eased into a more generous benefit and tax credit system.

If you do end up out of work, the New Deal for the unemployed will be there to help with training, or to find another job for you. And com ing back into work you will find you do not face the 100 per cent-plus effective tax rate which existed in the past.

Of course, if you are reading this, whoever you are, you are not only Gordon Brown's number one fan, you are also probably unique.

For the rest of us, the key question is whether the clever occupant of Number 11 has taken or given to us since he became Chancellor. For Brown the key question is whether we have noticed.

So who should be grateful? Have Middle Englanders gained over traditional Labour voters, families over individuals, men over women, the young over the elderly, southerners over northerners?

The problem giving Labour's Millbank apparatchicks the collywobbles is the alienation felt by traditional Labour voters over the policies of 'Tory Tony'.

On one level the tax breaks for small businesses introduced by the Chancellor, and the blaze of publicity surrounding the enterprise economy indicate there is something to worry about.

Nevertheless, Brown can claim that if anyone has delivered to the traditional Labour supporter it is he.

Since 1997 his tax measures, and particularly the increases in benefits, have seen the poorest 20 per cent of us increase their income after tax by more than 5 per cent.

By contrast, a series of measures impacting on the middle classes, including the abolition of mortgage interest tax relief and of the married couples' tax allowance, mean that the incomes of the wealthiest have fallen. Research by David Piachaud of the London School of Economics finds that Budget measures have had a marked impact on those in poverty, defined as on less than half average income.

Piachaud says Brown's measures have lifted 1 million families with children out of poverty. These measures include a children's element in the Working Families Tax Credit introduced by Brown to boost the former Family Credit benefit and deliver it in pay packets. On top of this come a children's tax credit - due in April next year - and higher child benefit.

Progressive macro-economic policies coupled with the New Deal have seen long-term unemployment fall by 500,000, and the minimum wage - something Brown has championed - has cut those in poverty by some 300,000.

But Piachaud finds that the poor who are also out of work have missed out, because the Jobseekers' Allowance has been uprated in line with prices, not earnings, which rise faster. He says: 'An estimated 2 million have been lifted out of poverty since the election. That's out of 14 million, so there is a lot more to do. But it is an impressive start. Simlarly, a third of the 3 million children in poverty have been lifted out.'

Ian Brinkley, senior economist at the Trades Union Congress, adds: 'If you are a family you have done reasonably well. If you are a family in work you have done very well. But it is not so good if you are of working age and poor without children and without a job, or if you are a pensioner.'

Martin Weale of the National Institute for Economic and Social Research believes Brown has concentrated resources and reformed the structure of welfare payments to ease the unemployed into work. This has been done by reducing the rate of benefit withdrawal as people move into the tax system, which before 1997 had in some cases been more than 100 per cent. In other words, they became worse off as they returned to work. However, Weale says, there is still much to do. The issue is complicated because people in different circumstances, entitled to different benefits, will have different withdrawal rates as their benefits and credits taper out.

Weale says an effective policy could be to concentrate on the withdrawal rate, setting a target of, say, 60 per cent, and focusing on delivering that figure, which is what matters to the unemployed moving into work.

The Government is floating proposals to tackle these issues by creating an Employment Tax Credit and an Integrated Child Credit to restructure the Working Families Tax Credit and Children's Tax Credit, which could ease the taper of these benefits into working wages.

The aim would be a package of benefits for children that targets unemployed families more effectively, along with extending WFTC to families without children.

The implications of such measures are dramatic. Since 1990 taxes have been paid to individuals, while benefits have been paid to families.

This has made it compli cated to introduce the WFTC because, although it has been a family measure, it has to be directed to the person in work - usually the man.

This has led women's groups to criticise tax credits as more likely to end up in the pub than in Mothercare. Proposals for a future Integrated Child Credit would pay it to the main carer, redressing the balance.

But some women think Brown should go further. Last week Labour MP Ruth Kelly pointed out that single parents are penalised by the tax credit system if they declare they are living with partners or their children's fathers. Kelly wants 'income splitting', which would add both the mother's and her partner's incomes, divide by two and calculate benefits for each half. This would introduce truer equality throughout the family, Kelly says.

Beyond issues of the family, Weale points out that savers - generally the elderly - have missed out because the Government's Individual Savings Accounts are less generous than previous Peps and Tessas - while spenders, generally younger, have found few harsh measures aimed at reining them in.

Back to the Millbank question: has Gordon done enough for Labour's core voters? Some of his measures have yet to come into operation. Possibilities, such as abolishing the 10p tax band, would further help the poor but not necessarily make tabloid headlines. And in high profile areas where the Government can claim to be addressing traditional concerns - health spending, for example - it has been beset by controversy over the double counting of figures.

Brown may have made some of the most far-reaching technical reforms to the tax system since Nigel Lawson. The question is whether he, like Lawson, proves too clever for his own good.
