webTitle: Unpleasant little things hiding in the woodwork

fields.headline: Unpleasant little things hiding in the woodwork
fields.standfirst:
Budget 2000: special report
Bank of England: Monetary Policy Committee
fields.trailText: What a wonderful position! A widely admired Chancellor, running a successful economic policy of which almost everyone approves. Output is booming, unemployment is at a 20-year low, inflation is under control, and the only question about the Budget surplus is: just how large is it?
fields.body:
What a wonderful position! A widely admired Chancellor, running a successful economic policy of which almost everyone approves. Output is booming, unemployment is at a 20-year low, inflation is under control, and the only question about the Budget surplus is: just how large is it?

As for the traditional spectre that haunted successive British Chancellors... when was the balance of payments last perceived to be a problem?

The pound? The fear - and reality - of devaluation also used to terrify Labour Chancellors of old. But sterling is strong, and investment funds are pouring into London.

The above is a precis, not a parody, of the conventional wisdom about the macro-economic background to Tuesday's Budget. But is it realistic?

Budgets are about what the present Chancellor likes to call 'tax and spend', so let us deal first with possible complications on that front.

Certainly the Treasury, can boast a healthy fiscal position. Booming consumer demand has swollen tax receipts and reduced the rate of growth of social security spending. Such has been the atmosphere of 'squeeze' engendered by the Chancellor's tough first two years that even in the current fiscal year, government spending, especially investment spending, has been less than expected.

The current Budget surplus is expected to be around £10 billion this year; and the Government appears to be in surplus to the tune of several billion. With the International Monetary Fund forecasting 3 per cent growth in gross domestic product this year, forecasts for the surplus in 2000-01 and onwards take analysts up to £20bn.

Thus, on 'current policies' the independent National Institute can see current Budget surpluses rising from £12.9bn in 2000-01 to £19.1bn in 2005-06.

But here comes the catch. At one level the Chancellor can afford a 'giveaway' Budget. The arithmetic already allows for his '1p off' income tax. But this is essentially a compensation for promised tax increases elsewhere - such as the removal of mortgage relief and of the married couple's allowance. Any 'giveaway' would have to go much further than that; and in theory the money is there for further tax cuts and increases in public spending.

But not necessarily next week. While the National Institute of Economic and Social Research calculates that the Prime Minister's 'aspiration' to give an appreciable boost to the the health service could be achieved in due course, the macro-economic scene will constrain the Chancellor.

You only have to think of how the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) has been ratcheting interest rates up to slow consumer spending and calm the property market.

The Chancellor has two choices: if he bows to populist pressures to cut taxes or introduce a major boost to public spending, this will be interpreted as inflationary by the MPC, which it will almost certainly respond by raising interest rates even more. The consequence could well be that the pound rises further - the last thing economists advising the Chancellor want.

The fact is that, beneath the conventional impression of a wonderful macro-economic position, there are some very unpleasant things in the woodwork. Recent announcements from Harland & Wolff and Rover threatening major industrial closures and widespread redundancies may result from an accumulation of long-term problems, but there is an important common factor: both companies have been hit by the strong pound. Scares at Ford also reflect the implications for profits of UK-based companies struggling to compete at an overvalued exchange rate.

In its recent report on the British economy, the IMF said: 'Given fiscal conditions and the strong real exchange rate, directors underscored the need to ensure that the fiscal stance remains supportive of monetary policy.' In plain English that means that, whatever the size of his Budget surplus, the Chancellor should not be contemplating any net tax cuts or public spending increases.

Just to ram the message home, the IMF added: 'Some directors went further to suggest that a strengthening of the real exchange rate would warrant a discretionary tightening of fiscal policy.'

This advice comes at a time when the Government is already having to admit, however reluctantly, that taxes have been rising as a proportion of gross domestic product since 1 May 1997. And the Institute for Fiscal Studies has emphasised in its prestigious Green Budget that the buoyancy of tax revenue is such that 'if the Chancellor wishes to prevent the tax burden from continuing to rise, he must cut taxes by around £3bn'.

The consensus emerging from the IFS and others is that Brown could announce tax cuts of £2bn on Tuesday - small in relation to a GDP of £800bn. He could still manage headline-catching gimmicks, while maintaining that the Budget was 'fiscally neutral' to please the MPC.

Thus, on 'current policies' the independent National Institute can see current Budget surpluses rising from £12.9bn in 2000-01 to £19.1bn in 2005-06. But here comes the catch. At one level the Chancellor can afford a 'giveaway' Budget. The arithmetic already allows for his '1p off' income tax. But this is essentially a compensation for promised tax increases elsewhere - such as the removal of mortgage relief and of the married couple's allowance. Any 'giveaway' would have to go much further than that; and in theory the money is there for further tax cuts and increases in public spending. But not necessarily next week. While the National Institute of Economic and Social Research calculates that the Prime Minister's 'aspiration' to give an appreciable boost to the the health service could be achieved in due course, the macro-economic scene will constrain the Chancellor. You only have to think of how the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) has been ratcheting interest rates up to slow consumer spending and calm the property market. The Chancellor has two choices: if he bows to populist pressures to cut taxes or introduce a major boost to public spending, this will be interpreted as inflationary by the MPC, which it will almost certainly respond by raising interest rates even more. The consequence could well be that the pound rises further - the last thing economists advising the Chancellor want. The fact is that, beneath the conventional impression of a wonderful macro-economic position, there are some very unpleasant things in the woodwork. Recent announcements from Harland & Wolff and Rover threatening major industrial closures and widespread redundancies may result from an accumulation of long-term problems, but there is an important common factor: both companies have been hit by the strong pound. Scares at Ford also reflect the implications for profits of UK-based companies struggling to compete at an overvalued exchange rate. In its recent report on the British economy, the IMF said: 'Given fiscal conditions and the strong real exchange rate, directors underscored the need to ensure that the fiscal stance remains supportive of monetary policy.' In plain English that means that, whatever the size of his Budget surplus, the Chancellor should not be contemplating any net tax cuts or public spending increases. Just to ram the message home, the IMF added: 'Some directors went further to suggest that a strengthening of the real exchange rate would warrant a discretionary tightening of fiscal policy.' This advice comes at a time when the Government is already having to admit, however reluctantly, that taxes have been rising as a proportion of gross domestic product since 1 May 1997. And the Institute for Fiscal Studies has emphasised in its prestigious Green Budget that the buoyancy of tax revenue is such that 'if the Chancellor wishes to prevent the tax burden from continuing to rise, he must cut taxes by around £3bn'. The consensus emerging from the IFS and others is that Brown could announce tax cuts of £2bn on Tuesday - small in relation to a GDP of £800bn. He could still manage headline-catching gimmicks, while maintaining that the Budget was 'fiscally neutral' to please the MPC.

webTitle: Defiant Brown to cut 1p off tax

fields.headline: Defiant Brown to cut 1p off tax
fields.standfirst: Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is set to go ahead with a 1p cut in income tax in the Budget this week, defying the growing clamour for more cash for the health service, to heal Britain's North-South divide.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown is set to go ahead with a 1p cut in income tax in the Budget this week, defying the growing clamour for more cash for the health service, to heal Britain's North-South divide.

The cut will be part of a cautious 'Budget for hard-working families'. The Chancellor is determined not to spend his massive 'war chest' - now estimated at £10 billion - on a pre-election bonanza that could ignite inflation and trigger another increase in interest rates. 'We are going to lock in the surplus,' said a senior Whitehall official.

But his insistence on courting Middle England's taxpayers is creating friction between Brown and the Prime Minister, the two of whom met at Downing Street on Friday to agree Tuesday's Budget.

After a series of blows to British industry, including the crises at Rover and Harland & Wolff, Blair is said to be nervous that the pound is too strong and the Government should be spending more on regenerating Labour heartlands. But Brown is more concerned by warnings from the International Monetary Fund and Bank of England against a spending bonanza. After last week's embarrassing admission that taxes have gone up during his Chancellorship, Brown is insisting on the 1p tax cut to mollify homeowners whose payments are about to shoot up because of the abolition of mortgage tax relief. Brown is also expected to extend the 10p tax rate.

Tax revenues have been so high during the current consumer boom that Brown would have to cut taxes by a net £3bn to escape being accused by the Tories of increasing the 'tax burden' still further.

Much of the Budget's small print is having to be decided in a last-minute rush. Privately, treasury officials complain about the difficulty of getting decisions from Brown and his tight circle of close advisers.

Brown's fear of setting off inflation is likely to bring relief to motorists. After the latest hike in world oil prices, petrol tax is unlikely to rise by more than 1p a litre, and may be frozen.

The price of a packet of cigarettes could go up by as little as 2p, with 1p on a standard size bottle of wine and 7p on spirits. Beer drinkers may escape any increase.

Families with small children are likely to benefit. Ministers were shaken last week by a survey showing Britain is still bottom of the European league for child poverty. Child benefit is to be raised by 3 per cent. Brown has also been working on a new unified tax credit for children, and has shown interest in a 'baby tax credit' which would be worth £60 a week for the first year of a child's life.

Changes to capital gains tax will please industry, and among other tax breaks there will be a cut in VAT on home renovations, as part of a policy of encouraging builders to re-use land that has already been developed instead of putting pressure on the green belt. high during the current consumer boom that Brown would have to cut taxes by a net £3bn to escape being accused by the Tories of increasing the 'tax burden' still further.

webTitle: Sick flee NHS crisis for private hospitals

fields.headline: Sick flee NHS crisis for private hospitals
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The crisis in the National Health Service is forcing unprecedented numbers of patients to buy private treatment. In a massive vote of no confidence in the NHS, which Tony Blair's Government has insisted is not in serious trouble, the number of people paying for private operations has risen by around 40 per cent since the 1997 election.
fields.body:
The crisis in the National Health Service is forcing unprecedented numbers of patients to buy private treatment. In a massive vote of no confidence in the NHS, which Tony Blair's Government has insisted is not in serious trouble, the number of people paying for private operations has risen by around 40 per cent since the 1997 election.

The figures suggest that, when it comes to their own treatment, few people trust Blair's attempts to play down the malaise gripping the service, which has led to people dying because there were too few hospital beds .

Figures obtained by The Observer from Britain's main private hospital groups indicate that the number of people paying for their own operations has risen at a far higher rate of growth than before the election.

In total, 160,000 people people borrowed money or raided their savings to pay for operations last year - almost 50,000 more than in 1996, the year before the election.

The figures are a huge embarrassment for the Labour Party, which won power on a pledge to save the NHS, and has been ideologically opposed to people paying for private treatment.

They show that a two-tier medical service - with people paying to jump waiting lists - has flourished more under Labour than under the previous Government.

Dr Liam Fox, the Shadow Health Secretary, said: 'People believed that Labour could help the NHS, but they can see it is failing, and they are voting with their wallet.'

A spokesman for the Department of Health claimed the NHS was carrying out more operations than ever, but admitted: 'People are going private because they are having to wait too long on the NHS.

'It is a reflection of the fact that for decades the NHS has been underfunded and has too little capacity. There are too few doctors and nurses, and that is what we are trying to change. It takes time.'

Mike Stone, director of the Patients' Association, said: 'People would rather pay than die. Labour were given a great opportunity to sort out the NHS, but still people are not getting the operations when they need them.'

The number of people with private medical insurance has remained fairly steady, but the figures obtained by The Observer show that all the main private hospital groups have seen a dramatic rise in the number of people paying for one-off operations.

Bupa, the largest UK private health care group, did more than 25,000 such operations last year, up 30 per cent in two years. The number grew by only 17 per cent in the two years before the election.

Dr Andrew Vallence-Owen, Bupa's medical director, said: 'About a quarter of our work is now people paying for their own treatment. There has been an increase in investigations and outpatient consultations. Open heart surgery has been increasing, there has been an increase in chemotherapy.'

Nuffield Hospitals said the number of self-pay operations has grown by 20 per cent a year for the last two years.

BMI Healthcare has seen an increase of up to 27 per cent in the last two years. Regional director Paul Preston said: 'There was a big lift in 1998 - almost an explosion - and it's carried on. We thought it was people spending building society windfalls, but they were borrowing or spending savings.'

Mark Ritson, 32, a west London firefighter who was crippled by an agonising back injury he got at work, paid £3,500 for an operation after the NHS said he would have to wait for between nine and 18 months.

'There was just no way I could wait that amount of time,' said Ritson, who was treated privately in 11 days.

fields.headline: Measure for measure
fields.standfirst: Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: So, apart from reform of inheritance tax, what else might Tuesday's Budget package include? We could hear some real news.
fields.body:
So, apart from reform of inheritance tax, what else might Tuesday's Budget package include? We could hear some real news:

 Alcohol, cigarettes and petrol: Past schemes that raised duties automatically every year - linked to the inflation rate - have been ended. So, in theory, anything is possible. But high 'sin' taxes are already encouraging people to buy things abroad and smuggle them into the UK.

 There could be a move to stop betting taxes leaking through the Internet and offshore gambling centres.

 One of the hottest tips is for another rise in the stamp duty on property transactions. Some commentators are predicting a rate as high as 5 per cent on the most expensive properties.

 Stockbrokers and private investors are hoping for a reduction, or abolition, in duty on share transactions.

The 10 per cent starting rate of income tax, introduced last year, may be extended to a higher income, perhaps £2,000 against £1,500 now. The ceiling on income liable to National Insurance contributions could be brought in line with the higher rate tax threshold. Considered an 'each way bet' by accountant KPMG.

 Insurance premium tax, which adds to the cost of most policies could rise again, possibly by 1 per cent to 5 per cent.

 There could be a new, lower rate of VAT on building work, aimed at making routine household maintenance more affordable. VAT could be introduced on new homes.

 Accountant KPMG believes we may see more detail on new tax charges on company cars.

 There could be a cut back, or phasing out, of existing employee shares schemes to make way for the new All Employee Share Option Plan, due to be introduced in April.

 Taxpayers may be offered discounts - possibly £25 - for filing self-assessment tax returns through the Internet.

 A cut in pension tax relief is regularly a topic of pre-Budget speculation, but some experts believe it unlikely given the pain caused to pension funds by abolishing tax credits on dividends.

webTitle: Hunts admit false trail on lost jobs

fields.headline: Hunts admit false trail on lost jobs
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: The Countryside Alliance, the leading pro-blood sports group, has admitted it may have exaggerated the number of rural jobs which will be lost if the Government bans hunting with dogs.
fields.body:
The Countryside Alliance, the leading pro-blood sports group, has admitted it may have exaggerated the number of rural jobs which will be lost if the Government bans hunting with dogs.

The Alliance has always publicly insisted that 16,000 jobs would go if there is a ban. It was these claims that led the Government to set up a Home Office inquiry led by former Treasury mandarin Lord Burns to investigate the impact of any anti-blood sports legislation.

However, in its submission to the inquiry, the Alliance has admitted that the real number might be only a quarter of this amount, although it adds: 'If only 25 per cent of jobs supported by hunting were lost as a result of a ban, that would still amount to a loss of more than 5,000 jobs.'

The Alliance has made much political capital about a hunting ban destroying jobs. Last September when it marched on the Labour Party conference in Bournemouth the number of protesters - 16,000 - was said to be a 'symbolic illustration of the number of jobs that would be lost in the event of a hunt ban'.

Last year research for the Journal of Rural Studies by Newcastle University's geography department said the true figure of any job losses was more likely to be only 1,000. The author of the report, Dr Neil Ward, concluded that the claims by the Alliance were wildly exaggerated and not sustained by the economic evidence.

At the time the Alliance dismissed the report as 'out of touch with reality' and insisted that 16,000 jobs would go. Yet it now appears to be admitting that this is not the case.

A spokesman for the Alliance said: 'The 16,000 figure comes from research undertaken by the Produce Studies Group. It is straightforward to work out the jobs generated by hunting. Our submission merely says it is much more complex to work out what the real figure of job losses will be - although it will be substantial.'

Although Tony Blair has promised legislation to outlaw fox hunting, it is unlikely parliamentary time will be found before the next election. Until now some Ministers, while instinctively opposed to hunting, have been swayed by claims that a ban would bring thousands of redundancies.

Mike Foster, Labour MP for Worcester, whose Private Member's Bill to ban hunting failed to get enough government time, said: 'We have also known that the 16,000 figure was grossly exaggerated and just a result of some creative accounting. The true figure is likely to be less than 1,000 and most of those will be able to find work if hunts move to artificial scent.'

Mike Baker, UK director of the International Fund for Animal Welfare, said: 'Anyone with a modicum of common sense would know their claims were absurd. It's about time they came clean.' Anti-hunt campaigners also claim that related job losses in pubs, shops and garages are grossly misleading.

Last week it emerged that the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food believes hunting is not an effective form of pest control. Its submission to the Burns inquiry said a ban would be 'negligible' in controlling pests such as deer, mink and hares.

fields.headline: Bloody truth behind  the chase
fields.standfirst:
on how hare coursers duped a Home Office investigation into blood sports

The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: on how hare coursers duped a Home Office investigation into blood sports
fields.body:
A frightened hare sprints into an open field watched by hundreds of cheering spectators. The animal is running for its life. Seconds later, two greyhounds race after it and in a flash one has its teeth locked around the hare's head. The crowd cheers. The other greyhound bites into the hare's hind legs.

The hare's screams can be heard as the two greyhounds fight over their prey, which thrashes around in pain.

A man in a black balaclava runs up and takes the hare from the dogs. He takes more than five attempts to break its neck. Finally, the hare's body goes limp and it is stuffed into a black bin liner.

This horrific event, caught on film by undercover investigators, is the fate of just one of the many hares killed at this year's Waterloo Cup - Britain's premier hare coursing event held over three days in February on Lord Leverhulme's Altcar estate, north of Liverpool.

As well as revealing the slaughter of hares, the film uncovers the lengths to which blood sport enthusiasts are going to ensure one of their favourite pastimes is not banned by future legislation.

For much of the first day, the organisers of the Waterloo Cup had special guests: a Home Office team investigating the impact a ban on hunting with dogs would have.

The undercover footage clearly illustrates how the team, headed by former Treasury mandarin Lord Burns, was shown a sanitised version of the 'sport', which would be illegal if the Government bans hunting with dogs as it promised in its election manifesto.

Instead of the typical 50-metre start - known as the 'slip' - the hare normally gets before the greyhounds are released, the film shows coursing officials holding the dogs back much longer while Burns was present. Many hares were given a 120-metre start and escaped unharmed.

The crowd - frustrated at not seeing as many 'kills' as usual - are heard yelling and swearing at officials to let the dogs go earlier. Only two hares were killed in the time Burns and his colleagues were there - a fraction of the usual number. When the Home Office team left, the officials adopted to their normal practice, giving the hares much less chance to escape.

The footage also shows that after Burns left, bookmaker Stephen Little, a big name in the sport and a sponsor of the Waterloo Cup, appeared to be taking bets from young children. This would be a criminal offence.

The International Fund for Animal Welfare (IFAW) - whose investigators took the film - have passed a copy of the tape to Lancashire Police.

At the end of the first day, the organiser, Sir Mark Prescott, is heard addressing the assembled crowd: 'The inquiry team could not have seen coursing in a better light. But I don't know if the Government will heed what they say.'

One of the undercover team who took the film said: 'The true barbarity of the Waterloo Cup was hidden from the inquiry.'

The IFAW investigator, whose sister took the footage that resulted in the prosecution of circus trainer Mary Chipperfield, said: 'I've been observing hare coursing for years, and you almost had to laugh at the contrived concern they were showing for the hunted animals this time around, just because these Home Office guys were watching.'

Animal rights campaigners believe this is not the first time the Home Office team has been prevented from getting a true picture of blood sports in action. In January, Burns was due to attend a meet of Bicester and Whaddonhase Fox Hunt, in Oxfordshire.

Burns called off the night before, after the hunt told him that the weather wasn't suitable. But investigators filmed the Bicester and Whaddon out hunting as planned the following day unobserved.

Labour MP Colin Pickthall, whose West Lancashire constituency is home to the Waterloo Cup, is a long-standing campaigner against hare coursing.

He said: 'It's no surprise to me the Home Office team were given a false picture of what happens. It is truly barbaric and really should be viewed in the same light as dogfighting and bear baiting.

'I was a guest with other MPs a couple of years ago and the same thing happened. We saw no hares killed but I later saw some footage of the coursing after we had gone and it was horrific. It simply does not belong in Britain in the twenty-first century.'

Supporters of hare coursing strongly reject the claims made by the animal rights group. Charles Blanning, secretary of the National Coursing Club - an affiliate of the Countryside Alliance - said: 'Our rules state the slip must be at least 80 yards and there were no differences or inconsistencies when Lord Burns was there.'

Blanning said over the three days there were 108 courses and only 18 hares were killed. He added: 'For the last seven years we have been told this is the last Waterloo Cup. I am confident there will be one next year, the year after and for many years after that.'

But the evidence compiled by the investigators debunks several claims made in the Countryside Alliance's submission to the Burns inquiry. Its document on hare coursing states: 'There is strong evidence that these animals do not outwardly appear distressed when chased,' and, 'When a hare is brought down death is virtually instantaneous.'

But the undercover footage shows hares being disembowelled alive by dogs; dogs pulling at either end of a live hare; and coursers taking several gos to break the neck of a hare not killed by dogs.

fields.bodyText: A frightened hare sprints into an open field watched by hundreds of cheering spectators. The animal is running for its life. Seconds later, two greyhounds race after it and in a flash one has its teeth locked around the hare's head. The crowd cheers. The other greyhound bites into the hare's hind legs. The hare's screams can be heard as the two greyhounds fight over their prey, which thrashes around in pain. A man in a black balaclava runs up and takes the hare from the dogs. He takes more than five attempts to break its neck. Finally, the hare's body goes limp and it is stuffed into a black bin liner. This horrific event, caught on film by undercover investigators, is the fate of just one of the many hares killed at this year's Waterloo Cup - Britain's premier hare coursing event held over three days in February on Lord Leverhulme's Altcar estate, north of Liverpool. As well as revealing the slaughter of hares, the film uncovers the lengths to which blood sport enthusiasts are going to ensure one of their favourite pastimes is not banned by future legislation. For much of the first day, the organisers of the Waterloo Cup had special guests: a Home Office team investigating the impact a ban on hunting with dogs would have. The undercover footage clearly illustrates how the team, headed by former Treasury mandarin Lord Burns, was shown a sanitised version of the 'sport', which would be illegal if the Government bans hunting with dogs as it promised in its election manifesto. Instead of the typical 50-metre start - known as the 'slip' - the hare normally gets before the greyhounds are released, the film shows coursing officials holding the dogs back much longer while Burns was present. Many hares were given a 120-metre start and escaped unharmed. The crowd - frustrated at not seeing as many 'kills' as usual - are heard yelling and swearing at officials to let the dogs go earlier. Only two hares were killed in the time Burns and his colleagues were there - a fraction of the usual number. When the Home Office team left, the officials adopted to their normal practice, giving the hares much less chance to escape. The footage also shows that after Burns left, bookmaker Stephen Little, a big name in the sport and a sponsor of the Waterloo Cup, appeared to be taking bets from young children. This would be a criminal offence. The International Fund for Animal Welfare (IFAW) - whose investigators took the film - have passed a copy of the tape to Lancashire Police. At the end of the first day, the organiser, Sir Mark Prescott, is heard addressing the assembled crowd: 'The inquiry team could not have seen coursing in a better light. But I don't know if the Government will heed what they say.' One of the undercover team who took the film said: 'The true barbarity of the Waterloo Cup was hidden from the inquiry.' The IFAW investigator, whose sister took the footage that resulted in the prosecution of circus trainer Mary Chipperfield, said: 'I've been observing hare coursing for years, and you almost had to laugh at the contrived concern they were showing for the hunted animals this time around, just because these Home Office guys were watching.' Animal rights campaigners believe this is not the first time the Home Office team has been prevented from getting a true picture of blood sports in action. In January, Burns was due to attend a meet of Bicester and Whaddonhase Fox Hunt, in Oxfordshire. Burns called off the night before, after the hunt told him that the weather wasn't suitable. But investigators filmed the Bicester and Whaddon out hunting as planned the following day unobserved. Labour MP Colin Pickthall, whose West Lancashire constituency is home to the Waterloo Cup, is a long-standing campaigner against hare coursing. He said: 'It's no surprise to me the Home Office team were given a false picture of what happens. It is truly barbaric and really should be viewed in the same light as dogfighting and bear baiting. 'I was a guest with other MPs a couple of years ago and the same thing happened. We saw no hares killed but I later saw some footage of the coursing after we had gone and it was horrific. It simply does not belong in Britain in the twenty-first century.' Supporters of hare coursing strongly reject the claims made by the animal rights group. Charles Blanning, secretary of the National Coursing Club - an affiliate of the Countryside Alliance - said: 'Our rules state the slip must be at least 80 yards and there were no differences or inconsistencies when Lord Burns was there.' Blanning said over the three days there were 108 courses and only 18 hares were killed. He added: 'For the last seven years we have been told this is the last Waterloo Cup. I am confident there will be one next year, the year after and for many years after that.' But the evidence compiled by the investigators debunks several claims made in the Countryside Alliance's submission to the Burns inquiry. Its document on hare coursing states: 'There is strong evidence that these animals do not outwardly appear distressed when chased,' and, 'When a hare is brought down death is virtually instantaneous.' But the undercover footage shows hares being disembowelled alive by dogs; dogs pulling at either end of a live hare; and coursers taking several gos to break the neck of a hare not killed by dogs. antony.barnett@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Injustice for all
fields.standfirst: Shayler - the truth is out there, on the NetRefugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Widdecombe's and Jack Straw's condemnations of  'bogus' and 'abusive' asylum-seekers serve the useful purpose of distracting attention from official incompetence. Both occasionally remember to insert the cooing caveat: 'But, of course, we have nothing against genuine refugees. We welcome them to these islands today as we always have in the past.'
fields.body:
Four facts are rarely mentioned when Fleet and Downing Streets incite hatred of asylum-seekers. The list begins with the easily checkable assertion that Britain has not been swamped with refugees, genuine or otherwise, when our figures are compared with other countries, particularly in the Third World. The reason why those who cannot prove that they have a justifiable fear of persecution are not being deported has everything to do with a decision by the Home Office in 1996, on Ann Widdecombe's myopic watch, to pay Siemens to deliver a spanking new computer system to process applications. Despite the loss of skip-loads of public money, the techno-wizards, who brought us the Passport Office fiasco, have yet to do anything as clever as providing terminals that work.

Widdecombe's and Jack Straw's condemnations of the 'bogus' and 'abusive' serve the useful purpose of distracting attention from official incompetence. Both occasionally remember to insert the cooing caveat: 'But, of course, we have nothing against genuine refugees. We welcome them to these islands today as we always have in the past.'

Neither they nor chunks of the press can therefore acknowledge our third unhelpful point - as of 1 April, it will be impossible for a refugee to reach Britain legally. The owners of planes, trains, automobiles, lorries, vans, camper vans, caravans, motorbike sidecars and tandems with a spare seat will be fined £2,000 if they carry a genuine refugee or economic migrant across the Channel. (The new law makes no distinction.) Asylum-seekers are, quite deliberately, being pushed into the hands of the people-smuggling rackets and will then - QED ! - be branded as criminals themselves by association.

The hatred of foreign beggars that causes editors and columnists to fleck their readers with spittle requires the suppression of the fourth and, in many ways, nastiest item on the list. Their invective deploys a sub-literary conceit, a self-pitying inversion which turns victims into persecutors and the comfortable into the oppressed. Beggars must be shown as con-artists. They grab fortunes that dot.com founders would envy from a decent but cozened public.

The rhetorical effect is spoilt if we add that Straw prevents asylum-seekers from working and is forcing them to live on vouchers and pocket money with a combined value which comes in at 30 per cent below the lowest level of income support.

A single man must survive on £25-worth of Home Office food vouchers, known as 'Asylos' to despairing human rights workers, and £10 cash a week. This paltry income is too lavish for Straw and the supermarkets. In front of me is a memo from Sainsbury's management team to its check-out boys and girls. Sainsbury's instructs the staff that asylum seekers can't spend their Asylos freely. The tokens can only be used to buy 'stated' goods - 'eg grocery items, toiletries, nappies. Tokens cannot be exchanged for cash and no change can be given on them.' If a mother buys baby food worth £4.51 with a £5 Asylo, Sainsbury's will keep the difference.

Blair's favourite supermarket has inspired policy-makers. The Home Office has realised that the arrival of the Asylo is an exciting opening for business. It has given Sodexho Pass, a French company, the right to distribute the vouchers. The corporation's marketing department is telling stores there are profits to be made from pocketing the change. 'Don't miss this revenue-making opportunity,' its publicity all but shouts.

Sainsbury's and the Home Office's lucky business partners are practising the modern equivalent of stealing pennies from blind men's cups. I can, nevertheless, hear the thick-skinned mutter: 'So what?' Asylum-seekers have come here willingly. About two-thirds of them could be told to leave when, if ever, the decrepit Home Office bureaucracy manages to deal with their cases. If the rest are really running for their lives, Blair's and Brown's penny-pinching must be preferable to a bullet in the head from the secret police back home.

Be careful before you imitate the snorts of the hard nosed. My wise colleague Neal Ascherson once warned that you should always keep a keen eye on how the Government treats asylum- seekers because it shows how they would deal with the rest of us if it thought it could get away with it.

Last week, as one wing of the Home Office was getting ready to close the ports to authentic refugees, another announced that uppity natives should be treated with greater severity than the most pathetic foreigner. Any petty offender who breaks a probation order twice, or a community service order, or an order to stop taking drugs, or any other kind of order, will be sent back to court to face an automatic punishment of up to three months in prison. Harry Fletcher, the spokesman for the probation officers' union, Napo, said that a breach of an order might be being late for an appointment.

When concerns about the already enormous prison population shooting upwards are put to the terrifying Paul Boateng, his face shines with macho gullibility. 'That's their choice,' snaps the Home Office Minister.

Fletcher is astonished that Boateng neither knows nor cares that the majority of offenders in prisons or probation hostels are unlikely to behave rationally. They are mentally ill or the victims of child abuse, or are so undereducated that they are not qualified to take the most menial work. (It says much about our public sector that the first civil servant most offenders meet who can do a passable job isn't a teacher or social worker, but the prison officer who locks them up.)

If they escape a jail sentence, they will lose half and in many cases all of their benefits. Alistair Darling, the Trot-turned-Blairite Social Security Secretary, is modestly proposing in his Child Support, Pensions and Social Security Bill to impoverish all accused of breaking a court order. New Labour has no time for the dated concept that a man is innocent until proved guilty. The mere charge will be enough to slash income and, presumably, leave the suspect with thieving or begging at the top of his list of ideas for staying alive. So much for being tough on the causes of crime.

What is shocking about Darling's law is its class bias. A nice, middle-class person (such as your correspondent) will not have his wages docked by the state if he breaks a court order not to engage in behaviour likely to cause a breach of the peace in the presence of the Prime Minister. We will be fine. Only the poor will suffer .

They will be 'bogus' asylum-seekers in their own land.

As we report on our news pages, Robin Cook and Peter Hain, his Foreign Office junior, are behaving rather bravely. They are letting it be known that they oppose what amounts to a sustained attack on the press over the David Shayler debacle.

I wrote last week about The Observer and our sister paper, the Guardian, being hauled off to the Old Bailey. The Guardian 's crime was to publish a letter from Shayler. MI5 said it was absolutely vital to get the original as evidence against its renegade spy. (Apparently, the case against him was so weak, the spooks couldn't claim he had broken the Official Secrets Act until they saw his contribution to a letters page.) My colleague, Martin Bright, was ordered to hand over notes, if notes exist, about a story he wrote about Shayler naming the names of MI6 officers who certainly knew about, and may have given money to, plotters trying to overthrow Gadaffi.

The judge ordered us to comply with the spies' demands. At no point did he recognise, even in passing, that a free press must scrutinise government and that the only way we can do this - however inadequately - is to assure readers that a whimsical secret police will not be able to leaf through our notebooks and browse through our computer systems (which they'd also like to do) after you have spoken to us in confidence. We are challenging the order.

Hain is the Minister responsible for Libya. He is horrified by what is happening: in part because he's a South African who suffered from the attentions of Boss, the 'intelligence community' of the white dictatorship; in part because he wasn't told about the court action. Cook, meanwhile, is protesting in the strongest language behind the scenes. Jack Straw, I'd guess, is his main target. This criminal investigation is being run out of the Home Office, MI5's nominal controllers, and all our inquiries are referred to its press office.

Both are courageous because Shayler's most damning revelation was that MI5 keeps files on politicians. American Presidents allowed J. Edgar Hoover to run the FBI as a private army which ignored the Mafia and hounded Martin Luther King. They knew Hoover had files on them, and guessed that if they checked him all kinds of dirt would appear. Cook and Hain must have some nagging fears themselves. (Who wouldn't?) That they still behave like democrats is very much to their credit.

They may be influenced by the absurdity of what is going on. Half of the print and broadcast media could be drawn into this in the run-up to a general election. While The Observer and Guardian are up before the courts for printing pretty innocuous pieces, a history of MI6 is arriving at the bookshops. MI6: Fifty Years of Special Operation (Fourth Estate, £25) is a corking read which I urge you to buy while you can. The author, Stephen Dorrill, names agents and shows how MI6 lied to successive Foreign Secretaries. At one point he identifies the MI6 officers involved in a plan to assassinate Slobbo Milosevic.

I asked him if he was worried about his book being banned? Well, naturally he was, in the present climate. But he maintained that every fact he quoted and spy he named has been published before in newspapers, specialist journals or on the Internet. What he has done is pull it all together.

The Internet Blair worships renders futile the cloaking of the bungling and sinister behind the Official Secrets Act. As the stars of the X Files , who are far more credible investigators than the security services, know: the truth is out there - on www.shayler.com, to be precise.

fields.headline: Taiwan's voters defy Beijing
fields.standfirst: Man that China did not want is elected President elected in face of Chinese threatsTaiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: Taiwan's electors yesterday defied the threat of a mainland Chinese invasion by electing Chen Shui-bian - the pro-independence candidate Beijing had told them to reject - as their President.
fields.body:
Taiwan's electors yesterday defied the threat of a mainland Chinese invasion by electing Chen Shui-bian - the pro-independence candidate Beijing had told them to reject - as their President.

The vote was a crushing defeat for the Chinese Kuo-mintang (KMT) party, which has ruled Taiwan for more than 50 years and which once jailed Chen during his 20-year struggle.

A record turnout gave Chen, the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate, a comfortable victory with 39.3 per cent of the vote. As one working-class voter put it: 'He comes from a poor family and understands us. We aren't bothered about China: it's just empty words from Beijing.'

At his headquarters last night, Chen - besieged by thousands of cheering flag-wavers - said: 'The Taiwan people have overcome darkness and fear and have used our sacred vote to defend democracy'.

Without mentioning Taiwan's independence, he promised to work for direct trade relations with the mainland and invited Beijing's leaders to visit the island.

But Beijing will not be happy at Chen's pledge 'to help the international community push for democratic reform and for human rights' - subjects on which China has very different views. Communist leaders had kept up pressure on Chen until the last minute, with one Beijing paper on the eve of polling accusing him of 'gambling with the lives of his people'.

US Defence Secretary William Cohen has urged China to 'tone down its rhetoric and threats of intimidation' and called for both sides to 'sit down and see how to reconcile their differences peacefully', an offer subsequently repeated by Chen. 'If they don't want to meet me in Beijing or Shanghai, then I shall be happy to meet them in Hong Kong or Singapore.'

Analysts believe President Jiang Zemin and his fellow Communist Party leaders may wait until Chen's inauguration on 20 May before deciding how to respond.

Chen will still face a KMT majority in the legislature although he can appoint his own Cabinet. A political earthquake may only just have begun. The DPP's chairman, Lin Yi-hsiung, spoke last night of building a new inclusive society that cared for 'clean mountains and clean water'.

This rosy view of the future was not shared by mainland China. Chen's victory 'will increase the likelihood of our using force to solve the Taiwan question', Hong Kong's Wen Wei Po newspaper, a Beijing supporter, said yesterday. The mainland Science Times accused Chen of 'gambling with the happiness of the Taiwanese people' while knowing full well that 'Taiwan independence means war'.

It was against this background of intimidation that voters turned out in record numbers - at 80 per cent, nearly 10 per cent higher than in the 1996 election.

Earlier Chen had cast his vote at the National Elemen tary School in a quiet street lined with banyans in the north of Taipei city. He stood in line with the voters outside the classroom polling station, overlooked by a large statue of Dr Sun Yat-sen. Sun led the 1911 revolution and founded the Chinese Nationalists whose power Chen has now overthrown.

His wife, Wu Shu-jen, accompanied him in her wheelchair, looking pale and strained but with a determined air. She was knocked down by a truck 15 years ago in an 'accident' no one believes to have been genuine. At the time Chen had challenged the Kuomintang by standing in an important county election.

Outside the school he walked without ceremony down the street, greeting local supporters who cheered, laughed and showed him their babies.

'There's no distance between him and us,' said Ms Lin, manager of a dry-cleaning shop around the corner. 'He's not corrupt and he doesn't have a big clique.'

Beijing will also be disturbed by Chen's declaration at a tumultuous eve-of-poll rally in central Taipei. He told the crowd of 300,000: 'You have all stood up. Taiwan has stood up!'

Chairman Mao used exactly the same phrase after the defeat of Chiang Kai-shek to proclaim that 'China has stood up'. Now his successors may fear that it has a rival across the Taiwan Straits.

Nevertheless, Chen is trying to send out positive messages to Beijing. He elaborated on a pledge to form an all-party 'task force' that would work immediately to 'resolve misunderstandings'.

He told reporters: 'Reconciliation with good intentions, active co-operation and eternal peace are the goals of the people and governments across the Taiwan Straits.'

Nevertheless, Chen is trying to send out positive messages to Beijing. He elaborated on a pledge to form an all-party 'task force' that would work immediately to 'resolve misunderstandings'. He told reporters: 'Reconciliation with good intentions, active co-operation and eternal peace are the goals of the people and governments across the Taiwan Straits.'

webTitle: P&O cruises buoyant but waters ahead look rough

fields.headline: P&O cruises buoyant but waters ahead look rough
fields.trailText: Lord Sterling, chairman of P&O, must find it rather galling that, having given the City the demerger it craved, his group's shares dropped by close to a third once the proposal was announced.
fields.body:
Lord Sterling, chairman of P&O, must find it rather galling that, having given the City the demerger it craved, his group's shares dropped by close to a third once the proposal was announced.

In truth, the fall has less to do with the demerger, which everyone seems to agree is a good thing, than with concern about whether P&O's cruise business can carry on growing at its current breakneck pace.

That worry was exacerbated by some rather gloomy comments on pricing and demand from US rivals such as Carnival.

P&O admits that the waters are looking choppy. Rates for the current year are similar to 1999's, suggesting that the years of steady increases are coming to an end.

That will not matter to profits this year; capacity is up by 23 per cent and P&O still expects every berth to be full, so there will be plenty of growth, regardless of rates.

It is, however, a sign that the rapid rise in cruising capacity is starting to have an impact on the market. It would be surprising if it didn't. WestLBPanmure estimates that the top three operators - including Royal Caribbean as well as P&O and Carnival - will add more than 40 per cent to 1999 capacity by 2002.

Nevertheless, demand for cruising has also been growing - by an average of 8 per cent a year for the past 20 years in the US. Its growing popularity elsewhere in the world means that this is likely to continue. P&O's fleet is newer than its rivals' ships; it has bigger operations in Europe; and it travels to more fashionable destinations. So it should take more than its fair share of that growth. Increases in capacity will slow the recent rapid growth, but not by enough to warrant P&O's shares falling to less than 12 times historic earnings. Buy.

A clean idea

In the beginning, brewing companies just made beer. Then they realised they could make far more money selling beer to the public, so they started buying up pubs and restaurants. Now, most of them have abandoned the brewing and turned themselves into retailers.

Oil companies, too, know the value of having a network of petrol stations, although many wonder whether they should bother to refine the oil that is sold in them. Should we then prepare ourselves for Unilever to abandon the manufacture of cleaning products and transform itself into a multinational Mrs Mop?

Refreshing as it is to hear a chief executive talk about the importance of washing the skirting boards instead of just giving a quick vac, this seems destined for the dustbin.

Everyone would agree with the 450 people in the Unilever focus group: we would give up cleaning like a shot if only we could afford it. But what if the company offering to do it is charging more than £40 to clean a one- bedroom flat?

And if we have trouble finding one capable and reliable cleaner, where will Unilever get hundreds of them? Some may be attracted by the national vocational qualification in cleaning and the corporate structure Unilever will offer.

But Unilever is likely to discover that, if there was serious money to be made in domestic cleaning, a company such as Rentokil, which already has expertise in running service businesses, would already have tried it.

It may work in some niches - a London lubricated by the millions flowing from dot.coms, for example. But it aims to take a fifth of the UK market - worth £1.3 billion, it estimates. To make a difference to its business - sales last year were more than £27bn and profits more than £3.5bn - it would have to replicate that around the world.

What is encouraging is that it shows Unilever is prepared to think radically about the future. Full marks. But, to drive profits, it will have to come up with something else.

Electra's affair

Managers of small companies have been complaining for years that the City no longer loves them.

Help is at hand. Electra, the fund manager behind the old Electra venture capital investment trust which is currently being wound up, is promising to put a little romance back into their lives.

Electra Active Management, being launched as an open-ended investment company (Oeic), makes a virtue of the fact that investors are no longer interested in small companies.

It will target those valued at between £20 million and £250m - and there are more than 1,200 to choose from - which it thinks are undervalued and which it believes can increase profits by at least 10 per cent a year.

But this is not a traditional small companies fund. It will not just buy the shares then sit back and wait for the price to increase. Instead, it will use the venture capital expertise of its managers to work with the undervalued companies to find ways of increasing their value.

That could be through acquisitions, selling poorer parts of the business, introducing new management or even taking it private - a route which, Electra estimates, was taken by 70 companies in the past two years.

That makes it rather specialised. It will take stakes in only 25 to 30 companies, generally buying less than 5 per cent, and will only consider those where the management is willing to accept Electra's help.

That will restrict its scope but, as Electra says, a friendly, co-operative approach is more likely to yield results - and make it easier to find new targets.

Electra's venture capital record is good. Shares in Electra Investment Trust, which is being wound up following a hostile bid from 3i, rose twice as fast as the FTSE All-Share index over the past five years; the quoted companies in its portfolio outperformed the small cap index.

This should also be a good time to buy into small cap funds. Their values are low but if the love affair with technology ends, they could be re-rated. Anyone with the £10,000 minimum to invest should consider a stake.

fields.headline: Bungle puts refugees into limbo
fields.standfirst: Immigration fiasco denies 'fast track' to asylum-seekersRefugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Asylum seekers fleeing the world's most brutal regimes have been kept waiting years for decisions on their cases because of an administrative anomaly which has brought the immigration service to chaos.
fields.body:
Asylum seekers fleeing the world's most brutal regimes have been kept waiting years for decisions on their cases because of an administrative anomaly which has brought the immigration service to chaos.

The bureaucratic bungle, revealed in a report to the Home Office, led to a rapid increase in the waiting list for asylum-seekers, which has reached 100,000, and arose because Dover and Heathrow immigration officials oper ated different procedures from the rest of the country.

The report reveals that thousands of asylum-seekers from the 19 countries which the Home Office acknowledges as the most repressive regimes in the world should have been accorded a 'fast-track' entry but were kept in the queue for cross-examination by Dover and Heathrow immigration officials.

The build-up in unresolved cases produced last week's fiasco in which 16 Romanian families who had been dispersed to Glasgow as part of a programme to take the pressure off central London, were sent back to Wandsworth a week later. The two councils blamed each other.Welfare workers who deal directly with refugees say the real problem comes not from deliberate abuse of the system by any group of asylum-seekers but monumental inefficiency.

Labour MP Fiona Mactaggart, a former director the Joint Council for the Welfare of Immigrants, said: 'The only people who gain by delays are those who want to cheat. The genuine asylum-seekers don't want to be kept here on welfare waiting for a decision: they want a quick decision so they can rebuild their lives.'

The growing backlog of unresolved cases comes as the Government introduces a new clampdown on racke teers, many of whom make vast sums from bringing in asylum-seekers. From 1 April, lorry drivers who are caught bringing in illegal immigrants will be liable to fines of £2,000 per immigrant. The maximum prison term for running an illegal immigration racket will increase from seven to 10 years.

The chaos in the system is detailed in an 80-page report for the Home Office, seen by The Observer and submitted to Home Secretary Jack Straw last July.

The report was kept secret for nine months while Ministers struggled to correct the worst faults. The report details how asylum-seekers from places such as Iraq or Iran were kept waiting unnecessarily for months after entering Britain at Dover or Heathrow.

The Home Office had recognised that some governments are so brutal that anyone who escapes from them has an almost automatic claim for asylum. For instance, an Iraqi could claim asylum by applying in writing to the Home Office's Immigration and Nationality Directorate, and filling in the appropriate form. Almost all would be allowed to stay without a personal interview with a case worker.

But those who arrived at Dover and Heathrow - points of entry for 80 per cent of refugees - were confronted by immigration officials operating under different rules. Though the Home Office listed 19 countries which it regarded as the most repressive in the world, officials at these two ports of entry recognised just four - Afghanistan, Liberia, Somalia and the war-torn states of the former Yugoslavia.

Consultants from Vantage Point, the firm hired last year by the Home Office to examine the asylum system, discovered that 350 Iraqi Kurds, whose persecution by Saddam Hussein has been recognised internationally, were in the queue at East Dover waiting to be interviewed.

Their names had been added to a list with thousands of others from all over the world - so many, that the average wait for an interview was two years. If the 350 Kurds had been able to apply for asylum in writing, the rules would not have required them to be interviewed at all.

The consultants warned that the system was so inefficient that it would not have been able to handle the flow of asylum-seekers effectively even if the Government had given it all the money and resources it needed and the notorious new computer system at its Croydon headquarters had worked properly.

At the time of the report, there was an average delay of 11 months between an asylum-seeker's arrival in Brit-ain and a decision on whether they could stay. The backlog of cases was then 76,570 cases. Each month, more than 4,000 new asylum-seekers arrived, while the decision rate for those already in the country was only 2,000 a month.

The authors warned that officials were going to have to increase their efficiency almost fourfold, handling nearly 8,000 cases a month if they were to get to grips with the backlog by April 2001.

The backlog has since climbed to nearly 100,000, having doubled since Labour came to power. There are 60,000 in London - 11,000 in just two boroughs, Haringey and Newham. The Government's attempted remedy has been the 'dispersal' system which seeks to move asylum- seekers to underpopulated estates in the North of England.

Last month Downing Street said that for the first time in years the number of cases successfully processed was greater than the number of new asylum- seekers coming into the country.

On 1 April, the new system of issuing asylum-seekers with vouchers instead of cash will come into force, along with a clampdown on trafficking in illegal immigrants.

fields.headline: The talented Mr Brown
fields.standfirst: Which Chancellor will be behind the red box and rictus smile this week? Will it be the 'Good Gordon' or the 'Bad Gordon'?New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The Observer Profile: Gordon Brown
fields.body:
At 3:30 this Tuesday afternoon, he will rise to the Dispatch Box, saturnine and granite-jawed. The chattering monkeys of the Westminster jungle will be silenced as the basso profundo tones of the big beast take command of the Commons. His speech will arch across the globe and swoop down to demonstrate mastery of minute details of the briefs of Cabinet colleagues to whom he will not have vouchsafed the secrets of his red box until just before lunch. Labour MPs will be anxious to see the sting drawn from Tory attacks on tax and the discontent in the Labour heartlands salved. They will not, however, be all that nervous. On the experience of his previous performances, Gordon Brown's fourth Budget will write stunning headlines for himself and for the Government. When he sits down an hour or so later, two things can be said with some certainty. The back benches will cheer him with waving order papers while a beamingly congratulatory Tony Blair enthuses for the watching TV cameras. The other thing that we can be sure of is that the one person in the Commons least content with his position will be Gordon Brown.

All politicians are driven animals, but the Chancellor burns with an unusually fearsome fire which uses up computer keyboards and colleagues alike. The son of Kirkcaldy absorbed the virtues of hard work and prudence at the knee of his Presbyterian Rector father, whose death 15 months ago Brown felt very keenly. Work is both duty and joy, and he struggles to comprehend why his drive is not matched by lesser mortals. He is rarely awake much later than six, soon after he's on the phone to his intimates, often mid-jog, and he'll be banging out e-mails when feebler spirits are heading for bed. The mundanities of daily life - things like how to open a milk carton without spurting the contents over your shirt - often confound him. He was once so engrossed in a conversation that he opened a car door into oncoming traffic and it was smashed off.

Brown lives as if this will be his last productive day on the planet. He is the second son of three brothers, an ambiguous status in the family hierarchy which often makes awkward high-achievers of middle children. When he lost the use of one eye after being kicked in the head playing rugby, the doctor told Brown that he could not say how long he might see with the other. The prospect of going blind - at some unknown time in the future - surely concentrated that formidable mind. Brown first came to some national prominence when he defeated the establishment candidate to be elected student rector of Edinburgh University. Biographers and profile writers always identify this as a landmark, youthful achievement. Yet Brown's own view is that it was a 'wasted year' which he could have spent more productively developing his ideas. The intensity of the man produces equal magnitudes of awed admiration and profound mistrust among colleagues. Another senior Minister, with no particular animus against Brown, says: 'Gordon is an outstanding Chancellor. And an appalling politician. I would trust him with my money, but never with my life.'

An outstanding steward of the Treasury he has been. By this stage in the life of every previous post-war Labour Chancellor, the holder of the office had been swamped by economic calamity. Dalton had resigned to be replaced by Cripps who would be devalued; Callaghan had been forced to quit; Healey was running into the throttling embrace of the international bankers. Brown presides over swelling financial surpluses, steady economic growth, and shrinking dole queues that have emboldened him to speak again of Labour's old ambition of full employment. His forecasts have consistently proved more correct than those of commentators or critics. Even some who attacked it at the time now acknowledge the lightning coup, in the first few days after the election, of handing control over interest rates to the Bank of England. It is a unique trio of feats: respected by the City, liked by party activists, and popular with the public. His approval ratings are currently better than those of Tony Blair. If his next three years are as successful as his first three, he will challenge Lloyd George for the title of most outstanding Chancellor of the past 100 years.

He is already at least as powerful the as the Welsh Wizard. Brown had to leave the Labour conference of 1998 early to fly to Washington for a meeting of the IMF. As he was driven to the airport with his economics advisor, Ed Balls, and his then spin-meister, Charlie Whelan, the car radio was broadcasting Tony Blair's conference speech. The Prime Minister listed the Government's achievements from the working families tax credit to the minimum wage. As the conference clapped each item, Brown growled over the applause: 'He fought that... he opposed that.'

This story speaks to his power. If Blair did fight, Brown prevailed. It speaks to his resentments against Blair. And it speaks to Brown's insecurities. Of all the people in the world, his fellow passengers hardly needed telling who is the principal architect of welfare and work reform.

His friend, the Labour MP Tom Clarke, claims that Brown is now more relaxed in his skin, which he puts down to finding happiness in his personal life. Brown and Sarah Macaulay have been partners for four years. Each spring, someone encourages the newspapers to read the banns for a summer wedding. Each summer passes and Gordon has still not produced a ring. He seems to regard marriage as he does the single currency: he favours a successful marriage in principle, but won't say when he expects his convergence criteria to be satisfied. Sarah is knitted into the tight Brown clan of trusties and has formed a close bond with his assistant, Sue Nye. Some report a melancholy wistfulness about Sarah when she is in the company of Sue's new-born. Brown's first love - Princess Margarita of Romania - finally gave up on him after five years, not because she stopped loving him but because 'it was politics, politics, politics, and I needed nurturing'.

Ironically, it is children, especially the children of working poor families, who are the greatest beneficiaries of the childless Chancellor. Child benefits and tax credits have been his most favoured instrument for shifting resources and opportunities from the well-off to the badly-off. One of the things that makes Brown a large, serious and, in many ways, unfashionable type of politician is that he is a social engineer who still believes that the state can change people's lives and behaviour for the better. He is much more than the economic overlord of this Government. His allies talk glowingly of how he has 'colonised' the entire welfare and work agenda. Over at Number 10, it's a source of complaint that billions have been poured into Brown's schemes at the expense of health and education, the areas more cherished by Tony Blair.

It is the compulsion to control that causes the greatest aggravation to col leagues. They groan that the pathologically secretive Brown's idea of consultation is to pick up the phone and bark at them what he has decided five minutes before he issues the press release. One extremely influential figure in the upper reaches of New Labour talks of there being a 'Good Gordon' and a 'Bad Gordon'. Good Gordon has the 'largest and clearest strategic mind in the Government'. At Cabinet 10 days ago, in his capacity as campaign chieftain, Brown gave other Ministers a masterful over-view of the path to winning the next election. Good Gordon is compelling company when he has a glass in hand and is relaxing among the few people he really trusts. Witty as well as wise, he is capable of flashing a smile much more charming than the forced rictus that is displayed on television.

Then there is 'Bad Gordon' who 'throws the most appalling tantrums with Tony when he doesn't get his own way'. Witnesses to the more explosive encounters between Blair and Brown often report their shock at the bullying, disdainful, expletive-laden language the Chancellor hurls in the direction of the Prime Minister. Blair - though his frustration can also boil into swearing and shouting - tends to be more sanguine about Brown than anyone else at Number 10. To those, and there are many, who bring him complaints about the Chancellor's behaviour, Blair is apt to reply that it is the price they must all be content to pay for Brown's brilliance.

There is a mutual dependence between the two. Brown came to office with a much more developed political philosophy than Blair who found it easier to discard ideological baggage because he has always travelled light. Brown has gone through intellectual turmoils trying to reconcile what he used to believe in - state planning and nationalisation - with the free-market-happy creed of New Labour. In times of need, Brown is still likeliest to be Blair's first port of call, whether it is beating back the nationalists in Scotland or dressing the flimsy frame of the Third Way with solid policy. What the Prime Minister does for his Chancellor is protect him against the animosity of Cabinet colleagues. Blair, the maestro of the mood of Middle Britain, also provides the political cover for Brown's redistribution by stealth.

What you cannot help but notice is that the praise Blair lavishes on the talents of Brown is not so generously reciprocated. The defining hinge of this complex relationship is what happened in the days following John Smith's death in 1994. Brown had always taken it as given that he would be the leader and can never be expected to make a full recovery from his shock and grievance that the assumption was not shared by Blair. From a mixture of obligation, guilt and sincere admiration for his abilities and his sacrifice, Blair ceded to him enormous latitude. Yet, however powerful Brown has become, it will never be quite enough so long as someone else bears the title First Lord of the Treasury. Brown would not be human - he certainly would not be Brown - if he was not doing everything to ensure that, if another leadership opportunity comes around, he will be positioned to grasp the ultimate prize.

When a potential rival or a perceived threat runs into trouble - glee has been pretty unconfined at the Treasury over the griefs of Stephen Byers - Brown's mood always seems to lighten. He will never forgive what he regards - even if the truth is more complex - as Peter Mandelson's treachery. Just as Mandelson will never forget Brown's complicity in the exposure of his home loan from Geoffrey Robinson which forced Mandelson out of the Cabinet in Christmas 1998. Blair's two best men bring the worst out of each other.

The least attractive side of both of their characters is the inability to drop a grudge or end a feud. Though Whelan and Robinson left the Government that Christmas, the old gang continues to operate, albeit more discreetly. Whelan, though he is now pursuing a successful alternative career as a journalist and broadcaster, is also doing bits of business on the side for his hero. Lines of Charlie boosting Brown or rubbishing possible rivals are still fed to sympathetic journalists. Staff at the New Statesman, which Robinson owns, say that the only time the proprietor has ever intervened in the editorial content of the magazine was to insist, at Brown's behest, that it run a weekly Scottish supplement, the idea being to reinforce his fiefdom north of the border. Some of his friends believe that Brown is on a sort of promise from Blair that the succession will be his mid-way through the next parliament. Blair will decide that he wants to be a proper father to his fourth child, and hand on the torch. Among Brown's enemies, there is a deep and abiding suspicion of his ambitions. Says one Blairite: 'I think Gordon plans to replace Tony - whether Tony plans to retire or not.' We would hear less of this if Gordon Brown could relax just a little, and enjoy harvesting the deserved plaudits for a Chancellor at the peak of his powers. And you can hear how he would reply to that: Peak? Peak? Whose saying this is my peak? I've only just begun.

James Gordon Brown

Born: Glasgow, February 1951

Educated: Kirkcaldy and Edinburgh University (history)

Current job: Chancellor of the Exchequer

Previous jobs: Lecturer in politics, Glasgow College of Technology (1976-1980) ; journalist; current affairs editor, Scottish Television (1980-1983)

Constituency: Dunfermline East (since 1983)

Girlfriend: Sarah Macauley

Likes: Football, tennis and golf

 Nigella Lawson returns next week
