The chattering monkeys of the Westminster jungle will be silenced as the basso profundo tones of the big beast take command of the Commons. His speech will arch across the globe and swoop down to demonstrate mastery of minute details of the briefs of Cabinet colleagues to whom he will not have vouchsafed the secrets of his red box until just before lunch. Labour MPs will be anxious to see the sting drawn from Tory attacks on tax and the discontent in the Labour heartlands salved. They will not, however, be all that nervous. On the experience of his previous performances, Gordon Brown's fourth Budget will write stunning headlines for himself and for the Government. When he sits down an hour or so later, two things can be said with some certainty. The back benches will cheer him with waving order papers while a beamingly congratulatory Tony Blair enthuses for the watching TV cameras. The other thing that we can be sure of is that the one person in the Commons least content with his position will be Gordon Brown. All politicians are driven animals, but the Chancellor burns with an unusually fearsome fire which uses up computer keyboards and colleagues alike. The son of Kirkcaldy absorbed the virtues of hard work and prudence at the knee of his Presbyterian Rector father, whose death 15 months ago Brown felt very keenly. Work is both duty and joy, and he struggles to comprehend why his drive is not matched by lesser mortals. He is rarely awake much later than six, soon after he's on the phone to his intimates, often mid-jog, and he'll be banging out e-mails when feebler spirits are heading for bed. The mundanities of daily life - things like how to open a milk carton without spurting the contents over your shirt - often confound him. He was once so engrossed in a conversation that he opened a car door into oncoming traffic and it was smashed off. Brown lives as if this will be his last productive day on the planet. He is the second son of three brothers, an ambiguous status in the family hierarchy which often makes awkward high-achievers of middle children. When he lost the use of one eye after being kicked in the head playing rugby, the doctor told Brown that he could not say how long he might see with the other. The prospect of going blind - at some unknown time in the future - surely concentrated that formidable mind. Brown first came to some national prominence when he defeated the establishment candidate to be elected student rector of Edinburgh University. Biographers and profile writers always identify this as a landmark, youthful achievement. Yet Brown's own view is that it was a 'wasted year' which he could have spent more productively developing his ideas. The intensity of the man produces equal magnitudes of awed admiration and profound mistrust among colleagues. Another senior Minister, with no particular animus against Brown, says: 'Gordon is an outstanding Chancellor. And an appalling politician. I would trust him with my money, but never with my life.' An outstanding steward of the Treasury he has been. By this stage in the life of every previous post-war Labour Chancellor, the holder of the office had been swamped by economic calamity. Dalton had resigned to be replaced by Cripps who would be devalued; Callaghan had been forced to quit; Healey was running into the throttling embrace of the international bankers. Brown presides over swelling financial surpluses, steady economic growth, and shrinking dole queues that have emboldened him to speak again of Labour's old ambition of full employment. His forecasts have consistently proved more correct than those of commentators or critics. Even some who attacked it at the time now acknowledge the lightning coup, in the first few days after the election, of handing control over interest rates to the Bank of England. It is a unique trio of feats: respected by the City, liked by party activists, and popular with the public. His approval ratings are currently better than those of Tony Blair. If his next three years are as successful as his first three, he will challenge Lloyd George for the title of most outstanding Chancellor of the past 100 years. He is already at least as powerful the as the Welsh Wizard. Brown had to leave the Labour conference of 1998 early to fly to Washington for a meeting of the IMF. As he was driven to the airport with his economics advisor, Ed Balls, and his then spin-meister, Charlie Whelan, the car radio was broadcasting Tony Blair's conference speech. The Prime Minister listed the Government's achievements from the working families tax credit to the minimum wage. As the conference clapped each item, Brown growled over the applause: 'He fought that... he opposed that.' This story speaks to his power. If Blair did fight, Brown prevailed. It speaks to his resentments against Blair. And it speaks to Brown's insecurities. Of all the people in the world, his fellow passengers hardly needed telling who is the principal architect of welfare and work reform. His friend, the Labour MP Tom Clarke, claims that Brown is now more relaxed in his skin, which he puts down to finding happiness in his personal life. Brown and Sarah Macaulay have been partners for four years. Each spring, someone encourages the newspapers to read the banns for a summer wedding. Each summer passes and Gordon has still not produced a ring. He seems to regard marriage as he does the single currency: he favours a successful marriage in principle, but won't say when he expects his convergence criteria to be satisfied. Sarah is knitted into the tight Brown clan of trusties and has formed a close bond with his assistant, Sue Nye. Some report a melancholy wistfulness about Sarah when she is in the company of Sue's new-born. Brown's first love - Princess Margarita of Romania - finally gave up on him after five years, not because she stopped loving him but because 'it was politics, politics, politics, and I needed nurturing'. Ironically, it is children, especially the children of working poor families, who are the greatest beneficiaries of the childless Chancellor. Child benefits and tax credits have been his most favoured instrument for shifting resources and opportunities from the well-off to the badly-off. One of the things that makes Brown a large, serious and, in many ways, unfashionable type of politician is that he is a social engineer who still believes that the state can change people's lives and behaviour for the better. He is much more than the economic overlord of this Government. His allies talk glowingly of how he has 'colonised' the entire welfare and work agenda. Over at Number 10, it's a source of complaint that billions have been poured into Brown's schemes at the expense of health and education, the areas more cherished by Tony Blair. It is the compulsion to control that causes the greatest aggravation to col leagues. They groan that the pathologically secretive Brown's idea of consultation is to pick up the phone and bark at them what he has decided five minutes before he issues the press release. One extremely influential figure in the upper reaches of New Labour talks of there being a 'Good Gordon' and a 'Bad Gordon'. Good Gordon has the 'largest and clearest strategic mind in the Government'. At Cabinet 10 days ago, in his capacity as campaign chieftain, Brown gave other Ministers a masterful over-view of the path to winning the next election. Good Gordon is compelling company when he has a glass in hand and is relaxing among the few people he really trusts. Witty as well as wise, he is capable of flashing a smile much more charming than the forced rictus that is displayed on television. Then there is 'Bad Gordon' who 'throws the most appalling tantrums with Tony when he doesn't get his own way'. Witnesses to the more explosive encounters between Blair and Brown often report their shock at the bullying, disdainful, expletive-laden language the Chancellor hurls in the direction of the Prime Minister. Blair - though his frustration can also boil into swearing and shouting - tends to be more sanguine about Brown than anyone else at Number 10. To those, and there are many, who bring him complaints about the Chancellor's behaviour, Blair is apt to reply that it is the price they must all be content to pay for Brown's brilliance. There is a mutual dependence between the two. Brown came to office with a much more developed political philosophy than Blair who found it easier to discard ideological baggage because he has always travelled light. Brown has gone through intellectual turmoils trying to reconcile what he used to believe in - state planning and nationalisation - with the free-market-happy creed of New Labour. In times of need, Brown is still likeliest to be Blair's first port of call, whether it is beating back the nationalists in Scotland or dressing the flimsy frame of the Third Way with solid policy. What the Prime Minister does for his Chancellor is protect him against the animosity of Cabinet colleagues. Blair, the maestro of the mood of Middle Britain, also provides the political cover for Brown's redistribution by stealth. What you cannot help but notice is that the praise Blair lavishes on the talents of Brown is not so generously reciprocated. The defining hinge of this complex relationship is what happened in the days following John Smith's death in 1994. Brown had always taken it as given that he would be the leader and can never be expected to make a full recovery from his shock and grievance that the assumption was not shared by Blair. From a mixture of obligation, guilt and sincere admiration for his abilities and his sacrifice, Blair ceded to him enormous latitude. Yet, however powerful Brown has become, it will never be quite enough so long as someone else bears the title First Lord of the Treasury. Brown would not be human - he certainly would not be Brown - if he was not doing everything to ensure that, if another leadership opportunity comes around, he will be positioned to grasp the ultimate prize. When a potential rival or a perceived threat runs into trouble - glee has been pretty unconfined at the Treasury over the griefs of Stephen Byers - Brown's mood always seems to lighten. He will never forgive what he regards - even if the truth is more complex - as Peter Mandelson's treachery. Just as Mandelson will never forget Brown's complicity in the exposure of his home loan from Geoffrey Robinson which forced Mandelson out of the Cabinet in Christmas 1998. Blair's two best men bring the worst out of each other. The least attractive side of both of their characters is the inability to drop a grudge or end a feud. Though Whelan and Robinson left the Government that Christmas, the old gang continues to operate, albeit more discreetly. Whelan, though he is now pursuing a successful alternative career as a journalist and broadcaster, is also doing bits of business on the side for his hero. Lines of Charlie boosting Brown or rubbishing possible rivals are still fed to sympathetic journalists. Staff at the New Statesman, which Robinson owns, say that the only time the proprietor has ever intervened in the editorial content of the magazine was to insist, at Brown's behest, that it run a weekly Scottish supplement, the idea being to reinforce his fiefdom north of the border. Some of his friends believe that Brown is on a sort of promise from Blair that the succession will be his mid-way through the next parliament. Blair will decide that he wants to be a proper father to his fourth child, and hand on the torch. Among Brown's enemies, there is a deep and abiding suspicion of his ambitions. Says one Blairite: 'I think Gordon plans to replace Tony - whether Tony plans to retire or not.' We would hear less of this if Gordon Brown could relax just a little, and enjoy harvesting the deserved plaudits for a Chancellor at the peak of his powers. And you can hear how he would reply to that: Peak? Peak? Whose saying this is my peak? I've only just begun. James Gordon Brown Born: Glasgow, February 1951 Educated: Kirkcaldy and Edinburgh University (history) Current job: Chancellor of the Exchequer Previous jobs: Lecturer in politics, Glasgow College of Technology (1976-1980) ; journalist; current affairs editor, Scottish Television (1980-1983) Constituency: Dunfermline East (since 1983) Girlfriend: Sarah Macauley Likes: Football, tennis and golf  Nigella Lawson returns next week

fields.headline: What British manufacturing?
fields.standfirst: Department of Trade and Industry
fields.trailText: In my view
fields.body:
It is when Chancellors are the object of adulation that they should be most on their guard. I have no doubt that Gordon Brown will turn in another vintage performance on Tuesday; but beneath the superficial perception of superb economic policies, financial stability and steady economic growth, the signs are multiplying that all is not well with what we used to call British industry. And this is bound to damage the wider economy.

We have to use the phrase 'British industry' with care, because industry located in Britain, rather like financial institutions located in the City of London, is increasingly foreign-owned. According to the Department of Trade and Industry, some 25 per cent of 'British' manufacturing output is from foreign-owned firms.

Sir Geoffrey Owen points out in his magisterial work From Empire to Europe (HarperCollins), that some three-quarters of 'British' car exports now come from Japanese assembly plants opened in Britain during recent decades, and from the older UK subsidiaries of Ford, General Motors and Peugeot.

Of course, if foreign-owned companies here are gradually closed down or sold as a result of decisions made in Munich, Tokyo or Detroit, then by definition the consequence is to reduce the percentage of foreign ownership as well as the manufacturing base itself. I am reminded of the point made to me early in the Eighties by Sir John Harvey-Jones, then chairman of ICI, before his next career as television's 'Troubleshooter'. Sir John was firmly of the view that, when it came to the crunch, foreign multinationals would not hesitate to close down their British subsidiaries.

In recent weeks there seem to have been crunches at Harland & Wolff, Rover, British Steel (now known as Corus) and, if not a crunch, then at least a severe scare at Ford. The impact will be bad enough on the business and workforce; but there are also likely to be repercussions on other local firms and communities.

The subtitle of Owen's book is 'The decline and revival of British Industry Since the Second World War'. It is the 'revival' thesis that intrigues me. Owen is dismissive of most government industrial policies of the pre-Thatcher years, and attributes British industry's putative revival to a mixture of the increased competitive pressures of the Eighties, and the benefits to the British economy of 'inward investment' - foreign ownership. Loosely translated, Britain's industry is supposed to have benefited from globalisation and Thatcherism.

Owen gives short shrift to 'short-termism' and other familiar explanations of poor industrial performance; his principal theme is that, unlike the Germans and the French, we did not expose ourselves to the beneficial winds of competition until late in the day. Given the timelags involved in these matters, I recently suggested to him at a National Institute of Economic and Social Research seminar that perhaps improved productivity in the Eighties could be attributed to the delayed impact of Sir Edward Heath's policy of taking us into the Common Market in 1973, rather than to Thatcherism.

Owen notes: 'However nationalistic [Mrs Thatcher] may have been on other issues, she had no inhibitions about making the British economy more dependent on foreign companies.' He also says: 'With hindsight, the overvaluation of sterling [in the early Eighties] could be regarded as a fortunate accident which contributed to the subsequent success of the Thatcher government's supply side policies' - the crisis forced improvements in productivity.

As a matter of fact, it was my old friend Lord (Peter) Walker who tried to salvage something from the macro-economic disasters of the early Eighties: faced with people like Thatcher and Sir Keith Joseph (who believed the Department of Trade and Industry should be abolished) he urged a policy of encouraging inward investment as a way of at least achieving some kind of industrial policy.

Higher productivity was a necessary but not a sufficient condition for improving the supply side. The growth of supply itself - actual production - was woefully slow in the UK in the Eighties, and still is.

And here we have once again an overvalued pound - a common factor behind recent industrial crunches and scares. I wonder if Owen thinks this is a prelude to another economic miracle.

A BMW spokesman pointed out last week that when the German company signed its original deal with the British government about Rover the pound was at DM2.80, and last week it was at DM3.15. 'Each pfennig means £8m of increased losses,' he said.

A leading British industrialist told me last week that 'if the present exchange rate persists, half of British manufacturing industry will be wiped out in the next two years'. He added: 'The firms that are shrugging this off are producing goods 70 per cent of whose content is imported.'

There are terrible echoes of 1981 here. We may not have monetarism, but we have a strong pound driving big business to the wall and a Chancellor obsessed with encouraging 'enterprise' and creating small businesses. I do hope it is not his ambition to turn every big business into a small business.

fields.headline: US faces war with ex-KLA
fields.standfirst:
Pentagon braced for bloodshed after raids on guerrillas
Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: US troops should prepare for battle with the former soldiers of the Kosovo Liberation Army, officials in Washington are warning.
fields.byline: Ed Vulliamy  in New York and Helena Smith  in Pristina
fields.body:
US troops should prepare for battle with the former soldiers of the Kosovo Liberation Army, officials in Washington are warning.

A year after Nato launched a bombing campaign to rescue the KLA, Pentagon commanders have formally alerted the US military that it expects to have to engage its former allies 'this spring'.

This comes as senior officials in the Defence Department continue to fight plans to send further reinforcements into what many consider a potential war zone.

The grim prognosis for the restive province has emerged days before the first anniversary of Nato's bombing raids against Yugoslavia after Slobodan Milosevic's refusal to negotiate over Kosovo.

It arises amid increasing tension between Washington and Nato commanders in Brussels over the peacekeeping operation in Kosovo.

US military officials and Western diplomats based in Pristina, Kosovo's edgy capital, say there is evidence that Albanian insurgents are bent on stirring trouble in southern Serbia, on the province's eastern boundary. They say they must be stopped now if bloodshed across the entire region is to be averted - not least in Macedonia, where conflict could easily trigger a much wider conflagration.

Diplomatic sources in Pristina warn that the extremists, who call themselves the Liberation Army of Presevo, Medvedja and Bujanovac (UCPMB) - named after the three Albanian-inhabited towns in southern Serbia's Presevo valley - should expect more US raids on strongholds of ethnic Albanian guerrillas of the sort conducted last week.

Weapons, ammunition and a supply cache were seized in the raids, aimed at stopping guerrillas from using Kosovo's US-controlled sector as a launching pad for cross-border strikes on Serbia. Analysts believe some 800 men have enrolled with the well-armed UCPMB, formed to 'protect' an estimated 70,000 Albanians living in Serbia within 15 kilometres of the Kosovo border.

'There is scope for great trouble. The next three months will be crucial in determining whether Kosovo is going to be a short-term success or a millstone around the neck of the international community,' said one European Union diplomat. 'We should expect to see more operations by US troops against guerrilla camps in the coming weeks. Frankly Nato is very frustrated that it can't go into Presevo and ensure the peace, that all it can do is seal the border.'

Talking to The Observer on Friday, a Pentagon official said the 'personal security' of US troops would be among 'elements that need looking at' before any manpower boost. The official said the Defence Department is operating on the premise that 'an armed conflict situation with the KLA is much more likely now than has been the case'. One official just returned from Kosovo told US Defence Secretary William Cohen on Wednesday that the intervention was at a 'decisive moment' and back at 'ground zero' a year after it began.

The situation of US troops was 'precarious', said the official. 'This has got to cease and desist, and if not, ultimately it is going to lead to confrontation between ethnic Albanians and K-For.'

Other officials told the New York Times that 'troops could not keep the peace between Serbs and Albanians within Kosovo and seal Kosovo's borders'. They added that last week's raid by the US military on KLA command posts and arms caches was a 'first step' to rein in the Kosovo Albanians. 'This was the first time,' said one official, 'that we went after something like an organised military infrastructure as opposed to searching houses where we suspected someone was holding a rifle or two.'

'There is an old American saying that "when the wood creaks, out come the freaks", but there is no way we are going to tolerate any trouble this spring,' said a US officer. 'We are very serious.'

In Washington, however, the tough Pentagon talk is at odds with the cautious optimism of James Rubin, the US Under-Secretary of State who returned from Kosovo to say: 'We do not believe we are drifting towards a conflict with Kosovo Albanian insurgents.' Rubin believed there was a 'deep reservoir of respect, thanks and goodwill towards the United States' among ethnic Albanians.

Rubin did, however, qualify his words with a warning that 'it would be a grave mistake to challenge American troops'.

A senior Pentagon officer countered: 'We have now fired the first shot at the Albanian insurgents and insurgents have a tendency to carry a grudge. If they come to see us as an enemy then [the raid] will be seen as a turning point.'

webTitle: Signs of order amid the mayhem

fields.headline: Signs of order amid the mayhem
fields.trailText: A week's worth of newspaper headlines paint a fairly comprehensive picture of our contorted industrial landscape; the mayhem and madness would not disgrace a Hieronymus Bosch triptych.
fields.body:
A week's worth of newspaper headlines paint a fairly comprehensive picture of our contorted industrial landscape; the mayhem and madness would not disgrace a Hieronymus Bosch triptych.

On Monday a proud Stephen Byers unveiled his brand new 'active industrial policy', which revolved around handing half a billion pounds to British Aerospace to go towards the development of a new 'super plane', which appeared to feature such unaeronautical concepts as squash courts and swimming pools.

On Tuesday a grinning Martha Lane Fox and Brent Hoberman saw their dot.com IPO lastminute soar to a valuation of £700 million-plus - not bad for a business that has the turnover of a High Street shoe shop.

On Wednesday it became clear to the world, and to a shaken Byers, that Rover was about to be sold by its BMW owners, despite elaborate recovery plans agreed with the Government less than a year ago. The 'active industrial policy' crashed and burned two days after its launch. By late Wednesday evening a further stunning fact was that the buyer was a venture capital company, Alchemy, known more for its buyouts of pubs and residential care homes than for its skills in heavy industry. Beware the Ides of March as a former Longbridge local might have said.

Oh, and like Byers' 'active industrial policy', lastminute.com's share price nosedived - to close almost at its flotation price.

On Thursday, the Dow Jones Industrial Average recorded its largest one-day rise in history, rocketing 500 points as investors poured money into traditional 'old economy' blue chips.

The new and old economies tangled like a couple of pitbulls in the dirt - with the dust and fury making it hard to spot who was getting the upper hand.

But what emerges from the chaos is in fact a reaffirmation of order. The wave of euphoria that even allowed Lastminute to float is in some ways a contributing factor to Rover's failure; when markets are excitable and consumers spend freely, the pound rises. And while Martha and Brent become rich on this euphoria, it cuts off the oxygen supply for German-owned Rover.

Events also affirmed how difficult it is for any government to get the balance of intervention and free-market policies right. Byers encouraged the notion of rip-off Britain, that cars were too expensive, while the Government taxed fuel punitively - it cannot have been too surprised then when, by encouraging such strenuous competition, it produced such a tragic loser as Rover.

However, the really shameful episode here is that having adopted a paternal attitude towards the BMW/Rover relationship, the DTI did not seem to be too good at hands-on parenting. The fact that for six months a tiny venture capital company could negotiate for a key part of the UK's manufacturing base without so much as a whisper reaching the Minister's ear is nothing short of a scandal. I don't believe the Government could have saved Rover - not without entering the euro - but there was surely a better way to manage the decline.

And there is one more underlying inescapable truth here: no matter what the fashions of the marketplace, well run realistic businesses will survive the trends while the flaky and weak ultimately go to the wall. So the chances of either lastminute.com or Rover still being around in two year's time are as slim as Byers' are of surviving into the next Parliament at the DTI.

On Wednesday it became clear to the world, and to a shaken Byers, that Rover was about to be sold by its BMW owners, despite elaborate recovery plans agreed with the Government less than a year ago. The 'active industrial policy' crashed and burned two days after its launch. By late Wednesday evening a further stunning fact was that the buyer was a venture capital company, Alchemy, known more for its buyouts of pubs and residential care homes than for its skills in heavy industry. Beware the Ides of March as a former Longbridge local might have said. Oh, and like Byers' 'active industrial policy', lastminute.com's share price nosedived - to close almost at its flotation price. On Thursday, the Dow Jones Industrial Average recorded its largest one-day rise in history, rocketing 500 points as investors poured money into traditional 'old economy' blue chips. The new and old economies tangled like a couple of pitbulls in the dirt - with the dust and fury making it hard to spot who was getting the upper hand. But what emerges from the chaos is in fact a reaffirmation of order. The wave of euphoria that even allowed Lastminute to float is in some ways a contributing factor to Rover's failure; when markets are excitable and consumers spend freely, the pound rises. And while Martha and Brent become rich on this euphoria, it cuts off the oxygen supply for German-owned Rover. Events also affirmed how difficult it is for any government to get the balance of intervention and free-market policies right. Byers encouraged the notion of rip-off Britain, that cars were too expensive, while the Government taxed fuel punitively - it cannot have been too surprised then when, by encouraging such strenuous competition, it produced such a tragic loser as Rover. However, the really shameful episode here is that having adopted a paternal attitude towards the BMW/Rover relationship, the DTI did not seem to be too good at hands-on parenting. The fact that for six months a tiny venture capital company could negotiate for a key part of the UK's manufacturing base without so much as a whisper reaching the Minister's ear is nothing short of a scandal. I don't believe the Government could have saved Rover - not without entering the euro - but there was surely a better way to manage the decline. And there is one more underlying inescapable truth here: no matter what the fashions of the marketplace, well run realistic businesses will survive the trends while the flaky and weak ultimately go to the wall. So the chances of either lastminute.com or Rover still being around in two year's time are as slim as Byers' are of surviving into the next Parliament at the DTI. emily.bell@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Stores set to win on cashbacks

fields.headline: Stores set to win on cashbacks
fields.standfirst: State-backed study wants £50 limit on shoppers raised
fields.trailText: State-backed study wants £50 limit on shoppers raised
fields.body:
Banks, already accused of profiteering, face a new threat tomorrow when a Government-backed inquiry is to support a campaign to lift restrictions on 'cashback' facilities for shoppers and drinkers.

Supermarkets, which have joined the campaign by retailers, are threatening to remove the banks' cashpoint machines from their stores unless the bankers lift the £50 limit on cashbacks at the tills. Pub chains are planning to expand trial cash services.

The Banking Industry Review will say the banks should relax the limit because consumers will soon be hit by penalties of up to £2.50 when they take as little as £10 from cashpoints - even though withdrawals costs the banks a maximum of 30p.

The inquiry head, Don Cruickshank, has already recommended in an interim report that the limit should be raised as part of a general relaxation of restrictions on consumer choice.

'Retailers are in discussions with each other and with the banks about the £50 limit and they would be very happy to see it raised,' said British Retail Consortium (BRC) official Ann Grain.

Sainsbury's said it had told banks it would not renew licences for the 919 cashpoint machines at its stores unless the limit is eased.

'Why should our customers pay a fine to withdraw cash from a machine outside our store when they can get it for free at our tills?' asked a spokesman. 'This limit is out-dated and unfair.'

Half of all adults in the AB social group use a cashpoint at least once a week and are expected to be among the worst hit by the banks' new fees. People living in rural areas and small towns are particularly badly affected.

Sainsbury says its cashback transactions have increased by 10 per cent since banks agreed to charge cashpoint users. Asda puts its rise at double that.

All kinds of retailers have joined the campaign, including brewer Whitbread. 'Our trial of the cashback service in the Hogshead pubs has been very successful, especially with students and in remote areas,' said a Whitbread spokeswoman.

The banks, which imposed the limit in the Eighties, claim that raising it would encourage fraud. The Cruickshank report is expected to reject this argument.

The retailers say increasing cashbacks would lessen the risk of theft because they will have less money in the tills. They would also benefit from reduced cash collection fees and bank charges.

The campaign is the latest twist in a long-running row between retailers and banks over charges. The BRC accuses the banks of 'cartel-like practices'.

The Cruickshank report is expected to criticise the banks for the way they levy charges and make 'excessive' profits. Its interim study found that the current system of cashpoint charges 'is inefficient, anti-competitive and socially exclusive'. It added: 'There is an overwhelming case for change.'

Cruickshank wants access to cash opened up: 'Retailers are natural suppliers of cash to their customers, and might be willing to increase their activities in this regard if permitted by card scheme rules.'

Some observers expect the former chief of the telecoms watchdog, Oftel, to take the ultimate step of recommending that banks be referred to the Office of Fair Trading.

The review's publication, the day before the Budget, will enable the Chancellor, Gordon Brown, to renew his attack on institutions whose power works against the consumer.

fields.headline: 'We-mail' splits online couples
fields.trailText: Love, honour, and cherish. But share e-mail? Not if you want to stay married.
fields.body:
Love, honour, and cherish. But share e-mail? Not if you want to stay married.

Joint e-mail accounts, dubbed 'We-mail', are replacing the mobile phone redial button as the biggest modern threat to relationships.

Couples may share a home, secrets, friends and finances, but, Internet companies say, joint e-mail addresses are guaranteed to get the crockery flying.

More and more newly-weds are sharing addresses - kevin&sharon@essex.co.uk - or creating new ones like wevegothitched.com. But going digital is often the prelude to getting ditched. Internet firms report thousands of couples falling out online. Wives are accusing their husbands of deleting e-mails so that they cannot read them. Husbands complain their wives read their messages but use the 'keep as new' button to cover their tracks.

One husband discovered his wife was deleting her outgoing messages complaining about him when her friends incorporated them in their replies. 'She was telling her friends things that she was not telling me,' he said.

One woman asked Microsoft to shut a Hotmail account after becoming convinced her husband was having an affair. 'She practically ordered us to ban her husband,' a spokesman said.

Men and women use e-mail in different ways, Internet companies say, causing thousands of 'domestics'. Men like a neat, regularly emptied inbox while women don't mind messages overflowing.

'We've had women furiously calling us because their husbands have deleted e-mailed photographs of their friend's new baby,' one Internet company told The Observer. 'Their husbands delete old files that their wives want to keep.' Stay-at-home mothers often resent their husband's work e-mail addresses. 'He can read all my e-mails but I can't read all his,' one woman complained.

Internet researchers say sharing passwords is perilous. 'Couples are used to negotiating tough issues but e-mail is mysterious and that makes it tricky,' says Prof Helen Petrie of Hertfordshire University.

Part of the problem is that people 'talk more freely' online, Petrie says. 'People find e-mail very disinhibiting because you are not getting an immediate response. People write things they would not dream of saying over the phone.'

And what if the e-strain gets too much and a couple separate? Who gets custody of the treasured e-mail address? One women who works via e-mail found she could not run her business without using an address with her husband's name.

'I want to use my maiden name again' she says. 'But a new e-mail address would kill my business. I'm stuck.'

The answer, says Matt Whyman, the agony uncle on AOL, is to stick to e-his and e-hers. 'Having a joint e-mail account is like having the speakerphone on every time someone calls you. Some things are best kept private.'

webTitle: Lord of gossips fights rumours that doom him

fields.headline: Lord of gossips fights rumours that doom him
fields.trailText: He is the doyen of gossip columnists. No soirée on the canapé circuit is complete without his balmy bourgeois brogue.
fields.body:
He is the doyen of gossip columnists. No soirée on the canapé circuit is complete without his balmy bourgeois brogue.

His Daily Mail column is read by millions and, with his troupe of Pekinese dogs and love of racing, he frequently graces the society columns himself. But now the gossips' gossip finds himself the target of the sort of rumours he has reported so diligently for a quarter of a century.

From the salons of the smart set to high-society balls, tongues are wagging with salty gossip. They are all asking the same question: is it time for the gadfly of Kensington and Chelsea to put down his pen?

Dempster's age is said to be on the mind of the new 32-year-old Mail proprietor, Viscount Rothermere. Those wagging tongues say he thinks Dempster's creaking tales of the newly-wed and the nearly-dead are passé.

The columnist, who will soon be eligible for a bus pass, denies rumours he is being quietly urged to make way for a younger generation, or that Rothermere's influential wife, Claudia, 'cannot bear' his column of aristocratic non-happenings.

The Mail will not discuss Dempster's position in public. At his London home, the man himself tells callers he has no plans to fall off his poisonous perch. 'I just laugh it off because I know it's not true,' he told The Observer .

'My boss, Lord Rothermere, finds it amusing because every time we appear in another column it shows we are doing the right thing. Claudia has telephoned me on several occasions just to say the stories are total fantasy.'

But journalists on the Mail , where insiders claim Dempster earns £1,000 per column, complain he is out of time.

'His column may have been OK for Fifties Britain when racing was the sport of kings and the class system meant something,' one said. 'But its snobby tone is totally wrong now. I mean, who, under the age of 60, actually cares whether the Duke of Arseshire has a couple of good new fillies?'

Executives say Dempster is no longer a protected species. 'Nigel's column is like page three of the Sun ,' one source at Associated, the Mail's owner , said. 'It is a very strong brand. But, at the same time, we know it is an anachronism. What do we do?'

Dempster's reputation was once as secure as the Mail' s rising circulation. But, unkind souls say, the strain of a life of prying began to get to him two years ago, when he was arrested for alleged drunk-driving, although he was acquitted when the court agreed his fear of needles was sufficient to excuse him taking a conclusive blood test at the time. Months later he was embroiled in fisticuffs with his deputy, Adam Helliker, when Helliker announced he was leaving for the Sunday Telegraph .

Things got worse last year when a series of Day-Glo posters featuring his distinguished face and the slogan 'Nigel Dempster is Bald' appeared in London. He blamed them on James Palumbo, who runs the Ministry of Sound club and has been a frequent victim of Dempster's column. The attacks continued in the Mirror, which mocked his love of high life and horse racing.

Dempster defends his subjects as ' de nos jours' . 'You look at the last few weeks and you will see a vast variety of people - footballers, rugby players. I'm afraid we do draw the line at Meg Matthews. The last time we wrote about a title? Oh, I think I wrote about Lord Montagu of Beaulieu's daughter, who is a decorator and does not use her title.'

He insists that he will retain his place at the top table in society circles because he, just like his column, is ageless.

'Diaries are timeless. You can put anything into them. I can cope with the professional jealousy of others. I'm very relaxed.' Friends will be relieved to hear it.

fields.headline: Midlands Ripper unmasked
fields.standfirst: Detectives now believe that the motorway killer they trapped in a routine DNA test may have murdered more women than Peter Sutcliffe.
fields.trailText: Detectives now believe that the motorway killer they trapped in a routine DNA test may have murdered more women than Peter Sutcliffe.
fields.body:
It was daylight, but the car's headlights were on. As Betty Wilson drove past the mud-caked brown Sierra parked on a grass verge, she noticed a small man in the driver's seat trying to pull a trilby hat down over his face. Alongside him was a woman sitting bolt upright in a jet black dress.

'Her eyes were open,' Wilson said last week. 'And she had strange marks on her face.' But she was in a hurry to get to work and drove on.

The 20-year-old woman in the Sierra, Samo Paull, was dead. She had been strangled and burst blood vessels had made her skin go mottled. The nervous-looking man was Alun Kyte, a loner from the West Midlands police now believe may be a worse mass killer than Peter Sutcliffe, the infamous Yorkshire Ripper.

Like Sutcliffe, Kyte had few friends and a violent hatred of women. He also preyed on prostitutes and killed them after sex. Like Sutcliffe, Kyte managed to evade arrest for years. But while Sutcliffe was jailed for killing eight young women, detectives believe Kyte, 35, may have murdered as many as 20 prostitutes in a macabre murder spree lasting almost two decades.

He was given two life sentences at Nottingham Crown Court last week for the murder of Paull, last seen alive in December 1993, and another Birmingham prostitute, Tracy Turner, last seen on 3 March 1994 at 12.41am at the Hilton Park Service station on the M6 near Staffordshire. Her naked body was found seven hours later, dumped on the verge of another desolate lane.

But the proceedings in court did not convey the full story of the activities of the so-called Midlands Ripper or the extent of his evil. As detectives told The Observer this weekend that they were examining the disappearances of prostitutes going back to 1984, the first details of Kyte's life were beginning to emerge - and a trail of deaths stretching from Liverpool to Glasgow.

It seemed, according to detectives, that he chose to live an itinerant lifestyle in order to maximise his opportunity to kill in different parts of the country.

There was little to suggest from his background that Kyte would embark on such a grisly criminal career. He was born on 7 July 1964 in Tittensor, Stoke on Trent. After growing up with his parents in a quiet suburban street in the Rickerscote area of Stafford, Kyte left school and started a series of odd jobs.

A sickly youngster, he always kept an inhaler nearby in case of a sudden attack of the chronic asthma he had suffered from since he was a boy. His mother and two sisters doted on him, believing he could do no wrong.

Few people knew Kyte closely. A rare childhood friend at the local pub says: 'He'd come in here with his mate, play pool and leave.' He was rarely seen with women and often lived in hostels or bed and breakfasts, and often travelled hundreds of miles in a week, telling acquaintances he was looking for work.

Detectives now know he was also scouring the country for victims. They were almost always prostitutes - picked because they were vulnerable and many did not have families who knew what they were doing. He also frequented motorway service stations.

When reports first reached police that a man was attacking prostitutes, it was difficult to know if the same person was involved. Information on the attacks was collated by Operation Enigma, the police's audacious attempt to find links between 72 unsolved murders of women throughout the country.

The operation, run by the National Crime Faculty in Hampshire, used tracking and data analysis techniques from Canada. Detectives and forensic scientists sought to upgrade DNA samples and genetic information discovered at the scene of every crime, and match them to unsolved murders.

But Kyte was cunning. A chilling insight into his modus operandi was provided to The Observer last week by a former prostitute in the Birmingham area. Now the mother of five children, she was working alone on a wet March night in the Balsall Heath area. At 10pm, she was approached by Kyte, who offered her £40 for sex. He was her seventh customer that night. 'He drove me in a tan Maestro for a few miles down the road, and we stopped in the dark, unlit car park of Moseley Hall Hospital.'

Kyte's accent was soft - reassuring. Cassette tapes and litter were strewn about the car floor; a tartan blanket was stretched across the back seat. Kyte went to the back of the car, something she was accustomed to, as many businessmen kept their money in their briefcase in the boot.

He got back in the car and put his left arm around her neck, and put a Stanley knife to her neck. 'He told me to give him my purse and house keys, and to take my clothes off. I was petrified and kept telling him not to kill me, that I was three months pregnant. Something in him must have changed at the mention of a baby, as he then told me to get out, and threw my clothes after me.'

The woman ran to the local police station and made a full statement. Since the murders of Turner and Paull, the police had moved to make the local prostitutes more aware of the threat. She admits her escape was down to luck; her abiding impression of the man with the blade to her throat was that he had been in that situation before.

Soon afterwards, Kyte was seen at Alton Services in the West Midlands masquerading as a reporter from Stafford. He asked detailed questions about recent murders in the area and whether the victims had been seen at the service station, and used a pay phone to make a fake call to his news editor.

Kyte enjoyed the high profile his gruesome murders warranted and managed to evade police despite being arrested for a string of petty offences. His favourite crime was to shoplift goods and return them for cash.

On the night of Tracy Turner's death, Central Television ran a reconstruction of Paull's murder. But the Crime Stalker programme went disastrously wrong: police believe Kyte saw the programme and that it fuelled his desire to kill again three hours later.

He was arrested in December 1997 at the scene of a rape. His victim had fled the lodging house where he had sodomised her and Kyte was arrested two hours later, leaving the premises. He was found guilty at Bristol Crown Court and sentenced to eight years in jail.

It was only after detectives took a routine sample that his DNA was matched with that found on the body of Turner in March 1998. He was charged with her murder in May of that year, and that of Paull's soon after. Detectives were jubilant: they had their man.

Now police are investigating his connection with the August 1994 strangling of Liverpool-born Julie Finlay, 23, found semi-naked in a field near the Raynford bypass; the 1997 Glasgow murder of prostitute Tracy Wylde; with the murder of Natalie Pearman in November 1992; with the 1994 strangling of Dawn Shields from Sheffield; with the March 1993 strangling of Gloucester prostitute Carol Clark, found dumped by a Bristol canal. They are also going back as far as the murder of 28-year-old prostitute Yvonne Coley in 1984.

Their relatives wait with what Julie Finlay's mother, Patricia, describes as the 'same set of emotions that occur every time the police have a lead'. They just want the crimes linked to the killer.

One emotion remains constant. 'I can't get Julie out of my mind', her mother says. 'Her killer is still alive while she's in a cemetery.'

Information on the attacks was collated by Operation Enigma, the police's audacious attempt to find links between 72 unsolved murders of women throughout the country. The operation, run by the National Crime Faculty in Hampshire, used tracking and data analysis techniques from Canada. Detectives and forensic scientists sought to upgrade DNA samples and genetic information discovered at the scene of every crime, and match them to unsolved murders. But Kyte was cunning. A chilling insight into his modus operandi was provided to The Observer last week by a former prostitute in the Birmingham area. Now the mother of five children, she was working alone on a wet March night in the Balsall Heath area. At 10pm, she was approached by Kyte, who offered her £40 for sex. He was her seventh customer that night. 'He drove me in a tan Maestro for a few miles down the road, and we stopped in the dark, unlit car park of Moseley Hall Hospital.' Kyte's accent was soft - reassuring. Cassette tapes and litter were strewn about the car floor; a tartan blanket was stretched across the back seat. Kyte went to the back of the car, something she was accustomed to, as many businessmen kept their money in their briefcase in the boot. He got back in the car and put his left arm around her neck, and put a Stanley knife to her neck. 'He told me to give him my purse and house keys, and to take my clothes off. I was petrified and kept telling him not to kill me, that I was three months pregnant. Something in him must have changed at the mention of a baby, as he then told me to get out, and threw my clothes after me.' The woman ran to the local police station and made a full statement. Since the murders of Turner and Paull, the police had moved to make the local prostitutes more aware of the threat. She admits her escape was down to luck; her abiding impression of the man with the blade to her throat was that he had been in that situation before. Soon afterwards, Kyte was seen at Alton Services in the West Midlands masquerading as a reporter from Stafford. He asked detailed questions about recent murders in the area and whether the victims had been seen at the service station, and used a pay phone to make a fake call to his news editor. Kyte enjoyed the high profile his gruesome murders warranted and managed to evade police despite being arrested for a string of petty offences. His favourite crime was to shoplift goods and return them for cash. On the night of Tracy Turner's death, Central Television ran a reconstruction of Paull's murder. But the Crime Stalker programme went disastrously wrong: police believe Kyte saw the programme and that it fuelled his desire to kill again three hours later. He was arrested in December 1997 at the scene of a rape. His victim had fled the lodging house where he had sodomised her and Kyte was arrested two hours later, leaving the premises. He was found guilty at Bristol Crown Court and sentenced to eight years in jail. It was only after detectives took a routine sample that his DNA was matched with that found on the body of Turner in March 1998. He was charged with her murder in May of that year, and that of Paull's soon after. Detectives were jubilant: they had their man. Now police are investigating his connection with the August 1994 strangling of Liverpool-born Julie Finlay, 23, found semi-naked in a field near the Raynford bypass; the 1997 Glasgow murder of prostitute Tracy Wylde; with the murder of Natalie Pearman in November 1992; with the 1994 strangling of Dawn Shields from Sheffield; with the March 1993 strangling of Gloucester prostitute Carol Clark, found dumped by a Bristol canal. They are also going back as far as the murder of 28-year-old prostitute Yvonne Coley in 1984. Their relatives wait with what Julie Finlay's mother, Patricia, describes as the 'same set of emotions that occur every time the police have a lead'. They just want the crimes linked to the killer. webTitle: Future of museums is illuminated by Kells

fields.headline: Future of museums is illuminated by Kells
fields.trailText: The Book of Kells, or rather a section of it, was on display in Canberra last week to coincide with Bertie Ahern's visit to Australia. In May it will travel to Washington, where it will be one of the highlights in a festival of Irish arts.
fields.body:
The Book of Kells, or rather a section of it, was on display in Canberra last week to coincide with Bertie Ahern's visit to Australia. In May it will travel to Washington, where it will be one of the highlights in a festival of Irish arts.

The eighth-century Celtic manuscript is Ireland's most important artistic treasure. Each year thousands of people visit the library in Trinity College, Dublin to marvel at its brilliant illuminations and the painstaking skills of the monks who created it.

The Book of Kells has been in Trinity for more than 300 years, although pages are occasionally loaned to other major institutions. Now a campaign is under way for it to be displayed in Kells, the small town in Co Meath where most of it was penned and which was its home until the dissolution of the monasteries during the Reformation.

A few years ago such an idea would have been dismissed out of hand. Art treasures of this kind were kept in museums where the right conditions could be guaranteed. But that mood may be changing.

Kells, like many other Irish towns, is intensely proud of its history. The local authority is currently restoring the eighteenth-century courthouse as a heritage centre, at a cost of over £1 million.

The centre will open this summer with an exhibition focusing on the town's centuries-old tradition as a monastic settlement. The district council hopes that a number of major art treasures, which originated in Kells but are currently held in museums in Ireland and Britain, will form part of this.

The most dramatic artefact would be the Book of Kells , but an approach has already been made to the British Museum for the loan of a medieval bishop's crozier. The response has been cautious but not unfavourable. The museum has said it would need guarantees on such matters as security, but is always keen to treat such requests sympathetically.

Trinity College was more pessimistic when the initial request was made for the Book of Kells to be brought home for a month this summer. But the campaign has been gathering momentum. Fine Gael leader John Bruton, who represents Kells in the Dail, has asked Trinity to reconsider. Michael Smith, the Catholic Bishop of Meath, has weighed in with his support. Now Dr Tom Mitchell, the Provost of Trinity, has agreed to meet the local authority.

The story highlights an issue which has already become a matter for debate in Britain. What are museums for? Traditionally, art treasures have been kept in galleries and institutions where they could be cared for by experts and their physical safety guaranteed. They were accessible to anyone who wanted to see them. Now, these conditions about security, atmosphere and so on can be met much more easily.

In recent years many museums have become conscious of the need to be more consumer-friendly by making exhibitions more attractive, particularly to young people who would not normally darken their doors except as part of a school trip.

Alongside this, there has been a huge growth of interest in local history in Ireland. Sometimes it seems that every small town has its own heritage centre or museum. At its best, such enthusiasm has produced institutions such as the Famine Museum in Strokestown, Co Roscommon, where material from the local 'big house' has been used, alongside historical documents, to examine the history of the Famine.

Such developments have been encouraged with a shrewd eye to the tourist industry. The attraction of cultural tourism has been growing all over the world and Ireland is keen to get in on the act. A town with a legacy of artistic artefacts is more likely to attract visitors.

It is no coincidence that the original proposal to bring the Book of Kells home to Co. Meath came from a group of coach drivers who pointed out that the scrum of tourist buses outside Trinity College would be greatly reduced if the book was moved elsewhere. Why not solve the traffic problem and bring some of the benefits of tourism to Co Meath?

The local council stresses that this is a one-off request for the manuscript to be allowed out on loan for a strictly limited period, as a focal point for the opening of the town's heritage centre and Kells has the resources and funds to meet conditions about security.

Bill Sweeney, town clerk of Kells, believes it would be genuinely interesting for people to see this wonderful work of art close to the setting where it was created. It is an attractive argument, but whether it will persuade Trinity to allow the Book of Kells to return to its home is another matter entirely.

webTitle: Exposed: where child porn lurks on the Net

fields.headline: Exposed: where child porn lurks on the Net
fields.standfirst: Worries about child sex led to the creation of a watchdog by Internet service providers. Demon is a member, so why can its subscribers still find paedophile images?
fields.trailText: Worries about child sex led to the creation of a watchdog by Internet service providers. Demon is a member, so why can its subscribers still find paedophile images?
fields.body:
For a few seconds, you don't know what it is you're looking at. There's something wrong with the photograph. Two people are involved in a sex act. Both are naked. One is three times the size of the other. The small one has pigtails. She looks a bit like your neighbour's daughter.

Every day thousands of paedophilic photographs showing adults abusing small children are posted on the Internet. The photos can be found in online newsgroups, the 90,000 or so 'discussion' forums that form the underbelly of the Internet and allow cyber-surfers to debate everything from American football to favourite television soaps.

Often snaps are posted in reply to a plea from a user seeking a particular kind of photograph. Those using the newsgroups to swap snaps talk to each other all the time. There is a sophisticated network. Frequenters of the newsgroups adopt handles such as Jet Boy and Captain Ecchi.

'A lot of the people who take this stuff seriously are serial collectors. That's why when we go into their computers we find they've got something like 6,000 stored images,' said Chief Superintendent Martin Jauch of the Metropolitan Police Force's Clubs and Vice Unit. But in addition to the older photographs, dating back to the 1970s, fresh ones appear daily. Many show children from the Far East and Third World. A large number are from the former Soviet Union. Only around 4 per cent originate from within the UK.

'It's like trafficking women. The same economics and geography applies,' Jauch said. Often a photograph will come with an abstruse website address that reveals a gallery of hardcore images, all of which can be viewed in return for a credit-card payment.

To enter the newsgroups a user needs to be signed up with an Internet Service Provider. Virtually all ISPs - including the big names such as BT, Freeserve and Virgin - ban what they believe are some of the more explicit newsgroups. There is one ISP, based in the US, that makes a great play of offering all the 90,000 newsgroups and guaranteeing subscribers anonymity. In Britain, the range of newsgroups is more restricted, a fact that angers many who believe that cyberspace should be unregulated.

Demon, one of the UK's largest ISPs with nearly 300,000 customers and owned by telecoms giant Scottish Telecom, now called Thus, is a strong supporter of an uncensored Internet and carries a number of the newsgroups banned by most rivals. The newsgroups are often explicitly named: several are described as pre-teens erotica. Others hide behind impenetrable acronyms. Sources in the Internet world suggest that there are up to 40 newsgroups carried by Demon that promote paedophile material.

Newsgroups are stored on an ISP's own news server - a computer database that records all the posted messages. If it were proved that Demon was aware paedophile material had been placed on its server and had failed to remove it, the ISP would be breaking the law. Demon says it acts quickly to remove paedophilic material when it is drawn to its attention.

Yesterday The Observer found scores of paedophilic material in several newsgroups carried by Demon. Some showed young teenage girls and boys; others were of young children performing sex acts on adults. It is illegal to download such material, but this newspaper, which has now destroyed the images, believes it was acting in the public interest.

Four years ago the Government became so worried about the way the Internet was becoming a playground for paedophiles that it threatened sweeping regulatory measures. Ministers became alarmed after the Metropolitan Police issued a list of 133 newsgroups which it believed contained material of a criminal nature.

In response, the ISPs, terrified that their autonomy was about to be curtailed, formed what was to become the Internet Watch Foundation, a self-regulatory body made up of the big players in the Internet. Demon was a driving force behind the creation of the IWF. One of its Internet experts, Clive Feather, be-came its first chairman. The idea was that the IWF would alert the ISPs to the presence of paedophilic material on their servers and would pass on complaints from the public. If an ISP refused to remove the material, the IWF would then alert the police.

But it is clear that something failed to spark at the IWF and in 1998 the Government called in advisers from accountants KPMG and law firm Denton Hall to suggest how the organisation could be strengthened. Relaunched last month, the new look IWF is endorsed by the Government and, in particular, the Department of Trade and Industry, which played a 'facilitating role in its creation', according to a DTI spokesman.

At the time of its launch, Patricia Hewitt, Minister for E-Commerce, said: 'The Internet Watch Foundation plays a vital role in combating criminal material on the Net.' To offset accusations of bias in favour of the ISPs, a new independent chairman was appointed. Roger Darlington, head of research at the Communication Workers Union, heads an enlarged 13-strong board. However, Demon retains two places on the board. Feather chairs the IWF's funding body. Demon contributes around £30,000 a year to the IWF's £225,000 running costs.

Critics have suggested that the fact that ISPs, notably Demon, continue to sit on the industry's own regulatory board represents a conflict of interest. But the Government is loath to scrap the IWF, believing a self-regulatory system is the best solution to a complex problem. The Metropolitan Police also believe that working with the ISPs, rather than trying to force some strong-arm solution, is the way forward.

'We have always taken the view that the co-operation approach was the best one. My disappointment is that the industry in general has not felt it possible to agree a consistent policy,' Jauch said.

Demon has in the past argued that deleting selected newsgroups was counter-productive. The IWF's Darlington said: 'There's a debate in the industry as to whether that [banning certain newsgroups] would shuffle the problem elsewhere.'

Certainly this policy of 'containment', as it is known in the industry, appears to have reaped dividends. The IWF, by monitoring some of the most notorious newsgroups, was able to alert the police to a prolific distributor of paedophile material. Leslie Bollingbroke, 42, who used the Internet pseudonym 'Sam', was recently jailed for four years for posting images of children.

However, the containment argument gets short shrift from other quarters.

'There is no evidence to support this argument, and much to suggest that it is misguided. Most British ISPs have removed paedophile groups without any increase in the amount of illegal content posted to other groups,' one expert said.

Critics of the self-regulation model also point out a paradox at its heart. The IWF often has to rely on tip-offs from the public. But few members of the public will admit to having downloaded paedophiliac material because this is a criminal offence. Recently the IWF's remit was expanded to examine racist publications in newsgroups - a move critics fear may dilute its ability to monitor paedophiliac postings even further.

The police, too, have only limited resources. 'Our Internet unit is very small. We can't monitor what goes on right across the Internet,' said Jauch.

Demon declined to comment on why it was practically the only ISP to continue to carry newsgroups that have been shown habitually to carry paedophilic material. In a written response to The Observer 's questions it stated: 'Newsgroups have long been established as being one of the most valuable of these services, and at their best serve to unite interested parties across the globe to share knowledge and information.'

Critics say paedophiles will merely end up subscribing to foreign ISPs if all of their UK rivals ban selected newsgroups, so a blanket prohibition is futile. However Jauch said: 'That's the same as a club owner saying, "Lots of people take drugs so therefore it's OK if I allow drugs in my club".'

One observer said: 'It's an interesting balance between the protection of children and civil liberties. Although it's not that difficult to work out which side most people fall down on.'

webTitle: Boy, 4 saved by fireman father dies in hospital

fields.headline: Boy, 4 saved by fireman father dies in hospital
fields.trailText: A Scottish Borders town was yesterday mourning the death of a four-year-old boy less than 24 hours after he and his baby sister were rescued from their burning home by firefighters, one of them their own father.
fields.body:
A Scottish Borders town was yesterday mourning the death of a four-year-old boy less than 24 hours after he and his baby sister were rescued from their burning home by firefighters, one of them their own father.

Keiran Riley died in the early hours yesterday at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children in Edinburgh where he had undergone emergency surgery for severe burns after the blaze at his home in Hawick on Friday morning.

His seven-month-old sister, Caitlyn, was snatched from her smoke-filled bedroom by their father, Kenny, a Lothian and Borders firefighter who drove the first engine to arrive at the scene.

Last night, she remained in a 'critical but stable' condition, suffering from the effects of inhaling the choking black smoke that had spread rapidly through the end-of-terrace house.

Mr Riley's wife, Caroline, 38, and her son Derek McLean, 20, were downstairs when the fire broke out and got the couple's two other children, Shannon, two, and Connor, one, outside to safety. But they were prevented by the flames from getting back inside to rescue Keiran and Caitlyn.

Colleagues said yesterday that the family were coping 'as well as they possibly could' under the circumstances.

A fire brigade spokesman said: 'They are doing OK, but it is pretty tough for any family to deal with this sort of tragedy.'

After spending Friday and most of yesterday morning at the hospital, Mrs Riley returned to Hawick to care for their other children while Mr Riley remained at his daughter's bedside.

The brigade has made counselling available, and has arranged transport for the family to travel between their home and Edinburgh.

A post-mortem is due to be carried out on Keiran today.

Mr Riley , a firefighter with 15 years experience, was 10 minutes from the end of his night shift when the 999 call came through from his stepson, Derek, shortly before 8am. He then sped to his home to his home in Queens Drive a qaurter of a mile away.

Without stopping to put on breathing apparatus, he beat his way through the flames and smoke to rescue Caitlyn while directing his colleagues towards Keiran's bedroom, where the blaze is understood to have started.

Mr Riley's assistant divisional commander, Ian Currie, praised him, saying his instincts had overtaken his normal firefighting duties.

'It's every fireman's nightmare when the house involved is your own. He acted as a father, without any thought for his own safety,' he said.

Police and the fire brigade have launched an investigation but foul play is not suspected.

'It's every fireman's nightmare when the house involved is your own. He acted as a father, without any thought for his own safety,' he said. Police and the fire brigade have launched an investigation but foul play is not suspected.

fields.headline: 'British helped to kill Billy Wright'
fields.standfirst:
Angry father of loyalist hero claims a UK set-up handed King Rat to assassins.

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Angry father of loyalist hero claims a UK set-up handed King Rat to assassins.
fields.body:
David Wright, the father of the late Loyalist Volunteer Force leader, Billy Wright, has always been proud to be British - until recently.

Now the 67-year-old grandfather from the loyalist heartland of Portadown says he has lost his faith in British justice after what he describes as a 'series of cover-ups' over the murder of his notorious son in the top-security Maze prison in 1997.

Billy Wright was a hate-figure for nationalists in Northern Ireland, who lived in fear of his Mid-Ulster UVF brigade and later the breakaway LVF, when a team of young loyalists called 'the rat-pack' carried out a campaign of sectarian killings in a part of the Province that became known as the 'murder triangle'.

But Wright's father says his son's reputation should not stop those who believe in civil liberties from investigating the strange circumstances of his death, two days after Christmas 1997.

Later this month David Wright will meet the human rights group British/Irish Rights Watch, which for years has highlighted allegations of the shoot-to-kill, torture and intimidation of republicans by the security forces, to discuss the case.

Wright has been told that the RUC file on his son's death has been closed following the arrest and conviction of three Irish National Liberation Army prisoners who breached security to shoot Billy Wright dead in the forecourt of H-Block 6.

But he is convinced the British state had a hand in setting up his son up for assassination. He points to a number of discrepancies in the official version of the events leading up to Billy Wright's murder, which have been handed over to British/Irish Rights Watch. These include:

* Visiting sheets: According to David Wright and the team investigating the death, sheets outlining who was due to visit relatives and loved ones on 27 December were sent down both wings of H-Block 6 the night before. One wing was occupied by the LVF, while the other was under the de facto control of INLA. This meant that INLA prisoners could see Billy Wright was due a visit from his girlfriend the next morn ing, enabling them to plan his murder. David Wright was given the visit sheets, which were sent down the LVF wing of H-6 a few days after the killing.

David Wright claimed that at the inquest into the murder in February 1999 there was confusion over a second visit-sheet produced in court by a Northern Ireland Office civil servant. He said the civil servant's visit-sheet was radically different from the one handed to him by LVF prisoners. At the inquest the civil servant could not explain why the charge sheets were different from the one handed to David Wright.

* The watchtower overlooking H-6: At the inquest it was admitted that no one was inside the watchtower overlooking the courtyard where two minibuses were parked ready to take LVF prisoners and later INLA inmates to visits in another part of the Maze. The prison officer meant to be manning the watch-tower, Raymond Hill, claimed he was called away via intercom on two occasions, including the period around 9.50 that morning when three INLA inmates cut a wire through a fence on to the courtyard and shot Wright dead inside the visiting van. The NIO initially said Hill was called away on only one occasion.

Five weeks ago Wright was granted a visit to inspect the area where his son was killed. He had been told by NIO officials that the watchtower was not in the line of sight of the part of the fence INLA prisoners cut through. But photographs that Wright requested taken from the watchtower show the hole in the fence would have been in sight of the prison officer, had he been there at the time.

* The camera that overlooks H-6: The security camera trained on the courtyard had not been working from 22 December and had not been repaired over the Christmas period, despite warnings from prison officers of serious trouble between loyalists and republicans in H-Block 6.

Despite the closure of the Billy Wright murder case, his father insists he will continue his campaign for an international, independent judicial inquiry, as nationalists are demanding similar investigations into the murders of solicitors Pat Finucane and Rosemary Nelson.

'The coincidences over the camera, the visit sheets, the absence of anybody in the watchtower in one morning are far too many to be convinced this killing was a fluke,' he said.

Asked why nationalists and republicans should be concerned about the disputed killing of a loyalist who was so loathed in their community, David Wright said: 'There is no death penalty in this country and no one, and I mean no one, should be killed for their political views. Once you go into jail, whether you are republican or loyalist, the state has a right to protect you from being killed or injured.

'The irony is, if Billy Wright had fallen and broken his leg in the gym, the authorities would have been held responsible. And yet they can let Billy Wright be killed in strange circumstances inside a so-called top-security jail. British justice does not exist.'

Those convicted of the killing, including Christopher 'Crip' McWilliams, the man who pulled the trigger, along with John Glennon and John Kenaway, will be freed this year under the Good Friday Agreement's early release scheme. Secretary of State Peter Mandelson, like his predecessor Mo Mowlam, has refused to meet David Wright to discuss his concerns.

 Additional reporting by Chris Anderson

webTitle: Blair was told to deny X-ray jobs to North

fields.headline: Blair was told to deny X-ray jobs to North
fields.standfirst: Wellcome Trust held cancer lab to £100m ransom
fields.trailText: Wellcome Trust held cancer lab to £100m ransom
fields.body:
The Wellcome Trust threatened to pull out of funding a top science project in Britain and back a rival one in France unless a £500 million installation was located in Oxfordshire instead of the North of England.

Threats by the medical charity forced the Prime Minister to move the site of a highly specialised X-ray laboratory from Cheshire to the South of England. His decision last week has provoked the biggest regional revolt Tony Blair has yet had to face.

On Tuesday an angry delegation of up to 70 MPs will accuse Blair of betraying Labour's Northern heartland and killing the scientific community outside the South-East. Critics blame an 'Oxbridge mafia' of scientists and Downing Street advisers for last week's decision.

It is the second time in a year that the wealthy medical charity, linked to drugs giant Glaxo Wellcome, has threatened to take jobs abroad if it does not get its way. In September, Wellcome demanded that Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott overturn a decision to reject a planning application for a £100m expansion of its human genome campus at Cambridge.

Concerns that the charity wields undue influence over government policy are fuelled by a number of close links between the Trust and Whitehall:

 Blair's chief scientific adviser, Sir Robert May, who advised the Prime Minister to move the laboratory to Oxford, works in the same Oxford University zoology department as Professor Roy Anderson, one of the key governors of the Wellcome Trust board. That university department received more than £1m in funds from the Wellcome Trust last year.

 The research of a top scientist at the John Innes Centre is funded by the Wellcome Trust. The Sainsbury Laboratory at Science Minister Lord Sainsbury's Gatsby Foundation and the John Innes Centre are based on the same site in Norwich and have set up a joint company to profit from their discoveries.

 The Wellcome Trust is paying for a key employee to work inside the Government's Office for Science and Technology. Sarah Ginn works for the Council for Science and Technology, which advises the Prime Minister on major scientific advances.

The decision by the Prime Minister to locate the new synchrotron laboratory at the Rutherford Appleton Laboratory in Oxfordshire has provoked protests worldwide from scientists. A synchrotron is a doughnut-shaped machine which can produce exceptionally good quality X-ray images by using electrons travelling at the speed of light, guided by magnets. The new facility is regarded as vital to the future of molecular biology and genome research.

Wellcome is contributing £100m towards the £500m cost of the new laboratory. The British Government is putting up close to £350m and the French are giving £50m.

Many scientists believe that basing the laboratory in Oxford will threaten the world-beating research into causes of breast cancer currently being undertaken by the team already based in Cheshire, at the Daresbury laboratory, near Warrington. They had hoped that the new lab would enhance their existing research and now fear the break up of their team.

Warrington MP Helen Southworth warned: 'It's not just a box you can label and send somewhere else. It's 500 jobs and 500 families.'

Dr Rob Lewis, who heads Daresbury's breast cancer team, said: 'This is an outrageous decision and a disaster for Britain. All the people at Daresbury will up and leave, and we will lose the team which took seven years to build up.

'We're not highly paid. Typical salaries are in the low twenties. Up here, that buys you a three-bedroom house. Down there, it gets you a box. Two senior electronics engineers have already resigned. This is meltdown.'

Liverpool MP Peter Kilfoyle, who quit the Government over his fears that it is ignoring the North-South divide, said: 'It's an outrageous decision. It's part of the attempt to put everything in the golden triangle of London, Oxford and Cambridge.'
