webTitle: Want a baby? Stay away from the wife

fields.headline: Want a baby? Stay away from the wife
fields.standfirst: The best way to get pregnant is not to seek romantic situations, but for the man to concentrate on building up his sperm count.
fields.trailText: The best way to get pregnant is not to seek romantic situations, but for the man to concentrate on building up his sperm count.
fields.body:
Forget wearing loose underpants and romantic candle-lit dinners. Scientists have discovered a simple way of helping couples to conceive: spend more time apart.

Men's sperm count in Britain has been declining rapidly in recent years, leading to fertility problems. But researchers have discovered that men's fertility levels double when they spend most of their time away from their partners.

A report in the scientific journal Personality and Individual Differences says a man's sperm count varies significantly depending on how much he sees his partner. The researchers found that when couples spend all their time together men inseminate 389 million sperm per ejaculation. But when only 5 per cent of their time is in each other's company, the figure almost doubles to 712m.

The report suggests it is not only a case of absence making the heart grow fonder, or of the testicles being replenished with sperm because they haven't been emptied.

It claims there is an evolutionary reason for the surge in fertility: it's the best way a man can ensure his genes win out if his partner has been unfaithful while he was away. By producing so many more sperm while away, a man increases the odds of crowding out a competing man's sperm when he returns.

The researchers say this supports the theory of 'sperm competition', an evolutionary response to humans not being naturally monogamous.

Fertility research has found that, at the time of conception, 4 per cent of women have sperm from different men in their reproductive system. One recent study suggested that one in seven men wasn't the biological father of who he thought was his child. There is also evidence that men produce two types of sperm - one to fertilise the egg, and another to fight off sperm from other males.

The journal report claims women were unfaithful to their long-term partners to maximise chances of becoming pregnant.

Females were likely to indulge in 'short-term mating' with other partners if sex with a regular partner was infrequent.

'An ancestral woman married to a man uninterested in sex may have had a more difficult time getting pregnant,' the report states. 'If this is correct, then fertility back-up is a possible function of a woman's short-term mating. Alternatively, a partner's lack of sexual interest may signal to the woman that he is channelling his sexual interest and perhaps commitment elsewhere, in which case the woman might benefit by doing likewise.' The theory of 'sperm competition' helps to explain the size of testicles across different species. In primates, there is a strong correlation between the size of testicles - and thus the amount of sperm produced - and the level of female promiscuity. The greater the promiscuity, the larger the testicles relative to body size. According to the theory, the males with the biggest testicles are more likely to have offspring, because they produce more sperm, which are more likely to crowd out the sperm of any rival male. Male gorillas can have small testicles and small amounts of sperm because the female of the species is highly monogamous. But chimpanzees are highly promiscuous and the males tend to have testicles relatively 10 times the size of those of gorillas.

Human males are somewhere between chimps and gorillas. This suggests ancestral humans were not as promiscuous as chimpanzees - but neither were they entirely monogamous.

Dr Amin Gorgy, clinical director of the London Fertility Centre, said: 'The bottom line is that it is an interesting theory, but it has not been proven, and I would think it is unlikely to change the cultural behaviour of human beings. However, some men find it difficult to stay monogamous, and maybe there is a biological reason for that.'

fields.headline: Falcons fall prey to smugglers
fields.standfirst: Stuart Millar,  our new Scotland Editor , uncovers a breed of criminals whose lucrative trade is not drugs, but wild peregrines spirited out of Britain to the Gulf
fields.trailText: Stuart Millar,  our new Scotland Editor , uncovers a breed of criminals whose lucrative trade is not drugs, but wild peregrines spirited out of Britain to the Gulf
fields.body:
As the large black Mercedes nosed through Dover towards the ferry, it was pulled over by Customs officers. Acting on a tip-off, they searched the car and its occupants. But they found no trace of the illegal and highly profitable cargo it was supposed to be carrying.

Then the officers decided to take the car apart - and there, in a sophisticated incubation system hidden inside the dashboard and wired into the Merc's electrics, they found what they were looking for: not drugs, but peregrine falcon eggs.

Once, stealing birds of prey was dismissed as the preserve of a few unscrupulous, overzealous twitchers. But an Observer investigation can reveal that the international trade in stolen wild peregrines is burgeoning after being taken over by a network of European criminal gangs, branching out from more conventional illegal activities to enjoy vast, virtually risk-free profits on offer.

With Scotland rapidly emerging as the world centre of a multimillion-pound trade stretching through Germany to the Gulf Arab states, investigators last week demanded stiffer penalties to help them in their battle of wits with the new breed of falcon smuggler.

Conservation experts suspect that up to 20 nests are being lost to the thieves each year, making them the most ruthless threat to the peregrines since they were almost wiped out by pesticide use in the Sixties and Seventies. The birds are included in the same category as tigers in the list of most endangered species.

The gangs carry out their raids in the dead of night kitted out with night-sights and full camouflage gear. As the Mercedes find demonstrates, they are employing expertise gleaned from drug operations to spirit their cargoes out of the country.

The two men involved, both Germans, each received 18 months in prison, but that is only because they were foreign nationals and were caught trying to leave Britain. Most of those caught stealing or trapping birds get off more lightly.

'We are talking about dangerous people who have been involved in other serious crimes,' said David Dick, the RSPB's leading investigator in Scotland. 'The attractions are obvious: if you get caught with a car full of drugs you are in serious trouble. But if you get caught with a load of wild peregrine falcons, the worst you're going to suffer is a fine and having your car confiscated. If you give criminals an easy option, they will milk it for all it is worth.'

The scale of the problem was highlighted last week when a man described as the biggest threat to Scotland's peregrines walked free from Ayr sheriff court after being found guilty of six charges, including setting a trap, trying to snare a falcon and using a live pigeon as bait.

It was Matt Morrison's fifth conviction on similar offences - even his lawyer told the court his client was 'in denial' on wildlife matters, but the unemployed 59-year-old received only a £2,700 fine and had his £500 E-reg Ford Sierra confiscated.

Operating from a council house on a shabby estate in Ayr, Morrison has become the key supplier to the European underworld's peregrine trade, according to RSPB investigators who have been monitoring his activities for a the past decade. He is believed to be the only Briton to have mastered the art of trapping live adult falcons, the ultimate commodity for the gangs as they do not need to be trained to hunt. Adult Scottish peregrines can command more than £6,000 each from Arab buyers.

Morrison is not the only British supplier, however. Police and the RSPB have established that at least three gangs from the north of England have moved into the game, including one operating out of the Newcastle area, whose main players all have a string of convictions for offences ranging from drug dealing to violence.

Rather than take live birds, they specialise in robbing nests of eggs and chicks. They are even understood to have carved up the main Scottish peregrine areas between themselves and Morrison.

Charles MacKay, Customs' senior officer on the endangered species team at Heathrow airport, said: 'It is the enthusiasts who perpetuate the trade because they are willing to pay for rare species, but more and more it is the serious criminal element taking over the supply side, because the potential penalties are soft and the rewards can be extremely high.'

The supply chain is as sophisticated as that used for drugs. A rich Arab decides he needs a new falcon and phones a broker in the German underworld who places the order with one of the gangs. Once captured, the adults, chicks or eggs are hidden until they are picked up by a courier from England who will drive them to holding centres in the south. They are then smuggled out of Britain to Germany, where they are 'laundered' into the legal, captive-bred falcon population with the help of breeders.

The falcons can then be exported quasi-legally to their buyers in the Middle East. Fully trained peregrines up to a year old typically fetch up to £5,000 while chicks are worth about £1,000 each. In some cases the gangs have set up training centres in Morocco to allow the birds to acclimatise to the intense heat.

British investigators have nothing but contempt for the smugglers. 'These people are not falcon enthusiasts,' said Dick. 'They are career criminals who don't see the peregrines as beautiful birds of prey, they see them as flying pound notes.'

Operating from a council house on a shabby estate in Ayr, Morrison has become the key supplier to the European underworld's peregrine trade, according to RSPB investigators who have been monitoring his activities for a the past decade. He is believed to be the only Briton to have mastered the art of trapping live adult falcons, the ultimate commodity for the gangs as they do not need to be trained to hunt. Adult Scottish peregrines can command more than £6,000 each from Arab buyers. Morrison is not the only British supplier, however. Police and the RSPB have established that at least three gangs from the north of England have moved into the game, including one operating out of the Newcastle area, whose main players all have a string of convictions for offences ranging from drug dealing to violence. Rather than take live birds, they specialise in robbing nests of eggs and chicks. They are even understood to have carved up the main Scottish peregrine areas between themselves and Morrison. Charles MacKay, Customs' senior officer on the endangered species team at Heathrow airport, said: 'It is the enthusiasts who perpetuate the trade because they are willing to pay for rare species, but more and more it is the serious criminal element taking over the supply side, because the potential penalties are soft and the rewards can be extremely high.' The supply chain is as sophisticated as that used for drugs. A rich Arab decides he needs a new falcon and phones a broker in the German underworld who places the order with one of the gangs. Once captured, the adults, chicks or eggs are hidden until they are picked up by a courier from England who will drive them to holding centres in the south. They are then smuggled out of Britain to Germany, where they are 'laundered' into the legal, captive-bred falcon population with the help of breeders. The falcons can then be exported quasi-legally to their buyers in the Middle East. Fully trained peregrines up to a year old typically fetch up to £5,000 while chicks are worth about £1,000 each. In some cases the gangs have set up training centres in Morocco to allow the birds to acclimatise to the intense heat. British investigators have nothing but contempt for the smugglers. 'These people are not falcon enthusiasts,' said Dick. 'They are career criminals who don't see the peregrines as beautiful birds of prey, they see them as flying pound notes.' stuart.millar@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: One in three Britons now own stocks and shares
fields.body:
One in three Britons now own stocks and shares

Nearly one in three adults in Britain now invests in the stock market - and more of them are switching to the Internet to carry out their dealing, according to a survey.

About 2.7 million people have considered buying stocks and shares on top of the 13.5 million who have some kind of stock market investment, according to the survey by RSGB for stockbrokers Charles Schwab Europe.

Climber falls 100ft

A climber was airlifted to hospital after falling 100ft from a cliff at Huntsman's Leap near Milford Haven, west Wales, coastguards said.

The man, who has not been named, was airlifted to Withybush Hospital in Haverfordwest by a helicopter from RAF Chivenor in north Devon. His condition is not yet known.

Fuel protest

Hundreds of lorry and tractor drivers hooted their horns to cheering shoppers yesterday as they converged on the centre of Newcastle upon Tyne to protest at rising fuel prices.

Organisers of the four-hour protest claim 400 vehicles took part, although police say there were only 180.

The convoy, organised by the Hauliers and Farmers Alliance, was protesting at the Government's policy of getting more freight off the roads and on to the railways. A police spokeswoman said: 'The noise was deafening.'

Truck deaths

A man and a boy died yesterday when they became trapped in the cab of a lorry which was partly submerged after overturning into a water-filled ditch on the Isle of Grain, Kent. A girl, also in the cab, was rescued.

Dublin honours Burmese human rights leader

The freedom of the city of Dublin was conferred on the Burmese opposition party leader Aung San Suu Kyi yesterday. Suu Kyi, who is under house arrest, has through her peaceful protest become a symbol for human rights campaigners across the world. She was represented at the ceremony by her son, Kim.

Last week thousands of Irish television viewers saw her talk of her hopes that the honour might mark a new beginning for Burma and Ireland.

The freedom of Dublin city was also conferred on U2 and their manager, Paul McGuinness. The Lord Mayor, Mary Freehill, said the band had put Dublin on the map long before the city was as popular and prosperous as it is today. Previous recipients of the freedom of the city include Nelson Mandela and also Jack Charlton.

Man held after killings

Police hunting the killer of a woman and her two young children who were stabbed to death in their home arrested a man in High Wycombe, Buckinghamshire, yesterday. The deaths shocked a close-knit housing estate in Bracknell, Berkshire. A divorced Pakistani woman, Shazia Zaidi, and her children, Saba, seven, and Zeeshan, six, were found stabbed at their terraced home on Friday.

webTitle: Unionists horrified by Trimble's arms U-turn

fields.headline: Unionists horrified by Trimble's arms U-turn
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Ulster Unionists who oppose the Good Friday Agreement were 'furious' last night at comments made by UUP party leader David Trimble in Washington DC that he would consider rejoining Sinn Fein in government ahead of IRA disarmament.
fields.body:
Ulster Unionists who oppose the Good Friday Agreement were 'furious' last night at comments made by UUP party leader David Trimble in Washington DC that he would consider rejoining Sinn Fein in government ahead of IRA disarmament.

Trimble's remarks come as the UUP faces a week of bickering leading to Saturday's crucial meeting of its ruling body, the Ulster Unionist Council.

Trimble's problems will be compounded when his former ally David Burnside forces an emergency extra meeting of the UUC to debate a motion making a return to government conditional upon retention of 'the proud name of the Royal Ulster Constabulary'.

Trimble loyalists are horrified at the prospect of this pre-condition becoming UUP policy. They argue that it would tie Trimble's hands in negotiations to get the institutions of the Good Friday Agreement reinstated and that such a policy will make it virtually impossible to reach a compromise with nationalists. The SDLP and Irish government, let alone Sinn Fein, would be unlikely to accept such a precondition.

The British Government could also be angered at such a move since Secretary of State for Northern Ireland Peter Mandelson has already accepted the name change to the Police Service of Northern Ireland, proposed in Chris Patten's policing review.

The Bill accepting most of the Patten report will be debated in the House of Commons in two weeks' time.

Even the NI Police Federation, which is actively lobbying MPs and peers for the retention of the force's title, is 'totally opposed' to Burnside's motion, the Observer has learnt. The Federation, which represents rank and file police officers, fears that it would be counterproductive for the RUC's name to be explicitly linked to one political party.

The Observer has also learned that prominent unionist supporters in the Conservative Party oppose Burnside's motion. Lord Cranborne, the former Tory leader in the House of Lords, has penned 'a stinging rebuke' to Burnside. Cranborne and Burnside were instrumental in founding the Friends of the Union, a ginger group of senior conservatives, journalists and business figures.

Nevertheless, Burnside's motion has considerable support and could become UUP policy. Seven UUP MPs have already issued a statement supporting the motion. One of the signatories, John Taylor, the deputy parliamentary party leader, says that the 'police federation is out of touch'.

Taylor has said that 'Mandelson will walk all over us and has made it clear he will do so'. Linking retention of the name of the RUC to the Unionists' return to Stormont was the last chance, he said.

Anti-Agreement MPs are expected to attack Trimble at Wednesday's parliamentary party meeting when he returns from Washington.

One, Willie Ross, yesterday criticised Trimble's 'unilateral about-turn' saying that 'It was an extremely foolish course of action', particularly ahead of Saturday's UUC meeting in Belfast.

webTitle: Cook hits at 'crazy' MI5 gag on press

fields.headline: Cook hits at 'crazy' MI5 gag on press
fields.trailText: The Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, and Foreign Office Minister Peter Hain launched an extraordinary attack on the Home Office over its attempts to force  The Observer to hand over records it might have relating to the former M15 officer David Shayler.
fields.body:
The Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, and Foreign Office Minister Peter Hain launched an extraordinary attack on the Home Office over its attempts to force The Observer to hand over records it might have relating to the former M15 officer David Shayler.

Cook made protests at the 'highest level' and Hain is said to be 'horrified' at what he believes to be a grave attack on press freedom through the actions against this newspaper and our sister publication The Guardian.

The revelations highlight growing tensions between the Foreign Office and Home Office on how to deal with allegations that MI6 was involved in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadaffi, in 1995.

A senior Whitehall source said: 'The Home Office has gone manic on this... it's bloody crazy, the Government should not be picking a war with the press.'

On Friday an Old Bailey judge ordered The Observer and Guardian to hand over material relating to Shayler to aid a Special Branch investigation into serious breaches of the Official Secrets Act.

Three weeks ago an Observer front-page article repeated claims by the former intelligence officer that M16 had been involved in a plot to murder Gadaffi. The Observer obtained the names of two MI6 officers allegedly involved but did not publish them.

The Guardian was ordered to hand over the original of an e-mailed letter it published from Shayler.

The Observer's barrister Michael Tugendhat QC argued that the Special Branch action was in breach of journalistic freedom of expression as enshrined in the European Convention of Human Rights. He said there was no evidence that the article damaged the national interest.

Roger Alton, editor of The Observer , said: 'Our front page story covered issues of enormous public interest. This case raises very important principles about journalists and their sources and the protection of their sources.'

Last night Shayler said: 'The Government is adopting the tactics of a totalitarian state by attacking the press in this way.'

Both newspapers said they would challenge the judge's order, taking it to the European court of human rights if necessary.

fields.headline: Work out with Debussy
fields.standfirst: Pelléas et Mélisande at a leisure centre? You'll feel the benefit...
fields.trailText: Pelléas et Mélisande at a leisure centre? You'll feel the benefit...
fields.body:
Pelléas et Mélisande
Castle Vale Leisure Centre, Birmingham
Forward Festival
Symphony Hall, Birmingham/Radio 3

You walk into a drab-looking school gym in the middle of a Birmingham housing estate. Two hours later you emerge enriched by a rare operatic experience. A likely story? It should really be no matter for surprise. City of Birmingham Touring Opera has been doing this sort of thing for 13 years. Each time they assert that, in its musical activities, Britain's second city is rather better at reaching out (not just the token 'outreach' or, even worse, 'access') than its first. This small-scale company, which won attention with its pocket-sized version of The Ring, manages to thrive on tough challenges and bare necessities.

Of all operas, Pelléas et Mélisande had seemed an unlikely contender for the leisure centre treatment. This most subtle, sensuous and elusive of scores relies for effect on the finesse of Debussy's orchestration, or so it had always appeared. Yet the moment the hall darkened and, in a skilful and effective arrangement by Marius Constant, the two pianos struck up the obscurely disquieting prelude, you knew Debussy would be well served. Even the brief cooing of a baby in the audience only heightened the atmosphere.

This sharply focused staging, by Franco Ripa di Meana, based on a shortened adaptation by Peter Brook, drove home the unavoidable truth that a few strong ideas well performed will always work, just as all the lavish sets and costumes in the world can never plaster a hole left by weak imagination. The almost circular stage, like a horizontal slice of eclipsed moon, rose and fell in sections (perhaps once too often). Characters appeared mysteriously, watching and waiting by stealth. The only props here were several large lumps of coal, giving weight to the vague impression that Maeterlinck's imaginary kingdom of Allemonde, with its castle and cave and forest, had here become a mine shaft with, as its covetous owner, the old, half-blind King Arkel, head of one of opera's more dysfunctional families (no mean feat considering the competition).

Even if that reading is too literal, the dank sense of oppression it inspired cast an uneasy spell, only broken when an arc of brilliant green light - the pool around which the adulterous lovers play - interrupted the blackness. Hugh Macdonald's translation was clear and audible. Felicity Hammond, despite a heavy cold, had an appropriately febrile nerviness as Mélisande, with Karl Daymond, not quite in best voice but a strong stage presence, as her strangely disconnected lover. Christopher Purves conveyed the black sense of hurt felt by Golaud and sang with expressive potency. The two pianists, Steven Maughan and CBTO's music director Jonathan Hinden, convinced you that Debussy had always intended his music this way. In great works the heat is at the centre not on the surface and always shines out. We certainly heard as much of Debussy as Proust did when he listened to the first performance on the telephone. There are two more performances, in Wakefield tomorrow and at Snape Maltings this Saturday. Olivier Messiaen first encountered Pelléas in 1918 when he was 10 years old. It left a lasting impression and his own music took root in that same anti-symphonic tradition. Those of us ineluctably drawn to Birmingham again on Wednesday had the chance to hear Messiaen's monolithic last summation, éclairs sur l'au-delà , first performed just after his death in 1992. This 11-movement contemplation, played by a vast orchestra, displays Messiaen at his most refined and most spectacular. In the ninth 'Birds of the Trees of Life' section, an astonishing trilling and twittering of eight clarinets, seven flutes and three piccolos bursts forth, by some elaborate calculation managing to play the songs of 25 different birds. Who will forget the mesmerising sight of Simon Rattle, back with his old team, furiously and emphatically wagging a different number of fingers to mark each new entry?

Paired with this twentieth-century masterpiece was a composition written this century (following the intention of the Forward Festival), commissioned by the orchestra from one of its regular collaborators, Judith Weir. Her large-scale choral work We Are Shadows, as its title suggests, reflects on the impermanence of life, using texts from Scottish graveyard inscriptions, Taoist philosophy and a poem by Emily Dickinson. The exotic mix of bamboo chimes, roto toms and a variety of bells and cymbals, reflecting Weir's acknowledged debt to 'cheerful' Buddhist funeral music, would have appealed to Messiaen, and made an apt contrast to éclairs.

In this aurally ingenious score, full of dry-bone rattles and whispers, the sound of all the string players tapping their fingers rapidly on the wood of their instruments, swirling up through the orchestra like a chill wind through trees and echoed elsewhere by flurries of ascending scales, was an especially brilliant touch. The excellently drilled treble voices of the City of Birmingham Symphony Youth Chorus, aged from eight to 12 and performing from memory, sang out the long, overarching lines with evident relish. So too did their senior partners, the CBSO's Symphony Chorus. There is a second chance tomorrow when the Festival Hall will be filled with these communions with nature and beyond.

fields.headline: Life after Jill
fields.standfirst: On the anniversary of Jill Dando's death,  Jay Rayner  meets three men whose lives have been irreparably changed by the murder - her fiancé, the detective in charge of the case, and, in his first major interview, her brother Nigel - and asks the question that haunts them: Why?
fields.trailText: On the anniversary of Jill Dando's death,  Jay Rayner  meets three men whose lives have been irreparably changed by the murder - her fiancé, the detective in charge of the case, and, in his first major interview, her brother Nigel - and asks the question that haunts them: Why?
fields.body:
As chief reporter for the Bristol Evening Post, Nigel Dando has knocked on the doors of too many people whose loved ones have been murdered. 'It's the job you most dread,' he says. 'Fifty per cent will say I don't want to talk about it. Go away. The other 50 per cent will invite you in. For them, it's a therapeutic thing, I suppose, a way of expressing their grief.'

Today, Nigel is being part of the 'other 50 per cent', although it's doubtful whether he views letting a reporter into his cottage in the hills outside Bath as balm to a darkened soul. Next month marks the first anniversary of his younger sister's death, by a single gun shot to the head, on her own London doorstep, and he knows that there is an appetite in the media for information. The beast must be fed. Into his living room the reporter must come.

He has given statements before; carefully chosen words of regret and tribute, reactions to developments in the investigation, polite - always polite - 'No comment' where necessary. But he has never before sat down and given an answer to that question which he, like every other journalist, including his late sister, has forever had on their lips, the one which goes: how does it feel?

He is not even sure he is minded to answer it now. It is not how the Dandos do things. Like his sister, he does not go in for overblown emotions or grand gestures. There is, for example, only one photograph of Jill Dando in the tidy, floral living room, a simple family shot, tucked away on a windowsill overlooking the garden.

'It's a case of not having much to say,' he says. 'The police are doing their job. We're missing Jill but we're getting on with it.' He sits in a chair side on to me, staring away at the unset fireplace, mug of coffee in hand, still. Just before Christmas, he received a number of requests for interviews. 'I knew what they wanted,' he says. 'Our first Christmas without Jill. I understood it. But I thought it would be mawkish.' All requests were refused. 'We accept Jill's gone,' he says. 'We are just trying to get on with life as best we can.'

Seated here, at the heart of the story, it appears there is not one Jill Dando murder, but two. The first is the murder of Jill Dando as national event, the stuff of newspaper headlines and comment pieces on the cult of TV personality and appeals for information by the police. Last week, that Jill Dando murder was all but turned into an institution, with the launch of a charity appeal to raise funds for a faculty of crime science at University College London in her name.

Then there is the other Jill Dando murder, the one that is about personal and very private loss, for her widower father Jack and her fiancé, the gynaecologist Alan Farthing, and her close friends. Nigel is unique among this tight knot of friends and family in crossing over between the two. He understands fully that his own bereavement is also a national story with a particular dynamic.

It has been like that from the start. He was first told something had happened to Jill by a friend in Bristol, an area reporter for the Daily Mail, but he assumed it wasn't anything particularly important. Then he received a second call from the same source. 'He said it was quite serious. I rang her home but got the answerphone. I rang her mobile but that was just diverted back to her answerphone. I also couldn't get hold of Alan.'

He was standing in the newsroom at the Bristol Evening Post at the time. 'Sky News was on the television, as it always is, and they just said Jill Dando has been shot dead on her doorstep. Even though it was a shock, I saw in a flash what size of a story it would be. I knew I was going to be besieged.' He was driven by a friend to his home town of Weston-super-Mare to check his father was all right and then he drafted a statement. 'You stand on the doorstep and you say the things you want to say and then you ask to be given space. You're not looking inward, you're looking outward.'

The remarkable thing, he says, is that the journalists abided by his request. They did keep their distance and they continue to do so. It is as if, a year on, there is now some cordon sanitaire self-imposed by journalists around Jill Dando's family. As he says, they turned out to be the work of a weird loner who had rustled something up in his front room. 'Stalker published his piece 21 days after the murder. Two, that a similar person spotted her by chance in Hammersmith and followed her home. Three, that she was followed from Chiswick. Four, that she told someone she was going to be there. Five, that they in turn told someone else. Six, that it was someone who lives on the street. And seven, after observation and analysis, the killer decided that by just waiting there he would eventually get her.

'So let's remove the least likely options,' Campbell says, 'which is that someone happened to be there by chance, or that someone spotted her in Hammersmith by chance. If he was dreading the moment when the floor was opened up for questions, he needn't have worried. Nobody wanted to ask him anything. At all. 'In the first few months, I was easily recognised. Then I went through a stage of people recognising me but not being sure why. Then recently, people seemed to stop recognising me altogether. That was an encouragement to get involved because it showed me I could go back to normality.'

I'm under no delusions that this is my claim to fame. So I have to use myself as effectively as I can.' He points at a picture of himself with the Countess of Wessex on the front of that day's London Evening Standard taken at the launch. 'If allowing that picture to appear on the front page of the paper helps, then so be it.' Even if it makes you cringe? He nods. 'Yes, and it does make me cringe. It's surreal.'

The appeal is a limited affair. Once enough money has been raised, it will close and Alan will try to rediscover the normality he craves. But he knows it will not be the end of public interest. 'Each one of those will be a huge event.' Each one will place demands upon him.

Never before in this country has a famous female TV presenter been shot dead on her doorstep.' It seems a slightly obvious comment but, as the first anniversary approaches, this may be the only real way to make any sense of the unsolved murder of Jill Dando.

She was a journalist who read the news and presented holiday programmes. She had a relaxed style which was, depending on your point of view, either easy-going or bland but never in-your-face. People felt they knew her. Then somebody shot her dead on her own doorstep. As her fiancé says, it's bizarre. It teaches us nothing. It's a tragic curio. And as time passes, and explanations defy discovery, it becomes only more so.

' many people would argue.' The appeal is a limited affair. Once enough money has been raised, it will close and Alan will try to rediscover the normality he craves. But he knows it will not be the end of public interest. 'We are yet to have an arrest, a charging of somebody and a trial,' he says, displaying the same conviction as others involved that those things will still happen. 'Each one of those will be a huge event.' Each one will place demands upon him. He asks that we not discuss the case. Today is meant to be about the appeal. Nevertheless, he does offer one thought. 'It's unique,' he says. 'Bizarre, unprecedented. Never before in this country has a famous female TV presenter been shot dead on her doorstep.' It seems a slightly obvious comment but, as the first anniversary approaches, this may be the only real way to make any sense of the unsolved murder of Jill Dando. She was a journalist who read the news and presented holiday programmes. She had a relaxed style which was, depending on your point of view, either easy-going or bland but never in-your-face. People felt they knew her. Then somebody shot her dead on her own doorstep. As her fiancé says, it's bizarre. It teaches us nothing. It's a tragic curio. And as time passes, and explanations defy discovery, it becomes only more so.  Donations to the Jill Dando Fund can be made by phone to 0800 015 0125, by post to the Jill Dando Fund, Lloyds TSB, 50 Notting Hill Gate, London W11 3JD or at jilldandofund.com

fields.headline: Hello boys...
fields.standfirst: Being over 40 is no bar to attracting younger men - the world is full of Mrs Robinsons
fields.trailText: Being over 40 is no bar to attracting younger men - the world is full of Mrs Robinsons
fields.body:
'I'm afraid Ms X is not convincing in the starring role. She is clearly past her sell-by date.' I'm quoting from a recent film review. I remember it, I suppose, because the actress in question is 47, the same age as me. I was dismayed by this summary judgment, but not surprised. After all, everyone talks like that. Here is what a female friend said to me recently, when we were discussing an unhappily married mutual acquaintance: 'You do realise that Y is getting dangerously close to her sell-by date. If she's wants another crack at marriage, she'd better get out of this one very soon.'

A cruel thought, perhaps, but an accurate reflection of current views about the sexual marketplace. When it comes down to it, most of us do believe that men have a longer shelf life than women do. Thus, a female film star is past her sell-by date from the moment she develops her first smile line. But her male counterpart can be fat, 50, bald, reeking of whisky and still be a stud. No one gasps if the girl he ends up with is young enough to be his daughter. If it's the other way around, it's just as shocking as it was 30-odd years ago, when Mrs Robinson seduced her first graduate.

This, presumably, is why we're seeing a West End revival of the play that made her infamous. But how very tame her story is, when I compare it to the things I hear from her real-life, modern-day successors. And although I do not have the figures to prove it, it does seem to be that there are more Mrs Robinsons about these days than there used to be. Either that or I have an unusually exciting assortment of friends, relatives, and acquaintances.

And as for their friends, all I can say is that they're having a lot more fun than I am. No two of their outrageous histories are alike, but there are some common threads. Most are divorced, most have full working lives, and most entered singledom when they too thought they were past their sell-by dates. They went into their new lives expecting solitude. Imagine their surprise when their phones started ringing off the hook.

The phones were still ringing when I went to interview a woman we'll call Sandra. Sandra is in the music business: she assured me that most of the 28 calls she had to take during my brief visit were 'strictly business'. But I gathered from her clipped remarks that not all the men at the end of the line wanted it to stay that way. When I told her so, she nodded grimly. 'Now, I just deal with it,' she said, 'But in the beginning - this was after two marriages with total shits - it really threw me. I felt like asking, are you sure you don't have the wrong number? I mean why me? Why not some pneumatic bimbo? But then I said to myself, hey, I guess I still have what it takes.'

Sandra describes herself as 'OK-looking and reasonably fit'. She never hides the fact that she is in her late forties, and she does not dress young. 'But yes, most of the people I have to work with are very young, so I do have to think twice about what I'm going to wear.' For my visit, she had dressed herself to look like a very expensive leopard - while her lover, a very handsome Israeli student, was wearing hardly anything at all. But his manners were perfect. 'He's nice, isn't he?' she said after he had left. 'And he's such a good dancer.' When I asked how long she thought it would last, she said: 'I'm not interested in long-term relationships anymore. At this stage of my life I'm not going to adjust for anyone.'

She didn't think her two school-aged children should have to adjust for anyone, either. 'And then there's the age issue. When you make a serious commitment to a much younger man, what you're really doing is taking on another child.'

This was something all the new Mrs Robinsons agreed on. While younger men were definitely more fun in the short term, in the long term they were hard work. As a woman named Cheryl put it: 'They all want the same four things: boobs, blow jobs, a captive audience so that they can talk about themselves ad nauseam, and pudding with custard. By which I mean, they like me because I can cook just like their mums.'

When I said that made a very poor advertisement for the Mrs Robinson lifestyle, a friend of Cheryl's named Becky insisted that it wasn't so bad if your real children had already grown up and left home. She was sure she was more indulgent with her 30-year-old lover than she had been with her children's fathers, but 'he's a struggling musician and so confidence is a problem for him, but because I don't feel competitive with him, it costs me nothing to build him up.'

She also liked introducing him to 'new things'. Hence their recent trip to Cuba. 'He couldn't believe his eyes!' They'd been able to hook up with some other musicians and do a gig. She brought out the photos, many of which showed Becky centre stage in a filmy black minidress. Then there were a few of the boyfriend wearing a pair of tight swimming trunks. In one picture, he was cut off at the neck. 'They didn't want to make a print of that one,' Becky told me. 'When I asked them why, they said it was because he didn't have a head. So I said, "don't you see that was the whole point?" '

She conceded that she would never have wanted a relationship like this when she was younger. It was just as well, she thought, that she no longer wanted 'the traditional contract' because 'I don't think many men my age would be willing to meet me halfway.' But a television producer named Amelia thought that women like Becky were too quick to talk herself down. 'It's the fact that you don't need them that makes you interesting. If you are of an age when they think you should be sitting at home darning socks, and you're going out to interesting places, meeting interesting people, and having a lot of fun, they just can't bear it, and then before they know it, they can't stop thinking about you.'

To prove her point, she let me listen to her voicemail - eight of her messages were from one man she had met and turned down at a party the previous week. Then she took me up to see her e-mails. Three of her new messages were from married men who had logged on in the middle of the night to record their fantasies for her. ('Do they count as younger men? They're all in their thirties.') The fourth, fifth, and sixth messages were from her ex-husband. ('I keep telling him to stop bothering me, and he keeps writing back to tell me what a sexy e-mail I can do when I'm angry.') Her seventh message was from an admirer at work. It was an invitation to 'lunch some time'. It ended like this: 'I hope you don't mind my telling you that I would be a very happy man if I could persuade you to wear your Barbarella suit.'

'Now I ask you! Imagine going out in a thing like that before seven in the evening! You'd think I had nothing to do but file my nails! So no, as you see, my life is not perfect. But it's not for want of offers. I could, if I wanted, go out with an unsuitable man every night of the week.'

She went on to point out that there were plenty of older women in the public eye who had full and interesting lives that had room for younger men. Think of Fay Weldon. Think of Francesca Annis. To draw a line between any of them and Mrs Robinson was to miss the point entirely.

The point of the Mrs Robinson story was that she stole a taste of that which was not rightfully hers and then she got punished for it. 'But I think I have a right to fun and intelligent human company because otherwise what is the point of living? If someone else thinks I'm past my sell-by date, then so be it, but I'm hardly out of favour, am I? The saddest thing about the Mrs Robinson myth is that it convinces so many women that they have to put up with dull men in bad marriages because it's the best they can expect. And it convinces so many men that they don't have to try very hard in their marriages once their poor wives are past their sell-by date.' She hopes that a few of them will want to start pulling their socks up after they have read this article.

 The Graduate, starring Kathleen Turner and Matthew Rhys, opens at the Gielgud Theatre on 5 April. Previews from next Friday. Box office: 0207 494 5065

webTitle: Is our son going to pot?

fields.headline: Is our son going to pot?
fields.trailText: My son is 15. We have just heard from his teacher that it is rumoured he has been smoking marijuana.
fields.body:
My son is 15. I am divorced from his father but we are on reasonably friendly terms. Our son divides his time between us. We have just heard from his teacher that it is rumoured he has been smoking marijuana and, more seriously, bringing the stuff into school.

He is a bright boy who suddenly seems lacklustre and insecure. We do not want to confront him without more evidence, but if the rumour is true, we are not sure how hard we should be on him. I am worried that our son is releasing stressful feelings about his divided life by smoking dope.
J.D. of London

The teacher acted generously in tipping you off. I would presume 'rumour' to be a euphemism, and accept this as a reliable source of information. You are right to have a cool think before acting, because the way you handle the matter could crucially affect the outcome.

Your guilt feelings should be given the cold-shower treatment. Regrettably, split families are now the norm, and yet youngsters still manage to advance into adulthood with no more neuroses than previous generations.

Experimenting with drugs is not confined to damaged or deprived children and is unrelated to family stability. Adolescents seek thrills, and when danger and rebellion are thrown into the stew, it becomes a must.

Your son will equate you and his father with the establishment; if you now take a tough, authoritarian line, you will have lost the battle before it's begun.

Marijuana is not thought to be especially damaging or addictive, and unless he has progressed to hard drugs, no particular harm need ensue. Often, young people realise deep down the folly of their behaviour. You must reach that more mature space.

I'd advise that you speak to him alone, calmly and rationally. Most kids like to act a little crazy but don't want to injure their prospects permanently; maybe the thought of possible expulsion will bring him to his senses. At all costs, avoid taking a moral or an emotional stance. Discuss the likely follow-on from being thrown out of school - a permanent blot on his record, difficulty in getting future employment.

Explain the downhill spiral into drug addiction. Then he has to make up his own mind, for your influence is vanishing. But do remember that drugs have to be paid for, and avoid being free with the pocket money for a bit. Make yourself available as a supportive friend rather than a guardian to evade.

Your ex-husband may not handle the situation as sensitively as you, and is best kept out of the discussion.

Reader's responses

Take the mickey out of your son if he seems stoned. Impress on him, even if it goes against what you feel, that you are not scared by his use of cannabis, perhaps that you knew anyway. This reaction will surprise him. He will not have been the devil he thought he was, so you will have undermined his reason for making a big deal of smoking it. Talk to a teacher he likes; he will have dealt with this before. It's not your fault. You're not alone. Neither is your son.
L.R. of London

You have to impress upon your son the risks of the situation. With hindsight, my son was probably taking cannabis when he was 15. At 19, he is about to be charged with use and intent to supply and is in financial trouble as well. I wish I'd known earlier and talked to him. You would be acting illegally if you let your son smoke in your home and lay yourself open to a search - not a pleasant experience. Please seek support from your local drugs advisory service.
J.A. of London

Next week's dilemma is from T.F. of London

I've been friends with P since university. We've always been close, to the extent that he came on my hen night. He accepted the invitation to the wedding but didn't turn up. I hear that he was sent abroad on business at short notice, but he has never contacted me to explain this. It's a year since I got married.

Now I see P at the supermarket or gym and, since I feel distressed and angry, I hide from him. If our friendship meant so little to him, I certainly don't want to resurrect it, but I don't want these incidents to get in the way of my life. What should I do?

Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on next week's dilemma to reach us by Wednesday

fields.headline: Sinister attack on free speech
fields.standfirst: Veteran journalist  Ian Hargreaves  questions the 'national interest
fields.trailText: The British government is doing itself serious damage in the David Shayler affair. All that can be said with certainty of Shayler is that he is an individual of questionable reputation who has made serious charges about M15 misconduct. Some have been substantiated, most not.
fields.body:
The British government is doing itself serious damage in the David Shayler affair. All that can be said with certainty of Shayler is that he is an individual of questionable reputation who has made serious charges about M15 misconduct. Some have been substantiated, most not.

He has been pursued by every legal means imaginable: an unsuccessful extradition attempt based on an Official Secrets accusation, thrown out by the French courts, and a sweeping series of moves in the civil courts to harass and silence him.

Now, a sustained attempt is under way to prevent journalists investigating Shayler's claims. The seizure of computer records following a Channel 4 programme by Mark Thomas has been followed by a judge's instruction to The Observer and the Guardian to hand over correspondence with Shayler.

It is a matter of first principle that journalists cannot and should not hand over such material, except where large and clearly identifiable wider public interests are at stake. If this essential bond of trust between journalists and their sources is violated by police or judicial action on trivial grounds, this principle is shattered.

Does the Shayler case involve such a matter of high public interest, as opposed to an employer's desire to hear no more about a disastrously misjudged hiring decision? It is difficult to see how. The judge may be right that 'there are reasonable grounds for believing a serious arrestable offence has been committed', but this is scarcely a revelation. We have known for months the Government thinks the Official Secrets Act has been breached.

The real question is whether the nature of this breach is outweighed by the public interest in knowing about and testing Shayler's accusations, for example about the alleged MI6 plot to assassinate Colonel Gadaffi. Judgment on this point is at the heart of the balance which must be struck between the right of a government to run a secure intelligence service and Shayler's rights to free speech under the terms of the European Convention, which will be fully incorporated into British law by the end of this year.

Unable to achieve a criminal trial under the Official Secrets Act, the authorities have resorted to trying to silence Shayler by suing newspapers which pay him for articles, and now by intimidating journalists into handing over legitimately gathered material.

This is not only a sinister attack upon press freedom, it is certain to be as laughably ineffective as previous attempts to close down M15 renegades, like Spycatcher Peter Wright.

Shayler's website (www.shayler.com continues to broadcast loud and clear from France. Should your patriotism deter you from dialling it up direct, there's a handy link to it on the BBC's online news service, which cheerfully publishes e-mail correspondence with Shayler from time to time.

The authorities need to ask themselves this: how far are they prepared to go in assaulting the deeply established conventions of journalistic practice and the public's right to be informed by free media? Does this case justify such extreme behaviour?

The central message of Shayler's website is that he does not wish to be forgotten. MI5 are triumphantly succeeding in granting him his wish. Could it be that he's still on the payroll?

 Ian Hargreaves is Professor of Journalism at Cardiff University

webTitle: Phil Hogan  gets in touch with his emotions

fields.headline: Phil Hogan  gets in touch with his emotions
fields.body:
My wife's old school chum Jackie has arrived with her own millions of offspring for the weekend, but rather than occupy ourselves with something safe and predictable, such as relaxing over a leisurely breakfast with the weekend papers while the kids enjoy themselves tormenting frogs and getting stuck up trees ('There's so much space here!' she enthuses, as we form a queue for the bathroom), she and my wife opt for the stimulating challenge of seeing what it would be like to trail seven unthrilled children though central London to visit something called the Museum of Emotions. I am almost jumping out of my dressing gown with the excitement of not quite being able to bring myself to ask what's in it for the rest of us. So we pack our combined weight in squashed sandwiches (which I'm supposed to cart around for hours until the time comes for no one to want to eat them) and get to the station just in time to successfully complete the notoriously tricky fifth Labour of Hercules - catching a train without leaving anybody on the platform.

There's nowhere like the South Bank for children's climbing equipment - or 'public art', as architects are pleased to call it - and we wander along to the Museum of the Emotions at the Oxo building, which has such strong brand associations with family values that you'd think they'd know better than to put signs up in the lifts asking you to be quiet. Still, no such constrictions at the show, which has a place where visitors are encouraged to scream before going in.

'Fancy a yell?' asks my wife.

'Don't you think we should wait till one of them does something wrong?' I say.

Down some steps into the love department, which is painted pink and has searching questions written on the walls. 'What does love taste like? What does love smell like?' The children wander around in vain looking for buttons to press while I catch up on my yawning. It's not that I don't want to be in touch with my feelings, it's just that I can't help thinking that hate and cynicism might be more interesting. My wife is trying to get the older ones to plant a seed for love to blossom. 'No way,' they say, backing off.

Their eyes light up at the bottom of a flight of stairs. 'Can we Dad? Please'

'It's not a ride,' I explain gently, 'it's a wheelchair lift.'

Up we go to a dark room full of cushions and beanbags, which looks like an ideal spot for kick-boxing and other high jinks of the kinetic kind. 'How does it make you feel?' I say, reading the sign. 'Like jumping around,' shrieks the six-year-old, jumping around. A nervous assistant rushes over and asks me to tell them not to jump around. 'Maybe that was the peace and quiet room,' I say, as we make our way to the fear zone, which turns out to involve lying alone on a couch waiting for something to frighten you out of your skin, and sure enough, eventually, a bell rings. Still, there are some interesting peepholes to look in to confront your personal nightmares. There are some knives and forks in one window marked 'sociophobia', which is a fear of sitting next to someone at a dinner party with an interest in caravaning. My own favourite is arachibutyrophobia, that well-known dread of getting peanut butter stuck to the roof of your mouth. You've got to laugh. And guess what? 'Time spent laughing is time spent with the gods' says a sign, which is, of course, ingeniously intended to make you laugh even more. The place is full of signs. 'Is it possible to feel nothing?' one asks, conveniently neglecting the entire history of coming back from the pub and falling asleep in a hedge. 'Boredom is like a zooming-in on the epidermis of time' another says. 'Please do not touch the piano.'

Eventually we've had enough. My wife sends me into the sighing and tutting corner, while she rounds up the kids, who are jammed in the 'anger' wardrobe, taking it in turns to hit each other with complimentary boxing gloves.

Back out in the fresh air, I pop into an art gallery to look at tablecloth designs while the rest of them go down a ladder on to the 'beach', which is really one of those muddy stretches of the river at low tide where the Thames washes up driftwood and oyster shells and used condoms. At last, we're ready for lunch, which means either picnicking outside in the freezing wind or following Jackie and our seven grubby urchins into the foyer of the Festival Hall.

'What do you think?' my wife says.

'I'm too cold to think,' I say. 'But I have a bad feeling about it.'

 e-mote to phil.hogan@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Fast forward
fields.standfirst: This week: Stuart Little
fields.trailText: This week: Stuart Little
fields.body:
Who's Stuart Little? He's a mouse who's creating a storm in the States, starring in a new blockbuster movie based on EB White's classic children's tale of the same name. He'll be saying 'cheese' to kids in the UK this summer, but be warned - the hype has already started. Kids can now join Stuart Little clubs on the net, as well as watch free promotional clips of the hit movie.

So it's a cartoon? No, no, no. The film stars human actors and actresses, live animals with adult voices, but then there's Stuart. Three inch-high Stuart Little walks on two feet, drives a car and talks. But most significantly of all, he is completely computer-generated. Even the fluffy white fur on his head was created using a mouse pad. Geeks see him as the Mickey Mouse of the wired age.

What's the plot? Stuart (voiced by Michael J Fox) goes to live in New York with a human family called the Littles. Mum Little (Geena Davis), and Dad Little (Hugh Laurie), invite him back to their home after discovering him in an orphanage. Their son, George, quickly bonds with Stuart, but the family's white Persian cat, Snowbell, is appalled to be sharing her home with a rodent. Some critics argue that the film is a serious attempt to promote greater tolerance of adopted children.

Does the cat catch the mouse? Snowbell, the feline star of the movie, does her best. Played by a real Persian cat, Snowbell (voiced by Nathan Lane) gets plenty of smart lines. Baring her claws, she can hardly suppress her desire to enjoy a fresh mouse sandwich. 'I can't believe I'm arguing with lunch,' she hisses, on one occasion. The genteel Mrs Little is forced to intervene, quickly reminding her cat, 'We do not eat family members.'

What's the future for Stuart? It's looking extremely bright for the little fella. The studios love him. He's much easier to work with than a lot of real actors or actresses. He doesn't demand huge fees. There are no tantrums and he's quite happy to say exactly what the directors want him to say. With Stuart Little about to join Tinseltown's hall of fame, there are now growing numbers of traditional movie stars and their agents who are getting worried that the big parts will only go to computer-generated characters.

fields.headline: The perfect... little black dress
fields.trailText: Picture any of the style icons of modern times and, 10 to one, she'll be wearing a Little Black Dress (or LBD): Audrey Hepburn in  Breakfast at Tiffany's, Isabella Rossellini in Dolce & Gabbana, Anita Ekberg dancing in that fountain... Need I go on?
fields.body:
Picture any of the style icons of modern times and, 10 to one, she'll be wearing a Little Black Dress (or LBD): Audrey Hepburn in Breakfast at Tiffany's, Isabella Rossellini in Dolce & Gabbana, Anita Ekberg dancing in that fountain... Need I go on?

For me, the ultimate practitioner of perfect LBD chic was the late Jean Muir. With just a few metres of black silk jersey, Miss Muir could conjure up a dress which was a masterclass in elegance and refinement. Every six months, at her fashion show, she could be relied upon to offer a new version of this fashion classic - a fluted hem here, a scooped neckline there - which would take my breath away. Each time I would sit and watch with wonder. How could she cut a dress of such complexity and make it look so simple? In the early 80s, having become what can best be described as 'style soul mates' (we certainly made a curious pair: Miss Muir was a sober vision in navy blue, while I dressed in ripped blue denim), I was lucky enough to be invited to rifle through her archives. That afternoon, for a few hours, I was in fashion heaven.

There can be few women who do not look like a film star when they don the right LBD. Last Christmas my mother, wearing a gorgeous stretch-velvet LBD (well, not so L, actually - Mother is not exactly what you'd call a small woman), looked as classy as Simone Signoret or Liz Taylor with nothing more than a trifling diamond brooch clasped to her ample bosom. This is perhaps why some women still favour a sliver of jet crepe or swathe of caviar chiffon when all around them fashion pundits are pushing the virtues of shocking pink or the drama of scarlet - it needs little or no dressing up. In an LBD, a woman is dressed up. Indeed, the perfect LBD has sophistication sewn into its very seams.

If I was ever asked to list my Desert Island LBDs, it wouldn't be easy. I would have to include the satin number worn by Amanda Lear on the cover of Roxy Music's second album (designed by Antony Price), Yves Saint Laurent's jet beaded shift created for Zizi Jeanmaire, one of John Galliano's bias-cut gowns, and, of course, anything by the divine Miss M.

 Iain R Webb is fashion director of Elle

webTitle: When is a coat not a coat?

fields.headline: When is a coat not a coat?
fields.standfirst: When it's a sleeping bag, of course. Or a kite, or even a tent, for that matter. CP Company's new range of outdoor clothing means you're prepared for anything
fields.trailText: When it's a sleeping bag, of course. Or a kite, or even a tent, for that matter. CP Company's new range of outdoor clothing means you're prepared for anything
fields.body: Transformables is the name given to an offshoot section of the CP Company's spring/summer 2000 collection, the mainstay of which is quality casualwear/sportswear. For autumn/winter 1999, Italian designer Moreno Ferrari teamed up with Sony to develop jackets that came with built-in Discmans and Dictaphones. This season, the emphasis is on the outdoors, and while £680 may seem a little steep for a plastic coat, the point is that at the pull of a toggle, it becomes a 'city' tent (handy during long waits on the Central line). What use you'd have for a jacket that becomes a kite is more questionable, but you get the idea...

webTitle: The rise of the new nerd

fields.headline: The rise of the new nerd
fields.standfirst: If you though tech-y lads were just geeks, think again. Richard Benson fears for the future
fields.trailText: If you though tech-y lads were just geeks, think again. Richard Benson fears for the future
fields.body:
Last month, the media magazine Press Gazette noted that while lads' mags had taken a tumble, sales of the layman's tech-journal Computeractive had shot up to almost double those of Loaded. 'NERDS: THE NEW LADS' boomed the headline, and while the PG probably was being a little bit ironic, there were plenty of people in the media and entertainment industries willing to take it seriously. Mark Ratcliff, head of youth-market research agency Murmur, reports that 'most people in charge of the companies I work for are looking at tech-y, computer kids as the new opinion-formers, in the way they used to look at New Lads'. There's a kind of 'centre of gravity' to pop culture, he says, and the people he works for reckon it's shifted from their postroom to their IT department. From hard men to hard disks. From silicon breasts to Silicon Graphics. From birds to nerds. Sort of.

To be at the epicentre of the new movement, it is not sufficient to be a yettie (Young Entrepreneurial Technical yuppie, if you didn't know). We are talking true nerds, as in Douglas Coupland's Microserfs - ie, someone who takes the net very seriously, who reclaims the word 'geek' as a title to be proud of. Beginners can start by looking at ThinkGeek.com, an online gift shop for, essentially, people who work in IT - or 'for smart masses', as its 'amusing' motto has it. As a vision of a nerd-friendly future, ThinkGeek is terrifying. There is no pop music for sale; instead, there is a book section offering only science fiction and books about computers with titles which sound like pop albums. The leather-bound, seven-volume editions of The Lord of the Rings and the Ultimate Hitchhiker's Guide are at the lighter end; at the darker, The Software Conspiracy and After the Goldrush. Need something to get you through these? Forget drugs and alcohol - head for the Caffeine section, with its vast collection of high-caffeine food and drink products. Then, when you need to burn off excess energy, the Toys page has an amusing range of plastic balls and guns you can use to 'attack' people in your office.

For further insight into the mind-set of people who frequent this site, check out the badges, T-shirts and stickers. If you ever thought that people who work in IT had bad senses of humour and fascistic tendencies, you will learn that you were right. The bad jokes are one thing. You can cope with 'Alcohol and calculus don't mix. Never drink and derive', 'Your information went data way -->' and 'Keyboard missing: press F1 key to continue' - but 'I don't suffer from insanity - I enjoy every minute of it' may well be the least funny joke made in the history of the world. More worrying are the many witty phrases - and there are lots of them - which proclaim nerd superiority. 'Blessed are the geeks for they shall internet the earth' seems OK, but then you move on to 'Obviously you are incapable of assimilating my genius', and 'We have enough youth. How about a fountain of smart?', and you wonder if some of these people aren't sitting at their terminals plotting revenge, like Travis Bickle sitting in his taxi.

I think we should resist nerd coolness. At best, it will replace the dangerous and enjoyable things in life with a 13-year-old boy's idea of fun: smoking banana skins and discussing masturbation. At worst, it will empower charmless misfits who make up for a lifetime of rejection by humiliating people with their technical knowledge - primarily the IT nazi, but also the smug mechanic and vengeful electrical repair man. Blokes like that don't meekly sit around wishing they were cool; they sit around smouldering, wondering when the world will finally LISTEN to THEM. Now, finally, it may be about to, and there's no knowing what they'll do.

It's probably too late to stop them, though. In America, a writer called Jon Katz has already developed a following with his belief that 'geeks have become the only people who understand how the world works'. Last month he appeared on a Boston radio phone-in show to publicise his new book, Geeks: How Two Lost Boys Rode the Internet Out of Idaho, and a mother called in to thank him. The previous evening, she said, her teenage son had come to her in tears because he was 'worried about being a geek'. She had tried to assure him that he wasn't, and that he was 'normal and healthy', but having listened to Katz, she now realised that 'it was a terrible mistake. I should have said, "Yes, you are a geek. Congratulations."' Be afraid, lads. Be very afraid.

fields.headline: Art and power
fields.standfirst: The new Tate Gallery at Bankside, and the first bridge across the Thames for a century, are the most ambitious projects this country has seen for decades. But they won't just change the way we look at art: they will transform a city
fields.trailText: The new Tate Gallery at Bankside, and the first bridge across the Thames for a century, are the most ambitious projects this country has seen for decades. But they won't just change the way we look at art: they will transform a city
fields.body:
Henry Tate was born in 1819. By the age of 26, in Liverpool, he had built up a chain of grocery shops and begun a wholesale business. In 1862 he began refining sugar. He took up a previously unexploited patent on a process for producing dry, granulated sugar. This was a success, and he opened another refinery in east London, at Silvertown, where he introduced the Langen cube process, patented by Eugen Langen, of Cologne. Tate's sugar cubes quickly replaced the conical sugar loaf in English domestic life. Henry Tate moved his family to a large mansion on Streatham Common, and began to collect art.

The industrial architecture of Silvertown has since been rediscovered by generations of art and architecture students. Bernd and Hilla Becher's photographs of similar structures elsewhere are now well-known; there are some in the Tate Gallery's collection. In retrospect, it seems not inappropriate that the national institution of both British and modern art should have its origin in something like sugar: an energy source; the commodity of a brutal, early capitalism; a crystal, a granular solid, and finally, a white cube, produced in astronomical quantities, which quickly disappears when placed in hot water.

In 1700, the consumption of sugar in England was only 10,000 tons a year, but by 1800, the figure had increased to 150,000 tons - more than 16kg per year per person. In England, consumption of sugar grew at the same time as that of tea. Tea drinking grew as gin drinking declined. By the end of the 18th century, tea drinking had become a national habit among all classes, and the tea was sweetened with large quantities of sugar. Henry Tate's sugar-cube fortune, his art collecting and his philanthropy, can all be seen as a product of the national habit of drinking tea.

When Tate began refining sugar, it was nearly 30 years since slavery had been abolished, but conditions on the plantations would not have improved much. One doesn't know what he thought about this, but Henry Tate was, by all accounts, a conscientious, somewhat shy man, who remembered the predicament of the people he grew up among in Liverpool, and devoted large sums to education, hospitals and libraries, in both Liverpool and London.

At the beginning of the nineteenth century, Millbank, where Tate Britain now stands, was the southern edge of marshy land behind Vincent Square. It was first developed as the site of the enormous, hexagonal Millbank Penitentiary, which was built between 1812 and 1821. The first Vauxhall Bridge was built at the same time, in 1816. When new, Millbank was the largest prison in Europe, England's principal prison for both male and female convicts, and the holding depot from which convicts were shipped to Australia. The Penitentiary's site covered 10 hectares, and it had 1,550 cells, some underground - known as 'the dark' - that were used to punish indiscipline. The layout was based on Jeremy Bentham's panopticon, though the actual design can't have permitted much visual contact. The building was disease-ridden, notorious for chronic rheumatism, ague and neuralgia, and prone to subsidence.
