fields.headline: Schools of thought
fields.standfirst:
They influenced everyone from Malcom
McLaren to Damien Hirst - Jonathan Jones
argues that art schools are the engines of our
counterculture
fields.trailText:
They influenced everyone from Malcom
McLaren to Damien Hirst - Jonathan Jones
argues that art schools are the engines of our
counterculture
fields.body:
In Britian art used to be something that happened to other people. You could go to art school, says the artist and teacher Michael Craig-Martin, but the idea of becoming a professional artist was absurd. It took the great pop artist Richard Hamilton years of teaching before he could contemplate a full-time career making his own art. Because of this, art colleges were intense, hothouse places, with brilliant, over-qualified teachers, and pupils who left with a comprehensive avant-garde education and had to find a use for it in a deeply conservative society.

'I came to Britain in the 60s,' remembers the Irish-born, American-educated Craig-Martin, 'and was immediately teaching in a provincial art school, and I couldn't believe how good the school was. They were sophisticated about art. What you often saw were extremely bright students who had failed in the conventional education system. At art college, the things that had been a disadvantage became an advantage. But when people came out of those institutions there was nothing for them. One of the reasons for them going into other fields, including pop music, was that there was nowhere for them to have a career in Britain.'

The art school that everybody now knows about is Goldsmiths, and its most famous pupil-teacher relationship is that between Michael Craig-Martin - known as an artist for classic conceptual works such as his claim to have transformed a glass of water into an oak tree - and Damien Hirst. In the 1980s Goldsmiths had a revolutionary teaching programme, devised by the head of the Fine Art Department, Jon Thompson. They were also taught - in a departure from the art school ethos - that they didn't have to go on the dole or become pop stars or teachers. They could have careers as artists.

Damien Hirst was still an undergraduate at Goldsmiths when he curated Freeze, the legendary first exhibition of the new British art, in 1988. The exhibitors, all fellow students, included Mat Collishaw, Ian Davenport, Sarah Lucas, Gary Hume, Fiona Rae, Angus Fairhurst, Anya Gallacio and Simon Patterson. Hirst himself brilliantly turned art into pop, and has created incisive, unforgettable images. In doing so, he has less in common with conventional artists than with such unconventional products of British art schools as Vivienne Westwood (Harrow Art School) and Malcolm McLaren (every art school you can think of).

Hirst pays fulsome tribute to his teacher Michael Craig-Martin. 'I think he's great,' he says. 'He encouraged you to go out there and meet people. If you went to an opening he'd come and talk to you. In England it's like a club that's hard to get into; he smashed that door down. Michael and Jon Thompson and a lot of the other teachers were just encouraging you to do anything - at every other college you had to choose either painting, where everyone was wearing berets, or sculpture, where they all looked like rugby players. Michelangelo, all great artists, do both'.

And the compliment is returned. 'All of that generation were on an undergraduate course,' remembers Michael Craig-Martin. 'They all had an unusual degree of self-possession about what they were doing. There were a lot of seminars that I led where they established a dialogue of critical interest in each other. As a tutor I encouraged them to think of what they wanted and not to think it's for someone else. The most striking thing about them was their unshakable conviction - which made them very stroppy.'

If the first wave of new British artists owed a lot to Michael Craig-Martin, other artist-teachers have influenced the artists who have emerged in the 1990s. Jon Thompson is acknowleged as a brilliant teacher and influence by Turner Prize-winner Steve McQueen. The video and installation artist Susan Hiller prefers to be known for her art, but her influence is very clear on her students Douglas Gordon and Tacita Dean.

But by being so good at producing artists, has the contemporary British art college closed off all the other things art schools have been good at since the 1960s? The peculiar world of the art school is at the heart of our culture. The more you look at recent British cultural history, the more it seems to have been mapped out over coffee in the cafeteria of some art college, argued over and fought for between students and teachers with goatee beards. This is not just about art: it is about a great tradition of subversion.

You can construct a family tree of British artists and their pupils since the early 1960s whose branches extend not just into art but into pop music, not just to Damien Hirst but to Pete Townshend, Bryan Ferry and the Sex Pistols' manager Malcolm McLaren. You can see analogies between McLaren giving up his Goldsmiths degree with an unfinished thesis on 'the psychogeography of Oxford Street' to found his shop Sex, and the late 60s rebellion at St.Martin's out of which British conceptual art was born. You can imagine the birthpangs of punk in students who rebelled against their polo-neck-wearing teachers. The most revered British artist at the height of the 1960s was the sculptor Sir Anthony Caro. He was also the leading teacher at St. Martin's College. Caro's welded steel sculptures were championed by the American critic Clement Greenberg, who argued that Caro was not just the leading British artist but the heir to the great modernist tradition of Jackson Pollock. This was taught as holy writ at the regular St. Martin's Sculpture Forum where, a student later recalled, 'Twelve men with pipes would walk for hours around sculpture and mumble.'

St.Martin's attracted students who wanted to be sculptors, but then found themselves totally alienated. This generation included Gilbert and George, Richard Long and Bruce McLean (who in turn taught the likes of Douglas Gordon at the Slade). They reacted violently against Caro. His art insisted that it had nothing to do with the world: they insisted theirs did. The story goes that Caro came into one of his classes to find twigs scattered on the gallery floor. He asked Richard Long what was the meaning of this. It was one-half of a two-part work, explained Long. The rest was on top of Ben Nevis. Gilbert and George sent out postcards and called them sculpture. The pipe-smokers fumed. A young dissident artist and teacher, John Latham, took Clement Greenberg's book Art and Culture out of the college library in 1966 and invited his students to come to his house and help him eat it. He got the sack.

The family tree of the British art school and its influence might begin with Richard Hamilton, who designed the poster for the first ever pop exhibition This Is Tomorrow in 1956. Hamilton's collage Just What Is It That Makes Today's Homes So Different, So Appealing? has a subversive irony that has characterised British pop ever since - but you don't have to trace this influence subliminally. As a teacher at Newcastle University in the 1960s one of his pupils was future Roxy Music singer Bryan Ferry. Ferry has always acknowledged Hamilton as his mentor. 'With pop art and Richard,' he has said, 'suddenly there was a whole new world that was relevant, and that was sexier and more potent because it had to do with everyday life'.

Pete Townshend attributes the pop art violence and aggression of The Who in the early 60s - smashing their instruments on stage, piling up the feedback - to the man he regards as his art school mentor, 'auto-destructive' artist Gustav Metzger. 'It was 1962, the time of the Cuban missile crisis,' Townshend told me recently. 'Metzger had a profound effect on me. I was doing my first gig with The Who and took it as an excuse to smash my new Rickenbacker that I had just hocked myself to the eyebrows to buy. I really believed it was my responsibility to start a rock band that would last only three months, an auto-destructive group. The Who would have been the first punk band except that we had a hit.'

British art has never been as internationally significant as it is today. But it would be wrong to say that art did not play a huge part in British life. Art may have seemed marginal in Britain since the Second World War, but secretly, through the art schools, it gave birth to British pop. Where did Jarvis Cocker meet the girl in Pulp's 'Common People'? He met her at St. Martin's.

Today the talent goes into the gallery instead of the charts. Art colleges are no longer utopian centres for an alternative lifestyle but places where you learn to be an artist. That's great for British art. But if Pete Townshend, Bryan Ferry and John Lennon had all become artists when they left art school, the cultural history of Britain since the 1960s would be unrecognisable.

Michael Craig-Martin says that in a way he regrets the professionalisation of the art schools, because it takes away their sense of difference from the university system: 'This aspect of it being seen as an alternative education has diminished.' Of all the Goldsmiths generation it is paradoxically Damien Hirst, whose first exhibition set this professionalisation of art in motion, who has most insistently tried to break out of the art world, to make pop culture. From his restaurant installations to his band Fat Les and his videos for Blur, he's the classic art school maverick - the last of the unprofessionals.

British art has never been as internationally significant as it is today. But it would be wrong to say that art did not play a huge part in British life. Art may have seemed marginal in Britain since the Second World War, but secretly, through the art schools, it gave birth to British pop. Where did Jarvis Cocker meet the girl in Pulp's 'Common People'? He met her at St. Martin's. Today the talent goes into the gallery instead of the charts. Art colleges are no longer utopian centres for an alternative lifestyle but places where you learn to be an artist. That's great for British art. But if Pete Townshend, Bryan Ferry and John Lennon had all become artists when they left art school, the cultural history of Britain since the 1960s would be unrecognisable. Michael Craig-Martin says that in a way he regrets the professionalisation of the art schools, because it takes away their sense of difference from the university system: 'This aspect of it being seen as an alternative education has diminished.' Of all the Goldsmiths generation it is paradoxically Damien Hirst, whose first exhibition set this professionalisation of art in motion, who has most insistently tried to break out of the art world, to make pop culture. From his restaurant installations to his band Fat Les and his videos for Blur, he's the classic art school maverick - the last of the unprofessionals.

fields.headline: Millennium bugs
fields.standfirst: If you aren't on the alert, microscopic armies can invade you food. But there are measures you can take to prevent food poisoning
fields.trailText: If you aren't on the alert, microscopic armies can invade you food. But there are measures you can take to prevent food poisoning
fields.body:
It's astonishing the damage that tiny bacteria in food can do. Anyone who has experienced the horror of being struck down by vomiting, diarrhoea, stomach/head pain or even fever as a result of ingesting food-poisoning organisms will know exactly what I'm talking about. Protecting yourself when dining out in restaurants or fast-food joints that use highly processed food products is difficult, but all of us should be aware of the precautions to take to ensure that we aren't exposing ourselves to any unnecessary risks at home, which is where most cases of food poisoning occur. It is impossible to overstress the importance of hygiene and the proper preparation of dishes - one only need to recall the tragic E coli outbreaks to realise that food poisoning can kill. To start with, we should always pay attention to shelf-life dates, cooking instructions, and fridge and freezer manufacturer recommended temperatures - the guidelines are designed to minimise bacterial contamination and growth.

The majority of fit and healthy people can be exposed to food-poisoning bacteria without there being any serious threat to their health, but individuals with compromised immune systems, such as the elderly or the sick, are much more at risk. Also at risk are pregnant women - in extreme cases, food-poisoning bugs can cause spontaneous miscarriages or brain damage. Three main types of food poisoning are of concern to expectant women: toxoplasmosis, listeria and salmonella. Toxoplasmosis is caused by a parasite, but can't be transferred from person to person. This parasite is harmless to most adults, but if caught during pregnancy it can cause miscarriage or damage to the baby in the womb. Toxoplasmosis can only be diagnosed by a blood test, but sadly, symptoms described as 'mild flu-like' don't usually appear until two to three weeks after contracting the disease, by which time some damage may have already occurred. Prevention is the best cure - you can avoid exposing yourself to this parasite by keeping away from animal faeces and cats, in particular. This bug lives in cats for about three weeks and can transfer to their faeces and remain infectious for up to 18 months.

Since it can be transmitted through the soil to other animals such as dogs, you need to take the following steps to prevent infection. Do not allow cat litter near food. Always wear rubber gloves to clean up pet mess. Wash your hands thoroughly after you have touched an animal or used the lavatory. Avoid eating undercooked or raw meat, such as steak tartare, which can harbour bacteria. Don't feed your cats and dogs raw meat, as this provides a route for infection. In addition, you should follow basic hygiene rules, such as keeping work surfaces clean, washing tea towels regularly, making sure that meat and poultry are cooked appropriately and washing all fruit and vegetables before you eat them. It is also important to keep cooked and raw foods separate in the fridge so that the bacteria from the raw foods do not infect the cooked foods. Also, use separate chopping boards for raw and cooked meat and fish, and another for vegetables and fruit. If cooked food is to be kept, it must be cooled as quickly as possible, then, when cold, wrapped and refrigerated. Always reheat rice until it is piping hot, as Clostridium perfringens - another less serious, but still diarrhoea- and vomiting-causing organism - may be found in rice that has been cooked and left in a warmish environment, then not thoroughly reheated. It's also unsafe to eat food from tins which have either been dented - the protective seal may be broken, allowing bacteria to enter - or have blown ends, which could signify the presence of the bacterium that causes botulism, even if only rarely.

You should also be vigilant about not exposing yourself to the nasty bacterium salmonella, which can cause diarrhoea and vomiting, and possibly fever and headaches, 12 to 48 hours after eating the infected food, and in rare cases has proved fatal. Salmonella thrives in foods that are insufficiently heated to kill the bacteria, particularly eggs, poultry and unpasteurised milk. Steer clear of foods containing raw and lightly cooked eggs, such as mayonnaise, soufflés, sauces such as hollandaise, and mousses. Egg dishes, such as quiche, along with poultry and meat, should be also be well cooked. You should be particularly careful when attending parties where food is left in warm rooms - the bacteria love this environment and quickly multiply to levels that will trigger symptoms.

Listeria monocytogenes causes most angst among pregnant women, because it can cause listeriosis, which may damage the unborn child or cause a miscarriage. Symptoms are rather like those of flu - headaches, aching limbs, etc - and, unlike most bugs, it can thrive even in cold conditions, so refrigerating food doesn't automatically mean you're safe. In the late 80s, there was an outbreak of listeria, which at the time was blamed on the consumption of unpasteurised soft cheese. Although the bug was mainly detected in the soft pasteurised Swiss cheese Vacherin du Mont d'Or, listeria was also isolated in foodstuffs other than cheese, so it is wrong to ignore other potential sources. Pasteurising a soft cheese will not necessarily stave off listeria growth, either - it's the cheese's acidity, water content, salt and balance of the good bacteria with potential bad bugs which cheese suppliers such as Randolph Hodgson at Neal's Yard Dairy, for example, feel strongly influences whether listeria bacteria will be able to take a hold and cause disease. The best way to minimise your risk of developing listeriosis is to avoid all soft and blue cheeses, including pasteurised soft cheeses. Instead, choose hard cheeses (unpasteurised or not) that have been matured for more than nine months (which the majority have), as listeria don't like the drier, saltier, hard-cheese environment.

It is important not to focus on cheese alone - listeria can find its way into ptés, salamis, prepared salads such as coleslaw, ready-washed salads, ready-made dips, etc. It's best to buy the ingredients yourself to make and eat foods fresh. If you buy ready-made chilled or frozen meals, make sure that you heat them thoroughly - lukewarm foods provide the perfect environment for harmful bacteria. Soft whipped ice creams can fall foul, too, so choose a sorbet or hard ice cream that has not been made with raw eggs (to avoid the salmonella risk). This way, you won't be getting more than you've bargained for.

fields.headline: Patient power
fields.standfirst: Chronic diseases are being beaten by a new group of experts: patients who are taking their health into their own hands. By Wendy Moore
fields.trailText: Chronic diseases are being beaten by a new group of experts: patients who are taking their health into their own hands. By Wendy Moore
fields.body:
Jean Thompson suffered the first ravages of arthritis at the age of 17. She spent much of her twenties and thirties in a wheelchair, and by her mid-forties felt unable to take a job more than a 20-minute car ride from her home. Now 52, she travels all over the UK, has confined her wheelchair to the garage and recently spent two months living abroad.

And she is not alone. Other people with long-term illnesses, ranging from haemophilia to liver disease, depression to chronic fatigue syndrome (ME), are reclaiming their lives after similar improvements in mobility, pain and various symptoms. Their secret is not a miracle drug or revolutionary new therapy, but a simple six-week course which teaches patients to become 'experts' in their own conditions.

'You need to get in touch with the resources you have got inside yourself,' explains Thompson, who found the approach so powerful she now co-ordinates courses across the country for the charity Arthritis Care and has helped extend the programme for people with other conditions.

Developed in California in the 70s specifically for people with arthritis, the 'expert patient' programme has been adapted to suit anyone with a chronic - or long-term - illness. In the UK, one in three people has a chronic disease or disability. The six two-and-a-half-hour lessons are designed to arm patients with the knowledge, skills and motivation to take control of their illnesses. Crucially, all lessons are taught by trained tutors with the same condition as their pupils.

Research in the US has shown that the programme can improve people's health and reduce hospital admissions. Now brought to the UK, it is already showing early success. In a sunny church hall, behind a busy south London shopping centre, 11 people with arthritis are having their final lesson. Although many are in pain, the hall rings with laughter and jokes as the group shares success stories and tips. They vow to carry on meeting.

Janis Austin, one of the two lay tutors, has had arthritis for eight years. Still only 42, she has had to give up her profession as a photographer. The course has helped her cope with symptoms and communicate better with doctors. 'The thing that has helped me most has been the positive thinking,' she says. 'I will not let this illness take over my life.' Irene Maloley, 57, agrees. She felt alone and frightened before beginning the course in November. Since then, she has suffered much less pain. 'It definitely helps,' she says.

Lessons are brisk, focused and heavily structured. The tutors discuss symptoms, medication, diet and exercise. But the emphasis is less on medical know-how, more on life skills. Patients learn techniques to relieve pain through relaxation, meditation and other methods; to handle feelings of anger, frustration and depression, and to communicate more effectively with their loved ones and health professionals.

'It empowers people, because what it does is it encourages them to make small steps to change,' says Thompson, who studied the approach in the US before bringing the idea back here. After piloting the system in the UK for arthritis, the government is now funding courses for people with different conditions in a project co-ordinated by the Long-term Medical Conditions Alliance (LMCA). The first seven courses took place last autumn and the second wave is running right now. Researchers from Coventry University are evaluating their impact. Similar sessions are also being run by the British Liver Trust for people with liver disease and other conditions.

Participants have so far ranged from 22 to 90 years old and, for some, the effects have been life-changing. One man who was housebound, from the after-effects in later life of childhood polio, has now embarked on a computer course. A woman with endometriosis - where the womb lining disintegrates and causes extremely painful periods - has negotiated treatment by laser surgery which doctors had previously told her was not available.

The health service, explains Thompson, is geared towards curing people with acute or short-term illnesses. 'The way health care operates in this country, you are immediately put into the victim role,' she says. Yet for people with chronic conditions - where illness is long-term and without cure - the needs are different. 'I know what is happening in my body better than the doctor does,' she adds.

Traditional self-help groups provide patients with medical information but no motivation to use it. Self-management training gives people the motivation to utilise information and change behaviour, she says. Jane Cooper, the LMCA's project manager, agrees. 'Over six weeks, it is amazing to see the shift in people. When you have people who feel empowered, they tend not to go to their doctor as often, they use services differently and they feel better about themselves.'

Georganne Wallace, who lives in Bexhill-on-Sea and undertook the course in Brighton last autumn for women with endometriosis, is living proof. For 15 years, she has suffered such severe pain she has even passed out in the street. Various remedies, including surgery and male hormone drugs, have offered little relief. Now, through exercise, relaxation, massage and other techniques learned on the course, she has reduced her painkillers to one a month. 'It really has made a lot of difference,' she says. 'I can manage the pain better. I feel generally happier.'

Such a transformation in patients can be quite threatening for doctors and nurses, but others welcome the trend. Dr Iain Murray-Lyon, a consultant gastroenterologist who treats people with liver disease at London's Chelsea and Westminster Hospital, believes patients should be regarded not as equals, but as superiors. He hopes the local health authority will soon set up expert patient courses locally. 'I think the more patients know, the better.'

 For more information about 'expert patient' courses, contact the LMCA on 020 7813 3637

webTitle: Once upon a time in the East End

fields.headline: Once upon a time in the East End
fields.standfirst: Tommy Hole was a hard man who thought his reputation for violence would carry him through to a peaceful retirement. But then he was gunned down in a pub in broad daylight. Was it the result of a 20-year turf war or a misjudged drugs heist? Nick Paton Walsh investigates
fields.trailText: Tommy Hole was a hard man who thought his reputation for violence would carry him through to a peaceful retirement. But then he was gunned down in a pub in broad daylight. Was it the result of a 20-year turf war or a misjudged drugs heist? Nick Paton Walsh investigates
fields.body:
The Beckton Arms is a small, boozy doldrums in London's East End. On one side it is flanked by Barking Road, on the other the A13. Each night the road heaves under the weight of traffic trying to get out of the capital, but the Beckton's side road remains still. Here, on a lethargic Sunday afternoon on 5 December of last year, one of Canning Town's most notorious faces, 57-year-old Tommy Hole, met his lifelong friend, Joe 'The Crow' Evans, for an afternoon's drinking. Hole had run into Geoff Humphries, Evans's son-in-law, earlier that afternoon and the three sat at the bar. At 3pm, someone came in, scouted around and quickly left. Surrounded by regulars, Hole, Evans and Humphries carried on drinking, unperturbed.

Fifteen minutes later, two men entered the Beckton by the front door. The half-light of midwinter filtered through the fake spray-on snow of the windows, but the incongruity between the pub's festive decorations and the newcomers' scarved faces stirred few. The televised crowd ripples from Football Italia occasionally eclipsed the muttering at the bar. The men walked up behind Evans and fired two shots with a handgun, the first entering the base of his skull at point-blank range. Hole's reflexes took him from his bar stool towards the back door. The two gunmen fired a further nine shots, four hitting Hole's upper body and one his head. The gunmen turned and left the pub, unflustered, walking with practised calm through the A13's underpass and disappearing into a labyrinth of cul-de-sacs. Humphries was left standing unscathed next to the landlady's children and a mother-to-be, and, despite a pub full of witnesses, the killers are still free.

In a 35-year criminal career, Tommy Hole was a convicted armed robber, car thief, drug manufacturer and dealer, attempted murderer and probable killer, who had spent half this time in jail.

Hole had left his wife Christina at 1.40pm that day, casually saying, 'Right, sweetheart, I'm off now, catch you later.' Christina and Tommy had married on 17 March 1995, while Hole was a voluntary resident of Rampton High Security Hospital, having completed a six-year sentence he began at Parkhurst Prison. He had been jailed in 1989 for armed robbery and for running a £400,000 amphetamine factory with his son Kevin. Father and son had adjacent cells, united in prison counterculture. They had practised a warped form of symbiosis for years, and were now inseparable. During their sentence, Kevin became ensnared in a drug deal with other inmates, and became depressed. One night in 1991 he seemed abnormally cheerful at lights out. But when Tommy walked between the neighbouring cells with his routine cup of tea the following morning, he found his son hanging dead from his cell door. The coroner's verdict was suicide. Hole suffered a nervous breakdown and was moved to Rampton.

Tommy Hole's prison career began in June 1963, aged 21, when he was sentenced to three months for forging banknotes. During this time, he escaped from the Hammersmith Hospital ward where he was being treated. Barely six months passed before he was in the dock again, receiving five years for robbery with violence after a payroll snatch had backfired. There is a maxim which says that criminals who spend too many of their days in jail should look for different work, or a better firm, but the frequency of Hole's court appearances is more testament to his profligacy as a criminal than his ineptitude. This was the London of the Krays and Richardsons, where the organisation of protection, heists and racketeering meant that young gangsters such as Hole considered jail part of the lifestyle. And as the amount of time Tommy did grew, so did his status. In 1973, Hole and George Davis - otherwise known as 'Darkie' George - were in Chelmsford Crown Court, with three other men, charged with a £47,000 whisky raid in Stratford, east London. The case leant on the evidence of supergrasses Charles Lowe and Kieran McCormack, both of whom said they were on the same raid. But Hole and Davis were seamless enough in their alibis to be found not guilty. By the time of his next conviction, Hole had increased in confidence.

It was 1975. A local man, James Venton, fell foul of Hole. Newspaper reports neglect to mention Venton's offence, but what followed was not about exacting retribution, but building reputation. Hole and a local boxer, Billy Williams, went to Venton's home. The two men dragged him into the street, where Williams held Venton down while Hole ran over him three times with a car. The brutality of the case made the headlines and Venton agreed to act as chief witness for the prosecution. Hole was jailed for seven years for attempted murder. Forty-eight hours later, three men went to the home of Venton's family and smashed four windows. Hole had begun to amass a loyal following.

While still serving time for attempted murder, Hole was charged with a £7,000 armed robbery at the London Electricity Board in Ilford, during which a policeman was shot. Hole was cleared, but George Davis was sentenced to 20 years. On his release, Hole campaigned for Davis's conviction to be quashed. His campaign led to several unorthodox publicity stunts, including digging up the Headingley test wicket and crashing a car into the gates of Buckingham Palace. Davis was subsequently released, but never pardoned.

It was the early 80s, however, that sealed Hole's reputation as a hard man when he was cleared of the murder of another gangster named Nicky Gerard. The sequence of events had begun with a 1970 turf war between Ronnie Knight - associate of the Krays, erstwhile husband of Barbara Windsor and a culprit in the £7 million Security Express robbery in 1983 - and 'Italian Albert Dimes', who the FBI considered the US Mafia's man in London. That year, Dimes's top enforcer, Alfredo 'Eyetie Tony' Zomparelli, came to blows with Ronnie Knight in the Latin Quarter nightclub in London's Leicester Square. Knight arrived with his two brothers, Johnny and David, and Billy Hickson, whom Knight describes as a 'headcase'.

In his biography, Living Dangerously, Knight maintains he was passive until the last, suggesting that Hickson attacked Zomparelli. In the 'war zone' that ensued, David Knight was stabbed twice in the chest by Zomparelli. Knight buried his brother in the spring of that year and swore he would see Zomparelli murdered, 'for with him alive, the hate in me would eventually kill me as well'. Knight did not, after all, have to carry out this act of supposed self-defence, as Nicky Gerard, the son of gangland boss Alfie Gerard, killer of Frank 'Mad Axe Man' Mitchell and Ginger Marks, came into Knight's Soho club with a proposition.

Gerard offered to keep Knight's hands clean of Zomparelli's death and to do the job for him. On 4 September 1974, Zomparelli was shot dead in the Golden Goose on Old Compton Street. A couple of days later, Gerard received a thick envelope from Knight, a bonus for what doubled as a warped crime of passion - Gerard was seeing a former stripper called Rozanna, who was Zomparelli's wife. Gerard and Knight were subsequently arrested, though neither was convicted.

In the 1980s, Nicky Gerard crossed Tommy Hole in a fight for influence in the East End underworld. On a Friday night in June 1982, in Canning Town, Gerard kissed his daughter Vicky goodnight, and left her on her 11th birthday to go to the pub for a drink. At 9.12pm he turned the ignition in his Oldsmobile and looked up to see two men a few feet from the car. They said a few words to him before opening fire with two shotguns and an automatic pistol. Gerard climbed from his car and crawled towards his house. Fifty yards from his home he was brought to a halt. 'He couldn't say that, because Nicky Gerard had plenty of lovely people around him, and they'd have had to do something. Tommy was a man of the world and he looked after himself. But the likeliest motive for Hole's murder does not lean so heavily on the faux-romance of his criminal past; it is comparatively prosaic.

Hole's penchant for an easy deal was not exorcised by his ordeal in prison. He continued running favours for London's heavyweights, together with minor scams. webTitle: And they don't use dead animals

fields.headline: And they don't use dead animals
fields.standfirst: Sensation is now history and its stars institutions. So what does the future of art in this country look like now? Louisa Buck introduces those on the crest of the new wave
fields.trailText: Sensation is now history and its stars institutions. So what does the future of art in this country look like now? Louisa Buck introduces those on the crest of the new wave
fields.body:
Darren Almond
 Time passing is a central theme in the work of Darren Almond - but although he grapples with often mind-boggling physical, human and psychological dimensions of time and space, he manages to do so in ways that are unexpectedly immediate and straightforward. He's transmitted a wall sized projection of an empty cell live from Pentonville Prison; he's exhibited a giant two metre long digital clock; and he has ventured where most artists of all generations have feared to tread with Oswiem, a pair of black and white films of people waiting at two bus stops in contemporary Auschwitz. In his most recent piece, a three-screen video projection, Almond continues to explore memories of the past by interviewing his father about all the physical injuries he has sustained throughout his life.

Fiona Banner
Fiona Banner is best known for her 'wordscapes', blow-by-blow written accounts of action-adventure movies that take the form of solid single blocks of text written on large surfaces, often the same shape and size as a cinema screen. She calls these textual chunks 'still movies', and they recapture in a single static image an experience that goes beyond words. Underlying all her work is a fascination with language as a form of communication - the possibilities of words as well as the way in which they so often fail us. Lately she's been making a series of sculptures of vast full stops in different fonts carved from white polystyrene - a substance that is itself a space filler, so light it's hardly there.

Simon Bill
Simon Bill's paintings use materials and techniques better suited to the DIY enthusiast - or the nursery school. Working on plywood or MDF, he conjures up suggestive organic shapes out of bizarre concoctions of flexible filler, maize seeds, foam rubber chips or just a network of marker pen doodles. Yet there's nothing naive about the way in which he knowingly teases at the boundaries of what is artistically acceptable and produces at the same time queasily beautiful and richly associative images in their own right.

Angela de la Cruz
Angela de la Cruz gives her works a hard time. Since 1994 she has been making what she calls 'everyday paintings', which start off conventionally enough as monochrome abstracts built up in layers of oil paint onto canvas, but which are then smashed, ripped, squashed and crumpled into strange shapes. These sad and sorry objects are presented crammed into corners, propped against walls or squeezed into unsuitable places. But by destroying her paintings she allows them to take on a new and haunting life of their own, occupying a no-man's land between painting, sculpture and performance.

Jeremy Deller
Few artists have achieved such a total immersion in the world of pop music as Jeremy Deller, and he, unlike many of his contemporaries, doesn't even play in a band. Instead he involves himself in the music of others, as when he got a traditional brass band to play classic Acid House anthems. His art often takes the form of events which intervene directly in real life: he has stuck 'I love Joyriding' stickers on the bumpers of flashy cars, and organised a show of artworks referenced by the Manic St Preachers - in which serious Picassos and Pollocks lent by the likes of the Tate Gallery combined with speeches by Arthur Scargill.

Rachel Lowe
Whether she is using her own films, working with pieces of found footage or borrowing from other people's snapshots, Rachel Lowe is concerned with the plethora of still and moving images that document and define our history, memory and experience. She often combines high and low-tech media - digital video, slide projections, painting, drawing, or photocopying - to manipulate images and make us question what we are seeing: sometimes figures are blacked-out into silhouettes, images are repeated, or slivers sliced out. In each case we are reminded that things are usually not what they seem, or what we want them to be.

Paul Noble
At some point in their careers, most artists find themselves becoming rather too well acquainted with the social security system, but few turn the experience into art. In his satirical boardgame Doley, Noble does just that by immersing his players in the pitfalls and problems of life on income support. Doley is a nihilisitic game for losers where skill is pointless and players struggle fruitlessly for survival. There's more dystopian vision in Noble's ongoing creation Nobson, a polluted, empty fantasy town which he has been creating in drawings, sculpture and installations since 1996 - there's even a guidebook to what Noble describes as 'town planning as self portraiture'.

Tim Noble and Sue Webster
Contemporary art's latest double act met at art college in Nottingham and have lived and worked together ever since. They make their dual presence felt in attention-grabbing artworks that both work with and send up the high media profile and cultish mythologising of so much contemporary art. They've covered many of the major players of the London artworld in tacky home-made tattoos, they've made neon signs, and exhibited a pile of their accumulated household rubbish which, when lit by a slide projector, projected a perfect shadow portrait of the pair's profiles.

Grayson Perry
Pottery is not a medium usually associated with contemporary or even fine art, and that is precisely why it is so appealing to Grayson Perry. He describes his pots and vases as 'stealth objects, agents to get into the homes of the well-to-do'. From a distance they are handsome, classically shaped and richly ornamented vessels, but close up they teem with depraved scenes. Every taboo is flouted in these perverse pots which both subvert and play off conventions of art and craft in order to launch a more general assault on British culture, class, sexuality and taste - and on the art world, which, inevitably, laps up whatever invective he slings at it.

Michael Raedecker
It's a time-honoured art historical tradition that real men don't sew. But Michael Raedecker goes one step further - he commits the ultimate artistic taboo of combining thread and paint to produce sombre-coloured, uncannily atmospheric landscapes, interiors and portraits in which sewn fabric is made to function in as many different ways as painted surfaces. Last year he won the prestigious John Moores painting Prize with an eerie canvas in which sequins, lurex and different coloured yarns were used to accentuate, not alleviate, a sense of mysterious and dreamlike emptiness.

Tomoko Takahashi
There's nothing new about creating art out of everyday junk, but rather than trying to transform it into anything else, in her epic installations Tomoko Takahashi allows the rubbish to remain emphatically rubbish. Huge tides of the stuff engulf walls, floors and ceilings, often threatening to take over completely. But initial appearances are also deceptive - what may seem as random and chaotic as a force of nature is in fact meticulously arranged and carefully considered. Whether she's using the building debris of a new gallery space, the paperwork of a design agency or filling the Saatchi Gallery with a floor full of dysfunctional appliances, Takahashi describes her work as 'visual music', with each minute element orchestrated and arranged to make up an intricate whole.

Keith Tyson
Keith Tyson never suffers from artist's block. This is because much of what he does is not his work at all: it is the work of the Artmachine. The Artmachine is a series of computer programmes designed by Tyson to provide an endless source of inspiration - it issues proposals for artworks and Tyson slavishly follows them to the best of his abilities. The results are often bizarre: the entire contents of the Kentucky Fried Chicken menu cast in lead; 366 painted, wallmounted breadboards; a thimblefull of paint dropped from a New York building. Tyson, who claims to be as much influenced by science as by art, is nonetheless a passionate idealist who wants his art to be 'philosophically charged - to say something about the nature of existence and origin'.

 This is an edited extract from Louisa Buck's book, Moving Targets 2, which will be published in July 2000, priced £12.99

They make their dual presence felt in attention-grabbing artworks that both work with and send up the high media profile and cultish mythologising of so much contemporary art. They've covered many of the major players of the London artworld in tacky home-made tattoos, they've made neon signs, and exhibited a pile of their accumulated household rubbish which, when lit by a slide projector, projected a perfect shadow portrait of the pair's profiles. Grayson Perry Pottery is not a medium usually associated with contemporary or even fine art, and that is precisely why it is so appealing to Grayson Perry. He describes his pots and vases as 'stealth objects, agents to get into the homes of the well-to-do'. From a distance they are handsome, classically shaped and richly ornamented vessels, but close up they teem with depraved scenes. Every taboo is flouted in these perverse pots which both subvert and play off conventions of art and craft in order to launch a more general assault on British culture, class, sexuality and taste - and on the art world, which, inevitably, laps up whatever invective he slings at it. But Michael Raedecker goes one step further - he commits the ultimate artistic taboo of combining thread and paint to produce sombre-coloured, uncannily atmospheric landscapes, interiors and portraits in which sewn fabric is made to function in as many different ways as painted surfaces. Last year he won the prestigious John Moores painting Prize with an eerie canvas in which sequins, lurex and different coloured yarns were used to accentuate, not alleviate, a sense of mysterious and dreamlike emptiness. Tomoko Takahashi There's nothing new about creating art out of everyday junk, but rather than trying to transform it into anything else, in her epic installations Tomoko Takahashi allows the rubbish to remain emphatically rubbish. Huge tides of the stuff engulf walls, floors and ceilings, often threatening to take over completely. But initial appearances are also deceptive - what may seem as random and chaotic as a force of nature is in fact meticulously arranged and carefully considered. Whether she's using the building debris of a new gallery space, the paperwork of a design agency or filling the Saatchi Gallery with a floor full of dysfunctional appliances, Takahashi describes her work as 'visual music', with each minute element orchestrated and arranged to make up an intricate whole. Keith Tyson Keith Tyson never suffers from artist's block. This is because much of what he does is not his work at all: it is the work of the Artmachine. The Artmachine is a series of computer programmes designed by Tyson to provide an endless source of inspiration - it issues proposals for artworks and Tyson slavishly follows them to the best of his abilities. The results are often bizarre: the entire contents of the Kentucky Fried Chicken menu cast in lead; 366 painted, wallmounted breadboards; a thimblefull of paint dropped from a New York building. Tyson, who claims to be as much influenced by science as by art, is nonetheless a passionate idealist who wants his art to be 'philosophically charged - to say something about the nature of existence and origin'.  This is an edited extract from Louisa Buck's book, Moving Targets 2, which will be published in July 2000, priced £12.99

fields.headline: Car wonder
fields.standfirst: Austin Powers loves them, Del Boy and Rodney would be lost without theirs and in Austria it enjoys a cult following. Andy Smith takes to the road in a Robin Reliant to find out if it really deserves its awful reputation
fields.trailText: Austin Powers loves them, Del Boy and Rodney would be lost without theirs and in Austria it enjoys a cult following. Andy Smith takes to the road in a Robin Reliant to find out if it really deserves its awful reputation
fields.body:
In my daydreams, I'd floated serenely through the gates of Reliant's factory in Burntwood, Staffordshire, on a cloud of ambrosial Murray Mints. A committee consisting of Norman Wisdom and Vera Lynn greeted me warmly, proffering stockings and ration books and a rousing rendition of 'White Cliffs of Dover'. I had, it seemed, died and gone to drive a Robin. 'So God does have a sense of humour,' I smiled to myself, 'and is prepared to overlook all those years of atheism.' What a guy. At which point an uncomfortable thought shattered my serenity and my head started to spin. The question was: am I in heaven or hell?

An improbable number of people would plump for the former. The Robin Reliant is enshrined in British folklore. In fact, if you believe the enthusiasts - who include Austin Powers and the Trotters of Only Fools and Horses - this ostensibly rather silly car is one of the essential avatars of 'Britishness', a sort of spangled cross between Herbie and Henry V, and there is nothing they will not claim for it. It was there at Dunkirk, sang backing with Cliff and the Shadows, was a much better presenter of the Generation Game than Jim Davidson. What I think they mean is that this game three-wheeler is eccentric, backward, and immured to progress of any kind. And where other people sweep such things under the carpet, we like to nail ours proudly to the mantlepiece, and cherish them as our nation's flying ducks. This may also be the point at which to note that the Reliant Robin's biggest export market is Austria, where it has allegedly acquired the status of a yuppy cult.

When the Jersey-based financier Kevin Leech (who also owns John O-Groats and Land's End, incidentally) rescued the company in 1997, he claimed to be making a cool, business-driven decision. At the same time, he will admit to being a Reliant collector of long standing. People lose all sense of reason in the presence of these motors. The company sold its first three-wheeled van in 1935, with an aluminium-bodied passenger car following in 1953. Glass fibre construction was introduced in 1956 and, despite a cursory face lift, the so-called 'plastic pig' has changed little since. Outside are a few of the 700-odd Robins which the factory is now turning out per year, alongside rows of French Ligier micro-cars and tiny Piaggio Ape utility vehicles, both of which are now imported and marketed by Reliant. This production figure is well down on the 15,000 Robins and Scimitars that were once produced at the old plant in Tamworth, though a claimed three-month waiting list suggests an enduring demand.

Stepping into the factory is not as it was in my fantasies, although the solvent-rich atmosphere does lighten the head. After a while, I feel sure that if they replaced the Muzak on the company Tannoy with techno and issued me with a whistle, I could have a damned good time. Instead, I am taken on a tour of the plant and an arcane-looking process by which fibre strips are pasted to the inside of Robin-shaped moulds, then strengthened with spray. Once the material inside them is dry, the moulds are simply turned upside down and shaken until something vaguely resembling a car body falls out. Parents witnessing this will nod their heads sagely, recognising the very same method by which they make jelly for their children's birthday parties. Indeed, as drives go, the end result turns out to be not so very different.

How to put this politely? We've come to drive Reliant's new premium British Racing Green, or BRG model, some of which are blue. With the benefit of hindsight, I realise that our interest was based, to a probably unhealthy degree, on the green shag pile carpeting it is fitted with. In the event, this is of a shade that will be instantly recognisable to anyone who has ever examined the inner folds of a used handkerchief, and under no circumstances compensates for a ride that Fred Flintstone would despair of. Soon, I am compiling a list of things I would rather do than drive this car, which turns out to be almost infinitely long and takes in such activities as visiting the dentist, being trampled by a team of horses, frying and eating my own testicles and sub-editing Denise van Outen's first novel. I recognise that, for aficionados, this is almost certainly part of the attraction.

The Robin comes with a first aid kit, but if you're over 5ft 9in, what you need is a knee-amputation kit and a course of limbo dancing classes in order to contort your way into the seat. Once in, your head is permanently crushed against the ceiling; the grey plastic trim is nasty and the buttons apparently salvaged from mid-70s Austin Maxis; the footwell is cramped enough that working the pedals is a form of torture. The gearbox has a kind of stiff, pure-mechanical charm, and operating a manual choke a certain nostalgia value, but the 850cc engine, so reliably simple when seen on the workbench, is adequate on the road, no more. Clearly, its major selling point remains the fact that it is classed, and taxed, as a motorbike, which makes it very cheap to run. After half an hour, I can't wait to get the BRG back to base.

Once there, I am persuaded to try out the Ligier, which is classed as a micro-car on the continent, and so similarly inexpensive to operate. In keeping with the mood of the day, this is analogous to being trapped in a washing machine which is stuck on the spin cycle. It runs on diesel, has electric windows, feels like it's made out of cardboard and does a job (as footballers say when justifying a very boring performance), but at not so very much less than the elegant and fiendishly clever Smart car, it fails to establish a convincing rationale for its existence. Riding the Piaggio, which functions like a bike and goes so slowly that you want to get out and push, if not simply run away, is little less than painful.

I had to admire the rejuvenated Reliant corporation's consistency in choice of products. With this in mind, I called and asked Allan Sutton, chairman of Kevin Leech's Glen Investments group, which acts as parent to no fewer than 104 separate companies, what this urge to corner the market in really uncomfortable drives is about. He pointed out that the light-car market is growing; Reliant is a strong brand; the Robin is a British design icon; it's horribleness is its selling point (actually, he didn't point out this last bit, I did). Confirmation that, however weird anyone else thinks we Brits are, they really have no idea. I'm ready now, Denise.

fields.headline: This little piggy...
fields.standfirst: ... will feed up to 20 people - just pop it in the oven for a day and forget about it
fields.trailText: ... will feed up to 20 people - just pop it in the oven for a day and forget about it
fields.body:
You are just going to have to believe me when I tell you that there is such a thing as a lazy Sunday lunch for 15 to 20 and, what's more, I propose you cook it. The reason you should believe me is that I am not someone who churns out vats of food without the merest furrowing of a brow or clenching of a knuckle. True, I like cooking, and I like my friends, but having to feed too many of them at one time can leave me positively curdled with resentment and panic. I'd like to be calm, I'd like to be unflappable, but some things are never going to come to pass.

So, working along the premise of change what you can and accept what you can't, I've found a way of cooking that satisfies my need to be hospitable while accommodating my hostessy shortcomings. The first imperative is that there should be a great deal, indeed too much, to eat. It might sound blasphemous to say that my Jewish-mother leanings are best satisfied by a whole shoulder of pork, but I've found this to be the case. The fact that this great weight of pig needs hardly any interference while it cooks satisfies the second requirement - namely that you are not working yourself into a lather during the little free time you have. But it's not as unsatisfying for an enthusiast as it sounds: before you put the meat into the oven (where you leave it for a full day), you smother it with a fragrant paste of your own making, thereby giving yourself an essential element of pottering, without which you may as well be pinging the microwave.

The last time I did my pig, I had 14 people coming for dinner. That turned into 16 - then another two people turned up at the last minute. I can't tell you how rewarding it felt to be cooking food that turned me into the sort of person who felt totally unflustered by that.

Before then, you need to start off with good ingredients. The pork has to be the best pork you can get. But this is easily found. You just phone Heritage Prime (01297 489 304) and throw yourself on Denise's mercy. Their organic pork, from a farm near Lyme Regis, is better than any pork you've ever tasted, or could hope to taste (it's where the Roux brothers and Raymond Blanc get theirs). I buy Heritage Prime bacon (hand-cured) by the loadful, to be stashed in the deep-freeze and taken out and eaten in glorious abundance whenever the need for a first-rate bacon sandwich hits (which is often).

You can order any part of the pig (or a whole one, butchered) or other meat, but it is the pork shoulder I regularly go for, asking them to score the skin diagonally to aid crisping (and eating). It's £8.70 a kilo (£ 3.95 a lb), which, considering the quality and the cost of rearing, is not at all bad. Last time, Denise sent me a photo of 'the girls' on the bluebell-flecked hill overlooking Lyme Bay, which I've stuck on my fridge. Although I realise it might sound macabre to be gazing at a picture of live pigs while cooking a dead one, it is healthier than buying sanitised packets of clingfilmed meat from the supermarket that pretends to have no relationship to its source. It tastes a lot better, too.

The paste I spread on this pork is made of ginger, garlic, chilli and sherry vinegar - which has a Chinesey tone to it. Indeed, the pork when it's finished - the crackling glazed and crisp, the flesh beneath melting and to be torn rather than carved - reminds me obscurely of Peking duck. There's the same mixture between velvet-tender meat and seared-crisp skin. Correspondingly, I suggest aromatic plums to follow, the syrup in which they're poached resonant with star anise and cinnamon.

If you have only a single oven, I suggest you cook the plums a day early, then just heat them over a gentle flame on the hob at the last minute (though it wouldn't be ridiculous to start cooking them once you take the pork out). After all, this is meant to be a lazy Sunday lunch.

Slow-roasted shoulder of pork

I first got the idea of cooking a shoulder of pork over 24 hours from the second River Cafe Cookbook ; my take on it is really a de-Italianified version. Any mixture of herbs or spices you want would do: this isn't a recipe so much as a suggestion.

1 shoulder of pork, skin scored (approximately 9.5 kilos)
6 garlic cloves
1cm of fresh ginger
2 fresh red chillies or 1 tsp dried red chilli flakes
3 tbsps olive oil (not extra virgin)
4 tbsps sherry vinegar

So, if you're planning to eat this for Sunday lunch, at about Saturday lunchtime, preheat your (clean) oven to the hottest it will go. Sit the pork skin side up on a rack over a roasting tin. I like to use a pestle and mortar to make my paste, because it makes me feel good, but you could just grate the garlic and ginger (one of those microplane graters available from Lakeland or Divertimenti is the tool for the job) and stir in chilli flakes, a tablespoonful of oil and two of vinegar if you want. Otherwise, pound together the peeled cloves and peeled chopped ginger with the fresh chilli, adding a tablespoonful of oil and two of vinegar when they're squished and paste-like.

Using your fingers, rub this paste over the scored skin, pushing bits into the cut lines of rind. Stagger across to the oven and put in the tray, leaving it for 30 minutes. Meanwhile, pour the two remaining tablespoons each of oil and vinegar into the bowl in which you mixed the paste. When the pork's had its half an hour, remove it from the oven, switching it to 125C or gas mark ½ as you do so. Now turn the pork over: I find it easiest to lift it by hand wearing ovengloves.

Pour the oil and vinegar over the underside (which is now uppermost on the rack) and put the pork back in the low oven, leaving it there for 23 hours.

Actually, you could leave it longer. One of the joys of this is that it cannot over cook. Anyway, after 23 hours, or 30 to 40 minutes before you actually want to eat, turn the oven back to the highest it will go, remove the pork and turn it crackling side up. Put it back in the oven for 30 minutes in which time it will get hot and crisp, though you can give it another 10 minutes, if you feel it needs it.

Remove, slice off the crackling in a horizontal swipe of the knife and break it into manageable pieces, then start carving or pulling at the tender meat.

I like cabbage with this - just slice it in the processor so you've got a huge pile of shard-like shavings - as well as broccoli (I'm lazy and buy it already floretted), though if you want potatoes, by all means cook potatoes. If you're not going in for the poached plums afterwards, you could think of setting a jar of hoisin sauce on the table, but, for me, there must always be a pot of English mustard.

Baked spiced aromatic plums

When you poach fruit like this in the oven, it keeps its shape while cooking to gentle tenderness. Although plums are the food of late summer and early autumn, there are good red fruit around at the moment that will particularly benefit from immersion in this aromatic syrup.

2.25 kilos plums
1 bottle of red wine
4 bay leaves
2 cinnamon sticks or a tsp ground cinnamon
4 cloves
2 star anise
seeds from 8 cardamom pods or scant half tsp ground
750g honey (either runny or thick)

Set oven to 170 F/gas mark 3. Since you want the halved plums to lie flat in one layer, you'll certainly need two baking dishes, maybe even three. Whatever, they need to be shallow dishes, and the plums should fit snugly, or you won't have enough syrup.

Cut the plums in half, remove stones and divide them between the dishes, cut side down. Then put all the other ingredients into a saucepan and bring to the boil. Pour over the plums, cover the dishes tightly with foil (or a lid, of course, if you've one that fits) and bake for about an hour, or until the plums are tender.

If you want to make these in advance, do - just keep the cooled, covered fruit in the fridge for three or so days until you need them, then reheat them gently on the hob. Opinions in my household are divided as to what goes best with these spicy, wine-dark plums. There is a custard contingent, but what I really love is something my grandmother used to make. She called it Barbados cream, but it is just yogurt mixed with cream, topped with brown sugar and left covered for a day until the sugar melts into syrup which drips down the cool whiteness of the cream: crème brlée without the crunch and with a desirably sharp edge.

Barbados cream

It's difficult to be precise about measurements. The idea is to stir together equal quantities of yogurt (I always use Greek) and double cream and then sprinkle over a good covering of brown sugar. In other words - especially where sugar is concerned - go by eye, by volume, rather than the scales. The quantities below make enough to fill a large shallow bowl (and it must be a shallow bowl) measuring about 30cm in diameter. I know this doesn't make a lot, but with the poached plums you really don't need a lot.

750ml double cream
750ml Greek yogurt
150g light muscovado sugar or more as needed

Mix the cream and Greek yogurt together then beat till fairly thick. Pour into a shallow bowl (or a couple of shallow bowls). Sprinkle over a thick carpet of brown sugar, cover with clingfilm and leave somewhere cool for at least 12 hours, or better still 24.

Although plums are the food of late summer and early autumn, there are good red fruit around at the moment that will particularly benefit from immersion in this aromatic syrup. 2.25 kilos plums 1 bottle of red wine 4 bay leaves 2 cinnamon sticks or a tsp ground cinnamon 4 cloves 2 star anise seeds from 8 cardamom pods or scant half tsp ground 750g honey (either runny or thick) Set oven to 170 F/gas mark 3. Since you want the halved plums to lie flat in one layer, you'll certainly need two baking dishes, maybe even three. Whatever, they need to be shallow dishes, and the plums should fit snugly, or you won't have enough syrup. Cut the plums in half, remove stones and divide them between the dishes, cut side down. Then put all the other ingredients into a saucepan and bring to the boil. Pour over the plums, cover the dishes tightly with foil (or a lid, of course, if you've one that fits) and bake for about an hour, or until the plums are tender. If you want to make these in advance, do - just keep the cooled, covered fruit in the fridge for three or so days until you need them, then reheat them gently on the hob. Opinions in my household are divided as to what goes best with these spicy, wine-dark plums. There is a custard contingent, but what I really love is something my grandmother used to make. She called it Barbados cream, but it is just yogurt mixed with cream, topped with brown sugar and left covered for a day until the sugar melts into syrup which drips down the cool whiteness of the cream: crème brlée without the crunch and with a desirably sharp edge. Barbados cream It's difficult to be precise about measurements. The idea is to stir together equal quantities of yogurt (I always use Greek) and double cream and then sprinkle over a good covering of brown sugar. In other words - especially where sugar is concerned - go by eye, by volume, rather than the scales. The quantities below make enough to fill a large shallow bowl (and it must be a shallow bowl) measuring about 30cm in diameter. I know this doesn't make a lot, but with the poached plums you really don't need a lot. 750ml double cream 750ml Greek yogurt 150g light muscovado sugar or more as needed Mix the cream and Greek yogurt together then beat till fairly thick. Pour into a shallow bowl (or a couple of shallow bowls). Sprinkle over a thick carpet of brown sugar, cover with clingfilm and leave somewhere cool for at least 12 hours, or better still 24.

fields.headline: Best cellars
fields.standfirst: This week: four 1998 southern French reds
fields.trailText: This week: four 1998 southern French reds
fields.body:
Forgive me for recommending four more of these after last week's eulogy, but they really are outstanding...

1998 Plan Macassan, Costières de Nîmes (£4.49, Oddbins). Made by a Franco-Australian collaboration, this deeply coloured blend of Syrah, Grenache and old Carignan is entirely unoaked. This allows the ripe plum and black-cherry fruit to cover the palate with supple generosity.

1998 Mas de Guiot Cabernet/Syrah, Vin de Pays du Gard (£5.99, Majestic). Denied the Costières de Nîmes appellation since it is 60 per cent Cabernet Sauvignon, this is a wild, tarry, oak-aged red with plenty of punch. Age it for two years, or drink it with something that soaks up the tannins.

1998 Domaine La Tour Vieille, Collioure (£8.75, Yapp Brothers, 01747 860 423). Situated in one of France's most beautiful villages, La Tour Vieille specialises in fortified Banyuls and delicious old-vine reds. This blend of 80 per cent Grenache and 20 per cent Carignan is rich and savoury, with spicy blackberry fruit and aromas of Mediterranean herbs.

1998 Domaine des Courtilles, Corbières (£8.99, Waitrose; or from Waitrose Direct, 0800 188 881). Just under £9 might seem like a lot for a Corbières, but this is no ordinary Corbières. It's a traditional style, made from bush-vine Carignan, Syrah and Grenache, but with a modern gloss. Big, rich and spicy, with concentrated fruit flavours and the structure to age.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Jamie Osborne was one of the greatest national hunt jockeys until he quit last year to become a trainer. Now, with head lad Ron Thomas, they are getting ready for the start of the flat season at Doncaster on Thursday
fields.trailText: Jamie Osborne was one of the greatest national hunt jockeys until he quit last year to become a trainer. Now, with head lad Ron Thomas, they are getting ready for the start of the flat season at Doncaster on Thursday
fields.body:
Jamie Osborne
Having fallen on my head once too often at the Cheltenham Festival in 1999, I decided to end my 15-year riding career and put into operation a long-term ambition to become a trainer of horses on the flat. Now I've got more than 50 horses and I employ 20 people in my yard at Kingsdown in Upper Lambourn, Berkshire. When I started, my priority was to get a good head lad, and the man I targeted was Ron Thomas because of his experience and his top-class reputation in the business. Peter Walwyn, who for years had been one of the best flat trainers in the country, had announced his retirement and Ron had been his head lad for 30 years.

I was lucky to get him. Walwyn was very protective towards his staff and insisted on interviewing me before he would let me even talk to Ron. But things worked out and I told Ron what I was planning to do and that I would like him to work for me as head lad. Walwyn gave him the green light and he said 'Yes'. There are parts of the job where I lack Ron's experience. He may be called a lad, but he's 55 years old and he's spent every day of the past 30 years feeling the legs of two-year-olds. He was helping to train Derby winners when I was still in nappies, so he knows everything there is to know about the fragile structure of a horse. Also, I need a head lad I get on with and trust absolutely because, when I'm not here in the yard, he is absolutely in charge. He looks after the staff, has the power to hire and fire them, issue instructions and bollock them when necessary.

We have a board in the tack room which we use to plan the next day's work and we run a list every day. There is a metal tab for each horse, and in the evening we go through the list, allocating riders. All the lads are accomplished horsemen or women, but, of course, some are better than others and some are better suited to certain types of horse. So, depending on the progress and training requirements of the horse and the ability of the lad concerned, we juggle the timetable for the next day.

I am on the gallops early in the morning and responsible for the training regime. Ron and I discuss the work schedules for each horse. We both have our input but ultimately the buck stops with me. Ron spends every day, all day in the yard. He knows the intricacies of every horse we have. Racehorses are prone to all sorts of physical problems. Ron must diagnose their ailments and problems very quickly.

There are other things on my mind apart from the business. I got married last autumn and Katie, my wife, is expecting our first child in May. We live in Upper Lambourn, just around the corner from the yard. She paints for a living, under the name Katie O'Sullivan. I'd love to have some of her paintings, but I can't afford them.

Although I'm responsible for the training, I have to spend much of my time away from the yard. For instance, I will go to the sales in the autumn and I will probably be at the races three or four days a week during the season. I have more than 100 owners and it is my job to look after them.

I try to call them every week and give them a progress report. Most people own horses for fun and, if they make a bit of money, it's a bonus, but they quite rightly expect the trainer to be there when the horse is running. So much of my time is taken up with getting on with my owners and promoting my yard, Kingsdown, to new ones. This means putting myself about a bit and there have been one or two occasions when Ron is in the yard at five in the morning at the same time as I am arriving home after a night entertaining clients. It's a hard life, but somebody's got to do it.

Ron Thomas
Jamie knew exactly what he wanted to do when he called me up last summer, and I liked the sound of it. There's no bullshit about him - what you see is what you get. He was one of the greatest national hunt jockeys of all time and won everything except the Grand National and the Gold Cup, although he was second in both races. He makes quick decisions but he discusses them with you first and he's never shy of asking for advice. He's worked with horses all his life and has a feel for them. It's early days, but I am certain he will be a successful trainer.

The yard was in a dreadful state when we moved in. There was shit caked all over the walls in the boxes and the air vents in the roof hadn't been opened for years. There was a plague of rats and the lads' quarters were filthy. The covered ride was flooded and the roof had collapsed. And there were pot holes everywhere. We spent a week cleaning up, redecorating the offices and the quarters, and washing out all the boxes. Now the yard is something to be proud of. Everybody mucked in. Jamie's dad helped and it created a good bond between us all.

Owners like coming here because the atmosphere is good, and that is because the lads are happy and Jamie is a good employer. He has provided all sorts of incentives for them and tried to create pride in the yard.

I live about 10 minutes' drive away with my wife and daughter, so I can get to the yard early. Most days we will watch the horses and discuss their progress. Jamie will ride out himself or we will drive up on the gallops and watch them exercise together. They are mainly two-year-olds bought at last year's autumn sales. When they arrived here, they were just babies, most were not broken. Now we have a collection of horses which will soon be ready to race. We have had to teach them to run in a straight line and to do what the jockey tells them. They have been monitored until we know everything about them. We will discuss their individual strengths and weaknesses and then work to bring them in peak condition at just the right time.

I had nothing to do with the selection of the horses, but I am more than happy with what we have. Jamie disappeared up to Newmarket and Doncaster, bought them on credit and then found them owners. Most people start in a small way, find the owners and then buy the horses. Jamie did it the other way round. That took nerve.

I think he thrives on tension. If it goes wrong, he's in big trouble, but he never seems to even contemplate the possibility. He knows he is going to succeed.

We are just training flat horses and the season starts soon. Jamie and I have been working as a team since last autumn and I can truthfully say that we get on well.

One of his strengths is that he was a great jockey who always used his head. He's still cocky and he's still got the brains and the touch but he's willing to learn. There is nothing autocratic in his nature. It is very important that people like you in this game, and you can't help liking Jamie.
