fields.headline: Art struck
fields.standfirst: How I fell in love with Britart. By Lynn Barber
fields.trailText: How I fell in love with Britart. By Lynn Barber
fields.body:
It was Thomas Hoving, a former director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, who famously declared, 'Art is sexy! Art is money-sexy! Art is money-sexy-social-climbing fantastic!' I think the social-climbing bit only applies in America but the art-money-sexy exclamation mark still stands. I've been artstruck for the past eight years and keep waiting for the excitement to wear off but it never does. I love the wild contrasts of the art world, the gambler's highs and lows, the wacky juxtapositions of extreme glamour and extreme grottiness, the exhilarating absence of any sensible stripped-pine middle-class bits in between. One day it's dinner at Anthony d'Offay's in Regents Park with Charles Saatchi and Jerry Hall, the next day it's out to the unused pages of the A to Z in search of some artists' co-op in El5. Basically the more serious you are about contemporary art, the further eastwards you have to travel: no serious art happens west of Bond Street.

Everyone in the art world seems to be either terribly rich or terribly poor - it's a bit like horseracing in that respect - but with the rich for once in the subservient role. That's why art parties are a liggers' charter - I've seen pinstriped men break away from Brompton Cross blondes to pursue some terrible smelly sleeping-bag-clutching crusty because hovering at the back of their minds is the unspoken question: Are you a homeless alky who's just wandered in off the street or are you an important New Neurotic Realist? Appearances are always deceptive at art parties. I'd seen someone I assumed was a ligger for years before he turned up on telly being Matthew Collings presenting Channel 4's This is Modern Art.

The combination of geographical and social adventure with non-stop alcohol are as it were the perks of the art world - but what about the art? I grew up with all the usual prejudices about contemporary art and in fact retained them well into my forties: why can't they draw, why can't they paint, why can't they paint things that look like things; why can't they paint like Vermeer, why can't they do a decent portrait; why do they charge so much for their work; how do we know we're not being conned? The fear of being conned by art seems to run very deep in the British psyche - it's been going on at least since Whistler. As I will explain in a minute, there is a simple way of freeing yourself from the fear of being conned. But let me go on a bit about my conversion.

I saw Rachel Whiteread's Ghost - her plastercast of a room - in, I think, 1992 and couldn't get it out of my mind. My first reaction was the kneejerk - 'But it's only a load of old plaster, not beautiful, what's the point?' Nevertheless Ghost haunted me, and when Whiteread cast her House at Bow in 1993 I rushed to see it. This time, perhaps because I'd been fretting about Ghost so much, I didn't need to ask what was the point - I felt I knew immediately: to dignify an ordinary house by making it into art, to honour it and make it unforgettable.

Getting the point felt like a great achievement, so I was possessively distressed when I learned that House was to be demolished. And who should be responsible for demolishing it but my old friend, Eric Flounders, the Leader of Tower Hamlets council. I decided it would be a simple matter to take Eric out to lunch, suck up to him a bit, and then say 'By the way, Eric, please don't demolish House'. Unfortunately he snarled like an enraged pit bull when I raised the subject. With all the many many problems of Tower Hamlets, he ranted, this effing House was the only thing to get an ounce of media attention or public concern. He stomped off in a fury, so then I decided to write an article trying to enlist public support - again, it did no good at all, and House was demolished a few weeks later. But my article caught the eye of Doris Saatchi, who took me to lunch and gently suggested that perhaps I should write more about contemporary art. I said my total ignorance was a handicap, but she said not necessarily - if I interviewed artists I would probably learn something. Up till then I had thought there was a great Trespassers Will Be Prosecuted sign outside the art world - it was as if she had handed me the key to the gate.

My first problem was getting rid of the notion that artists had to be able to draw or paint or at least do something I couldn't do. I wanted them to have a 'God-given talent', the equivalent of perfect pitch, that made it OK for them to be artists and me not. But I eventually saw, by analogy with my own field, writing, that the skill side is unimportant. I mean, with writing - there are people who can turn out grammatically perfect essays with every word correctly spelled, but you still don't want to read them because they're boring. And then there are other people whose spelling is wonky and grammar fallible but you hang in there and read them because they've got something interesting to say. So with art: technical skill is useful but not enough - in fact not anything without ideas. In theory, any of us could have gone to Charles Saatchi and said, 'I'd like you to pay for me to import a l4-foot tiger shark from Australia and put it in a tank and show it in your gallery' - but as Damien Hirst always says, unanswerably, 'But you didn't, did you?'

It was Damien Hirst, of course, who started it all with his l988 Freeze show - and what an incredibly generous act that was, for an art student to organise a show for his fellow students. It meant that a whole generation came out of Goldsmiths like an army, instead of being picked off singly by the Cork Street dealers. And it was Damien Hirst who enlisted Charles Saatchi (who up till then had mainly collected American art) and set him off on his great British buying spree. Saatchi's advertising background and Damien's natural showmanship created the perfect synergy for launching Britart - with Damien's shark, as it were, the brand logo.

Of course there is controversy about Saatchi's role and about his taste. Some complain that he goes for 'soundbite art', that he favours the quick sensational statement; others complain that his taste is too fleeting, that he buys art almost like pop singles and then discards it; others again maintain that he is purely a dealer. But let's just say for the moment that Saatchi was a Maecenas to an important generation of British artists, and that even if he never buys another painting, or mounts another show, we should be grateful to him for giving us Sensation.

Damien, of course, played the role that David Hockney played for Britart in the Sixties - he made art 'sexy' in media terms. He took the flak, raised the hype, enraged the Mail and Telegraph -readers and created an atmosphere of controversy and excitement that ultimately benefited the whole art scene. The fact that he was so likeable and came from a non-art background - his father actually told the press, 'I can't for the life of me see the art in his work' - were all to the good, and obviously pickled sharks and dissected cows were a gift for cartoonists. He has tactfully retreated in the last couple of years and left the way clear for other artists to grab the spotlight, as Tracey Emin so enjoyably did last year.

But media attention inevitably leads on to money, and this is where it all gets sticky. Again, Damien put it best: 'Art is about life; the art world is about money'. The artists themselves are clearly not money-motivated: on the contrary, they tend to be extremely left-wing, anti-capitalist, anti-consumerist. And yet they sustain this glossy artbiz pyramid which is all about money. Some of the dealers seem more like City traders than art lovers - some of them actually were City traders - quite a few of them still wear pinstriped suits. Britart in the Nineties attracted not only serious collectors, but also speculators, and the Saatchi auction in l998 revealed that they were onto a good thing - most of the big names had doubled or tripled or quadrupled in value in less than a decade. Artists get very shifty if you try and talk about the money side - they say they leave all that to their dealers. But the disparity between intention and end-use is very striking. Artists make art for themselves - the fact that it ends up as a luxury status object in a millionaire's penthouse is something they prefer not to address.

Money is the fly in the ointment, the goad in the flank, the thing that makes the Great British Public so suspicious of art. But why should we care? We're not actually buying this stuff - no one expects us to. That's the great point about contemporary art: we don't have to buy it. If a few collectors want to pay high prices for it, then fine, especially if, like Charles Saatchi, they want to show it to the public - great. But would we honestly want to own, say, Sarah Lucas's Two Fried Eggs and a Kebab and have to cook it new fried eggs every day? And what would we do with Marc Quinn's Self - his head made out of his blood - or Damien Hirst's A Thousand Years ('steel, glass, flies, maggots, MDF, insect-o-cutor, cow's head, sugar, water') when the electricity went off? The curatorial problems of contemporary art are a nightmare, so we should thank our lucky stars that we don't own it, and don't have to.

And once you clear your mind of the idea that you might actually buy any of this art, then all the old worries about am I being conned fly out of the window. If all you have to do is look at it, the worst that can happen is that you can waste an hour looking at something boring, which God knows we do often enough when we switch on the television. A lot of contemporary art can be seen for free in public or commercial galleries; even the Saatchi only costs £4, and although the staff in the commercial galleries often look rather snotty, I have found they are touchingly grateful for human contact - they get lonely in their gloss-white cubes.

I used to consider myself an art-lover because I was happy to spend a day in the National Gallery, or to drive round the back roads of Tuscany in search of another Piero. I now feel that that sort of art-love is necrophilia. If you care about art at all, then you must engage with contemporary art, however difficult or irritating you find it. It's no use saying Matisse or Michelangelo did it better - doubtless they did, but they would never have flourished if the society of their day only admired dead art. That is why, much though I enjoy Brian Sewell's writing, I think he does a disservice to art. Art is too important to consign to the heritage cupboard: we need it now; we need more of it; and we are very very lucky to be living in a golden age for British art. People will say, 'To think that Rachel Whiteread, Damien Hirst, Gary Hume, Sarah Lucas all walked the streets of London at the same time'. And now we've got the fun of seeing who will be their equivalents in the next generation. The portents are good - there's tons of new art out there in an enormous diversity of styles. Some of it will turn out to be trash but some of it won't, and you don't have to worry about what it costs because you're not going to buy it. Just look at it, and enjoy.

As I will explain in a minute, there is a simple way of freeing yourself from the fear of being conned. But let me go on a bit about my conversion. I saw Rachel Whiteread's Ghost - her plastercast of a room - in, I think, 1992 and couldn't get it out of my mind. My first reaction was the kneejerk - 'But it's only a load of old plaster, not beautiful, what's the point?' Nevertheless Ghost haunted me, and when Whiteread cast her House at Bow in 1993 I rushed to see it. This time, perhaps because I'd been fretting about Ghost so much, I didn't need to ask what was the point - I felt I knew immediately: to dignify an ordinary house by making it into art, to honour it and make it unforgettable. Getting the point felt like a great achievement, so I was possessively distressed when I learned that House was to be demolished. And who should be responsible for demolishing it but my old friend, Eric Flounders, the Leader of Tower Hamlets council. I decided it would be a simple matter to take Eric out to lunch, suck up to him a bit, and then say 'By the way, Eric, please don't demolish House'. Unfortunately he snarled like an enraged pit bull when I raised the subject. With all the many many problems of Tower Hamlets, he ranted, this effing House was the only thing to get an ounce of media attention or public concern. He stomped off in a fury, so then I decided to write an article trying to enlist public support - again, it did no good at all, and House was demolished a few weeks later. But my article caught the eye of Doris Saatchi, who took me to lunch and gently suggested that perhaps I should write more about contemporary art. I said my total ignorance was a handicap, but she said not necessarily - if I interviewed artists I would probably learn something. Up till then I had thought there was a great Trespassers Will Be Prosecuted sign outside the art world - it was as if she had handed me the key to the gate. My first problem was getting rid of the notion that artists had to be able to draw or paint or at least do something I couldn't do. I wanted them to have a 'God-given talent', the equivalent of perfect pitch, that made it OK for them to be artists and me not. But I eventually saw, by analogy with my own field, writing, that the skill side is unimportant. I mean, with writing - there are people who can turn out grammatically perfect essays with every word correctly spelled, but you still don't want to read them because they're boring. And then there are other people whose spelling is wonky and grammar fallible but you hang in there and read them because they've got something interesting to say. So with art: technical skill is useful but not enough - in fact not anything without ideas. In theory, any of us could have gone to Charles Saatchi and said, 'I'd like you to pay for me to import a l4-foot tiger shark from Australia and put it in a tank and show it in your gallery' - but as Damien Hirst always says, unanswerably, 'But you didn't, did you?' It was Damien Hirst, of course, who started it all with his l988 Freeze show - and what an incredibly generous act that was, for an art student to organise a show for his fellow students. It meant that a whole generation came out of Goldsmiths like an army, instead of being picked off singly by the Cork Street dealers. And it was Damien Hirst who enlisted Charles Saatchi (who up till then had mainly collected American art) and set him off on his great British buying spree. Saatchi's advertising background and Damien's natural showmanship created the perfect synergy for launching Britart - with Damien's shark, as it were, the brand logo. Of course there is controversy about Saatchi's role and about his taste. Some complain that he goes for 'soundbite art', that he favours the quick sensational statement; others complain that his taste is too fleeting, that he buys art almost like pop singles and then discards it; others again maintain that he is purely a dealer. But let's just say for the moment that Saatchi was a Maecenas to an important generation of British artists, and that even if he never buys another painting, or mounts another show, we should be grateful to him for giving us Sensation. Damien, of course, played the role that David Hockney played for Britart in the Sixties - he made art 'sexy' in media terms. He took the flak, raised the hype, enraged the Mail and Telegraph -readers and created an atmosphere of controversy and excitement that ultimately benefited the whole art scene. The fact that he was so likeable and came from a non-art background - his father actually told the press, 'I can't for the life of me see the art in his work' - were all to the good, and obviously pickled sharks and dissected cows were a gift for cartoonists. He has tactfully retreated in the last couple of years and left the way clear for other artists to grab the spotlight, as Tracey Emin so enjoyably did last year. But media attention inevitably leads on to money, and this is where it all gets sticky. Again, Damien put it best: 'Art is about life; the art world is about money'. The artists themselves are clearly not money-motivated: on the contrary, they tend to be extremely left-wing, anti-capitalist, anti-consumerist. And yet they sustain this glossy artbiz pyramid which is all about money. Some of the dealers seem more like City traders than art lovers - some of them actually were City traders - quite a few of them still wear pinstriped suits. Britart in the Nineties attracted not only serious collectors, but also speculators, and the Saatchi auction in l998 revealed that they were onto a good thing - most of the big names had doubled or tripled or quadrupled in value in less than a decade. Artists get very shifty if you try and talk about the money side - they say they leave all that to their dealers. But the disparity between intention and end-use is very striking. Artists make art for themselves - the fact that it ends up as a luxury status object in a millionaire's penthouse is something they prefer not to address. Money is the fly in the ointment, the goad in the flank, the thing that makes the Great British Public so suspicious of art. But why should we care? We're not actually buying this stuff - no one expects us to. That's the great point about contemporary art: we don't have to buy it. If a few collectors want to pay high prices for it, then fine, especially if, like Charles Saatchi, they want to show it to the public - great. But would we honestly want to own, say, Sarah Lucas's Two Fried Eggs and a Kebab and have to cook it new fried eggs every day? And what would we do with Marc Quinn's Self - his head made out of his blood - or Damien Hirst's A Thousand Years ('steel, glass, flies, maggots, MDF, insect-o-cutor, cow's head, sugar, water') when the electricity went off? The curatorial problems of contemporary art are a nightmare, so we should thank our lucky stars that we don't own it, and don't have to. And once you clear your mind of the idea that you might actually buy any of this art, then all the old worries about am I being conned fly out of the window. If all you have to do is look at it, the worst that can happen is that you can waste an hour looking at something boring, which God knows we do often enough when we switch on the television. A lot of contemporary art can be seen for free in public or commercial galleries; even the Saatchi only costs £4, and although the staff in the commercial galleries often look rather snotty, I have found they are touchingly grateful for human contact - they get lonely in their gloss-white cubes. I used to consider myself an art-lover because I was happy to spend a day in the National Gallery, or to drive round the back roads of Tuscany in search of another Piero. I now feel that that sort of art-love is necrophilia. If you care about art at all, then you must engage with contemporary art, however difficult or irritating you find it. It's no use saying Matisse or Michelangelo did it better - doubtless they did, but they would never have flourished if the society of their day only admired dead art. That is why, much though I enjoy Brian Sewell's writing, I think he does a disservice to art. Art is too important to consign to the heritage cupboard: we need it now; we need more of it; and we are very very lucky to be living in a golden age for British art. People will say, 'To think that Rachel Whiteread, Damien Hirst, Gary Hume, Sarah Lucas all walked the streets of London at the same time'. And now we've got the fun of seeing who will be their equivalents in the next generation. The portents are good - there's tons of new art out there in an enormous diversity of styles. Some of it will turn out to be trash but some of it won't, and you don't have to worry about what it costs because you're not going to buy it. Just look at it, and enjoy.

webTitle: Beds and beef (A short history of British Art)

fields.headline: Beds and beef (A short history of British Art)
fields.standfirst: British artists from Hogarth to Hirst have favoured the domestic over the heroic, argues Peter Conrad
fields.trailText: British artists from Hogarth to Hirst have favoured the domestic over the heroic, argues Peter Conrad
fields.body:
Politically and commercially, 'British' has become a dubious or dirty word. The union which comprises Great Britain is fraying; in advance of its collapse, corporations already treat Britishness as a self-love which no longer dares to speak its name. British Airways briefly banned the flag from its tail fins, while British Petroleum and British Telecom cover their embarrassment by using only initials. All well and good, since the idea of Britain was never much more than a governmental fiction, serving to cover the family quarrels between four different nations.

In art, however, Britishness can still safely be celebrated. Modernism internationalised art, eliminating differences between Europe's separate schools. Britain, luckily, resisted the modern revolution in painting, and remained true to its own quirky national tradition. When Nikolaus Pevsner delivered the 1955 Reith lectures on 'The Englishness of English Art', he dolefully concluded that 'England has no Michelangelo, no Rembrandt, nor a Dürer or Grünewald, a Greco or Velasquez'.

He was only half right. We do possess such gods, but not in the visual arts: our British Michelangelo is Milton, and we have our own Rembrandt in the person of Shakespeare, while Dickens might be our Grünewald. British painters may not have painted cosmological ceilings like Michelangelo or fiercely exalted altar-pieces like Greco. Their achievements are less supernatural, but for that reason all the more comprehensible and lovable. They ignore angels in favour of domestic pets; instead of witchy divinities like the Mona Lisa, they study people who are as resolutely individualistic as Britain itself - Hogarth's Shrimp Girl or the equine country ladies of Gainsborough, Stanley Spencer's Patricia Preece with her sagging boobs or David Hockney's weary, worn, yet somehow beatific mother.

Classical art revered the ideal, a statuesque, platonically perfect improvement of the actual human form. Renaissance art emphasised the sanctity of the image: in the work of Giotto or Mantegna, the invisible face of the deity materialises before our eyes, as if on the Turin shroud. British art has always defied the precepts of both classical Greece and Renaissance Italy. Hogarth argued that the 'line of beauty' was irregular, rampantly energetic, lacking the poise and rectitude valued by classical design. The Victorian painter Lawrence Alma-Tadema tried to imagine Olympus, but his bathing nymphs have waxy flesh, and look as if they are taking part in an antique advertising campaign for cosmetics.

British art is earthy, worldly, and has scant respect for sanctity. In Constable's Salisbury Cathedral from the Meadows, that yearningly vertical spire is grounded by a team of muddy horses mired in a pond in the foreground, just as in Turner's Ploughing Up Turnips, Near Windsor, the hazy outline of the castle is upstaged by the peasants with their grubby piles of vegetables.

Our indigenous saints and martyrs never manage to lift off from the soil in which turnips are grown. In Stanley Spencer's St Francis and the Birds, painted in 1935, the pantheistic saint is a fat man in dressing gown and slippers, preaching to a rowdy congregation of barnyard fowls. Francis Bacon's career began in 1944 with an attempt to portray the crucifixion. But, characteristically, he saw the sadistic tableau from below, studying some twisted, screeching figures at the foot of the cross (and modelling their stricken mouths on some illustrations of oral diseases he found in a medical text book).

Ruskin hoped to establish a more respectable lineage for British art, which ought - he believed - to promote 'the chief worship which lay in the nation's heart'. 'In Athens,' he said, 'we have the triumph of Pallas; and in Venice, the Assumption of the Virgin.' He looked to Turner, born on St George's Day, to perform the local version of such miracles by slaying the dragon, which for Ruskin symbolised the mercenariness of philistine Britain. But Turner declined to fulfil the prophecy, and Ruskin sadly acknowledged that 'here in England, our great spiritual fact is the Assumption of the Dragon'. He should not have been dismayed. Turner's insular originality enabled him to paint a god of a new kind - the dynamo of industrial locomotion, the creative and destructive force which agitates nature in Rain, Steam, and Speed.

British art rejects the luminous pallor of the classical statue, or the gilded heaven of the Byzantine icon. Its tones tend to be murky, smudged and leaden like the overcast skies favoured by Constable. British artists are virtuosi of bad weather, from Turner's blizzards to Howard Hodgkin's Rain, in which inky clouds and the drenching squalls they disgorge cause the dry, solid world to deliquesce.

Rather than smoothing flesh into marble or refining it into the spirit's semi-transparent envelope, our painters emphasise the ruddy, meaty physicality of the world. A tradition extends from bleeding sirloin in Hogarth's Roast Beef of Old England to the cattle hacked into sections by Damien Hirst, or from the pustules in Blake's sketch of Satan Smiting Job with Boils to the soiled sheets aired by Tracey Emin in last year's Turner Prize show.

Dickens likened the narrative of Oliver Twist, which mingles sentimentality and grotesquerie, to the layers of 'streaky bacon'; Shakespeare's double plots alternate in the same way between tragedy and comedy, anguish and folly. Joshua Reynolds painted a great Shakespearean actor hesitating between the solemn exhortations of the tragic muse and the wanton enticements of her comic sister. Garrick's uncertainty, in this portrait painted in 1760-1, catches the mixed motives of British art, which attempts to balance what Matthew Arnold called 'high seriousness' with a more instinctive, barbaric low humour.

The earliest native craftsmen, during the Roman occupation, changed the faces they carved: classic heads were given bug eyes, elongated jaws, or nastily thinned lips. Gargoyles with toothache grimace on the rooftops of medieval churches.

By the eighteenth century, caricaturists like Thomas Rowlandson practised a physiognomic black magic, outraging the edicts of classical humanism as they showed men regressing to beasts. Another unbroken continuity extends from James Gillray's John Bull in 1798 - a piggish guzzler, feeding his belly with frigates - to the latex ogres of Spitting Image: Roy Hattersley with his incontinent spitting and spluttering, grey John Major, and the blowsy, tipsy royal dowagers.

But the British version does not merely relish the ugliness and abasement of Shakespeare's 'bared forked animal'. It corrects classical and Renaissance theories of beauty and acclimatises them to these eccentric islands by finding treasure in dross, or splendour - as Wordsworth put it - in the humble, downtrodden grass. Constable declared that he loved 'old rotten planks, slimy posts' and decayed brickwork, and envied Shakespeare's capacity to 'make everything poetical', even the bedraggled sheep-cotes and creaky mills frequented by Poor Tom, the mad mendicant in King Lear.

The point was repeated in the twentieth century by Algernon Newton, who believed that 'a gasometer can make as beautiful a picture as the Grand Canal'. The canals so lovingly painted by Newton were far from grand: they are the neglected industrial conduits of suburban London - sunken, secretive, moodily desolate.

The Victorian classicist Lord Leighton admiringly recalled the public honour accorded to painters in Renaissance Italy. In his picture of Cimabue's celebrated Madonna carried in Procession through the streets of Florence, he recreated the ceremonial parade on a canvas almost 20 feet long, and identified Giotto and Dante in the throng of lookers-on: this is a society unified and immortalised by art.

George Eliot, reflecting on the same Florentine festivities in her novel Romola, claimed that, 'There has been no great people with processions.' In Britain, however, painters have had better luck with the random jostling of crowds or mobs. Hence the idyllic indiscipline of W.P. Frith's Derby Day, with its yobs, yokels, swells, oafs, guttersnipes, acrobats, fallen women and quarrelsome dogs, none of them paying any attention to the race they have supposedly come to see. A critic in 1858 aptly remarked that the gathering was 'the great Saturnalia of British sport'. It is as if Chaucer's Canterbury pilgrims had made a detour to Epsom Downs, forgetting that their destination was meant to be a cathedral.

History painting, which depicts momentous political events, has never been at home in Britain (though it throve in nineteenth-century America, where art helped to confer identity on a new nation). Constable toiled to record the pomp which commemorated the opening of Waterloo Bridge in 1817, but could not prevent his attention from straying. The ranked dignitaries are submerged by the turbid river, and the city is obliterated by a showery sky.

Like Thackeray in Vanity Fair , who reduces the battle of Waterloo to noises off, British artists see history from the sidelines. W.R. Sickert in 1932 painted Miss Earhart's Arrival as a blurred and unsatisfactory epiphany. The flyer Amelia Earhart has landed in London after a solo flight across the Atlantic; the achievement is epic, but the painter has no more than a distant glimpse of her plane, obscured by craning well-wishers, colliding umbrellas, and the customary gauze of rain. In 1942, Richard Eurich attempted to paint the plucky Allied forces during the landing at Dieppe. Once again, the grand occasion is scarcely visible, erased by Turneresque pyrotechnics in the sky and by geysers of sea spray which blot out the naval convoy.

Rather than painting battles, British war artists tend to show how the violence of history is absorbed into a somnolent, unchanging landscape. At Cowley in 1941, Paul Nash painted a cemetery of downed German planes by moonlight. He called the result Dead Sea, because the scene looked to him like a silver, inundating ocean, a static surf of metal.

Retreating from the public arena, British artists concentrate on the private life. An unknown painter in the first decade of the 17th century showed The Cholmondeley Sisters sitting up in a shared bed cradling their new babies, born on the same day. The infants, tightly swaddled and packaged for display, are as inert as wood carvings; the braided costumes and stiff ruffs of the mothers are equally formal. But their wan, wary faces look startlingly contemporary: you might have seen them yesterday in a maternity ward, illustrating a television news item about the NHS.

Renaissance paintings were destined for churches or palaces. British artists expect their work to hang in less grandiose settings, and adjust art to the confessional intimacy of the home. In Marriage à la Mode and The Rake's Progress, Hogarth analysed the moral condition of his subjects by keeping an eye on their ostentatious or squalid housekeeping. In 1853 in Holman Hunt's The Awakening Conscience, a kept woman rebels against the shame of confinement in a suburban villa; for the sake of verisimilitude, the painter took over a 'maison de convenance' in St John's Wood as his studio. Tracey Emin may intend to shock us by embroidering a tent with the tawdry list of her sexual conquests or publicising her unmade bed, which doubles as an ash tray. If you remember the traditional domesticity of British art, nothing could be more boringly conservative.

A domesticated art requires house-trained pets. Samuel Johnson made a profound comment on the priorities of British art - and on the downright, steadfastly lowbrow posture of British character - when he said 'I had rather see the portrait of a dog I know than all the allegories you can show me'. Dogs are omnipresent in all periods of British painting. A gun dog noses a dead rabbit, part of the squire's catch in William Dobson's portrait of Endymion Porter, painted in the 1640s, and in 1725 a blue-blooded, elegantly emaciated greyhound could well be a relative of the patricians in Philip Mercier's Schutz Family. The pug in Hogarth's 1745 self-portrait advertises the pugnacity of its master.

In Victorian paintings, dogs acquire human emotions and lachrymose eyes. Eventually they outgrow their status as companions and qualify as subjects in their own right, like Cedric Morris's Belle of Bloomsbury, painted in 1948. No, Belle is not some Virginia Woolf wannabe. She is a bull terrier bitch with droopy pink dugs and a supercilious gaze - every bit as erotically self-possessed as a courtesan by Goya or an Ingres odalisque.

Though the canon is overwhelmingly canine, British art does contain one unforgettable cat. Its name (allegedly) is Percy, and it sits in Ossie Clark's lap, digging its nails into his groin with characteristic feline arrogance, in Hockney's 1971 conversation piece Mr and Mrs Clark and Percy. Acting on an aesthetic whim, Hockney changed the cat's name and sex: it was actually called Blanche. But the creature ignores all such human designs on it by turning away to gaze out the window. Despite this disdain, I would sooner converse with Percy than with the fatuous, fashionable Clarks. In due course Hockney transferred his affection from cats to dogs, and during the Nineties he made multiple portraits of his dachshunds, as gregarious and yappingly loquacious as their owner.

There are heroic figures in British art, but they are not conquerors like David's Napoleon, rearing on his mount as he crosses the Alps. In fact they are generally not even human. In Britain, an epic hero is likely to have antlers: look at the stoical, beleaguered stags painted by Edwin Landseer. George Stubbs's horses are nobler and more valiant - especially when savaged by lions - than any military eminence who might hoist himself on to their backs.

Heroes have vertical ambitions. British artists have always preferred horizontal bodies, like the pensive Sir Brooke Boothby who uses a riverbank as his chaise longue in Joseph Wright of Derby's portrait, painted in 1781. The pre-Raphaelite Ophelia of John Everett Millais gently reclines on her watery bier; Henry Moore's reclining women share their fecundity with the terrain from which their alabaster bodies have been carved.

More often than not, these figures lolling in the landscape have nodded off. In 1793, Henry Fuseli painted The Shepherd's Dream, visualising a metaphor from Milton's Paradise Lost: the shepherd's unconscious mind has conjured up a pagan orgy of maenadic fairies. The mad Richard Dadd, who murdered his father, painted an even more alarming wonderland or underworld in The Fairy-Feller's Master-Stroke, which he worked on obsessively between 1855 and 1864. In a thicket of dry grass, littered with prickly nuts, dwarfish gnomes and saturnine elves cavort, their sinister revels supervised by Oberon and Titania from A Midsummer Night's Dream. The Dreamer in Landscape sketched by John Craxton in 1942 dozes among the stalks, pods and thrusting tendrils of a riotously overgrown nature.

What are all these slumbrous characters dreaming about? They have a shared reverie, which is the recurring refrain of British art. Their unleashed imaginations make pictures of a paradise lost, or a lost childhood (which is the same thing). Hockney's A Bigger Splash shows the precise instant when the bland peace of Eden is disrupted, marred by that explosion on the surface of the swimming pool; Peter Blake's Toy Shop leads the way back to innocence with its window display of harmless targets, miniature fighter planes, tiny trains - and of course a painter's palette and a bristling set of paintbrushes. Artists, who are wiser and also more unguardedly naive than the rest of us, continue to believe that we can locate the door in the wall which will open on to a secret garden, where unfallen Eden is preserved.

Ruskin, with his usual mad literalness, thought that his Guild of St George could reconstruct Jerusalem, and pledged to make 'some small piece of English ground, beautiful, peaceful and fruitful'. Derek Jarman had more success in persuading the vision to take root and grow when he planted his resilient garden of herbs and wild flowers in pebbly soil on the coast at Dungeness. Ruskin vowed to banish railways from his utopian allotment; Jarman, resigned to grim actuality, laid out his garden next to the fuming towers of a nuclear power station.

At best we live in what Shakespeare's John of Gaunt half-heartedly calls a 'demi-paradise'. Even so, artists still tenderly keep the myth alive. Whether or not political federation happens, these islands will remain imaginatively offshore, unabsorbed by the continent. From the beginning of its history to the end, British art has always been dottily and incorrigibly romantic. The British pretend to be pragmatists, anchored by their empiricism. Art confirms a very different truth: this is a country of visionaries, fantasists and idiosyncratic zanies. No wonder Shakespeare sent Hamlet from Denmark to England - for there, to expand the comment of a sagacious clown, all the men (or at least all the artists) are as wickedly funny and as lyrically lunatic as he is.

Constable declared that he loved 'old rotten planks, slimy posts' and decayed brickwork, and envied Shakespeare's capacity to 'make everything poetical', even the bedraggled sheep-cotes and creaky mills frequented by Poor Tom, the mad mendicant in King Lear. The point was repeated in the twentieth century by Algernon Newton, who believed that 'a gasometer can make as beautiful a picture as the Grand Canal'. The canals so lovingly painted by Newton were far from grand: they are the neglected industrial conduits of suburban London - sunken, secretive, moodily desolate. The Victorian classicist Lord Leighton admiringly recalled the public honour accorded to painters in Renaissance Italy. In his picture of Cimabue's celebrated Madonna carried in Procession through the streets of Florence, he recreated the ceremonial parade on a canvas almost 20 feet long, and identified Giotto and Dante in the throng of lookers-on: this is a society unified and immortalised by art. George Eliot, reflecting on the same Florentine festivities in her novel Romola, claimed that, 'There has been no great people with processions.' In Britain, however, painters have had better luck with the random jostling of crowds or mobs. Hence the idyllic indiscipline of W.P. Frith's Derby Day, with its yobs, yokels, swells, oafs, guttersnipes, acrobats, fallen women and quarrelsome dogs, none of them paying any attention to the race they have supposedly come to see. A critic in 1858 aptly remarked that the gathering was 'the great Saturnalia of British sport'. It is as if Chaucer's Canterbury pilgrims had made a detour to Epsom Downs, forgetting that their destination was meant to be a cathedral. History painting, which depicts momentous political events, has never been at home in Britain (though it throve in nineteenth-century America, where art helped to confer identity on a new nation). Constable toiled to record the pomp which commemorated the opening of Waterloo Bridge in 1817, but could not prevent his attention from straying. The ranked dignitaries are submerged by the turbid river, and the city is obliterated by a showery sky. Like Thackeray in Vanity Fair , who reduces the battle of Waterloo to noises off, British artists see history from the sidelines. W.R. Sickert in 1932 painted Miss Earhart's Arrival as a blurred and unsatisfactory epiphany. The flyer Amelia Earhart has landed in London after a solo flight across the Atlantic; the achievement is epic, but the painter has no more than a distant glimpse of her plane, obscured by craning well-wishers, colliding umbrellas, and the customary gauze of rain. In 1942, Richard Eurich attempted to paint the plucky Allied forces during the landing at Dieppe. Once again, the grand occasion is scarcely visible, erased by Turneresque pyrotechnics in the sky and by geysers of sea spray which blot out the naval convoy. Rather than painting battles, British war artists tend to show how the violence of history is absorbed into a somnolent, unchanging landscape. At Cowley in 1941, Paul Nash painted a cemetery of downed German planes by moonlight. He called the result Dead Sea, because the scene looked to him like a silver, inundating ocean, a static surf of metal. Retreating from the public arena, British artists concentrate on the private life. An unknown painter in the first decade of the 17th century showed The Cholmondeley Sisters sitting up in a shared bed cradling their new babies, born on the same day. The infants, tightly swaddled and packaged for display, are as inert as wood carvings; the braided costumes and stiff ruffs of the mothers are equally formal. But their wan, wary faces look startlingly contemporary: you might have seen them yesterday in a maternity ward, illustrating a television news item about the NHS. Renaissance paintings were destined for churches or palaces. British artists expect their work to hang in less grandiose settings, and adjust art to the confessional intimacy of the home. In Marriage à la Mode and The Rake's Progress, Hogarth analysed the moral condition of his subjects by keeping an eye on their ostentatious or squalid housekeeping. In 1853 in Holman Hunt's The Awakening Conscience, a kept woman rebels against the shame of confinement in a suburban villa; for the sake of verisimilitude, the painter took over a 'maison de convenance' in St John's Wood as his studio. Tracey Emin may intend to shock us by embroidering a tent with the tawdry list of her sexual conquests or publicising her unmade bed, which doubles as an ash tray. If you remember the traditional domesticity of British art, nothing could be more boringly conservative. A domesticated art requires house-trained pets. Samuel Johnson made a profound comment on the priorities of British art - and on the downright, steadfastly lowbrow posture of British character - when he said 'I had rather see the portrait of a dog I know than all the allegories you can show me'. Dogs are omnipresent in all periods of British painting. A gun dog noses a dead rabbit, part of the squire's catch in William Dobson's portrait of Endymion Porter, painted in the 1640s, and in 1725 a blue-blooded, elegantly emaciated greyhound could well be a relative of the patricians in Philip Mercier's Schutz Family. The pug in Hogarth's 1745 self-portrait advertises the pugnacity of its master. In Victorian paintings, dogs acquire human emotions and lachrymose eyes. Eventually they outgrow their status as companions and qualify as subjects in their own right, like Cedric Morris's Belle of Bloomsbury, painted in 1948. No, Belle is not some Virginia Woolf wannabe. She is a bull terrier bitch with droopy pink dugs and a supercilious gaze - every bit as erotically self-possessed as a courtesan by Goya or an Ingres odalisque. Though the canon is overwhelmingly canine, British art does contain one unforgettable cat. Its name (allegedly) is Percy, and it sits in Ossie Clark's lap, digging its nails into his groin with characteristic feline arrogance, in Hockney's 1971 conversation piece Mr and Mrs Clark and Percy. Acting on an aesthetic whim, Hockney changed the cat's name and sex: it was actually called Blanche. But the creature ignores all such human designs on it by turning away to gaze out the window. Despite this disdain, I would sooner converse with Percy than with the fatuous, fashionable Clarks. In due course Hockney transferred his affection from cats to dogs, and during the Nineties he made multiple portraits of his dachshunds, as gregarious and yappingly loquacious as their owner. There are heroic figures in British art, but they are not conquerors like David's Napoleon, rearing on his mount as he crosses the Alps. In fact they are generally not even human. In Britain, an epic hero is likely to have antlers: look at the stoical, beleaguered stags painted by Edwin Landseer. George Stubbs's horses are nobler and more valiant - especially when savaged by lions - than any military eminence who might hoist himself on to their backs. Heroes have vertical ambitions. British artists have always preferred horizontal bodies, like the pensive Sir Brooke Boothby who uses a riverbank as his chaise longue in Joseph Wright of Derby's portrait, painted in 1781. The pre-Raphaelite Ophelia of John Everett Millais gently reclines on her watery bier; Henry Moore's reclining women share their fecundity with the terrain from which their alabaster bodies have been carved. More often than not, these figures lolling in the landscape have nodded off. In 1793, Henry Fuseli painted The Shepherd's Dream, visualising a metaphor from Milton's Paradise Lost: the shepherd's unconscious mind has conjured up a pagan orgy of maenadic fairies. The mad Richard Dadd, who murdered his father, painted an even more alarming wonderland or underworld in The Fairy-Feller's Master-Stroke, which he worked on obsessively between 1855 and 1864. In a thicket of dry grass, littered with prickly nuts, dwarfish gnomes and saturnine elves cavort, their sinister revels supervised by Oberon and Titania from A Midsummer Night's Dream. The Dreamer in Landscape sketched by John Craxton in 1942 dozes among the stalks, pods and thrusting tendrils of a riotously overgrown nature. What are all these slumbrous characters dreaming about? They have a shared reverie, which is the recurring refrain of British art. Their unleashed imaginations make pictures of a paradise lost, or a lost childhood (which is the same thing). Hockney's A Bigger Splash shows the precise instant when the bland peace of Eden is disrupted, marred by that explosion on the surface of the swimming pool; Peter Blake's Toy Shop leads the way back to innocence with its window display of harmless targets, miniature fighter planes, tiny trains - and of course a painter's palette and a bristling set of paintbrushes. Artists, who are wiser and also more unguardedly naive than the rest of us, continue to believe that we can locate the door in the wall which will open on to a secret garden, where unfallen Eden is preserved. Ruskin, with his usual mad literalness, thought that his Guild of St George could reconstruct Jerusalem, and pledged to make 'some small piece of English ground, beautiful, peaceful and fruitful'. Derek Jarman had more success in persuading the vision to take root and grow when he planted his resilient garden of herbs and wild flowers in pebbly soil on the coast at Dungeness. Ruskin vowed to banish railways from his utopian allotment; Jarman, resigned to grim actuality, laid out his garden next to the fuming towers of a nuclear power station. At best we live in what Shakespeare's John of Gaunt half-heartedly calls a 'demi-paradise'. Even so, artists still tenderly keep the myth alive. Whether or not political federation happens, these islands will remain imaginatively offshore, unabsorbed by the continent. From the beginning of its history to the end, British art has always been dottily and incorrigibly romantic. The British pretend to be pragmatists, anchored by their empiricism. Art confirms a very different truth: this is a country of visionaries, fantasists and idiosyncratic zanies. No wonder Shakespeare sent Hamlet from Denmark to England - for there, to expand the comment of a sagacious clown, all the men (or at least all the artists) are as wickedly funny and as lyrically lunatic as he is.

fields.headline: Time to pass the 11-plus test
fields.trailText: The ballot in Ripon on 11-plus selection (Comment, last week) satisfies nobody and serves to increase feelings of bitterness. If the Government wants to abolish selection without alienating its supporters then it should call the bluff of the grammar-school lobby.
fields.body:
The ballot in Ripon on 11-plus selection (Comment, last week) satisfies nobody and serves to increase feelings of bitterness. If the Government wants to abolish selection without alienating its supporters then it should call the bluff of the grammar-school lobby.

The 11-plus supporters want to believe that selection works, that only a minority of people are worth educating much beyond junior-school level and that the rise of the comprehensives has lowered standards. That none of these is true is something this group has at least subconsciously acknowledged by failing to provide evidence to support their case.

If I could pass legislation I would make it legal for any school to select its pupils on the basis of ability provided the school could show its selection procedure had a sound scientific basis. This would involve proving that the pre-First World War theory on which it is based is true and that supporters can demonstrate what human intelligence is, as well as measure it. They would also have to explain why the 11-plus got it wrong about millions of people.
David Smith
London E10

 Blunkett would have us believe that what many people interpreted as a pledge regarding selective education was really no more than a bit of fun? The joke is lost on this former member of the Labour Party. God knows how much fun the other parties will have at New Labour's expense in the run-up to the next general election. Good luck to them.
J.E. Smith
Brewood, Stafford
