webTitle: A day in the life of British art

fields.headline: A day in the life of British art
fields.standfirst: Matthew Collings takes a frantic ride around London with his artistic friends old and new
fields.trailText: Matthew Collings takes a frantic ride around London with his artistic friends old and new
fields.body:
10.20am I go down a little street off the Cambridge Heath Road in Hackney and get buzzed in a square grey door. Big black letters spell out 21 Herald Street. Tiny letters over the buzzer spell out Interim Art. Outside it's all charming and working-class picturesque. Next door is the Built On The Rock evangelist church, with its slogan: 'God is too big to fail and too strong to let you down.' Inside the Interim Art gallery, all is gleaming.

Maureen Paley is the perfect dealer or gallerist of now. Perfect for the job. It's a weird job. You have to behave in an unreal way. Already, at 10 in the morning, she's hard at work being unreal. I've known her for 20 years, ever since she first came to London from New York. The way I cope with the act is to compliment her on it. 'Wow, this space is good!' 'Yes I think of it as my Dia Foundation! Don't you love it?'

I do! At least for now! At other times I might feel there has to be some kind of human resistance to the rising tide of these weirdo perfect gallerist types, the Jay Joplings and so on. In fact, I start to think about his second space about to open in Hoxton Square, with a little '2' next to the 'White Cube'. Can't he see the '2' is redundant and it makes the whole gag redundant?

But now isn't the time for hostility. I can see Maureen is riding high, with her thick black hair pulled back tight, her red lipstick, white face, gold flower-shaped ear rings, all-black outfit, new black shoes and black fluffy trim down her black cardigan. She tours me round the place and I marvel at the sights. She designed the gallery herself, with its lovely chrome toilet area, magnificent office, good storage and luxurious showing space.

She says she still lives in her house in Beck Road, half a mile away, where the old Interim Art used to be. She started it in the early Eighties. She originally got the house from the subsidised artists' space organisation Acme. We smile at the memory of the old ethos of Acme. Cold, lonely, subsidised artists' spaces were the rule.

She says it was a more socialist era, adding quickly that she loves that. 'Oh yes, me too!' I say. 'Now I suppose it's more a style era?' I venture. 'Yes!' she says.

She doesn't just think toward a single point nowadays. There was a time when single-point thinking was right. But now it's all-round thinking, or all-over or something. I nod and frown and absolutely agree, inwardly wondering what we're talking about while outwardly keeping the stylish leaning and swaying and gesturing going, for the benefit of Tony, The Observer's photographer, who is clicking away, revving us up to great feats of intellectual posing.

Two young assistants - their combined ages would add up to the age that Maureen and I both are - rustle papers in the background. The phone rings. Maureen takes the call and immediately goes into a slightly different accent. 'I will speak with Wolfgang,' she says in an unmistakable German way yet without using any actual German. 'I know of your collection. We will send a presentation.'

In a few hours she's going to be on her way to New York for the city's annual international art fair. It's called The Armory Show, an ironic reference to the real venue of the exhibition in 1917, where Marcel Duchamp first exhibited a real urinal. Art fairs - like car fairs or yacht fairs, basically trade fairs - are for contacts, not just for selling, I learn. There's ambassadorial work to be done, fronting the gallery, but the main thing is meeting up with like-minded colleagues from abroad. 'It's like insider information - people telling you about things before the news has broken.'

I imagine the drift of the information exchange: how is the backlash against young British artists going? Is it real or only an intellectual pose? A pose of course! Although at the same time everybody knows who the good YBAs are: the ones Maureen and the unrealist colleagues have signed up! Of course the actual conversation would be much more difficult to understand, more serious, more multilingual.

11.05am The light falls in Rachel Whiteread's studio off the Kingsland Road, between Dalston and Shoreditch, in beautiful dusty diagonal rays. Assistants work on big plaster things and carry equipment around. On a surface in the corner of one space are piles of remaindered hardback books. Unusually for an artist's studio, they look like books somebody might read, the novel Gorky Park for example. In fact they're for casting. When they've been used for bookshelf sculptures they're so ridden with concrete or plaster or gel or other bits of matter they can't be re-cycled and they have to be thrown away.

Today, Rachel is working on a secret public art commission. She hasn't officially submitted it yet so she can't talk about it. She agrees to do a bit of filing on some plaster casts of the backs of human heads so Tony can photograph her at work. She seems unused to the activity and holds the file half-heartedly. Maybe it's already filed enough.

But also, I suppose, filing and sanding and so on is probably more the kind of work her assistants are paid to do. A lot of her work is planning more than sanding - behind the scenes work; working out how to get a very clear, apparently simple sculptural idea not to crack or sag or fall down or turn an unpleasant colour. She has to commission special firms to come up with new types of resin, new mixes for concrete - technical things that have never been done before.

I notice the heads are a bit like something I've seen in a Dali painting. This gives her pain. She tries to avoid thinking about him, she says. 'Ha ha! I know what you mean!' I say. I'm full of goodwill, having decided on the way here that I'm on her side. I used to be against her art because of its aesthetic of cool designer minimalist elegance. Now I feel that kind of thing is a relief rather than an annoyance. I used to feel uncomfortable with the pretentious death rhetoric that automatically goes with any art critical mention of her art. But after all, it's not her fault what art writers say. She's only done one piece that was directly about death, she says, a work about her father.

She's already designed her Trafalgar Square plinth on a plinth - a transparent resin version of the existing stone plinth, which will stand upside down on the real thing. I look at computer-generated slides of it with her now. I find it looks good. I feel much better liking it than not liking it.

She says she's finding the new secret project quite hard. She had to give a slide presentation the other day to the commissioners, offering examples of good public art and bad public art.

'Oh, what were they?' The good example was the Vietnam memorial in Washington. I agree that no one could complain about that. I imagine she would be reluctant to say what the bad example was, probably something like Bill Woodrow's bronze sculpture of a writhing tree growing out of a head rising out of the ground that's due to go up on the Trafalgar Square plinth before her one.

But in fact it's a holocaust memorial in Austria. The memorial has a lot of stone figures of wailing victims and another victim kneeling on the ground scrubbing the streets. Apparently the kneeling figure was so often and so completely defaced by graffiti that the city council had it covered in barbed wire, which made for a rather unfortunate image.

Her own holocaust memorial in Vienna is presently surrounded by wooden planks and will be un-planked in October.

She says she found the whole Vienna experience harrowing and frightening. She explains that it's all quite complicated because some of the fiercest opposition has come from the Jewish community, who'd much rather have more wailing figures than the huge inside-out library that Whiteread has designed.

This monumental work is ingenious, with smaller sections of library housed within the hollow structure, ready to be installed on the outside if any of the outside sections are too badly defaced by hostile graffiti-ists. She's had endless rows with the city. One of them was over air bubbles. An uneven surface is part of the aesthetic but the city wanted a surface that would be less expensive to clean.

'What do you think about Gilbert & George leaving your gallery?' I ask. Her gallery is Anthony d'Offay. I feel sure she won't want to be thought of as a gossip but in fact she laughs and says they probably wanted to go somewhere sexier like White Cube.

1.10pm Horrible foetuses in jars are lined up in rows on shelves at the Royal College of Surgeons in Lincoln's Inn Fields. One is a big overweight thing with wrinkled fingers. The horrors go on endlessly. There's a real skull with another one grown out the top. Apparently it was an Indian child who died from a cobra bite. Before that, the eyes in the top head had functioned as well as the ones in the bottom head.

Jenny Saville, the painter, walks up the long rows, explaining the sights. She's been coming here for years for inspiration, as long as she's been a painter. It's part of her work. I don't really believe her obsession, and find it depressing. But I don't feel strongly about it, she can do what she likes, I think.

'Why do you paint like Lucian Freud?' I ask. She says she doesn't any more. It's de Kooning she likes now. She likes the slipperiness of his surfaces. It's a look she's trying to get in her own work.

Next month, her wall-length painting of naked women lying squashed together, making an impression of several pale women fused into one fleshy thing, will go up at the Saatchi gallery as part of the Ant Noises show, Saatchi's anagrammatic follow-up to Sensation. She shows me the nineteenth century foetuses fused in a row that inspired the arrangement.

This is the first time I've met her. Because her painted women are enormous I imagined she would be too but in fact she's the opposite. Recently she had a sell-out show at Larry Gagosian in New York, a gallery even more powerful and sexy than White Cube. Gagosian sold her painting of Della Grace for over a hundred thousand pounds to the collector S. I. Newhouse, the publisher, who now has it in his house between a Warhol Marilyn and Jeff Koons's Eighties stainless steel cast of an inflatable bunny rabbit.

The painting is huge, it shows in graphic painterly detail the sex-change stuff Della Grace has had done over the years, including a recent operation to have her clitoris built out so it projects like small penis.

'What's she like?' I ask, grateful to be outside in the fresh air on the college steps. 'He,' she corrects me. But after a bit of a lecture about gender terrorism she gets going on the subject of Della Grace's character, which she admires, and soon lapses into unselfconscious 'her's and 'she's. It was a confrontation at first, she admits, the sight of Del's hairy buttocks and chest. But she's fascinated by cosmetic surgery. When the breasts come off at Del's next op, she's going to paint another portrait. I'm not sure I can bear any more of it.

She says she thinks outrageous cosmetic surgery is the future. She's attended quite a few ops as an observer. She asks if I'd ever consider surgery. I say no, false teeth is enough - would she? No, she says, she's heard the kinds of comments the surgeons make in cosmetic surgery ops. What, do they go 'phwoar'? 'Yeah!' she says.

3.17pm I race out of Holborn in my Golf, calling ahead on my mobile to the Delfina Art Trust to let the director know we'll be too late for lunch. I sense Tony (who comes from Baja in California, and is an experienced driver as well as a very good portrait photographer) beside me, cowering and wincing and attempting to combine the two expressions with mimed apologies to pedestrians as I ride over sections of pavement.

3.45pm The Delfina, in Bermondsey Street, near Tower Bridge, is a magnificent example of the new era's art values. It's a top restaurant that takes all major credit cards, with a gallery attached and a lot of artist's studios. The artists are from Britain and the rest of the world. They have to apply to come here. They can stay for two years for no rent, or for a little rent if they are rich.

The set-up is exclusive in that only artists who know where art is at or who are fancied by the Delfina applications board to know where it's at, will ever get on to the programme. But after that, it's admirably free. The artists all go to each other's studios; they meet at lunch where critics and curators drop by and there's an atmosphere of friendly open chat about how to get shows; or, I should say, serious discourse about the issues.

The Delfina restaurant, one of the best in London, has works on display by some of the art stars who have passed through. There is a drawing of Leonardo DiCaprio by Karen Kilimnik and a wall-size photo by Wim Delvoye of a mountain beside a city. Carved into the side of the mountain in mighty capitals is the legend: 'MUM THE KEYS ARE YOU KNOW WHERE.'

Glancing at this marvel of expensive digitally altered contemporary art noodling, I head for the receptionist in front of the gallery space. She calls up the director David Gilmour on the phone and he quickly appears to greet me. He takes me off to meet Urs Fischer, an enormous German with a densely tattooed left arm, who is hard at work making exact facsimiles of his studio walls which will be shipped off soon to an important exhibition in Ghent. 'Fantastic, Urs!' I say.

Then Urs joins David and me and another German artist for a visit to Keith Tyson's studio over the road at The Tannery, a former warehouse, now a studio complex, and Tony photographs another artist, Gary Webb, assisting Keith on the making of a humorous sculpture. Keith, a big, friendly 30-something, is one of the Delfina board, along with installation artist Anya Gallacio. I know his name but I have never seen his work before. I immediately recognise it as, well, bullshit. But he is energetic and his bullshit has energy too.

'Ha ha it's great!' I say, looking around at his blackboard scribbles, or texts, soon to be shipped off to the same exhibition in Ghent that Urs is going to be at, which it turns out is organised by top international curator Jan Hoet. While Keith explains that some of the texts on the blackboard installation are a self-invented language and the whole ensemble relates to the notion of mapping, I find myself thinking I'd like to have a studio at Delfina. I like the atmosphere of easy give-and-take, of creative people saying what they feel. I make a mental note to apply very soon to Keith for admission.

4.10pm Although Tony was feeling much better after photographing Keith and the picturesque, atmospheric bustle of the Delfina scenario, I can tell his whole mood has dropped right down again now we've got to Dot, a little gallery in Teesdale Yard near Shoreditch. For one thing he can't tell what makes it a gallery and I can't really explain it. Maybe it isn't one. It's run by the artist Elizabeth Price. Her project here is to archive material that artists have been invited to send in over the course of a year.

'What kind of material?' I ask. Anything they like, it turns out. To the naked eye it seems to be abject or idiotic material. Jigsaw puzzles from junk shops brought round by Matthew Thomson, whose practice as an artist is to assemble the puzzles. A box of notes by Margarita Gluzberg; the notes are just scraps but the box has been specially made by a professional box maker. It says 'Important Thoughts of Margarita Gluzberg' on the lid. And junk mail from the Czech artist Pavel Buchler, each unopened envelope stamped with his name.

Dot is in a former workshop. The surrounding streets seem genuinely poor, the council blocks genuinely run-down. There are no restaurants anywhere. Elizabeth takes us out into the yard where she fly-posts a poster by Bank, the artists' collective. One of them, Millie Thomson, is out here with us, drinking tea. More archivists mill. Everyone is talkative. It's a post-Sensation contemporary art situation - words, thoughts, tea and talk, instead of expensive consumer objects.

The posters are agitprop parodies in resonant but non-existent European languages. One shows a cartoon of a little man shrugging gormlessly. The words read: 'Redical nonnnsplus SPEKKEN'. Another one says: 'Non-dialektic nilder'.

4.45pm I phone ahead to Gilbert & George to apologize for missing tea time. 'Good morning,' a recorded voice says. 'You have telephoned the answer machine of George and Gilbert.' Then it explains that they're out and they'll get back to whoever's calling when it's convenient. 'Leave a brief message. Goodbye. And good riddance.' Then George picks up and cheerfully asks if everything's OK. 'Don't worry at all,' he says when I start to talk. 'We've got nothing better to do than to wait for you!'

5.00pm I arrive at the famous Fournier Street location, off Brick Lane, and they're at the door in their light brown suits, each with a gleaming new tie with a minty-coloured abstract pattern. They get differently patterned ones sent over free throughout the year by an admirer in Europe. 'A maniac!' they say. 'We like him very much.'

Tony, quite nervous again, follows me following them down the hall and into the wood-panelled front room. This is the first time I've noticed a painting of Jesus on their wall. 'It was always there,' they say. In fact, on this visit I notice the presence of the Lord everywhere. His portrait in their front room, in an unusual pink robe, was bought at an auction and is thought to be by Palmer. They've got a kind of stone Christian drinking fountain in the little garden between their house and studio, with a touching carved inscription on it, welcoming those who are thirsty to come and drink.

In the studio, there's not much sign of labour because they've just finished a big project, recently shipped off to Bonn - a giant photo-work commemorating the end of the Millennium. A version for their files, in watercolour, still taped to the wall, has notes in the margins recording shutter speeds. Every bit of street graffiti they've incorporated into the image is pencilled-in. Gilbert laughs at the obscenities on park benches - 'They want to spoil everything that's provided for them!' They're very polite. They make tea and bring out champagne and chat to Tony about life in London compared to Baja.

We try photographing them against a projection of a photo of their own spit but it's too dark. Then we use their own powerful studio lights to light a shot of them draped on their enlarger, which looks like something industrial or even military, maybe First World War, with its khaki colouring. I look at their photos of pieces of insect wing shot with a microscope lens. ('Mosquitoes have killed more people than all the totalitarian dictators put together - more than Stalin! And do you know, they're all women!')

'Why did you leave d'Offay,' I ask, not expecting a totally forthright answer, knowing how guarded the art world is about professional things. 'Because he's a cunt,' they laugh. 'He only likes the world's most expensive artists,' Gilbert says. 'And that's not us!' But they won't say where they're going, if it's sexy White Cube or sexy Gagosian (who's about to open a space in London.)

George sees us out. The evening shadows are drawing in. The little yard with its Pugin bench and Arts and Crafts objects is charming and calm. They're great aesthetes. They know all about Pugin and Eastlake and William Burgess and William de Morgan. There are atmospheric creepers and trellises, and views either side of more of the same in intricate silhouette patterns. George points at the sky - 'Rather beautiful peach coloured clouds,' he says, and so they are.

In the hall he hands out gifts. 'Have you got a word processor, Tony?' he asks. 'Yes.' 'Here's a Gilbert & George mouse mat.' Because I know they walk everywhere I ask if they'd ever get a train out to the countryside and go for a walk. 'Are you mad!' They love the beauty of nature but they don't like the bigotry out there. They prefer to take their chances in the urban melting pot. They only go to the country once a year to stay in the Norfolk (or somewhere) holiday home of top German curator Rudi Fuchs, to show loyalty. 'Good morning!' they once said to a young couple with a pram outside a lovely church near his house. 'Fuck off you weird looking prats!' came the reply.

7.30pm Now it's the evening, the time everyone in the art world goes to private views to unwind. I walk through the darkness of Northburgh Street, off Goswell Road, in Clerkenwell, with my partner, Emma Biggs, an intellectual and a staggering beauty who runs a world wide mosaic company in Holloway Road. With us are two of her children, Peter and Claudine. We approach an anonymous-looking brick rectangle; perhaps not so much anonymous as kind of community hall or scout hut. It's the Cabinet Gallery, recently relocated here from Brixton. Inside I have no difficulty recognising the art works. They are the things dotted around the place or hanging from the ceiling.

I introduce my little family to Tony who has already been here for some time arranging his lights. After we've looked about, admiring a mirror thing, a cork tile thing and a straggly unwound cassette tape thing, he sets us up near a yellow thing and we wait for people to come and talk to us.

The first one is one of the two Cabinet directors, Andrew Wheatley. He admires his own floor colour, a warm pale khaki grey. 'No artist is going to repaint this floor!' he says. We get on to Cabinet's first ever exhibition which was called To Hell. It was their abjection phase. We're quite a long way into the discussion before I realise he's not talking about Mike Kelley, one of the international kings of abjection in art in the Nineties, but Mary Kelly, a feminist artist of the Seventies. I'm just trying to get used to the idea of Mary Kelly's make-over by Cabinet, from boring to interesting, when it turns out he means Mary Kelly, the nineteenth century murderee, one of Jack the Ripper's victims.

Peter is complaining that the art is crap. 'Oh no,' I say, 'It's good. It's minimalist. Look, this one's all diamonds.' It's a 3-D diamond shape made of painted card on a kind of bird table. 'It's a functionalist aesthetic,' Emma corrects me, 'Not a minimalist one.' 'Yeah, functionalist,' I say. 'And this one's like cubism! Those checkered diamond shapes are like the patterns in cubism!' Peter insists it's still dull. 'I didn't say it wasn't dull, just not crap.' Then an artist comes up and says it is crap.

I make my way to another part of the gallery to say hello to Matthew Higgs, one of the curators of The British Art Show, which starts touring the country in April. He's sitting at a white table with computers and beer bottles and catalogues on it, reading the Masculin/Feminin catalogue he just brought back from the Pompidou Centre today. It's an exhibition about sexuality and theory. Paul Noble, one of the most successful artists at Maureen Paley's Interim Art, widely tipped to be nominated for the Turner Prize this year, is looking over his shoulder. 'Awesome!' he's saying, 'She's holding his knob!' I try to interest Claudine in the negative diamond shapes in a metal security grill over one of the windows.

As the time-honoured strategy at private views is to stand still and wait for someone to come up to you, so no one will think you haven't got any friends, nobody is moving much. Emma gets into a conversation with the artists' collective, Bank. They're known as a collective but in fact there's only two left now. 'The first one that went was only marginal anyway,' Simon Bedwell, one of the remaining pair, says. 'What about the other one?' 'Well you'll have to ask Millie about him.' But when Millie (who I saw earlier today at Dot) joins in, we're already onto the subject of some books they are reviewing for a special edition of Modern Painters which I'm editing.

'How are the reviews coming on?' I ask. They say they've been reviewing them aesthetically. One by Julian Stallabras, the Courtauld Institute lecturer, has a curious transparent pink colour on the cover, they've noticed. And one by the art historian T.J. Clark - a cri de coeur about the age of disillusionment after the demise of modernism - has a pronounced coffee table aesthetic. They say when it comes to painting both writers seem to be desperately reaching for their cravats and pipes. Then Millie says another book they're reviewing, by Picasso's biographer, John Richardson, about the art collector Douglas Cooper, makes them out to be a right pair of poshies poshing around Europe. And it makes Picasso out to be a miserable git. We enjoy ourselves in this way a bit more and then get leave from Tony to be off.

At Granita restaurant in Islington, later on, Emma's oldest son, Luke, joins us. A precocious gourmet, Luke admires the sauce on his quail: 'I say, isn't that juniper berries!' He is scratching the scab shape on the back of his hand, an upside-down cross, to keep up with his Satanist classmates at his expensive public school opposite the new Tate Gallery at Bankside. Emma says she enjoyed talking to Bank, but was aware of the strain of agreeing all the time and also of the loudness of her own voice and posh accent. As I'm laughing and trying not to notice Luke's festering symbol the mobile goes and it's Tony to say he thinks he may have knocked the mirror thing over.

 Matthew Collings is the author and presenter of Channel Four's This is Modern Art.
fields.bodyText: 10.20am I go down a little street off the Cambridge Heath Road in Hackney and get buzzed in a square grey door. Big black letters spell out 21 Herald Street. Tiny letters over the buzzer spell out Interim Art. Outside it's all charming and working-class picturesque. Next door is the Built On The Rock evangelist church, with its slogan: 'God is too big to fail and too strong to let you down.' Inside the Interim Art gallery, all is gleaming. Maureen Paley is the perfect dealer or gallerist of now. Perfect for the job. It's a weird job. You have to behave in an unreal way. Already, at 10 in the morning, she's hard at work being unreal. I've known her for 20 years, ever since she first came to London from New York. The way I cope with the act is to compliment her on it. 'Wow, this space is good!' 'Yes I think of it as my Dia Foundation! Don't you love it?' I do! At least for now! At other times I might feel there has to be some kind of human resistance to the rising tide of these weirdo perfect gallerist types, the Jay Joplings and so on. In fact, I start to think about his second space about to open in Hoxton Square, with a little '2' next to the 'White Cube'. Can't he see the '2' is redundant and it makes the whole gag redundant? But now isn't the time for hostility. I can see Maureen is riding high, with her thick black hair pulled back tight, her red lipstick, white face, gold flower-shaped ear rings, all-black outfit, new black shoes and black fluffy trim down her black cardigan. She tours me round the place and I marvel at the sights. She designed the gallery herself, with its lovely chrome toilet area, magnificent office, good storage and luxurious showing space. She says she still lives in her house in Beck Road, half a mile away, where the old Interim Art used to be. She started it in the early Eighties. She originally got the house from the subsidised artists' space organisation Acme. We smile at the memory of the old ethos of Acme. Cold, lonely, subsidised artists' spaces were the rule. She says it was a more socialist era, adding quickly that she loves that. 'Oh yes, me too!' I say. 'Now I suppose it's more a style era?' I venture. 'Yes!' she says. She doesn't just think toward a single point nowadays. There was a time when single-point thinking was right. But now it's all-round thinking, or all-over or something. I nod and frown and absolutely agree, inwardly wondering what we're talking about while outwardly keeping the stylish leaning and swaying and gesturing going, for the benefit of Tony, The Observer's photographer, who is clicking away, revving us up to great feats of intellectual posing. Two young assistants - their combined ages would add up to the age that Maureen and I both are - rustle papers in the background. The phone rings. Maureen takes the call and immediately goes into a slightly different accent. 'I will speak with Wolfgang,' she says in an unmistakable German way yet without using any actual German. 'I know of your collection. We will send a presentation.' In a few hours she's going to be on her way to New York for the city's annual international art fair. It's called The Armory Show, an ironic reference to the real venue of the exhibition in 1917, where Marcel Duchamp first exhibited a real urinal. Art fairs - like car fairs or yacht fairs, basically trade fairs - are for contacts, not just for selling, I learn. There's ambassadorial work to be done, fronting the gallery, but the main thing is meeting up with like-minded colleagues from abroad. 'It's like insider information - people telling you about things before the news has broken.' I imagine the drift of the information exchange: how is the backlash against young British artists going? Is it real or only an intellectual pose? A pose of course! Although at the same time everybody knows who the good YBAs are: the ones Maureen and the unrealist colleagues have signed up! Of course the actual conversation would be much more difficult to understand, more serious, more multilingual. 11.05am The light falls in Rachel Whiteread's studio off the Kingsland Road, between Dalston and Shoreditch, in beautiful dusty diagonal rays. Assistants work on big plaster things and carry equipment around. On a surface in the corner of one space are piles of remaindered hardback books. Unusually for an artist's studio, they look like books somebody might read, the novel Gorky Park for example. In fact they're for casting. When they've been used for bookshelf sculptures they're so ridden with concrete or plaster or gel or other bits of matter they can't be re-cycled and they have to be thrown away. Today, Rachel is working on a secret public art commission. She hasn't officially submitted it yet so she can't talk about it. She agrees to do a bit of filing on some plaster casts of the backs of human heads so Tony can photograph her at work. She seems unused to the activity and holds the file half-heartedly. Maybe it's already filed enough. But also, I suppose, filing and sanding and so on is probably more the kind of work her assistants are paid to do. A lot of her work is planning more than sanding - behind the scenes work; working out how to get a very clear, apparently simple sculptural idea not to crack or sag or fall down or turn an unpleasant colour. She has to commission special firms to come up with new types of resin, new mixes for concrete - technical things that have never been done before. I notice the heads are a bit like something I've seen in a Dali painting. This gives her pain. She tries to avoid thinking about him, she says. 'Ha ha! I know what you mean!' I say. I'm full of goodwill, having decided on the way here that I'm on her side. I used to be against her art because of its aesthetic of cool designer minimalist elegance. Now I feel that kind of thing is a relief rather than an annoyance. I used to feel uncomfortable with the pretentious death rhetoric that automatically goes with any art critical mention of her art. But after all, it's not her fault what art writers say. She's only done one piece that was directly about death, she says, a work about her father. She's already designed her Trafalgar Square plinth on a plinth - a transparent resin version of the existing stone plinth, which will stand upside down on the real thing. I look at computer-generated slides of it with her now. I find it looks good. I feel much better liking it than not liking it. She says she's finding the new secret project quite hard. She had to give a slide presentation the other day to the commissioners, offering examples of good public art and bad public art. 'Oh, what were they?' But in fact it's a holocaust memorial in Austria. The memorial has a lot of stone figures of wailing victims and another victim kneeling on the ground scrubbing the streets. Apparently the kneeling figure was so often and so completely defaced by graffiti that the city council had it covered in barbed wire, which made for a rather unfortunate image. Her own holocaust memorial in Vienna is presently surrounded by wooden planks and will be un-planked in October. She says she found the whole Vienna experience harrowing and frightening. She explains that it's all quite complicated because some of the fiercest opposition has come from the Jewish community, who'd much rather have more wailing figures than the huge inside-out library that Whiteread has designed. This monumental work is ingenious, with smaller sections of library housed within the hollow structure, ready to be installed on the outside if any of the outside sections are too badly defaced by hostile graffiti-ists. She's had endless rows with the city. One of them was over air bubbles. An uneven surface is part of the aesthetic but the city wanted a surface that would be less expensive to clean. 'What do you think about Gilbert & George leaving your gallery?' I ask. Her gallery is Anthony d'Offay. I feel sure she won't want to be thought of as a gossip but in fact she laughs and says they probably wanted to go somewhere sexier like White Cube. 1.10pm Horrible foetuses in jars are lined up in rows on shelves at the Royal College of Surgeons in Lincoln's Inn Fields. Apparently it was an Indian child who died from a cobra bite. Before that, the eyes in the top head had functioned as well as the ones in the bottom head. Jenny Saville, the painter, walks up the long rows, explaining the sights. She's been coming here for years for inspiration, as long as she's been a painter. It's part of her work. I don't really believe her obsession, and find it depressing. But I don't feel strongly about it, she can do what she likes, I think. 'Why do you paint like Lucian Freud?' I ask. She says she doesn't any more. It's de Kooning she likes now. She likes the slipperiness of his surfaces. It's a look she's trying to get in her own work. Next month, her wall-length painting of naked women lying squashed together, making an impression of several pale women fused into one fleshy thing, will go up at the Saatchi gallery as part of the Ant Noises show, Saatchi's anagrammatic follow-up to Sensation. She shows me the nineteenth century foetuses fused in a row that inspired the arrangement. This is the first time I've met her. Because her painted women are enormous I imagined she would be too but in fact she's the opposite. Recently she had a sell-out show at Larry Gagosian in New York, a gallery even more powerful and sexy than White Cube. The painting is huge, it shows in graphic painterly detail the sex-change stuff Della Grace has had done over the years, including a recent operation to have her clitoris built out so it projects like small penis. 'What's she like?' I ask, grateful to be outside in the fresh air on the college steps. 'He,' she corrects me. But after a bit of a lecture about gender terrorism she gets going on the subject of Della Grace's character, which she admires, and soon lapses into unselfconscious 'her's and 'she's. It was a confrontation at first, she admits, the sight of Del's hairy buttocks and chest. But she's fascinated by cosmetic surgery. When the breasts come off at Del's next op, she's going to paint another portrait. I'm not sure I can bear any more of it. She says she thinks outrageous cosmetic surgery is the future. She's attended quite a few ops as an observer. She asks if I'd ever consider surgery. I say no, false teeth is enough - would she? No, she says, she's heard the kinds of comments the surgeons make in cosmetic surgery ops. What, do they go 'phwoar'? 'Yeah!' she says. 3.17pm I race out of Holborn in my Golf, calling ahead on my mobile to the Delfina Art Trust to let the director know we'll be too late for lunch. It's a top restaurant that takes all major credit cards, with a gallery attached and a lot of artist's studios. The artists are from Britain and the rest of the world. They have to apply to come here. They can stay for two years for no rent, or for a little rent if they are rich. A version for their files, in watercolour, still taped to the wall, has notes in the margins recording shutter speeds. Every bit of street graffiti they've incorporated into the image is pencilled-in. Gilbert laughs at the obscenities on park benches - 'They want to spoil everything that's provided for them!' They're very polite. They make tea and bring out champagne and chat to Tony about life in London compared to Baja. fields.headline: Let there be light
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Jones meets Martin Creed, a soft-spoken genius who looks set to be the next big thing in British art.
fields.trailText: Jonathan Jones meets Martin Creed, a soft-spoken genius who looks set to be the next big thing in British art.
fields.body:
Martin Creed, Martin Creed. Will people just shut up about Martin Creed. Martin Creed is the most talked-about young artist in London, and that's saying something. Martin Creed has one of his works on the cover of the Tate Gallery publication Moving Targets 2. Martin Creed, everyone says, is a shoo-in for this year's Turner Prize shortlist. Martin Creed has been commissioned to make a large neon sign celebrating the opening of Tate Britain.

It wasn't always so. He once sent a crumpled-up ball of paper to the Director of the Tate Gallery, Nicholas Serota. This was not just any ball of paper but a work of art, Martin Creed's Work 88: a sheet of A4 paper crumpled into a ball. Serota's secretary sent it back. The paper had been neatly flattened to fit into an envelope.

That ball of paper would be worth a lot of money today. You can see another version of it in a glass case on a white plinth in Martin Creed's retrospective, MartinCreedWorks, currently at Southampton City Art Gallery. A retrospective, and he's only 32. And he's just had an artwork unveiled in Times Square, New York, commissioned by the city's prestigious Public Art Trust.

Who is this Martin Creed? He's an artist who since 1987 - when he was 19, and a student at the Slade - has been engaged in a systematic series of comically slight, yet straightfaced artworks with titles like Work 79: some Blu-Tack kneaded, rolled into a ball, and depressed against a wall. At least that appears on a wall at about the height of a painting, so you can see a resemblance to a work of art. With other items in the Creed corpus, like Work 100: on a tiled floor, in an awkward place, a cubic stack of tiles built on top of one of the existing ones, you don't know there's any art in the room until you trip over it.

Creed is also a musician. He's the guitarist, singer and songwriter in Owada, an art rock band, whose gigs and recordings are part of his work as an artist. Creed's songs are numbered items in the same series as his visual art, and share the same spartan aesthetic; songs such as 1234, whose lyrics go, 'One, two, three, four, One, two, three, four.'

When I meet Creed he tries to explain his art, talking in the same soft Glaswegian accent he sings in. He reminds me of Ivor Cutler, a drily funny eccentric character, a natural star. 'Things are a weight on my mind,' says Creed, 'you know, physical things. One of the reasons that I like music is that music when it happens, it happens in the air; it's not a physical thing. Things are... I do find them a weight.'

Britain leapt to the forefront of contemporary art in the Nineties with excess and drama. We've had sharks and unmade beds, we've had violence, horror, confession, mess. Perhaps it was inevitable that in its search for the next big thing the art world would veer the other way, and that Minimalism would become the hottest ticket in town. Cue Martin Creed.

Except that Creed is not really a Minimalist and his work is much more original than the way he sometimes talks about it. The Sixties Minimalists rejected the idea of the transcendent work of art, the painting or sculpture you looked through to discover a meaning. They made godless art objects that were just objects, that aimed to make you self-aware, to throw you back on yourself. Dan Flavin put fluorescent strip lights on the wall; Carl André arranged bricks on the floor. These are still the most awkward, frustrating works of modern art - and the moment you see one of Martin Creed's works you realise how much and how little he owes them.

The first thing you encounter in Creed's exhibition at Southampton City Art Gallery - touring to Leeds, Liverpool and London - is the work that on paper sounds the most ludicrously Minimalist of all: Work 127: a door opening and closing and a light going on and off . At Southampton it has been set up just on your left as you enter the exhibition, using the door and light of a curator's office, whose filing cabinets, desk and pinboard decorated with posters and postcards you peer at as the door mysteriously opens on to the darkened room. Suddenly, as the door swings back towards you, the light comes on: you stare into the eyes of Christ in a German Renaissance painting and try to take in the post-it notes... then the light snaps off, and the door is shut. It starts to swing open again, and you stretch for another glimpse into the room. Again, just as you're getting the feel of the place, the door swings shut.

This is a wonderful, introspective installation. The pleasures of Creed's art have nothing to do with their formal nature and everything to do with the stories and social encounters they generate. He's a poet of the everyday. Looking into the curator's office, you feel tantalised by and excluded from someone's private world. Creed's art is not really about numbers, or things. It's about inner worlds and secret feelings, and it veers between melancholia and exuberance.

I've never encountered an artist who so transcends the rules he sets himself, who seems so parsimonious on paper and so generous in the gallery. Creed's touring exhibition of public museums flirts brilliantly with the museum's grandeur; there's even an installation called 'all the sculpture in a collection', which consists of all the sculpture in the collection of Southampton City Art Gallery, from Rodin to Rachel Whiteread, placed higgledy-piggledy in one room. Max Wall, a Victorian admiral, a Degas bronze... it's somehow a sad spectacle. Nearby there is a neon sign that says THINGS. Every so often it lights up in hellish red.

'I like things a lot, I like things a lot,' sings Creed on his latest CD. At the end of this manically enthusiatic paean to objects he suddenly cries, 'No, No'. Things do have a horror, they pile up, gather dust. When Martin Creed is miserable he sees the world crushed by things, but when his art is happy it is about, as he says, 'feeling free, aye, you know'.

Creed was brought up in the suburbs of Glasgow, and he thinks his art is quite Scottish - 'a bit anal'. And there's something else as well: 'My parents are Quakers. Do you know about Quakers? The Society of Friends - and they worshipped in silence. I used to go to Quaker Sunday school when I was a child. A Quaker meeting consists of one hour of silence. There's no hierarchy. If anyone wants to say anything they stand up and say it. In court you used to have to swear on the Bible to tell the truth and Quakers had exemption from that because they believed you should always tell the truth.'

One of the exhibits in Creed's show con sists of 30 metronomes in a row, all running at slightly different speeds. Clackety clack, clackety clack. As you look along the line of furiously beating instruments you think of time itself running to different beats. The orderly ticking of the metronome is something Creed grew up with. He had a musical childhood, learning the violin when he was four, switching to the piano in an act of rebellion when he was 12. This musical training is crucial to his art. There are musical scores and songs in his series of numbered artworks, ranging from purely visual jokes on musical notation to actual recordings.

In the Sixties, John Cale, a musically prodigious child from the South Wales valleys, went to the United States on a classical music scholarship and ended up playing in Andy Warhol's Velvet Underground. There's something about Creed that makes you think of Cale - 'I love the Velvet Underground,' he confirms. Cale played in the ensemble of classical musician La Monte Young, one of the founders of the Fluxus movement who invented the 'instructional' artwork, which consists of an instruction - musical or otherwise - which would then be interpreted in unpredictable ways. 'When I started doing installations like the light going on and off,' says Creed, 'the way that all those works exist is on paper. The work is the score for the piece. All the works are like pieces of music in the sense that they're scores, they're instructions, which makes me feel better about them in the sense that it makes the actual physical object less important, less precious. It doesn't matter if it gets damaged or thrown away.'

Creed's most extravagant work to date is Work 200: Half the Air In A Given Space, whose instructions are as follows: 'Choose a space. Calculate the volume of the space. Using air, blow up white 12in balloons until they occupy half the volume of the space. As usual the space should be full of air, but half of it should be inside balloons...'

This is a work of art that has no weight, no permanent shape, no certainties of any kind - except that when you are in the room, everything you do changes the room for everyone else. It's not difficult to see what he's getting at. It's not the artwork that matters, but the way it sets up relationships between people. You become a member of an airy commonwealth. In Southampton, the balloon room seemed warm and funny. Funnier still when parents edged in with children who went crazy, running as fast as they could through the undulating mass. The balloons no longer filled 'half the air in a given space'. They filled perhaps a third or a quarter of the room. Some were shrunk and shrivelled. No one cared. It was beautiful.

Creed's passion comes through most of all in his neon public artworks. On the classical portico which is all that's left of the London Orphan Asylum visible from Clapton High Street in London, white neon letters promise EVERYTHING IS GOING TO BE ALRIGHT. Creed put this up a year ago, a commission by the Peer Trust with Hackney Historic Buildings Trust. The sign was meant to come down last summer, but instead it has become a fixture, a public artwork local people like. He's just done another public text, this time for Chelsea and Westminster Hospital. This one reads: DON'T WORRY.

Are these messages reassuring or anxiety-provoking? 'When I made that,' says Creed about the orphanage sign, 'I was very depressed. I was going through a really bad time.' With both signs, Creed seems to be telling us that everything will be fine - eventually. When everything has changed.

For the opening of Tate Britain he's putting a neon sign across the building, Work 143, reading: THE WHOLE WORLD + THE WORK = THE WHOLE WORLD. Which you could read as meaning either that art should assimilate itself entirely to the world or that art adds nothing to the world. Is it an optimistic or pessimistic statement? 'It depends on your mood,' says Creed's friend Andrew Wheatley at the Cabinet Gallery, which has represented Martin Creed since it was run from the Brixton flat of Wheatley's partner Martin McGeown.

I don't think the statement is ambiguous at all. I don't think Martin Creed's art is pessimistic at all. When you experience it you understand immediately what he is saying, that things are only things, and the only way they matter is in their capacity to connect people to each other.

Martin Creed makes artworks that are as light as air. Despise it, burst the balloon, that's your decision. Laugh with it, dive in the balloons and you'll have more fun.

 MartinCreedWorks is on show in Southampton until 26 March, and then tours the country.

webTitle: It's the giving that is the point

fields.headline: It's the giving that is the point
fields.trailText: I warmly support Neal Ascherson's plea for our beggars to be left in peace (Comment, last week).
fields.body:
I warmly support Neal Ascherson's plea for our beggars to be left in peace (Comment, last week).

Why does this new breed of abrasive and ungrateful beggar send our would-be philanthropists into such spasms of work-ethic self-righteousness? In other societies, beggars are instruments of Providence: a reminder of their own undeserved good fortune, of the capriciousness of fate, of the insignificance of manners and appearances, and of the fact that, stripped of all baggage, we share a common humanity. In these societies it is the donor who does the thanking.
John McLaughlin
Birkenhead, Merseyside

fields.headline: Brewer's scoop
fields.trailText: It is entertaining that a mystical formula, originating in or around 1759, is the 'secret' of Guinness brewing (News, last week). Yet by that date, porter brewing was quite healthy.
fields.body:
It is entertaining that a mystical formula, originating in or around 1759, is the 'secret' of Guinness brewing (News, last week). Yet by that date, porter brewing was quite healthy.

In the beginning, only brown malt was used so porter was a fairly dark brown brew. Professor Peter Mathias in his book on the British brewing industry (1700-1830) says that the use of roasted malt was questionable because of the lack of a reliable roasting process. This was solved by Daniel Wheeler's 1817 patent and soon two related firms were roasting malt in Dublin near Guinness's brewery.

Fortunately books still exist showing that between 1820 and 1850 the amount of roasted malt was steadily increased (four or five fold) till it reached modern proportions in about 1850. So much for the 'secret formula' of 1759!
H.S. Corran
Curator Guinness Museum 1965-1972
Hoylake, Merseyside

fields.trailText: Of the 88 films that the Arts Council supported since September 1995, 56 have been completed. The rest are in production (Focus, last week). Of the 56 films completed, 90 per cent have been, or are about to be, distributed in the UK. Lottery-funded films are  more likely to be released in the UK   than other British films.
fields.body:
Of the 88 films that the Arts Council supported since September 1995, 56 have been completed. The rest are in production (Focus, last week). Of the 56 films completed, 90 per cent have been, or are about to be, distributed in the UK. Lottery-funded films are more likely to be released in the UK than other British films.

The Arts Council is a minority investor in the films it supports. More than £70 million has been levered in from UK commercial sources. Lottery funding has attracted £80 million in overseas investment in British films. During the last four years 34 directors, 19 producers and 29 screenwriters have made their first feature films with Lottery funding.
Peter Hewitt
Chief Executive, The Arts Council of England
London SW1

webTitle: Lessons we never learned after Bulger

fields.headline: Lessons we never learned after Bulger
fields.trailText: I read with rising anger of the horrendous abuse suffered by children in the unnamed Brighton family (News, last week). Anger at the appalling conditions that the children were allowed to remain in and anger that social services dare to blame a piece of legislation for their total incompetence in not protecting these children earlier.
fields.body:
I read with rising anger of the horrendous abuse suffered by children in the unnamed Brighton family (News, last week). Anger at the appalling conditions that the children were allowed to remain in and anger that social services dare to blame a piece of legislation for their total incompetence in not protecting these children earlier.

As a child advocate, I have worked on numerous cases of child abuse, both for victims of abuse and for parents falsely accused of harming their children and I have the documentary evidence that, even when there have been absolutely no concerns of abuse, emergency protection orders have been issued at the drop of a hat and children hauled from their homes indiscriminately.

This appears to be a case of sheer incompetence by the services in place to protect children. Perhaps one might ask the social services why they did not get an EPO? Seventy-two hours later everyone would have been in the civil courts who remove children on the grounds of probable harm as opposed to hard evidence and there was certainly enough evidence as to the extent of abuse and neglect these children were suffering.

I hope that one day these children grow into stable and balanced adults, (although statistics indicate that this is hard to achieve). I also hope that they use new legislation that has been passed and sue the local authority for their failure to protect them - maybe then, when it is hit in what counts most to it, its pockets, it will think twice before ever leaving children in this type of danger again.
Penny Mellor
Coven, Wolverhampton

 Jay Rayner's article brought to light what may be grave inadequacies in the response by a social service department to continuing emotional and physical neglect of the children.

It is quite false to say the Children Act of 1989 provided any justification for leaving children at unacceptable risk of harm. The Children Act in fact broadened the previous statutory criteria for social service intervention and the language used in the Act was more down-to-earth than the language of previous legislation.

Under the Act real harm to a child or future likelihood of harm became the starting-point justification for taking protective court proceedings - and for removing children from their families if necessary through court orders.

When the Children Act was being introduced, my impression was that many social workers took the view that the Act and associated guidance was intended to assist in raising the level of social-work practice, not to keep children with their families whether they were at unacceptable risk or not. The Children Act was child-centred legislation, not a parents' charter to abuse or a social services' charter to let abuse continue.
John Ellison
Member of Law Society Children Panel
London N1

 Seven years ago, two confused 10-year-old boys killed a toddler in a brutal attack. They were subjected to an unfair trial and the outrage and abuse of the press. Talk of their release and rehabilitation is still taboo.

Now you report the case of an adult couple with responsibility for the care of their seven children. This responsibility was not met. Three children died, and the others were subjected to an horrific catalogue of abuse and neglect. The parents were acquitted of murder due to a legal technicality, and after countless visits by police and social services, have only just been convicted of cruelty and neglect.

Strangely, this is the first I have heard of the dreadful story. There is no tabloid outcry baying for the blood of these cruel parents. We seem to live in a society which more readily accepts that mature and rational adults kill children, than that immature and irrational children kill other children.
Kate Hough
Manchester

fields.headline: Damning Lies
fields.trailText: As Studdert Kennedy wrote in his 1919 book  Lies : 'If the man of superior abilities is not a public servant he is a parasite, and more unworthy of his manhood than an ignorant and drunken pauper.'
fields.body:
Clearly our 'young rich' (and their elders) need reining in if we Westerners are to avoid degrading ourselves in a debt-ridden world where a child dies every two and a half seconds of hunger or preventable illness. As Studdert Kennedy wrote in his 1919 book Lies : 'If the man of superior abilities is not a public servant he is a parasite, and more unworthy of his manhood than an ignorant and drunken pauper. If he uses his ability to serve himself at the expense of his fellow men, to get on and get over them, his "success" is the measure of his failure. He is like those enormous bloated flies that buzz round the dead on a battlefield...'
Frank McManus
Christian Council for Monetary Justice
Todmorden, W Yorks

fields.body:
There is an omission from your survey of reasons for the avoidance of holiday packages that applies to those who travel as 'singles' (News, last week).

With a few notable exceptions, the heavy loading for those who travel alone, amounting to an additional 30-50 per cent of the cost to somebody sharing a room, is unjustifiable and therefore unacceptable. This should be a matter not only for the travel industry but, given that most single package-holiday users are women, for the Equal Opportunities Commission.
Diane Munday
Wheathampstead, Herts

fields.headline: Prove Hague wrong, Gordon
fields.trailText: It's the budget this week and, once again, we are debating tax. Only this year there is a different twist. Last week, William Hague decided to go for broke. Low taxes are not just the building block of a dynamic entrepreneurial economy, he declared, they foster responsibility and self-reliance. 'If that is not a moral argument,' said Hague, 'I do not know what is.'
fields.body:
It's the budget this week and, once again, we are debating tax. Only this year there is a different twist. Last week, William Hague decided to go for broke. Low taxes are not just the building block of a dynamic entrepreneurial economy, he declared, they foster responsibility and self-reliance. 'If that is not a moral argument,' said Hague, 'I do not know what is.'

Meanwhile, New Labour has acknowledged that taxation as a proportion of GDP had risen. Not that that was a bad thing, argued Alastair Campbell. It was the precondition for the higher quality public services which the public wanted. Suddenly and unexpectedly, ideological water has opened up between the two parties, with Hague hoping he can rekindle the spirit of Thatcherism and New Labour daring to take him on.

But now that we have left the world of marginal rates of tax, the Right has a harder case to make. Low-tax Russia is a disaster; low-tax Japan has stagnated economically for a decade. High-tax Denmark and Holland are the fastest growing economies in the EU. The simple idea that economic dynamism is caused by low taxation - always suspect - is no longer tenable. Even the success of the United States's 'new economy' has more complex economic roots than the sole explanation that its tax rates are lower than in Europe.

But the moral dimension for low taxation that Hague wants to argue is tendentious. The contrast is between characterising the state as an entity which compulsorily confiscates the earnings of an otherwise free individual for no good purpose, and the state as a kind of club, for which the membership fee is the taxation. It is a fee which entitles the citizen to a wide range of benefits - from law and order to free universal health care. Hague's practical difficulty is that British public opinion is decisively in the second camp. A poll of world opinion undertaken for the Economist reports that of 17 countries, Britain was the only one in which there was a majority asking for more public services, even if it meant higher taxation.

Hague's moral case is weaker. Schools and hospitals are not financed by confiscation; they are financed by the democratically validated decision to pay taxes as the best means of funding services that are free for everyone. Presented in these terms, taxation represents a moral statement in which the taxpayer is declaring his willingness to construct a better society.

Schools, hospitals and roads are not free. The Conservative delusion is that the same outcomes are available through voluntary action. They are not. Without universal provision and progressive taxation, grave inequalities emerge that are more serious threats to any notion of justice, upon which any good social order hangs.

Hague is on to a loser, as long as he is made to confront the inadequacies of his argument. For three years, New Labour has sought to dissimulate its views and throw a cloak over its actions. This argument is there to be won and Gordon Brown can make a start in next Tuesday's budget.

fields.headline: The Shayler case
fields.trailText: This paper finds itself before the courts. At issue is our reporting of the case of David Shayler, a former officer with MI5, whose allegations of an illegal plot by officers of MI6 to assasinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadaffi, have been carried by a number of papers. His claims have been sent to the Home Secretary, Jack Straw. They are available for anyone to see at a number of websites, including Shayler's www.shayler.com. So how have the security services and Special Branch responded? Not by investigating whether servants of the Crown colluded in an illegal plan to murder a head of state, albeit an unpleasant one. Instead, they have come after The Observer (and our sister paper, the Guardian), demanding that we provide them with notebooks, emails and letters so that they can build a case against Shayler and, potentially, those journalists who have had contact with him.
fields.body:
This paper finds itself before the courts. At issue is our reporting of the case of David Shayler, a former officer with MI5, whose allegations of an illegal plot by officers of MI6 to assasinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadaffi, have been carried by a number of papers. His claims have been sent to the Home Secretary, Jack Straw. They are available for anyone to see at a number of websites, including Shayler's www.shayler.com. So how have the security services and Special Branch responded? Not by investigating whether servants of the Crown colluded in an illegal plan to murder a head of state, albeit an unpleasant one. Instead, they have come after The Observer (and our sister paper, the Guardian), demanding that we provide them with notebooks, emails and letters so that they can build a case against Shayler and, potentially, those journalists who have had contact with him.

As a newspaper, we have no difficulty with secrets or with the principle that secrecy, where necessary, should be protected by the law. What we find unacceptable, however, is that those laws should be used to prevent the reporting of alleged wrongdoing to protect barely accountable state organs.

It is not enough for us to say that we believe that the judgment made against us on Friday at the Old Bailey is fundamentally flawed. We believe that important principles are at stake. The first is the principle that people should be able to contact the media, safe in the knowledge that we will not disclose their identities or hand over their communications to the police. Second is the principle that a free press should be able to report allegations of serious wrongdoing by Crown servants without the risk of being bullied in the courts.

We shall, of course, be seeking judicial review.

webTitle: Siege of 'spree killer' sours gun control deal

fields.headline: Siege of 'spree killer' sours gun control deal
fields.trailText: The United States yesterday faced yet another high-profile shooting outrage as more than 100 armed police laid siege to a 'spree killer' who blasted his way into an apartment block in Baltimore.
fields.body:
The United States yesterday faced yet another high-profile shooting outrage as more than 100 armed police laid siege to a 'spree killer' who blasted his way into an apartment block in Baltimore.

The gunman took over an apartment before dawn, holding four hostages. Joseph Palczynski had been hunted by the police and FBI after killing four in a deadly rampage in the Atlantic seaboard city last week. The standoff came at the end of the tenth day of the hunt for Palczynski. Police posted a $10,000 reward for his capture on Thursday.

The killings began on 7 March, four days after Palczynski's girlfriend, Tracy Whitehead, said he beat her when she moved out of the apartment they shared and moved in with a colleague.

Authorities say Palczynski abducted Whitehead at gunpoint after fatally shooting George and Gloria Shenk, the couple who had sheltered her. Outside the Shenk home, he then allegedly shot and killed David Meyers, 42, a neighbour who tried to help Whitehead. The next day, police said, Jennifer McDonel was fatally shot and a two-year-old boy was wounded when they drove by as Palczynski fired shots during an attempted carjacking.

The outrage comes hours after celebration of the most far-reaching safety deal ever agreed between the government and a big gun maker - Smith and Wesson - on Friday night.

And another shootout, in Atlanta, occurred as the announcement was being made. The Muslim militant Jamil Al-Amin, known as the 1960s Black Power militant Rap Brown, was being hunted after allegedly shooting dead a deputy sheriff who tried to arrest him.

Hours later, the Baltimore night was shattered by a burst of gunfire as Palczynski shot his way into the house. After an initial exchange of fire with police officers, the siege quietened into a tense cat-and-mouse game.

As dawn broke yesterday Palczynski was holding an army of Swat snipers at bay as negotiators tried to find a peaceful solution.

Police sealed off the area to all residents while the four hostages - who are believed to be a family - waited for rescue.

Police spokeswoman Vickie Warehine said a specialist team of officers was continuing to have regular radio contact with the fugitive. 'We are trying to bring this to a peaceful end,' she said.

webTitle: Teenage riot explodes out of Bangkok jail

fields.headline: Teenage riot explodes out of Bangkok jail
fields.trailText: Hundreds of teenage boys broke out of a juvenile detention centre on the outskirts of Bangkok yesterday in a protest against what they said were overly harsh disciplinary measures.
fields.body:
Hundreds of teenage boys broke out of a juvenile detention centre on the outskirts of Bangkok yesterday in a protest against what they said were overly harsh disciplinary measures.

Armed with metal rods, staves of wood and bottles, more than 200 detainees rampaged through the streets nearby. They played a rough game of cat-and-mouse with dozens of riot police before order was restored and most were returned to the Karuna Observation Centre in the city's Bang-na district.

The boys, all aged between 14 and 19, occupied buildings yesterday morning and threatened to burn them down to highlight what they said were unpleasant living conditions and harsh discipline implemented by a new director.

They accused him of using violent punishment against rule-breakers. Some of the boys told the ITV television network that they have been caned for not behaving well or listening to instructions.

The police, under orders not to hurt the escapees, used fire hoses and tear gas to try to contain them.

webTitle: Return of the killer virus that spread terror in New York

fields.headline: Return of the killer virus that spread terror in New York
fields.trailText: It was the news that researchers were dreading. A dead red-tailed hawk, found in Bronxville, a suburb of New York, was last week found to be carrying the fatal West Nile virus that terrorised the city last year. Now the entire East and Gulf coasts of the United States are braced for the imminent return of a mysterious killer which may strike with enhanced ferocity.
fields.body:
It was the news that researchers were dreading. A dead red-tailed hawk, found in Bronxville, a suburb of New York, was last week found to be carrying the fatal West Nile virus that terrorised the city last year. Now the entire East and Gulf coasts of the United States are braced for the imminent return of a mysterious killer which may strike with enhanced ferocity.

'It's time. The virus is out there,' said pathologist Ward Stone as he emerged from a sealed laboratory where he had examined the hawk. West Nile encephalitis's first dramatic appearance in the Western hemisphere - in a cluster of cases in Queens, New York - sent the city into a frenzy in August. Helicopters sprayed entire neighbourhoods with disinfectant after the disease killed horses, thousands of birds and several people. Symptoms began with flu-like shivers and were followed by fever, disorientation and brain swelling that led to death in seven out of the 62 cases of people affected by the virus.

Scientists at the Center for Disease Control (CDC) in Atlanta, Georgia, had hoped the illness - spread by mosquitoes from birds to humans - would die out over winter. Now their hopes have been dashed. Apart from the hawk, mosquitoes hibernating in underground rooms beneath the historic Fort Totten district of Queens have been found to be virus-positive. As America's East Coast begins to warm, mosquitoes carrying the West Nile killer are expected to spread further than last year. As Nicholas Kramer of the CDC said: 'The virus is still here and there is a good chance it will amplify this summer.'

Warning circulars have been posted to all New York doctors and emergency instructions for citizens are being drafted, while it has been decreed that all dead birds must be handed in to health authorities. This weekend a sad stream of dead birds was being directed to New York state pathology laboratories.

What really alarms American health officials is the danger of the disease establishing itself permanently in the country. But what will happen if migrating birds have already begun to spread West Nile across eastern America? The next months will be the 'test of how long-lasting or fleeting' West Nile is in the US, said Dr Roger Nasei, of the CDC.

Californian expert Ian Lipkin said last week 'there is definitely a cause for concern'. But his fears were countered by CDC expert Duane Gubler, who said it was still possible this year's outbreak could be contained. The species of mosquito most closely linked to the virus does not emerge until later in the spring when a mass spraying campaign begins.

The aim will be to eliminate larvae and breeding sites. Property owners will be told to unclog roof gutters, empty or chlorinate swimming pools, and throw away old tyres and buckets.

A more worrying prospect has been raised by virologists in Britain. West Nile disease is closely related to the illness St Louis encephalitis, which is fairly common in America. That raises the fear that people already infected with the latter may become especially vulnerable to West Nile disease.

'There is a process called antibody dependent enhancement,' said Dr Ernie Gould, deputy director of the Institute of Virology and Environmental Microbiology in Oxford. 'We have observed it in other diseases, and I believe it could happen with West Nile.'

In short, America faces the threat of a deadly new epidemic. The next few months will determine how serious that danger is.

webTitle: 'Brides of Death' join Franco's crack unit

fields.headline: 'Brides of Death' join Franco's crack unit
fields.trailText: Franco must be turning in his well-appointed yet masculine tomb at the news that the philosophy of equal opportunities has ushered out the macho past of his country's finest fighting unit. The Spanish Legion, whose soldiers are known as 'The Bridegrooms of Death', is admitting girls.
fields.body:
Franco must be turning in his well-appointed yet masculine tomb at the news that the philosophy of equal opportunities has ushered out the macho past of his country's finest fighting unit. The Spanish Legion, whose soldiers are known as 'The Bridegrooms of Death', is admitting girls.

The first of Death's 'brides' to pass out as legionnaires were on display last week in Melilla, one of two Spanish enclaves in Morocco still guarded by Spain's elite military unit. Nuria Albi ñana and María Pilar Galdón are the first to graduate as frontline infantry troops, having survived the same punishing training as male comrades.

Galdón is following in the family footsteps: her father and uncles were legionnaires, though last week she was forced to sit on the sidelines with a dislocated elbow. 'I was a bit sad about that, because I like going on parade,' she said.

Albinaña simply likes the image: 'The Legion is known for being strong.' It is also known for credo best summed up in the battlecry: 'Long live death! Long live Spain! Long live the King! Long live the Legion!'

One battalion horrified the dictator Primo de Rivera during the 1920s by appearing for inspection with enemy heads speared on their bayonets.

According to the Legion's system of beliefs, 'life is beautiful and so is death when defending it. Death is not the end if it comes during a fight for ideals. This death comes without pain and is not so horrible. What is truly horrible is to live betraying those ideals.'

Formed in 1920 and modelled on the French Foreign Legion, its most famous commander was Lieutenant-Colonel Francisco Franco, who made sure of its support for the Nationalist cause when the Civil War began in 1936 and who then used his lengthy dictatorship to strip women of many rights.

Until last year, Spanish law barred women in the armed forces from certain frontline positions and combat roles - these two are the first to benefit from new equality legislation. 'If a woman likes this, why shouldn't she join up? We are capable of it, the same as them, there are no differences,' Albiñana says.

Colonel Enrique de Vivero Fernández, commanding officer of Tercio 1 Gran Capitán of the Legion of Melilla, says his troops made only minor changes to accommodate the new comrades. Soldiers sleep four or six to a dormitory, with lockable doors and private bathrooms, so the women share one room.

'It was something new for the troops to find themselves with women sleeping next door, but they have taken it as part of the life of the Legion,' Vivero says. 'I don't think they distinguish between men and women in normal life, it's simply another comrade.'

As for fraternisation, the Legion's rules are the same for all: sexual relations are prohibited on base. But, as Vivero says, 'one's private life is private' - even when death is your intended.
