webTitle: The man who knows too much

fields.headline: The man who knows too much
fields.standfirst: The robber with secrets to unseat politicians has been run to ground in the Philippines. Now the French fear what he'll say,  Paul Webster  reports in Paris
fields.trailText: On the feast of the Epiphany three years ago, a convicted bank robber with enough secrets in his personal safe to bring down scores of world politicians summoned his children and grandchildren to a seventieth birthday party at his chateau in the Loire Valley.
fields.body:
On the feast of the Epiphany three years ago, a convicted bank robber with enough secrets in his personal safe to bring down scores of world politicians summoned his children and grandchildren to a seventieth birthday party at his chateau in the Loire Valley.

As gifts were handed out, no one guessed that Alfred Sirven, the mastermind behind an international conspiracy to buy and sell world leaders like goods in a shop, was about to slip away into obscurity.

Three years later, he has been found on a holiday island in the Philippines, living with his Filipino mistress and surrounded by files on hundreds of corrupt political and business deals. Nothing, except fear of his disclosures, now stands in the way of his return to France for questioning as the central figure in the Elf scandal: the multi-billion-pound swindle that has sullied several once respectable names - not least the late President François Mitterrand and former German Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

But if the average French voter was asked 'who is Alfred Sirven?', few could identify him as the runaway head of the international division of the state-owned oil company.

The most common photograph of Sirven, nicknamed the Man Who Knows Too Much, is at least 15 years old. Today, that face is reportedly grey-bearded and his skin yellow from a tropical disease that has kept him bedridden.

Nothing in his background as the son of a prosperous Toulouse printer could predict a Machiavellian career following his service as an adolescent in the French Resistance and in the Korean War with seven decorations for bravery as an infantry sergeant. While convalescing in Japan, he took up armed bank robbery which led to three years in jail. But his ambition soon saw him use his Korean connections and Gaullist sympathies to start a career with Mobil Oil in 1956.

Exploiting his membership of the Freemasons, he climbed the ladder as a personnel manager in some of France's best-known firms, honing skills he later employed at Elf by buying off union opposition. His career peaked in June 1989, when he moved into an office on the 41st floor of Elf's glass-fronted Paris skyscraper as unofficial banker to the Mitterrand regime. The reward for his undercover activity over the next four years, until the scandal broke, has been estimated at $60 million.

Loïk Le Floch-Prigent, the fallen Elf chairman, has been frank about the links between Mitterrand's policies and the underground work carried out by Sirven, who handed out a fortune in Africa to subsidise politicians' greed.

'Elf made Bongo in Gabon and helped Paul Biya become President of Cameroon,' the ex-chairman said. 'It was Elf that paved the way to influence in Nigeria and Chad and arbitrated in the Angolan civil war. Elf worked closely with secret services and was an intelligence unit in itself.'

Knowing that Mitterrand had given Le Floch-Prigent carte blanche to dig into the Elf cashbox for the president's friends, Sirven spent well. He told his glamorous assistant, Christine Deviers-Joncours, to seduce the Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas. As Sirven's ex-lover, Deviers-Joncours, through books and broadcasts, has been the main source of lurid sex-and-drugs details of Elf's tactics. She goes on trial in June alongside her ministerial ex-lover, who allegedly changed France's China policy for Elf.

Her tales are nothing compared to what Sirven could reveal. Since he fled, blunders by the French police and diplomatic service have been seen as reluctance to bring him back to France.

There was detectable relief in government circles across continents when Sirven fled France with his Filipino mistress, Vilma Medina, stopped in Switzerland to pick up millions of smuggled dollars, then disappeared. But did he? New evidence shows he lived openly in Manila for two years before recently moving to an island location being kept secret by French officials, where he has set up a shrimp-fishing firm.

By the time journalists had solved - in a few days - a mystery over his whereabouts that supposedly baffled French authorities for three years, the Elf inquiry had unearthed enough dirt to sabotage the careers of several Mitterrand protégés such as former Prime Minister and Brussels commissioner Edith Cresson, and the late President's son and African adviser, Jean-Christophe Mitterrand. Today, Lionel Jospin must be looking nervously round his colleagues, worrying whether others benefited from crooked deals.

Whatever the risks from Sirven's disclosures, the government may be forced to step up pressure for extradition after Philippines police said they wanted to expel him.

Vilma Medina is also under suspicion after a three-year spree in which she bought luxury cars and houses and set up businesses. There are tales of her lugging huge sums of cash to buy the million-dollar island property. Suspicion that Sirven also creamed off some of Elf's funds for himself is the least of the worries for a Socialist government struggling to shake off the Mitterrand legacy of corruption and greed.

'He wanted power even more than cash,' a former colleague confided. 'He knew how to exploit weaknesses and built up huge files like a secret policeman so he could maintain a hold on those he corrupted, some of whom must still be in office. You might call that blackmail.'

fields.headline: World In brief
fields.trailText: Amazon Indians reject power line
fields.body:
Amazon Indians reject power line

Indians in Venezuela's Amazon region have rejected a plea by President Hugo Chávez to permit the completion of a high-voltage power line to neighbouring Brazil. Work was halted on the 470-mile line last year after the Pemon Indians knocked down pylons in protest against the damage that was being done to their tribal territory.

Banks to give German party credit

Germany's largest banks are to give the scandal-plagued Christian Democrats more credit until they reform laws to prevent future corruption. The move follows the admission of ex-Chancellor Helmut Kohl that he received illegal money from unnamed donors.

Sex aid

Albanian police have confiscated five million contraband condoms from Greece. The truck driver claimed they were a gift from humanitarian groups to encourage safe sex among Balkan people. The condoms are being guarded by police while authorities decide what to do with them.

Rogue police ahead

Motorists passing through Poland no longer have to pull over for police at night - because of ambushes by criminals in disguise. Leaflets are to be distributed to drivers telling them that highway robbers typically pose as police in uniform with red lights on the roof of their cars.

Hamas 'bomb plot' foiled

Palestinian police have seized explosives and arrested five members of the militant Islamic group Hamas suspected of plotting bomb attacks in Israel. The men had 66 lbs of explosives in their possession, and were allegedly intending to bomb a bus station.

Algerian festival toll rises

Eight more people were killed in Algeria in the build up to the country's important Muslim holiday, bringing the toll of those murdered to 19 in the past three days.

webTitle: Veterans of Red Army arrested in airport swoop

fields.headline: Veterans of Red Army arrested in airport swoop
fields.trailText: Japanese police swooped on four ageing members of the Japanese Red Army as they arrived in Tokyo yesterday after being deported from the Middle East.
fields.body:
Japanese police swooped on four ageing members of the Japanese Red Army as they arrived in Tokyo yesterday after being deported from the Middle East.

The three men and one woman are suspected of taking part in international terrorist operations, including hijackings, embassy seizures and attempted murders, more than a quarter of a century ago.

Despite the suspects' advanced age - Masao Adachi is 59, Nariko Yamamoto is 58, Haruo Wako is 50 and Kazuo Tohira is 46 - and the fact that the once-feared Red Army has not been active for more than a decade, police took no chances in a large-scale operation to seize them as soon their plane touched down at Narita Airport.

The four had flown on a private jet from Amman in Jordan, where they had been handed over to Japanese diplomats in a long-awaited coup for the government in Tokyo.

Japan has been trying for decades to bring these senior Red Army members to justice. Three of the group are on an international wanted list for attempted murder. Wako is believed to have led a Red Army guerrilla unit after being trained in Beirut. He allegedly played a key role in the seizure of the French Embassy in the Netherlands in 1994.

Adachi is seen as the group spokesman. He issued a statement for the organisation when a Red Army-led assault team hijacked a Japan Airlines plane over the Netherlands in 1973.

Yamamoto reportedly acted as liaison officer between the Red Army and Palestinian guerrilla groups. She was expelled from France in August 1974.

Although their actions were an embarrassment for Japan, they have long been treated as anti-Israeli war heroes in Lebanon, where they have been sheltering for more than a decade.

Under pressure from Tokyo, Lebanese authorities stopped turning a blind eye to their existence three years ago and imprisoned the group for passport violations. They were released earlier this month and deported from Lebanon yesterday.

But Japan did not have everything its way. The government in Beirut refused to directly extradite the four and it granted asylum to a fifth member of the group.

Kozo Okamoto, one of the world's most notorious terrorists, was arrested after he took part in the 1972 assault on Israel's Ben Gurion airport that left 24 people dead. He went to Lebanon in a prisoner swap in 1985.

The Lebanon government said he would be allowed to stay because he is still suffering 'from physical and psychological injuries sustained while in Israeli prisons'.

webTitle: Justice after 15 years for the love children

fields.headline: Justice after 15 years for the love children
fields.standfirst: Japanese judge backs High Court paternity ruling and allows two daughters to inherit a millionaire banker's money
fields.trailText: Japanese judge backs High Court paternity ruling and allows two daughters to inherit a millionaire banker's money
fields.body:
Last year a little girl moved onlookers to tears when she played her violin on a remote mountainside where her father had died in a plane crash, three weeks before she was born.

The invitation to attend a memorial ceremony at the site of the 1985 smash was the first time Diana Yukawa, now 14, had been acknowledged publicly as the secret daughter of a millionaire Japanese banker.

But she still had no father's name on her birth certificate. Today all that has changed after a 15-year fight by her remarkable British mother.

Last Monday a High Court judge ruled that Diana and her sister Cassandra, 18, were the blood children of Akihisa Yukawa, known as Aki, and his young English mistress, Susanne Bayly.

On Friday, a Japanese judge backed the British paternity ruling and told the lawyers for Yukawa's estate they must recognise the sisters as rightful heirs. Their identities established, tomorrow their financial future should also be secured when Japan Air Line is expected to announce that compensation will be awarded, more than a decade after the deadliest single aircraft disaster ever.The girls are expected to be awarded hundreds of thousands of pounds.

Like all other officials, JAL had refused to acknowledge the girls. While all the children of the other 523 passengers of the 747 were handsomely provided for by the airline, Diana and Cassie were ignored.

Susanne Bayly,who shared a Tokyo flat with Yukawa, was unmarried and as such not regarded as important by the airline or police. Yukawa's death, she was told, was a matter to be discussed 'with families only'.

'All three of us have changed over this last week,' Bayly told The Observer yesterday. 'After so long it's incredible to have everything happen so quickly. It's a mixture of elation that justice has been done and sadness that Aki is not here. It is nice to have the recognition that it was not just a sordid affair. We all miss him very much.'

For Diana, it means her birth certificate can be amended to include her father's name and that she will be able to continue to devote herself to the violin.

'I'm so happy,' said Diana. 'When the judge said my mum and dad were a "close and loving couple" I just couldn't stop smiling. It was just amazing.' The fight is over but the remarkable story Bayly and her lover kept hidden for their seven years together can now be told.

Bayly was a 21-year-old ballet dancer when she met Yukawa, a 49-year-old married businessman, having dinner with a mutual friend in London. 'It was real 'eyes across a crowded room' kind of thing,' said Bayly.

'There was a loneliness in him. His wife had been in a terrible car crash and was brain-damaged. She was in hospital and his two sons grown up. For a few months we were in love only mentally. There were many intense discussions.

'I felt I had met my soulmate and I couldn't believe that this perfect man actually respected me. He helped me find my identity, to stop being so serious. Because of the age difference, probability always was that he would die before me. In those precious seven years he tried to prepare me to cope when he wasn't there.'

The couple moved to Tokyo, aware that Japanese society would not accept their relationship. He, a married man of high birth and wealth, worked for an important bank which would not accept a whiff of scandal - she a young foreigner and, by then, the unmarried mother of Cassie.

Yukawa continued to visit his wife and pay for her care. His sons, both older than Bayly, were kept in the dark about his new family. 'We had to be secret,' said Bayly. 'But I loved him and I did not want to do anything that would upset things. He often said I was more Japanese than the Japanese.'

Unusually, the mother of Yukawa, a romantic and poet, accepted Susanne with open arms.

'She was fantastic and without her I could not have coped. She adored the girls and after Aki's death it was she who sent us the money to survive. When his sons discovered we existed they gave us a one-off payment to go away and then cut us off.'

Bayly was eight months pregnant when Yukawa phoned to tell her he had to fly to Osaka for an overnight business trip. 'I felt very jittery about it,' said Bayly. 'I asked him not to. He tried to catch a train but it was full. He got one of the last two seats on the plane. The last thing we said to each other was "I love you".'

A power cut in her apartment increased her unease. When the power came back, the television came on to footage of a mountainside scarred with wreckage. The crippled plane had taken 40 minutes to fall out of the sky. Some passengers had time to write notes to their loved ones. On television the passenger list was read out. 'Cassie heard Aki's,' said Bayly. 'She shouted "Papa" and our world just collapsed. Diana's birth was a blur.'

Cassie's memories of her father are vivid. Now a student at the Royal Academy of Music in London, she is a talented pianist, as was her father. It was her search for information about the crash that led to the family being invited to travel to Japan for last year's ceremony.

Yukawa had died instantly, clutching a picture of a doll Cassie had asked him to buy for her. 'The saddest point is that Aki can't see our beautiful daughters, that's the biggest void,' said Bayly.

fields.headline: The new waiting game
fields.standfirst: Jeeves has never been in such demand as the super-rich fund a £4 billion boom in domestic service, writes  Sarah Ryle
fields.trailText: Jeeves has never been in such demand as the super-rich fund a £4 billion boom in domestic service.
fields.body:
The career of Pedro Sanchez mirrors the wealth revolution in modern Britain. In the Sixties, he was leading a Jeeves-like lifestyle as butler to the aristocracy. In the Seventies and Eighties, he was taking the shilling of industrialists and Arab princes. These days, his ambition is to work for a pop star - preferably his idol, Eric Clapton - before he hangs up his perfectly pressed jacket for good.

In the meantime, like thousands of others, he is happy to work for the new super-rich: the merchant bankers, lawyers, entrepreneurs and minor celebrities who are making domestic service one of the fastest growing areas of the UK economy. Most live in London and have large, country retreats. Many have staff in both locations.

The Canadian newspaper proprietor Conrad Black recently advertised for a man with Sanchez's experience. He was prepared to pay £60,000 plus the perks a butler expects - a flat and living expenses are just the start.

This is why so many people are signing up to pamper the rich, says the boss of one of the more established domestic service agencies. Demand for help is so strong that international conglomerate Unilever has set up a domestic service subsidiary. In the UK alone, home-help spending has doubled to £4 billion in a single year.

In 1901, when the British population was 38 million and every middle-class home had at least one servant, there were 1.7 million women and 140,000 men in service. Now there are two million out of a population of 59 million. When former Beatle George Harrison is employing more than 30 people just to keep his garden nice, business really is booming.

Domestic staff are no longer rigidly demarcated as butlers, housekeepers or chauffeurs. 'Back in the Sixties, the Beatles used to have a personal staff of at least 12,' Sanchez recalls. Today's pop stars such as Geri Halliwell and the Gallagher brothers make do with fewer people. Sanchez says he is expected to perform various roles.

The greatest demand, though, is for nannies. Nearly two-thirds of couples with young children are both working. Sanchez says winning over the lady of the house is crucial for good upstairs/downstairs relations: 'They are very rich and very bored and often their husbands are off travelling the world, sometimes with the secretary, so who are they going to take this out on? The staff of course.'

Even those who don't work can find a nanny is not enough: they have maternity nurses like Veronica Doyle, who guides women through the first four months of motherhood. Now working for a wealthy merchant banker's wife in Chelsea, Doyle cared for Lucas Morad, the love-child of Mick Jagger and Luciana Morad, who last week had her claim for £23,000 a month in child support reduced to £6,250. The first 10 weeks of Lucas's life were spent in Manhattan besieged by paparazzi. Doyle was hounded by reporters who, she says, made up things. 'I was devastated when they printed things I was supposed to have said about Mick Jagger. He was paying my wages, for goodness sake.'

She has also looked after Jemima and Zac Goldsmith, whose mother, Lady Annabelle, she describes as a 'a real lady', even though she did not mind doing a spot of hoovering herself.

Doyle admits to having worked for 'difficult' employers whose new-found wealth had not prepared them for handling servants.

Her 'apprenticeship' was served with the aristocratic Drummond family in Scotland in the late Fifties, with whom she is still in touch. 'It was the best experience I could have possibly had. A lot of these younger girls have not had enough experience to have confidence and are terribly exploited.

'But there is another side to the coin. Some ask for so much now. They want not just a flat, but a flat with their own entrance, their own phone, even their own car.'

Sanchez says self-confidence is the key to a happy working relationship: 'Employers are like dogs. They can smell fear. You must show you are confident in your ability and you are always professional. I have worked for difficult, awkward men, but I have almost always handled it. I worked for Lord Hanson for more than three years - very few people have lasted so long with him - and he was a difficult but marvellous man. But John Aspinall was so difficult that even I left after a matter of weeks. The problem was respect. It wasn't going to work.'

Hanson was a stickler for punctuality - lunch was served at one o' clock sharp and was finished by 2pm, drinks were at six. Those were rules Sanchez could live with.

'The real aristocracy know exactly how to behave because they grew up with servants,' says Sanchez. 'They respect the people who work for them. A lot of the people with new money find staff make them feel claustrophobic and they don't know what to expect. They are the ones who are most likely to expect staff to wear uniforms and be very subservient.'

Portuguese and Filipino staff are particularly popular, Katherine Shields of Staff of Distinction says, because they are 'very adaptable and willing to please', which is a polite way of saying subservient. Australian nannies are more popular than their British counterparts because they are less stuffy and 'always cheerful'.

Confidentiality agreements such as the one signed by the Blair nanny, Ros Mark, are a recent development.

'When I began we would have been insulted by such an agreement,' says Sanchez. 'Discretion is vitally important. Butlers have to learn not to listen. It is not always the bosses who do the exploiting: butler John Percival Hole waited until his boss Rodney Price (former chairman of the Thistle hotel group) went away before he threw a party, 'borrowed' the Bentley Turbo and sold it before embarking on a drink-and-drugs binge in Germany. Morgan says they can be 'chippy and unconfident', even 'penny-pinching' about perks. York says the new rich are 'not saddled with sentimental noblesse oblige'.

In the Seventies and Eighties, he was taking the shilling of industrialists and Arab princes. These days, his ambition is to work for a pop star - preferably his idol, Eric Clapton - before he hangs up his perfectly pressed jacket for good. In the meantime, like thousands of others, he is happy to work for the new super-rich: the merchant bankers, lawyers, entrepreneurs and minor celebrities who are making domestic service one of the fastest growing areas of the UK economy. Most live in London and have large, country retreats. Many have staff in both locations. The Canadian newspaper proprietor Conrad Black recently advertised for a man with Sanchez's experience. He was prepared to pay £60,000 plus the perks a butler expects - a flat and living expenses are just the start. This is why so many people are signing up to pamper the rich, says the boss of one of the more established domestic service agencies. Demand for help is so strong that international conglomerate Unilever has set up a domestic service subsidiary. In the UK alone, home-help spending has doubled to £4 billion in a single year. webTitle: Satellite folly as billions burn in space

fields.headline: Satellite folly as billions burn in space
fields.trailText: It is destined to be the most costly technological blunder in history. Sixty-six satellites which cost the Iridium telecommunications group more than $5 billion to build and launch are to be sent spiralling into Earth's atmosphere and allowed to burn up, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
It is destined to be the most costly technological blunder in history. Sixty-six satellites which cost the Iridium telecommunications group more than $5 billion to build and launch are to be sent spiralling into Earth's atmosphere and allowed to burn up, it was announced yesterday.

The decision follows the Washington-based company's failure to find a buyer to rescue it from bankruptcy and adds a new name to the list of the world's greatest scientific failures.

Iridium's failure also brings an end to dreams that engineers could create a telecommunications system that would allow users of handheld phones to make calls from any point on the globe. Only 55,000 customers could be persuaded to sign up and have now been disconnected.

'No bid was received which was a qualified bid,' William Perlstein, an attorney representing the debt-plagued firm, told a bankruptcy court in Manhattan. Judge Arthur Gonzalez then ordered Iridium to spend $8.3 million to start winding up its business while selling its remaining Earth-bound assets, including ground stations.

The last act of the company - whose major stakeholder is the US electronic giant Motorola - will be to 'de-orbit' and ultimately burn up its constellation of 66 satellites orbiting 485 miles above the ground, a network that is estimated to have cost up to $7bn to create just over a year ago.

Engineers will tip the craft, one by one, on a death ride that will send them down in flames above the ocean - a spectacle that should be visible from Earth. It could take up to two years to complete the scuttle.

Iridium's failure is a bitter blow to Motorola. Although international phone calls have been relayed by satellites for several decades, these are typically transmitted to probes that orbit in deep space where their velocities exactly match the speed of Earth's rotation, allowing them to hover over one area.

However, this geostationary orbit is so high - 22,000 miles - that only telephones linked to powerful transmitters can use them. Iridium signals needed no boosting because they were picked up by low-orbiting satellites. The drawback was that dozens of satellites were needed. The phones were as big as bricks and were initially priced at $3,000 apiece, with calls costing as much as $7 a minute. Even worse, they did not work indoors.

The final blow was the rapid spread of ground-based networks which now let business travellers, a prime market for the satellite phones, stay connected from most major destinations.

Iridium's fate bodes ill for ICO Global Communications, a second satellite phone network, which filed for bankruptcy protection shortly after Iridium. A new buyer is desperately attempting to save the service, while Teledesic, a third satellite network, is scheduled to begin service in 2004 - though it is marketing its services as 'an Internet of the sky'.

 robin.mckie@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Be very afraid of the future

fields.headline: Be very afraid of the future
fields.standfirst: Shockwaves from an extraordinary article in  Wired magazine on the violent pace of technology have reached right up to the White House.  Edward Helmore reports
fields.trailText: Shockwaves from an extraordinary article in  Wired magazine on the violent pace of technology have reached right up to the White House.
fields.body:
Here is a portrait of the future. A future where humankind is under threat from hugely powerful and self-determining computers. This was the world of Arnold Schwarzenegger's Terminator, of Philip K. Dick and Dr Who , of mad scientists - until last week. Now it is a deadly serious projection of a technological Armageddon, being examined in the office of the world's most powerful man.

A 20,000-word essay written by leading software innovator Bill Joy, published in the magazine Wired, has proved so provocative that President Bill Clinton's office requested a copy. The tract, titled 'Why The Future Doesn't Need Us,' argues that new twenty-first century technologies of digital, biological and material science present us with dangers at least as fearsome as nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, if not more so, and suggests that accelerating technological change could cause 'something like extinction' of human beings within two generations.

Joy's critique is not so much remarkable for its message - there have always been social critics and marginalised scientists warning of danger in the progress of technology - but because it came from within the highest reaches of a technological establishment that rarely breaks rank in offering an optimistic future of the new sciences as wealth and health enhancing.

'Finally, someone who is responsible for creating significant parts of today's technological infrastructure is voicing the concerns that have been labelled "Luddite" when voiced by others,' says Howard Rheingold, founder of The Well, a pioneering Bay Area Internet community in San Francisco. 'Technology is a wonderful vehicle, but we have no road map, headlights, or rear-view mirror.'

Joy, co-founder and Chief Scientist at Sun Microsystems, the Silicon Valley software giant, said his warning was meant to be reminiscent of Albert Einstein's famous 1939 letter to President Franklin D. Roosevelt, alerting him to the possibility of an atomic bomb.

But Einstein's warning at the dawn of the nuclear age was directed towards a small number of decision makers. Joy, by contrast, set his sights on a far larger community of technologists and scientists, funded by private enterprise, unconstrained by government - potentially more difficult forces to rein in. In the twentieth century, he points out, 'building nuclear weapons required, at least for a time, access to both rare - indeed, effectively unavailable - raw materials and highly protected information.

'But the twenty-first century technologies - genetics, nanotechnology and robotics - are so powerful that they can spawn whole new classes of accidents and abuses. For the first time, these accidents and abuses are within the reach of individuals or small groups. Knowledge alone will enable the use of them.'

And Joy certainly fears the worst: 'I think it is no exaggeration to say we are on the cusp of the further perfection of extreme evil, an evil whose possibility spreads well beyond that which weapons of mass destruction bequeathed to the nation-states, on to a surprising and terrible empowerment of extreme individuals.'

Within scientific and technological communities, Joy's doomsday scenario has been welcomed as an articulate exercise but one that underestimates the profound benefits technology has brought and promises in the future.

'Bill Joy is probably the most influential commentator at present because he's spreading a message that makes people anxious,' says Charles Platt, a science writer at Wired . 'Anything that creates fear get a lot of attention but it's bad news for people if they want, say, genetically engineered medicine to avoid age-related diseases or to avoid getting killed by the next global viral plague that comes along.'

Nathan Myhrvold, a theoretical physicist who studied under Stephen Hawking and is currently on sabbatical from his job as chief technology officer at Microsoft, pointed out that such dire predictions are usually inspired by fear of change. 'Every other "unprecedented" challenge of the past has been overcome,' he says. 'Is this case really different? Or are we once again falling into the trap of overestimating technology's downside and underestimating people's ability to cope?'

Bruce Sterling, the techno guru who was among the first cyberpunk writers, takes a wry approach: 'I'm touched by the guy's sincerity. It's clear he's troubled by this issue and thought it was something he ought to share with the rest of us. He's clearly gone to pains to research the issues, to look for other people who might have shared his problems in the past, and he hit on an excellent one with Robert Oppenheimer. But if you're going to have an Oppenheimer moment my feeling is you should have it before you detonate the device.'

The author's apocalyptic vision of the future centres on new technologies which will be able to replicate themselves, without human help - nightmarish scenarios in which technologies exceed man's power to control them.

By using the struggle to limit nuclear, chemical and biological weapons as his inspiration, Joy concludes by proposing that we stop to consider where our progress is leading before we enable our own extinction.

'The only realistic alternative I see is relinquishment: to limit development of the technologies that are too dangerous, by limiting our pursuit of certain kinds of knowledge.'

If Joy's fear of twenty-first century technologies is exaggerated, his arguments have at least opened up a debate over whether technology fits the society we want. 'He is making the case for technological determinism - if I can do something, I will do it - but that has been proven not to be the case,' says Dr Charles Bugliarello, chancellor of Polytechnic University in Brooklyn.

'There is a constant see-saw between technological advances and societal advancement. Sometimes machines are ahead, then society adjusts. In other cases, society advances and then machines catch up. The essential issue is that machines have not had the benefit of the evolutionary process that biological organisms have had. Their development has been so rapid that we don't have a way of checking whether their development makes sense.'

For Jason Lanier, a pioneer in the field of virtual reality, one remedy would be to reject machine-centred designs that supplant human decision-making. A simple example of this is the common function in word processors that inserts capital letters at the start of sentences and periods at the end.

Joy's concerns centre on three areas, many of which have been addressed by science-fiction writers and technologist-authors such as Ray Kurzweil in The Age of Spiritual Machines: When Computers Exceed Human Intelligence , Hans Moravec in Robot: Mere Machine to Transcendent Mind , and George Dyson in Darwin Among the Machines: The Evolution of Global Intelligence .

Joy predicts that by 2030, computers will be a million times more powerful than today, lending the possibility that robots may exceed humans in intelligence and have the ability to replicate themselves. Primitive examples of the kind of thing Joy is talking about include 'replication attacks' in the virtual world of computer viruses, the kind which have caused shutdowns of Internet sites and e-mail systems.

He also points to nanotechnology - the science of creating minute machines atom by atom - that could in time produce tiny, self-reproducing mechanisms, and warns these could wreak havoc if released accidently or by malicious intent. In genetics, he supposes that the widening availability of knowledge about powerful genetic engineering could lead to a 'white plague' - an artificially designed disease that can kill selectively.

In making his argument, Joy finds he's walking in the shoes of Theodore Kaczynski, the lapsed scientist widely discredited as a madman who conducted a 17-year bombing campaign against scientists in protest at technology, the so-called 'Unabomber'.

Though he unequivocally condemns Kaczynski's use of violence, he notes he now shares the jailed bomber's terror of the 'unintended consequences, a well-known problem with the design and use of technology'.

Like Kaczynski, Joy fears the potential positive applications of science are outweighed by the dangers: 'I have always believed making software more reliable, given its many uses, will make the world a safer and better place,' Joy writes. 'If I were to come to believe the opposite, then I would be morally obligated to stop this work. I can now imagine that such a day may come.'

fields.headline: After the darkness, the dawn
fields.standfirst: She was registered blind in 1982. Then a visit to change her glasses changed her life. Now, with her sight restored, she is a testament to the quiet values that shaped a generation of ordinary Britons
fields.trailText: She was registered blind in 1982. Then a visit to change her glasses changed her life. Now, with her sight restored, she is a testament to the quiet values that shaped a generation of ordinary Britons.
fields.body:
They'll go round North Wales again this year. By coach. It will rain. They will stop for cups of tea. In the roadside caffs they will be careful with the pennies, for money doesn't grow on trees - never did, of course, but especially not at their age it doesn't.

They went last year, and it was nice, but it wasn't great. Jean, being stone blind, had to spend days sitting in the swaying fug listening to Arthur as he tried, gamely, to describe the passing sights. She's a good-natured old bird, stoic and uncomplaining of life, but even she admits - as I struggle to work out precisely how many seconds I could have lasted in the same seat before spontaneous combustion occurred or I tried to choke off life by eating my own headscarf - that it got 'a little bit boring'.

So they'll go again this year, and it will, says Jean, be the greatest holiday she's ever had. She's looking forward to seeing Wales. To seeing the sea, the hills, the other people's faces. And the colours. Most of all, more than anything, she's looking forward to the colours.

Miracles don't seem to favour the rich and famous, and perhaps with good reason; they've happened to them, by definition, already. They tend to happen to the unknown and the ordinary, the civilians, the millions usually drowned out by the caterwaul of wealthy, gossipy media London yelling at its navel. And so it's nice - well, it's more than nice, it's lovely, but nice seems to be our word for the day - to find a tale that can still stop you in your tracks and bring the sun out; and to find a couple who remind you of another country, an older Britain, simpler and duller but still resonant; a Britain that has, like Jean and Arthur themselves, never quite got around to giving up.

It was in 1982 that Jean was, quite massively wrongly, registered blind, at the age of 59. She had never seen well, wearing glasses from the age of nine, and her sight had been getting progressively worse throughout the Seventies. 'By 1982 I could hardly see a face in front of me - the right eye had gone completely, and the left was just a blur.' She had only had cataracts - huge, clouding cataracts, but operable nonetheless - but the hospital didn't realise. She was registered blind, and given a white stick. 'And it got even worse. It was black, pretty black, most of the time. I didn't question the diagnosis, for there is a family problem: my mother, sister and brother all went blind.'

Because of the years of failing sight, going blind was, she says philosophi cally, perhaps easier for her than most. She took herself off to classes, learning Moon, a blind-language set in raised shapes, rather than Braille. She had her friends. She had her (then) husband, Alf. She could hear, and she would crouch next to the television, struggling to make out a faint moving shadow as she listened to the soaps - 'The soaps were my saviour. Movies were more difficult, with the silences, but the great thing about the soaps is that there was always someone talking.'

Since she began talking, last week, about her sudden recovery, in case there's someone else out there in the same situation, she has come across as big-hearted, unresentful and, yes, stoic. But as we talk a little further about the black years, she remembers more and, if not with bitterness, then with an ineffable sadness.

The little, daily things. Standing at a crossroads for 20 minutes at a time, waiting for all sounds to die away. Trying to cook: 'I'd get terribly frustrated. After I'd got the pot on, I couldn't tell if the gas was lit or not, so I'd put my head down to smell for gas, and my hair would singe. And with the oven... always getting burns on my arms. Or trying to read: the Moon system is good, but takes up a lot of space; so if I tried to read a book - oh, you know, mostly weepies, love stories, what most women read - I'd need 24 boxes in the house. It was too much.'

The poignant things. 'I would get out the photographs' - her and Alf, the four children, the 11 grandchildren - 'and stare and stare at them. I knew I couldn't see them, but it didn't stop me trying. Sometimes with the telly too. I used to love wildlife programmes. And so I'd hear them say, "And now the elephant finally appears", and I'm going, "Where is it? Where is it? " I so wanted to see that elephant.'

And the tears. The one thing her eyes were still able to do was cry, especially after Alf died in 1990. 'The worst part was that I couldn't go about on my own. I'd lost my independence. Did I cry? Yes. A lot. Especially at night. Especially after I lost my first husband. I felt very... alone. Blindness does that to you: even when you're in a crowd, you feel you're the only one.'

Arthur, her husband today, was married to Jean's cousin, Flossie. He 'lost' her, as the euphemism goes, around the same time. The four had always been close; it was that kind of life, that kind of generation. Arthur, the driving instructor; Alf, the delivery man who had to retire because of TB; Jean, who left her job in a psychiatric ward to care for him; Flossie, who joined them every Friday night for friendly foursomes of knockout whist, and could never get the hang, as Arthur remembers fondly, of following his lead. And so, in 1992, it was only natural that the remaining pair should get together to talk about the old days, and then, in love and in need, get married.

Jean had always worn her glasses, even though they were no good; she felt friends wouldn't recognise her otherwise. And then, last year, the indomitable, patient, loving Arthur, whom Jean had by then nursed through a stroke, said to her: 'You've worn those glasses for 39 years. Time you got them changed.' He had an appointment for new reading glasses, and put Jean's name down too. 'I said rubbish, but he insisted I went.'

Her appointment was from 3pm to 3.30. The optometrist, Ruth Douse, who was eight years old when Jean went fully blind, had found huge and heavy cataracting, and wanted her to see a specialist as soon as possible. Dr Roger Wilson, consultant surgeon at the East Surrey Hospital, operated on her left eye six weeks ago, under local anaesthetic, and asked Arthur to take off the patch gently in the morning.

'I was scared,' says Jean. 'They had told me not to hope for too much, but I was scared nothing would have happened. Of course, you hope.' She sat down in the living room, facing the window. 'Arthur lifted off the patch. And I just shouted: 'Oh, my God!'

'He was worried, thought I was upset 'cos nothing had happened. But it was the opposite. "Will you look at those colours!" I said. "Will you look at that grass out there?" The left eye was done shortly afterwards and there were surprises, of course. Eighteen years in the dark... she had had to imagine a lot. She smiles as I ask her about public figures. The lines and wrinkles were a shock.

But the delights are everywhere. Arthur quietly went up to the attack and brought down all Jean's summer clothes, hung them in her wardrobe, and told her to go and have a look. She cried again; she had always thought she was dressed in black. Plants - bright, zinging pot plants, guaranteed to burst open in the spring - have been ordered for the front door. 'Even now, I still say, "Look at that colour, isn't it beautiful?"

'I say it everywhere. In Sainsbury's; suddenly I'll stop, and say, "Oh look at the colour on those tins; look at that row of jars." He hurries me on, says people will think I'm mad. Well, I might be, but I'm happy.'

In the roadside caffs they will be careful with the pennies, for money doesn't grow on trees - never did, of course, but especially not at their age it doesn't. They went last year, and it was nice, but it wasn't great. Jean, being stone blind, had to spend days sitting in the swaying fug listening to Arthur as he tried, gamely, to describe the passing sights. fields.headline: A hypocrisy that kills
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Someone should have cut out last Monday's headline in the  Andersonstown News and posted it to Channel 4's  Big Breakfast. Last Monday's splash on the  News would have qualified for pun of the week: 'IRA back on the beat'.
fields.body:
Someone should have cut out last Monday's headline in the Andersonstown News and posted it to Channel 4's Big Breakfast. One of the highlights of this programme is when Johnny Vaughan singles out the best play on words in the headlines of Britain's red-tops. Last Monday's splash on the News would have qualified for pun of the week: 'IRA back on the beat'. This was a reference to the Provos' resumption of so-called punishment shootings in nationalist areas. The masked lawmen of west Belfast, Strabane and south Armagh have yet to start wielding the baseball bats again (they might be waiting for a new consignment from America after the St. Patrick's Day hooleys) but when they do it will make the News headline all the more poignant.

Paramilitary bobbies back on the beat doing what they like doing best - beating their victims. It conjures up a halcyon world of Noddyland PC Plods giving the village ruffian a clip around the ear to keep him in place. Of course, PC Plod in Provoland and Loyalistland is more inclined to cripple him.

The Andersonstown News editor, Robin Livingstone, should not just be applauded for such a brilliant if perhaps unintended pun. Writing in Ireland on Sunday , he pointed out that the resumption of so-called punishment shootings was political, that the vacuum caused by the suspension of the power-sharing executive indirectly led to the IRA taking up the gun again. His remarks were an honest admission that 'community policing' Provo-style is in fact a key element of a carefully wrought political strategy rather than a visceral communal response to rising crime, the real aim of which is not just to maintain control in Catholic areas but to also send out menacing signals to Brits and unionists.

Ironically, David Ervine of the UVF-linked Progressive Unionist Party, repeated this line in the Irish Times, saying that all the politicians caught up in the current impasse following suspension were in some way responsible for the new wave of punishments and shootings.

The only conclusion to draw from this argument is that working-class teenagers and young men are paying the price for politics not working. In this twisted logic it is not the boys with the baseball bats and the Browning automatics who are responsible for wounding, maiming and murdering but the political leaders up at the Assembly. That must be comforting to the victims.

Mr Ervine's argument is particularly absurd given that loyalist terrorism against its own community - via the UVF, LVF and UDA - never abated even when the power-sharing executive was working. The Prods kept 'punishing' other Prods. The sociological explanation of continuing violence, the mantra that 'we are all to blame', is merely a means of letting those guilty of such human rights abuses off the hook.

What is bizarre is to listen to apologists of paramilitary 'justice' justify these practices while knowing that the same people attend seminars on human rights or turn up for the launch of Bill of Rights commissions. More disturbing is the disgraceful silence of human rights groups who have failed to protest at the ongoing punishment attacks in Protestant areas and their resumption in republican redoubts.

The apologists of paramilitary injustice, republican or loyalist, are like the Communist sympathisers who formed the backbone of the National Council of Civil Liberties in Britain in the 1930s. George Orwell excoriated the CP members and supporters in the NCCL who campaigned against human rights abuses at home while excusing purges, mass expulsions and executions in Stalin's Soviet Union. The same moral doublethink is alive and well in Northern Ireland where supporters, spokesmen and fellow travellers of paramilitarism and the practices of Islamic-style justice keep a straight face when talking about the need for a bill of rights.

 Henry McDonald's biography of David Trimble is published by Bloomsbury, £16.99.

fields.headline: Springclean your money
fields.standfirst: Check everything, says  Virginia Wallis.  Knocking just 1 per cent off a mortgage can save you £15,000
fields.trailText: Check everything, says Virginia Wallis. Knocking just 1 per cent off a mortgage can save you £15,000.
fields.body:
You don't need to be an expert in feng shui to understand the benefits of a thoroughly good clear-out. Your rooms will look bigger, you will cut down on cleaning time - and instead of being surrounded by guilt-inducing reminders of unfortunate impulse buys, you will get a warm glow from knowing that you've done your bit for the world's poor by depositing your unwanted stuff at the local charity shop.

Not convinced? You must be a member of the 'you never know when it might come in handy' brigade. So, presumably, was the man who lost the entire contents of his loft to thieves who got in through the loft space of a house further down the terrace. The burglary was bad enough, but his biggest headache was the insurance claim.

'We did everything we could to help,' says Sue Winston of Norwich Union, 'but the problem was that he had no idea what was in the loft, so he didn't know what to claim for.'

But at least his claim was met. Even if you can remember all the things you've got stashed away in the loft, cellar, garage or garden shed, how sure are you that they are adequately insured?

What many people don't realise, according to Winston, is that with new-for-old policies, even semi-discarded items need to be insured for their full replacement value (irrespective of whether you would actually want to replace them). If they are not, you risk having any future claim on your contents policy scaled down, or not paid at all.

Insuring all those belongings you can't do without shouldn't add too much to your premium. At Norwich Union, for example, an extra £5,000 on the sum insured will add about £15 a year to your insurance bill. This is about the same as the saving you could make on your car insurance if you managed to clear enough space in the garage to get the car in.

But if all this talk of unaccounted-for clutter is upsetting your minimalist sensibili ties, can you honestly say your finances are in as sleek a condition as your surroundings? They're not if the contents of your purse or wallet could do with a good going over (see below).

And they're most definitely not if you are one of the 4 million homeowners which Direct Line estimates are spending an unnecessary £1 billion a month on their mortgages.

'This is a classic case of rip-off Britain,' claims Stephen Geraghty, managing director of Direct Line Financial Services. He has a point. Shaving just one percentage point off the interest you pay on a £60,000 mortgage would save you £600 a year, or £15,000 over the 25-year life of the loan. Moving your house insurance away from your lender will free up an average £50 a year, says Geraghty.

Bigger savings are to be made if your lender persuaded you to take out Mortgage Payment Protection Insurance (MPPI), especially if you get rid of it altogether, which may be an option if you're among the 45 per cent of people whose ability to meet monthly mortgage payments would be unaffected by illness or redundancy.

This could be the case if your employer provides a decent sick-pay scheme, you could rely on a partner's income or your savings - or a redundancy payout - could cover your mortgage payments for a year.

But even if you do need the cushion of insurance, you can still save around a third of your premium by switching to a standalone policy such as those available from: Berkeley Alexander (01273 477784); John Charcol Insurance Brokers (0800 939393) which is offering six months' free unemployment cover to John Charcol mortgage customers; and Securityfirst (01376 347369) which gives three free months' cover to any mortgage borrower.

Simon Burgess of Securityfirst is so confident that customers will save money that he is offering to pay £100 to anyone able to find cheaper cover elsewhere.

webTitle: Dust it - and put it safely away

fields.headline: Dust it - and put it safely away
fields.trailText: Good news for hoarders: the financial system gives lots of scope for hanging on to things. It is best to file records of the following.
fields.body:
Good news for hoarders: the financial system gives lots of scope for hanging on to things. It is best to file records of the following.

 Tax: Even if you don't get a self-assessment tax return, you are legally required to keep records of income and capital gains for at least 22 months after the end of the tax year to which they relate, and for at least five years and 10 months if you are self-employed. If the Inland Revenue asks to see a document - such as dividend vouchers, certificates of interest paid, your P60 or proof of business expenses - and you haven't got it, you can be fined up to £3,000.

 National Insurance: Hang on to all your P60s. They are your only evidence of the National Insurance you have paid during your working life. You don't have to keep them beyond the Revenue's time limits, but they will be useful evidence if you need to query the amount of state pension you get when you retire.

 Bank: Even if you don't have to keep statements for tax purposes, Brian Capon of the British Bankers' Association advises keeping bank and credit card records for at least six years. Whether you keep chequebook stubs, cash machine receipts or credit card chits once the transaction has appeared on your statement 'depends on how cautious you want to be', says Capon. If you suspect there will be a dispute over a cheque payment, keep a record of the payee, number and date of the cheque so your bank can trace it.

 Insurance: Keep your life policies, or make the beneficiary look after them. Suzanne Moore of the Association of British Insurers advises keeping a note of claims because you may need this information when renewing the insurance.

 Investment: Hang on to everything. All that paper-work you get when you buy protects you if you were badly advised.

fields.headline: Small changes, big savings
fields.trailText: If you want to make savings, it could be worth changing your utility company.
fields.body:
If you want to make savings, it could be worth changing your utility company. For comparative price information on both gas and electricity suppliers, phone the OFGEM Helpline on 0800 887777. If you have Internet access, try the interactive 'dual fuel calculator' at www.buy.co.uk.

Switching phone companies could be worthwhile too - especially since there is no longer the hassle of having to change your phone number when you change the company that supplies your phone line. And you may not even have to do that. BT customers can carry on renting their line from BT but may save on call costs by routing calls through one of the increasing number of 'indirect access' providers. Using the 1363 service from Var Tec Telecom (0800 0925200), for example, saves 47p on a 10-minute daytime national call on a weekday compared with BT's standard rate.

If you are looking to cut the cost of both voice calls and those to the Internet, the service from quip! may be of interest. Savings are similar to those from Var Tec but from the end of March, if you spend £5 a month on voice calls and change your Internet Service Provider (ISP) to LineOne, calls to the Internet will cost nothing. To register, go to www.quip.co.uk. From April a similar scheme will be available to customers of Freeserve (pick up a disk at Dixons or go to www.freeserve.net No-cost Internet access is also available from www.callnet.com (0906 944 4040) and www.x-stream.co.uk (0800 358 5678). For up-to-date information on other companies offering no-cost Internet access, go to www.net4nowt.com.

fields.headline: Cut those costly purse strings
fields.trailText: The contents of your purse or wallet can say a lot about you. If they are saying you're carrying around expensive, unnecessary clutter, the time has come to give them the once over. But where to start?
fields.body:
The contents of your purse or wallet can say a lot about you. If they are saying you're carrying around expensive, unnecessary clutter, the time has come to give them the once over. But where to start?

Say no to store cards

If you are striving for simplicity in your financial affairs, the first thing to go should be any store cards. Since the demise of its 'no credit cards' policy last September, you really have no excuse for hanging on to a John Lewis or Waitrose card - even if it did always stand out as a reasonable deal compared with other stores' cards.

Marks & Spencer Charge-card holders can cite the convenience of shopping on credit as a good excuse for holding on to their cards only until after May, when M&S plans to start taking 'normal' credit cards (although this could happen earlier).

As far as cards from other stores go, unless you genuinely make use of their temptations to spend more in the form of sales previews, special offers and/or a free catalogue, they are just cluttering up your purse or wallet and adding to your pile of statements.

If you use the store cards to borrow, you should definitely get rid of them. The interest rates they charge (see table) are more than twice the rate of much better value credit cards.

Which? magazine says someone running a £400 store-card debt could pay an extra £55 in interest a year compared with a 'best buy' credit card from Capital One (0800 952 5252). The John Lewis and Waitrose cards were a lot less expensive, but still cost an extra £5.

Chuck out the cheques

No one is suggesting you do away with your current-account cheque book, but a strong candidate for the bin is the chequebook some issuers provide with their credit card.

When you write a credit-card cheque, the amount is added to your card bill, so they can be convenient if whoever you are paying doesn't take plastic. But purchases made like this are treated as cash advances, so interest (at a rate usually higher than for purchases) starts clocking up as soon as the item hits your account.

On top of the interest, some card issuers charge a handling fee. Royal Bank of Scotland, for example, charges 1.5 per cent of the value of the cheque (minimum charge £1.50); the same percentage is charged on those linked to an Alliance and Leicester Money Back card, but the minimum charge is £2. However, there's no handling fee on cheques with cards from Beneficial, the Co-operative Bank and MBNA.

But cost is not the only factor. Another good reason for abandoning these cheques is that you're not covered by the Consumer Credit Act if something goes wrong with the goods you have bought and the retailer won't help. Credit card issuers aren't obliged to come to your rescue in the way they are if a purchase is made with plastic, and the goods cost between £100 and £30,000.

Cut your consumption

Unless you already manage to survive with one or two cards, why not get rid of the others? It'll solve the problem of where to keep all the shop loyalty cards you may have, there will be fewer payment dates to remember and you'll have a lot less paper to keep track of. But which ones should go?

If you are among the estimated 40 per cent of people who always pay bills off in full every month, first to go should be those aimed at people running a debt on their card which give no interest-free credit. Moneyfacts says these include Alliance & Leicester Diamond, Bank of Scotland One Visa, Co-op Bank Advantage Visa (both normal and gold versions), Halifax Visa Balance, Hamilton Direct Bank Visa and Sainsbury's Bank Merit Visa.

Once you've cut up and cancelled these, consider ditching those for which you pay a fee ,such as American Express Blue Amex, Clydes-dale Mastercard, Co-op Bank Gold Base Rate Visa, HSBC Platinum Visa, Popular Bank Gold Visa and the Woolwich Secured Mastercard, as well as those which may be about to charge. Cards which don't have a first-year fee but do after that include American Express Gold Amex and Green Amex, Capital Bank Sterling Visa, Halifax Gold Mastercard, HSBC Gold Visa and Ulster Bank Gold Mastercard.

With Barclaycard and Barclaycard Gold, First Direct Gold Visa, Halifax Visa and NatWest's Amex card, you'll avoid the fee only if you meet the card issuer's minimum spending requirements.

Ideally, that leaves cards which give something back, as a donation to charity, in Air Miles (or other loyalty points) or as hard cash.

Sainsbury's customers collecting Air Miles with a NatWest credit card may like to know that switching to the Classic Visa from Sainsbury's Bank (0500 405060) could more than treble their miles.

If you would rather have money, the most generous cashback card is from Egg (apply at www.egg.com it gives 1 per cent of anything you spend (2 per cent of purchases at its online shopping zone). If you don't have Internet access, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter (0800 917 1333) refunds 0.5 per cent of spending up to £2,000; 1 per cent on amounts over that. The MoneyBack cards from Alliance & Leicester (0500 838383) apply the same percentages, but you won't get the higher rate until your spending exceeds £4,000.

Dust off your debts

If you are running credit card debts, your best way of getting cash back is to reduce the interest you pay.

Which? reckons someone transferring a £1,000 debt from a card with an APR of 19.9 per cent to a card with a six-month introductory 'teaser' rate of 5 per cent or less, with a follow-up rate of around 15 per cent, could save around £70; the savings are more if the teaser rate stays until the balance is paid.

Debts transferred to Tesco Visa (0800 406050) attract a teaser rate of 4.9 per cent until the end of this year; those to Egg Visa, a rate of 4.5 per cent for six months. After that it is a cheapish 9.9 per cent.

Rather than offer a teaser rate on debt transfers, some cards offer a low rate only for new purchases, so check the small print. The best deal if you want to use a credit card to spread the cost of a new purchase over several months is from Capital One (0800 952 5252). Its Premier Visa Card charges no interest on new purchases until the end of June, followed by a reasonable 11.9 per cent.

Current account quiz

Before you can declare your spending power truly pristine, take a hard look at your cashcard and the current account it belongs to. If you give a helping hand to the shareholders of Alliance & Leicester, Barclays, Co-op, Lloyds TSB or NatWest by paying a monthly fee when you overdraw, you should consider changing your bank arrangements. Overdrafts from Abbey National, Bank of Scotland, First Direct, the Halifax, HSBC, Nationwide and the Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) are fee-free.

Paying from £48 to £108 a year even when you are in credit is unnecessary. Even if the perks with 'packaged' accounts such as Barclays Additions, First Direct Premier Cheque, Lloyds TSB Gold Service or Select, NatWest Advantage Gold and the RBS Royalties accounts seem attractive, they are rarely worth the fees. In most cases, you will do better to take your business elsewhere.

If your current account costs you nothing, now sift your savings accounts to ensure they are not lagging behind the best on offer (see Databank, page 18).

webTitle: For the banks, free and easy doesn't do it

fields.headline: For the banks, free and easy doesn't do it
fields.trailText: The banks protest too much, methinks. Their claims to be responsible lenders are now being questioned by the chief financial regulator, the Financial Services Authority.
fields.body:
The banks protest too much, methinks. Their claims to be responsible lenders are now being questioned by the chief financial regulator, the Financial Services Authority.

On several occasions in the past year, The Observer has questioned the banks' denials that they advance credit too easily. They say their systems are watertight - but a sharp rise in unsecured personal lending has prompted the FSA to launch an investigation. It fears banks are being too free and easy, especially in the way they lend to people speculating in high-tech shares.

The FSA should not confine its inquiry to the issue of indiscriminate lending for share trading. There is strong evidence from debt counsellors that personal loans and credit card lending are growing at a pace many people cannot handle.

A week ago, the FSA's consumer panel criticised it for failing to act quickly enough on a series of issues. It seems banks may have been getting up to their old tricks - lending exploded in a similar manner in the eighties - under the regulator's nose. But although the FSA is not yet as quick as it probably ought to be, it is fleeter of foot than its predecessor, the Securities and Investments Board. It has also spotted a relaxation in mortgage lenders' safeguards, as they advance larger and larger multiples of income.

NEWSPAPERS use up a great deal of ink criticising financial institutions. But surely there are banks, insurance companies and financial advisers who do a good job and please most customers most of the time?

The aim of the Consumer Finance Awards, set up by The Guardian, The Observer and our personal finance magazine Money Observer and reported on page 21, is to discover which organisations are pleasing their customers.

Among the winners is, in the personal pensions category, Equitable Life. To many this will be baffling, given the dispute over the way the insurer cut guarantees on some pensions.

Many policyholders still clearly feel happy enough with Equitable to have voted for it, and the result underlines the tragedy of Equitable's situation. If this prompts renewed reflection at Equitable over the way it has treated its guaranteed annuity pensioners, the awards will have more than fulfilled their purpose.

fields.headline: Your faith in trusts
fields.standfirst: Joanna Slaughter hails unit trust and investment trust savings schemes - particularly within a tax-free wrapper
fields.trailText: Joanna Slaughter hails unit trust and investment trust savings schemes - particularly within a tax-free wrapper
fields.body:
Unit trust and investment trust savings schemes have always been a bargain. They allow those without capital to invest in a huge range of industrial and geographical sectors without paying an extortionate price. This is no small advantage in a marketplace where costs are weighted against smaller investors. The discipline of saving also largely eliminates timing headaches.

The schemes offer flexibility, an advantage not shared by regular-premium life insurance savings schemes or personal pensions. Plans can be cashed in at any time without penalty, and contributions can be waived, topped up or reduced.

In terms of value, if not take-up, these equity-based schemes have ruled supreme for some time. The coming of personal equity plans provided the extra advantage of tax-free dividends and capital gains, while retaining most, if not all, the flexibility of unit trust or investment trust savings.

However, unlike straightforward savings schemes, Peps could not offer entry to virtually every investment market, so non-Pepped savings plans continued to score for those wanting exposure to markets outside the EU. These schemes also remained useful for investors wanting to exceed the annual maximum investment for Peps.

With the advent of Isas (individual savings accounts) the balance of advantage has tilted even further towards unit trust or investment trust savings schemes within a tax-exempt wrapper. Not only do Isas offer tax benefits, they also provide access to a far wider range of investments than Peps. Almost every unit trust, Oeic and investment trust qualifies as an Isa, and the majority of Isas have a regular savings facility.

Some argue that the tax benefits of Isas are becoming increasingly modest and that their effect in enhancing investment returns on modest sums is correspondingly small, particularly when investors are not liable for capital gains tax. While this is true, it is no argument for not investing in Isas.

First, investors with Isas have no contact with the Inland Revenue. Investors with savings schemes outside an Isa have to account for them under self-assessment. Second, by placing investments in a tax shelter, investors are both grabbing the tax benefits and protecting some investment capital against an uncertain fiscal future. There is no guarantee that taxes on income and capital gains will not rise over the next 10 years.

With the vast majority of unit trust and Oeic savings schemes there is also no extra charge for the Isa wrapper. Investment trusts, however, often make a small extra charge for the Isa package. Foreign & Colonial, for example, has a £50 initial and £60 annual charge, plus 0.2 per cent dealing costs.

And while the likes of Edinburgh Fund Managers, Fidelity Investments, Finsbury Asset Management, Friends Ivory & Sime, Investec Guinness Flight, Pantheon and Personal Assets make no charges on their savings and investment schemes, the list of investment trust companies offering Isas with no charges is much shorter. It comprises Friends Ivory & Sime, Majedie Investments and Scottish Investment Trust, while Stewart Ivory has a 'free' Isa in that it is waiving the annual £35 Isa charge for two years.

Investment trust manage ment charges are lower than those levied on unit trusts and Oeics, so most investment trust Isas remain competitively priced. Nevertheless, investment trust aficionados need to be sure that any extra charge for an Isa wrapper does not wipe out all the tax benefits.

As a general rule, an Isa is likely to be the best choice for investors who want to make monthly contributions to a stock market fund, though above the annual Isa limit - £5,000 from next year - investors will have to use unit trust and investment trust savings schemes.

 Extracted from the March issue of 'Money Observer', on sale at newsagents for £3.50. For 12 issues at £31.97, a saving of £10, call 0870 870 1324 and quote ref: MYCG004.

webTitle: We can't enjoy the sun for worrying about clouds

fields.headline: We can't enjoy the sun for worrying about clouds
fields.standfirst: What will happen when my weather forecaster husband retires? Monica Neville asks  Margaret Dibben
fields.trailText: What will happen when my weather forecaster husband retires? Monica Neville asks Margaret Dibben.
fields.body:
MONICA NEVILLE

AGE: 56

LIVES IN: Aberdeen

OCCUPATION: Does not work outside the home

EARNS: Nil

MORTGAGE: £30,000 endowment

DEBTS: None

INVESTMENTS: (joint) £72,000 in equity-related investments, £40,000 in other savings

PENSIONS: Married woman's state pension, plus husband's

AIMS: To find out if they will have enough money to live on in retirement

Monica Neville is worried. She explains: 'As with, I suspect, many people in the run-up to retirement, I am becoming anxious as to just how comfortable we will be.'

She and her husband Timothy, have no money problems at the moment. They can comfortably afford their mortgage, they have been able to save quite a bit, and their two sons are grown up and self-sufficient. But Monica is concerned about the income they will have to live on once Timothy retires. She wants to know whether they ought to restrict their spending now to ensure they will have enough later on.

She explains: 'It has got to the stage when my first thought about any expenditure of a vaguely major nature, such as a modest holiday or having the bathroom retiled is: Can we afford it? We can afford it now, but can we afford to eat into our savings?'

She does not know how much income Timothy's pensions will produce, nor how much they will need to live on. She adds sadly: 'Some of the pleasure has gone out of life because of all this worrying.'

Timothy will retire in 2007 when he is 65. He is a weather forecaster on offshore oil rigs. His basic salary is around £24,000, although actual pay depends on overtime. He will get a Civil Service pension based on some 14 years' previous service, paying around £3,500 a year. In his present job, he is in a non-contributory company pension scheme, but his employer contributes only £290 a month and, since 1983, his pensions have grown to just £95,500. He also has a free-standing AVC worth £34,000, but stopped paying into this in 1998 because he thought he had been sold the wrong product.

Instead, every spare penny is going, or has gone, into unit trusts, investment trusts, Peps, Isas, Tessa, and 'any other scheme I can find', says Monica. She has thought carefully about what to buy, so these are spread across the UK, Europe, US and the Far East.

But she still feels she needs to save as much as she can, particularly in Isas. This may involve switching some of the unit trusts outside Peps or Isas: 'I plan to save the maximum in maxi Isas, using money from salary and unit trust or share sales.

She pleads: 'If you were able to help set my mind at rest and give me some idea of how much income we can expect in retirement, I would be extremely grateful.'

Adviser 1: Ian Millward

Monica is sensible to put retirement at the top of her agenda: they still have seven years to save.

Timothy's pension seems low. They should check which fund the money is paid into: this close to retirement, they should not take too much risk. It may not be worth restarting the FSAVCs, as annuity rates are poor at the moment.

They will almost certainly need investment income to supplement their pensions. They should choose investments from which they can withdraw 5 per cent a year after tax but where capital keeps pace with inflation. Based on their current savings, they could draw income of £5,000 to £6,000.

Monica is right to want to put the maximum into Isas, but if this involves selling shares or unit trusts, cost is the issue. She could use the windfall shares to part-fund a Maxi Isa. But, if she wants to use her existing unit trusts, the best policy is to buy them back with the current manager. Many, but not all, groups take the pragmatic approach that it is in their interests to hang on to the money so the cost can be minimal. Monica should check beforehand in case they try to charge a new bid-offer spread.

 Ian Millward works for Bath-based Chase de Vere

Adviser 2: Paul Garwood

Timothy should get pension valuations from the Civil Service, his personal pension and the Benefits Agency. The Civil Service pension could provide around £3,650 a year, increasing with inflation and including a 50 per cent widow's pension.

His personal pension, based on 7 per cent growth, should give about £220,000 at retirement to buy an annuity. This could provide £15,400 with no reduction on Timothy's death, or £17,160 halving on his death, or £20,350 with no pension for Monica.

They have £72,000 in stock market-based investments, and £40,000 in cash. They should regularly check that the interest they receive is competitive.

Their stock market investments might produce income of 2 per cent to 3 per cent, while cash deposits should pay at least 6 per cent. This provides an annual income of about £4,200, hopefully with capital growth.

My only concern is that, the starting pensions look reasonable, but they ought to consider inflation protection, either by taking a lower starting pension or by foregoing income in favour of capital growth.

 Paul Garwood works for Smith & Williamson in London

Advice is for guidance only.
