But Monica is concerned about the income they will have to live on once Timothy retires. She wants to know whether they ought to restrict their spending now to ensure they will have enough later on. She explains: 'It has got to the stage when my first thought about any expenditure of a vaguely major nature, such as a modest holiday or having the bathroom retiled is: Can we afford it? We can afford it now, but can we afford to eat into our savings?' She does not know how much income Timothy's pensions will produce, nor how much they will need to live on. She adds sadly: 'Some of the pleasure has gone out of life because of all this worrying.' Timothy will retire in 2007 when he is 65. He is a weather forecaster on offshore oil rigs. His basic salary is around £24,000, although actual pay depends on overtime. He will get a Civil Service pension based on some 14 years' previous service, paying around £3,500 a year. In his present job, he is in a non-contributory company pension scheme, but his employer contributes only £290 a month and, since 1983, his pensions have grown to just £95,500. He also has a free-standing AVC worth £34,000, but stopped paying into this in 1998 because he thought he had been sold the wrong product. Instead, every spare penny is going, or has gone, into unit trusts, investment trusts, Peps, Isas, Tessa, and 'any other scheme I can find', says Monica. She has thought carefully about what to buy, so these are spread across the UK, Europe, US and the Far East. But she still feels she needs to save as much as she can, particularly in Isas. This may involve switching some of the unit trusts outside Peps or Isas: 'I plan to save the maximum in maxi Isas, using money from salary and unit trust or share sales. She pleads: 'If you were able to help set my mind at rest and give me some idea of how much income we can expect in retirement, I would be extremely grateful.' Adviser 1: Ian Millward Monica is sensible to put retirement at the top of her agenda: they still have seven years to save. Timothy's pension seems low. They should check which fund the money is paid into: this close to retirement, they should not take too much risk. It may not be worth restarting the FSAVCs, as annuity rates are poor at the moment. They will almost certainly need investment income to supplement their pensions. They should choose investments from which they can withdraw 5 per cent a year after tax but where capital keeps pace with inflation. Based on their current savings, they could draw income of £5,000 to £6,000. Monica is right to want to put the maximum into Isas, but if this involves selling shares or unit trusts, cost is the issue. She could use the windfall shares to part-fund a Maxi Isa. But, if she wants to use her existing unit trusts, the best policy is to buy them back with the current manager. Many, but not all, groups take the pragmatic approach that it is in their interests to hang on to the money so the cost can be minimal. Monica should check beforehand in case they try to charge a new bid-offer spread.  Ian Millward works for Bath-based Chase de Vere Adviser 2: Paul Garwood Timothy should get pension valuations from the Civil Service, his personal pension and the Benefits Agency. The Civil Service pension could provide around £3,650 a year, increasing with inflation and including a 50 per cent widow's pension. His personal pension, based on 7 per cent growth, should give about £220,000 at retirement to buy an annuity. This could provide £15,400 with no reduction on Timothy's death, or £17,160 halving on his death, or £20,350 with no pension for Monica. They have £72,000 in stock market-based investments, and £40,000 in cash. They should regularly check that the interest they receive is competitive. Their stock market investments might produce income of 2 per cent to 3 per cent, while cash deposits should pay at least 6 per cent. This provides an annual income of about £4,200, hopefully with capital growth. My only concern is that, the starting pensions look reasonable, but they ought to consider inflation protection, either by taking a lower starting pension or by foregoing income in favour of capital growth.  Paul Garwood works for Smith & Williamson in London Advice is for guidance only.

webTitle: Design is the key to a bloodless renovation

fields.headline: Design is the key to a bloodless renovation
fields.standfirst: To get what you want you need to know what you want - before the builders start, writes  Robert Liebman
fields.trailText: When we employ builders to renovate our houses and flats, many things can go wrong - and at least some of them usually do.
fields.body:
When we employ builders to renovate our houses and flats, many things can go wrong - and at least some of them usually do.

Even if home owners are lucky enough to end up with a builder who is not a cowboy, they often harm their own cause by settling for a poor design - or no design at all.

During even moderate renovations, our homes become building sites, more money than we are comfortable with is at stake and emotions are raw. Even successful renovations rarely end with a beaming proud owner and a builder paid in full. Relief that it is finally over is the usual order of the day.

'To get what you want, you have to know what you want,' says a man for whom that sentiment is easy to express. Michael Holmes gets plenty of on-the-job training, having built his own house a few years ago, he is now renovating a 1960s bungalow. He is also the editor of Homebuilding and Renovating magazine.

For most people and most renovations, there is simply too much to learn and too little time in which to learn it. A few years ago, surgeon Tom Rosenbaum bought a house in west London which already had an extended kitchen and a loft room from a renovation completed by a previous owner.

'I was dissatisfied with the style and the quality,' says Rosenbaum. 'Style is personal and subjective. The loft was poorly done to begin with, and it had a bad old roof.'

Now he has a well insulated house with underfloor heating, a new improved roof and bathrooms and toilets where he wants them. He also found some evidence that previous renovations were, by any objective measures, shabby.

'I trusted my builder, who had done excellent work for some neighbour friends of ours. That was the key to my approach. He brought specialists in and he told me in advance what he would be doing,' says Rosenbaum, who is basically satisfied now that the three-month ordeal is over.

But Mark Brinkley, author of The Self-Builder's Bible, notes that relying on your builder can mean being constrained by his limitations: 'Many builders stay with the archaic, the tried and tested. Technology is coming along, bringing a lot of new changes. Builders have every reason to be wary because many don't keep up, and can screw up badly.'

Rosenbaum paid the emotional and financial price for previous shoddy work. There is no doubt that the originally renovated loft, like a sauna in summer and like an ice store in winter, was a half-time room at full cost.

'Of course, I would have liked more time to read and do research,' says Rosenbaum. 'I also would have liked time to be there with the builders, to tell them where to put the sockets and all sorts of other things. But they understood my gut feelings and they stuck to budget. Come back in five years and we will see how it is holding up. That will be the real test.'

Holmes, who admits to making more than his share of errors, says: 'Home owners tend to shop for and take the cheapest they can find, often because they feel they have to for financial reasons. Only afterwards do they realise they had choices, although people are reluctant to admit mistakes.'

'Design is not an added extra, and the cost of design is more than justified. Investing in good design includes selecting quality materials,' Holmes adds. 'My advice is: don't buy on price alone.'

'The most obvious choice for a designer,' says Holmes, 'is an architect. But not all architects really listen to their clients. Interview several and get a feel for how they react to you. When architects are left to their own devices, you'll get what the architect wants, not what you want.'

The Royal Institute of British Architects (Riba) has an advisory scheme under which it provides the names of three architects in your area. 'Riba's scheme is very targeted,' says Holmes. 'If you want a renovation in the arts & crafts style, Riba can supply specialists in that style.'

You can hire an architect to do only the basic design, or they can supervise the entire project. Full-time supervision may be advisable for some large-scale or complex projects, or where the client will be away from the premises.

But Holmes notes that, in addition to being more expensive, some architects are not very good at supervising builders.

An alternative is to hire an architectural technologist. 'They are less highly qualified and usually cheaper than an architect and may actually be better for renovations,' notes Holmes. 'Some architectural technologists may do nothing other than renovations, whereas architects tend to concentrate on entire house design.'

The British Institute of Architectural Technologists (Biat) will send you a directory listing members in your area.

Architects concentrate on design, whereas 'an architectural technologist will be more hands-on and focus on the right products and performance for your job', says Holmes.

He urges a third, often-overlooked option. 'There are designers who have no professional qualifications at all, but renovations are their livelihood, and this may be the best option,' Holmes says.

'This is especially if one comes to you via a recommendation. Otherwise, they advertise in the Yellow Pages. This is a chancy way to hire anyone. You must check them out carefully, follow up references and see samples of their work.'

The Interior Decorator and Design Association (Idda) brings interior designers and decorators into the picture.

'Decorators deal only with furniture and furnishings, but designers concentrate on spatial and structural matters,' says a spokesperson for the association.

Riba: 020 7580 5533;

Biat: 020 7278 2206;

Idda: 020 7349 0800.

Mark Brinkley's 'Housebuilder's Bible: The Millennium Edition' is for renovators as well as self-builders and provides a wealth of information on fixtures, fittings, rooms, materials, costings, safety and much else. It costs £18 from Rodelia Ltd; tel: 01223 290230: or mark@brinkley.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: High price of Serps scandal
fields.trailText: Barely known, much less understood, by a large section of the population, the acronym Serps - the State Earnings Related Pension Scheme - refers to the state pension scheme that supplements employees' basic state retirement benefit.
fields.body:
Barely known, much less understood, by a large section of the population, the acronym Serps - the State Earnings Related Pension Scheme - refers to the state pension scheme that supplements employees' basic state retirement benefit.

Many middle-aged people seek information from the Department of Social Security on how much they are likely to get. But many of those who have done so in the past decade were given the wrong information, and only belatedly discovered that, if they died, their spouse would get half the amount of Serps pension they had been led to expect.

The Government announced proposals for correcting the problem - known as the Serps misselling scandal - last week, to a howl of protest from campaigners for the elderly.

Here is a guide to what is going on and what to do if you are affected:

What went wrong?

In 1986 the Conservative government announced that from April 2000 the widows or widowers of people who had been receiving Serps top-up pensions would get half the pension their spouse received while alive. The change takes effect when the partner dies after the implementation date. But it was not until 1996 that DSS leaflets mentioned the change, and for years DSS staff have been telling people that full Serps pensions would apply. This meant that they had made no plans to replace the lost spouses' pension with private pensions or investments.

How much is at stake for the people who are affected?

At present, the average Serps payment is £20 for men and £12 for women. So widows of Serps recipients would see their incomes cut to £10 a week.

So what's to be done?

The Government has delayed the starting date for the new system until October 2002. No one whose spouse dies before then will be affected. Meanwhile, any one who can prove they were misled by the DSS can apply to have their full Serps spouses' pension protected.

How would I prove that I was misled?

With some difficulty. There are no records of who said what in exchanges between DSS staff and the public. So those who do not have a letter containing the incorrect information may have a struggle.

That all sounds like hard work. Couldn't the Government have just scrapped the plan?

This is what charity Age Concern believes should be done. A spokeswoman says: 'It is wrong for the onus to be placed on the individual. It is the Government, not just this one but also the previous one, that has failed to inform people.'

It wants the Government to invite all Serps contributors to make a claim and is considering taking legal action under European human rights legislation.

If the average loss for a widow is just £10 a week, surely the Government could have afforded to scrap the change?

That sum may not sound much, but when multiplied across a rising number of pensioners over a lengthy period, it mounts up. The Government's own estimates say that by postponing the change to 2002 it will lose £2.5 billion. But the National Audit Office believes this understates the potential cost. If a third of those potentially affected were to claim successfully, the cost would rise by another £5.7bn. For each extra 10 per cent of successful claims the cost rises by a further £1.9bn.

When would I be able to make a claim?

The DSS will begin to consider applications from an as-yet-unannounced date next year.

How can I get more information?

The DSS's helpline is 0845 600 6116; Age Concern can be called on 0800 009966.

fields.headline: Real world
fields.trailText: A strong pound and low interest rates in Europe are bringing property in holiday spots within reach, says a survey by Abbey National. Sales to Britons of homes in France and Italy are up 75 per cent.
fields.body:
A strong pound and low interest rates in Europe are bringing property in holiday spots within reach, says a survey by Abbey National. Sales to Britons of homes in France and Italy are up 75 per cent.

A two-bedroom flat in Tuscany would cost around £50,000. Villas in Tenerife could start at £100,000, or nearer £200,000 on the Costa Brava. In Nice you should get a two-bedroom apartment for £80,000 if you are prepared to live away from the seafront.

fields.headline: What you could get
fields.trailText: Working Families Tax Credit is aimed at up to 1.4 million families in which at least one parent is working for at least 16 hours a week. It was introduced last October to make it easier for parents to stay in work.
fields.body:
Working Families Tax Credit is aimed at up to 1.4 million families in which at least one parent is working for at least 16 hours a week. It was introduced last October to make it easier for parents to stay in work.

There are four elements to it: a £52.30 basic tax credit per family; an extra credit of £11.05 if one parent works more than 30 hours a week: tax credits for each child, starting at £19.85; and a childcare tax credit paying up to 70 per cent of childcare costs.

You need to be individually assessed to see if you qualify. Some families will get just a few pounds; others will get more than £100 a week.

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: HSBC Fixed Income Isa
fields.trailText: HSBC Fixed Income Isa
fields.body:
Contact: 0800 299 299 or contact local branch

Aim: To provide a fixed, tax-free income, rising from 6 per cent in the first year to 10 per cent in the fifth.

Bells & whistles: The fund will pay 6 per cent in the first year, 6.5 in the second, 7 in the third, 7.5 in the fourth and 10 in the fifth. Investors can choose to take their income quarterly or roll it up, giving them a total return of 41 per cent at the end of the five-year term.

How it works: The fund is set up as a Dublin-based company, whose shares are held in a tax-free Isa. Income is pre-determined, but return of capital is linked to the performance of the FTSE 100 index. Provided the index is no lower at the end of the five-year period than at the start, investors will get a full return of capital. But if the FTSE 100 has fallen, investors will receive an amount reduced directly in proportion to the fall in the index. Investors can also transfer existing Peps into the fund.

Minimum: £3,000

Charges: Built into the product

Tax: Free of capital gains and income tax.

Risk: Low to medium.

Should you invest? Martyn Laverick of Bath adviser Chartwell says: 'We like the fact that the starting yield of 6 per cent is only slightly lower than many corporate bond funds, and it rises to a decent 10 per cent by the end.' As to capital risk, Laverick points out that investors who put money into the stock market the day before the 1987 crash recovered their stake plus gains within five years.

Chris Wicks of Glossop adviser Bridgewater says the Fixed Income Isa is good, provided investors understand it is not risk-free. 'Although the FTSE 100 has gone up over most five-year periods,' he says, 'the number of technology stocks has made it much more volatile.

Points out of 10: Laverick - 7, Wicks - 7.

webTitle: Beware the lure of the new boss

fields.headline: Beware the lure of the new boss
fields.trailText: It is not hard to see why British Airways should have decided to ditch Bob Ayling. In the four years since he took over as chief executive, BA shares have underperformed their FTSE 100 peers by more than 60 per cent. In the past year alone its price has almost halved. That is partly a reflection of a poor climate for airline operators but, analysts agree, BA's troubles owe a great deal to the Ayling effect. Surely, a change of pilot will allow the shares to take off again.
fields.body:
It is not hard to see why British Airways should have decided to ditch Bob Ayling. In the four years since he took over as chief executive, BA shares have underperformed their FTSE 100 peers by more than 60 per cent. In the past year alone its price has almost halved. That is partly a reflection of a poor climate for airline operators but, analysts agree, BA's troubles owe a great deal to the Ayling effect. Surely, a change of pilot will allow the shares to take off again.

Not necessarily. An analysis of the record of companies which have abruptly ejected their bosses - a list which includes such luminaries as BP, Barclays, Sainsbury and Rank - shows that a change of manager does not always bring a change in its share price performance.

In the short term, the news is often welcomed. Sackings are often preceded by months of speculation about the chief executive's tenure. The financial performance will have been poor and the company may have lost the confidence of investors and analysts. The prospect of change, any change, is welcomed. The bounce in BA's share price following Ayling's departure is typical.

Within weeks, however, doubts start to creep in. Companies which are reduced to firing their chief executives do not normally have a successor in place. Often the chairman or some other non-executive acts as caretaker until a new appointment is made, a process that can take months. In the meantime the business drifts, key staff can be tempted away and those who remain spend much of their time worrying about their own, rather than the company's, future. The City gets worried and the shares start to drift again.

The appointment of a successor does not always arrest the slide - ask Luc Vandevelde at Marks & Spencer or Matthew Barrett at Barclays. Even if the person recruited is talented and respected, like Sir Peter Davis at Sains bury, they will often have a difficult job simply stabilising the new company before they can start to improve the business. Assuming they succeed - and not all of them will - it can take years before that success is reflected in the share price.

Sainsbury, Rank, Barclays, NatWest and Mirror Group are among companies that have ditched their chief executives in the past 18 months. Of those, the last has since done well, but only because it has merged with Trinity Group.

Barclays is back where it started when Martin Taylor left in November 1998 and Rank has dropped a further 30 per cent since Andrew Teare departed. Going fur ther back, shares in Pilkington are now worth just 40 per cent of what they were, relative to the market, when Paolo Scaroni took over in May 1997.

One of the few exceptions is BP, which has gone from strength to strength since Robert Horton was ousted in 1992. But that was because they already had an excellent insider to take his place, in the shape of David - now Lord - Simon.

The moral is not to get carried away by excitement over a change of boss. Buying on the back of a management change is seldom a sensible strategy. Instead, you should look for well-run companies where the lines of succession are already established.

An analysis of the record of companies which have abruptly ejected their bosses - a list which includes such luminaries as BP, Barclays, Sainsbury and Rank - shows that a change of manager does not always bring a change in its share price performance. In the short term, the news is often welcomed. Sackings are often preceded by months of speculation about the chief executive's tenure. The financial performance will have been poor and the company may have lost the confidence of investors and analysts. The prospect of change, any change, is welcomed. The bounce in BA's share price following Ayling's departure is typical. Within weeks, however, doubts start to creep in. Companies which are reduced to firing their chief executives do not normally have a successor in place. Often the chairman or some other non-executive acts as caretaker until a new appointment is made, a process that can take months. In the meantime the business drifts, key staff can be tempted away and those who remain spend much of their time worrying about their own, rather than the company's, future. The City gets worried and the shares start to drift again. The appointment of a successor does not always arrest the slide - ask Luc Vandevelde at Marks & Spencer or Matthew Barrett at Barclays. Even if the person recruited is talented and respected, like Sir Peter Davis at Sains bury, they will often have a difficult job simply stabilising the new company before they can start to improve the business. Assuming they succeed - and not all of them will - it can take years before that success is reflected in the share price. Sainsbury, Rank, Barclays, NatWest and Mirror Group are among companies that have ditched their chief executives in the past 18 months. Of those, the last has since done well, but only because it has merged with Trinity Group. Barclays is back where it started when Martin Taylor left in November 1998 and Rank has dropped a further 30 per cent since Andrew Teare departed. Going fur ther back, shares in Pilkington are now worth just 40 per cent of what they were, relative to the market, when Paolo Scaroni took over in May 1997. One of the few exceptions is BP, which has gone from strength to strength since Robert Horton was ousted in 1992. But that was because they already had an excellent insider to take his place, in the shape of David - now Lord - Simon. The moral is not to get carried away by excitement over a change of boss. Buying on the back of a management change is seldom a sensible strategy. Instead, you should look for well-run companies where the lines of succession are already established.

fields.headline: Timekeepers of the  century
fields.standfirst: The Rolex may be ostentatiously fashionable, but demand is pushing up the price of the reliable Omega.  John Windsor on a sign of the times
fields.trailText: The Rolex may be ostentatiously fashionable, but demand is pushing up the price of the reliable Omega. John Windsor on a sign of the times
fields.body:
What is a Sixties Rolex Oyster watch doing on a lorry driver's wrist in a transport caff? Well, apart from impressing people, it is portable wealth that in hard times can be converted into cash - perhaps £500 from a dealer for a stainless steel Rolex Oyster, or £2,000, if he is lucky, for an Oyster Perpetual Chronometer, Explorer model.

Pawnbrokers love Rolexes, whereas dealers, auctioneers and 'wristie' aficionados shake their heads over them, saying they are over-hyped. They are not hand-made; Rolex's production line churns out 200,000 of them a year, compared with the mere 10,000-15,000 genuinely hand-made watches assembled by the skilled craftsmen of Patek Philippe.

But that's Rolex for you. They are in a class of their own, a singular example of a commodity that holds its value because of constant demand by the undiscerning - rather than the opinion of connoisseurs. Never mind what the experts say; most people still think Rolex is the best watch you can buy - so they remain valuable.

Richard Chadwick, watch specialist at Christie's South Kensington, in London, names two other makes, apart from Patek Philippe, that are almost as well known as Rolex: Cartier and Vacheron & Constantin.

As timepieces, they may be better value than Rolex, but they are more vulnerable to changes in fashion and ups and downs in the economy. Rolex prices were hardly shaken during the recession of the early Nineties, whereas Patek Philippe prices fell by up to two-thirds, especially at the top end of the market.

Classic watches are luxuries, the first items to be unloaded when unemployment looms. But whereas discerning City slickers may rush to trade in their Patek Philippes, undiscerning lorry drivers tend to hang on to their Rolexes until the bailiffs knock.

Watch prices fell two years ago, perhaps because of the strength of the pound, but are now on the mend. Private buyers are rapidly overcoming their fear of auctions and bidding against dealers - having realised that they can buy a secondhand watch at auction for as little as a third of its retail price and half the price asked by dealers. About 30 per cent of bidders at Christie's South Kensington's watch sales are private buyers - double the number three years ago.

The result is that the market is being driven increasingly by fashion. But - investors note - because private buyers are becoming more discerning, the fashion is to buy makes whose quality has gone unrecognised: the opposite of the Rolex syndrome.

Chadwick tips as up-and-comers these lesser-known quality watches: Breguet, Audemars Piguet, Jaeger Le Coultre and Blancpain. But his favourite is Omega. Until recently, Omegas were regarded as second- division, mainly because their bold, chunky Seventies designs had become unfashionable. They are now regarded as period pieces. Omega craftsmanship overtook Rolex's between 1930 and 1950, scoring a greater number of impressive observatory certificates for timekeeping in extreme cold and heat.

It was the first make to be chosen as official timekeeper for the Olympic Games, in 1932, and the RAF chose them for its servicemen during the war. Omega's highly accurate chronometer model, launched in 1952, had overtaken Rolex in sales by 1958.

But while Rolex's publicity successes tend to be remembered - the first woman Channel swimmer of 1927 wore one, Sherpa Tensing conquered Everest in one, and Paul Newman had one named after him - Omega's have been forgotten - except, perhaps, for the triumph of Neil Armstrong's Omega Speedmaster Professional, which he wore as he became the first man on the moon in 1969. Omega watches have since been on more than 50 space missions.

Three years ago, you could pick up an Omega Speedmaster Professional at auction for £400 or less. At Chadwick's dedicated Omega auction last November, marking the thirtieth anniversary of the moon landing, a Speedmaster Professional 1994 sold for £1,092 (including 15 per cent premium) and another, from 1990, for £970.

As a whole, classic Omegas that sold for £250 at auction three years ago are now pushing £1,000. They will rise further, judging by the demand from educated private buyers for historic, collectable models. Omega led the race to make a commercial waterproof watch and its Marine model of the Thirties, with ingenious sliding case, fetched £2,070 at the November auction, against an estimate of £1,000-£1,500. Three years ago, the likely price would have been between £300 and £500.

Among other quality up-and-comers is Jaeger Le Coultre, especially its clever Reverso model, with a reversible dial pivoted in a frame. It was originally designed in the early Thirties for British Army polo players in India, who kept smashing their watch dials. They are still in production.

A recently made one is estimated at £2,000-£3,000 in Christie's South Kensington's next sale this month. A couple of years ago, only £1,500 might have been expected. A Thirties Reverso in the same sale is estimated at £1,500-£2,500. It might have fetched £1,000 a couple of years ago.

The only way to ensure that the watch you buy is in perfect condition is to buy new. Unlike dealers, auctioneers give no guarantees. And a few dealers maintain that a secondhand watch that has gone without cleaning for two years is irreversibly past its best. Chadwick disputes this. Doubts about condition are probably the biggest factor discouraging bidding at auction by private buyers, who do not know their way around a watch's innards. But is the premium price of the brand-new worth it, when at auction you can buy recently made watches for as little as a third of their retail value?

All watches sold at Christie's have had their insides examined by the auctioneers, and you can ask for a free condition report on the watches you intend to bid for.

More and more private buyers are plucking up the courage to compete with dealers in the saleroom. After all, a dealer must drop out of the bidding if the bids approach the price at which he knows he can sell at a profit. Private buyers may vex dealers by pumping up prices, but many privateers are carrying off watches at below dealers' prices.

Watches seem likely to become one of those auction markets - such as furniture, modern design and contemporary art - that will reach sustainable highs because of pressure of demand from private buyers.

In this month's auction, will it be a private buyer or a dealer who snaps a up an eccentric Vacheron & Constantin watch with a map of Thailand on its dial, at an estimated £12,000-£15,000? It was bought brand new only last December - for a whopping £38,000 - and comes complete with box, booklet and original packaging.

If you are really, really, smart, you will already have put your name down for a new Cosmograph Daytona, with the intention of bunging it straight into auction. The retail price is £3,300, but there is a waiting list and they have been selling at auction for between £4,000 and £5,000 - a nice little earner. The make? Rolex.

 Important Watches, Christie's South Kensington, 29 March (2pm). Call 020-7581 7611

fields.headline: Service gets its own reward
fields.standfirst: Readers name the financial services companies that care for customers
fields.trailText: Readers name the financial services companies that care for customers
fields.body:
Do you think customer service has been replaced by customer delight. Maybe it has, but financial services providers cannot afford to become complacent about consumers, even at a time of unprecedented growth.

The sobering message for banks, building societies, insurers, fund management houses and stockbrokers during the current boom is this: you may have more reasons than ever to think well of yourselves, but your customers may not be so impressed. And, in the final analysis, cashflow comes from customers, not from your shareholders.

The latest customer service surveys in the US make interesting reading. The National Quality Research Center at the University of Michigan Business School, which conducts annual surveys of the customers of 175 companies and five government agencies, discovered that satisfaction overall stands at 72.8 out of a possible 100, down 1.4 points from its level five years ago.

In other words, while the Dow Jones nearly tripled and corporate profits shattered all records, overall customer satisfaction actually declined. Why should this be? Is it that people have become more demanding? Yes, and customers also want greater value for their money.

No one doubts the importance of good service - repeated studies tell us that customers who receive it will stimulate new business by each telling up to 12 other people about it, while those treated badly will tell their tales of woe to up to 20 potential customers. It is also reckoned that 80 per cent of those who feel their complaints are handled fairly will stay loyal.

Similarly, you won't find a company willing to admit it is being complacent about customer service. But some go dangerously close.

The fact that the economy continues to boom even though customer satisfaction is falling may suggest to some firms that providing value is not actually that crucial to financial performance.

New challenges for customer care have come with the rapid growth in shopping and investing via call centres and the Internet. But countless reports of well known websites failing to fulfil orders seem to convey the message that if a company feels it is bold and innovative enough, the customer does not seem to matter.

Even more damaging, however, is failure to keep in touch with customers - this is a chronic weakness in many companies, and one that tends to become acute when good times encourage complacency.

Providing high quality customer service in financial services is not easy.

On paper it looks simple, and anyone can conduct market research. But it is another matter entirely to look the customer in the eye and say, 'I really want you to tell me what you think,' and then to act willingly and quickly on the feedback.

The Consumer Finance Awards are an opportunity for readers of the The Observer, Money Observer and the Guardian to reward those financial services providers which have demonstrated such a willingness to listen, to learn - and to act.

webTitle: Sound advice from the ethical bankers

fields.headline: Sound advice from the ethical bankers
fields.standfirst:
The Co-op's team of highly trained IFAs come with a good recommendation
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Co-operative Bank Financial Advisers (CBFA), a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Co-operative Bank, is the outright winners of the award for best customer service in the independent financial advisers category.
fields.body:
Co-operative Bank Financial Advisers (CBFA), a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Co-operative Bank, is the outright winners of the award for best customer service in the independent financial advisers category.

CBFA has been going in its current form for 11 years and is the bank's only means of promoting regulated financial services to its customers and others. Unlike its high street rivals, which all have a tied advisory or bancassurance operation promoting the investment, life and pensions products of just one supplier, the Co-op has chosen the independent advisory route. The 75 IFAs working for CBFA do not just sell Co-op Bank products, but offer a full financial planning service, recommending the best products on the market to suit a client's needs.

CBFA's services are available to anyone though, historically, the majority of clients are Co-op Bank customers who come through branch and telephone banking referrals. Its concentration of advisers tend to mirror geographically the locations of the Co-op Bank, so they are strongest in the North East, North West, the Midlands and South Wales.

'We offer a very good service from highly trained individuals,' says CBFA managing director David Cox. 'They are all recruited from within the industry and we insist they have the top level (Level 3) Financial Planning Certificate plus a minimum of two to three years' experience.'

When a new client contacts CBFA, an initial fact-finding meeting is set up within a few days at their home, office or the nearest Co-op bank branch. At this meeting, the adviser collects all the mandatory information about the client's finances, and then goes away and comes up with recommendations.

Reflecting the parent bank's ethical investment philosophy, a key part of CBFA's financial planning questionnaire asks whether customers want an ethical slant on their investments.

'Around 50 per cent go for that and every one of our IFAs is able to advise on ethical investments,' Cox says. 'I think the fact that we offer the opportunity to invest ethically is important to many of our clients and is one thing that makes us different from other IFA groups.'

Clients are told that they can choose to pay for advice on a set-fee basis, a commission basis (where the Ifa will take a commission on any regulated product the client buys), or a combination. 'Some 90 per cent of our clients go for commission basis because that way, if they decide not to go ahead with our recommendations, they know they won't be out of pocket,' Cox says.

The adviser then takes the information away, leaving the client with the guarantee that they will return within 10 working days with their recommendations.

'The philosophy is to offer a full financial planning service, which means getting enough information to be able to recommend what we believe the client needs and not what he perceives he needs,' Cox says.

'If, for example, a client comes to us with £20,000 to invest, but has a young family and no life cover, we will recommend that he puts part of the money into family protection products. And part of our financial planning policy dictates that a certain proportion of people's savings must be in emergency instant-access deposits.'

This award backs recent CBFA market research findings, which found that 90 per cent of its customers were, 'very or quite satisfied' with its service. When asked the most important factor influencing their decision to deal with CBFA, 31 per cent said it was because the advice was independent, 30 per cent because it was part of the Co-operative Bank and 19 per cent because of the bank's ethical policy.

fields.headline: New standards set for mortgages
fields.trailText: Standard Life Bank, launched in January 1998 as a wholly owned telephone bank subsidiary of Europe's largest mutual life insurance company, Standard Life, has won the award for best customer service in the mortgages category.
fields.body:
Standard Life Bank, launched in January 1998 as a wholly owned telephone bank subsidiary of Europe's largest mutual life insurance company, Standard Life, has won the award for best customer service in the mortgages category.

After starting with savings products, the bank launched its first mortgage product, Freestyle - one of the new breed of flexible mortgages - in January 1999. Freestyle has been so popular, particularly with remortgagers, that in the first year the bank acquired 10,000 borrowers, completed £4.1 billion worth of mortgage business and took 11.4 per cent of net new lending in the market.

With a standard variable rate of 6.75 per cent and a discounted rate of 6.06 per cent for the first six months (rates correct at time of going to press), there are no arrangement or compulsory insurance fees.

Freestyle allows the borrower after the first year to overpay by lump sums or increase monthly payments without penalty, thereby reducing the outstanding loan immediately. And, because interest is calculated each day, they receive the immediate benefit of any overpayment.

Borrowers can also choose to take up to two months a year as payment holiday.

Freestyle loans are made on the basis of 'affordability' tests rather than income multiples, which means customers may be offered more than they actually need to borrow. The surplus remains available to fund big expenses such as holidays, cars or home improvements.

The bank also prides itself on a rapid application process and well trained staff. 'We aim to reach the conditional offer stage after eight to nine minutes,' says managing director Neil Ross.

webTitle: Banking and the art of conversation

fields.headline: Banking and the art of conversation
fields.trailText: For a progressive forward-looking organisation which is regarded as a high-tech, leading-edge pioneer of remote banking, First Direct - winner of the best customer service overall category - has a refreshingly traditional explanation for its success.
fields.body:
For a progressive forward-looking organisation which is regarded as a high-tech, leading-edge pioneer of remote banking, First Direct - winner of the best customer service overall category - has a refreshingly traditional explanation for its success.

'It's our people,' says First Direct chief executive Alan Hughes. 'Our customers don't want to buy financial services. They want to feel good. They want reassurance that they are in control, that they are known as an individual.

'We're happy to show our competitors around our operations. Often we'll come to the end of the tour and they'll shake their heads and say, "but we still don't understand what it is that you do differently". Our people, we tell them, are the only difference.

'In the way that we recruit our people and manage them, we are encouraging them to treat the customers as their friends and to let their personalities shine through.'

To work at First Direct, conversational skills are of paramount importance. 'The ticket to the game may be the banking transaction, but customers don't remember the transaction,' says Hughes. 'But they do remember the conversation.'

First Direct has had the field to itself since it leapfrogged the banking world more than 10 years ago by offering the UK's first 24-hour telephone banking service. It now has almost a million customers and more are joining up - at the rate of 10,000 every month.

The bank's record on customer service is staggeringly impressive. In a recent NOP survey, 86 per cent of customers said that they were either 'extremely' or 'very' satisfied with the service it provides; 80 per cent said banking with First Direct was better than banking with other banks; and 76 per cent had recommended First Direct to friends and colleagues in the past 12 months.

Now 24-hour banking is an industry standard. Which bank doesn't have a telephone banking arm? So how has First Direct maintained its competitive edge? According to Hughes, more bank customers are transferring their accounts to First Direct than to any other bank.

'Customers want to be known as an individual,' explains Hughes. 'And when they call us again, they can pick up exactly from where they left off. It's as if the 4,000 of us are one. Even if you know that staff at your local branch, it's unlikely that you'll get that kind of attention to detail.'

According to Hughes, First Direct looks to the world of retail for its inspiration. 'Most of our customers bank only with us - but they do deal with other retailers, and that's who they judge us against.'

Hughes' favourite retailer? 'It would have to be the John Lewis Partnership, because when I talk to someone there it is evident that they care, that they want to serve you, that they're actually on your side.'

As might be expected, First Direct is investing heavily in Internet banking. But while other banks may have been quicker to roll out their websites, First Direct has been working at its own pace, trying to work out ways of injecting some personality online.

'We are dubbing our firstdirect.com initiative the Internet bank you can talk to,' says Hughes. 'The technology is changing, but the principles remain the same.

'One in five of our customers already deals with us via the screen. But we've found that while the routine enquiries are done over the screen, customers prefer to call us when they want to do something more complex. 'Banking with a screen enables us to give our customers a greater choice of information. It makes it simple for them to be in control, and it shifts the balance of power in their favour. We won't be afraid, for example, to give our customers information on what other products and services there are in the marketplace.

'Banks are only just learning about retailing. Some may say that giving customers more information is a dangerous strategy. But in our opinion the only dangerous strategy is not giving customers what they want.'

fields.headline: A little sparkle with customers
fields.trailText: Most banks find it difficult to get excited about such a bread-and-butter product as a cheque account. But for First Direct - the winner of the best current account provider category - cheque accounts are a vital means of establishing a relationship with its customers.
fields.body:
Most banks find it difficult to get excited about such a bread-and-butter product as a cheque account. But for First Direct - the winner of the best current account provider category - cheque accounts are a vital means of establishing a relationship with its customers.

Commercial director Peter Simpson says: 'Cheque accounts are at the heart of our business - a mechanism for us to deal with our customers every day, and we've developed all our infrastructures around the cheque account.'

According to Simpson, operating an effective and efficient cheque account service can be extremely complex: 'If you think about all the transactions which have to be processed every day, the humble cheque account is a much more complex product than savings, mortgages or credit cards.'

However, the key factor that differentiates the First Direct cheque account from others, he says, is how staff interact with customers. 'We have created a culture which people seem to enjoy and that comes across on the phone - a little sparkle with the customer.'

Simpson believes it's time to develop the cheque account further if customers are to continue receiving the quality of product and service they have come to expect.

'Our cheque account was very innovative 10 years ago, when it was the first to offer an overdraft buffer, but though our prices are OK, I'm not mad about our unauthorised overdraft charges or credit interest. The time for any organisation to invest in its products is when they're doing well, so we'll be addressing those issues soon.'

webTitle: Churchilll: innovative insurer that always likes to say yes

fields.headline: Churchilll: innovative insurer that always likes to say yes
fields.trailText: The 2,500 staff of Churchill, the UK's second biggest direct insurer, will perhaps be not altogether surprised to win the award for best customer service in car and home insurance.
fields.body:
The 2,500 staff of Churchill, the UK's second biggest direct insurer, will perhaps be not altogether surprised to win the award for best customer service in car and home insurance.

'We are genuinely passionate about service - it has always been the highest thing on our agenda,' says spokesperson Kay Gorman. 'Our aim is to deliver the unquestioned, publicly acknowledged best customer service in the insurance industry, and we are very, very dedicated to that.'

Chief executive Martin Long, who started Churchill in 1989, set the company tenet from day one: customers must be not just satisfied, but delighted.

'Following that philosophy through has paid off,' says Gorman. 'It means staff always question whether something can be done better and go that step further to help. If, for example, an assistant says they will phone a customer back within 48 hours, they'll aim to "delight" the customer by calling back sooner. Or if, say, a customer needs an insurance certificate urgently, we'll email the whole company to see if anyone can drop it off that day on their way home.'

Churchill started with 89 staff selling just car insurance direct to the public. A year later it added home cover and, more recently, travel and pet insurance. Now, with 1.35 million policyholders, it is the sixth largest motor insurer and number 17 in home insurance. It has 1,400 customer service assistants manning its main call centre in Bromley, south London, and a further 300 at its new call centre on Teesside.

The company was the first to provide a total telephone claims system. 'You make one call, quote your policy number and we deal with everything else from there, whether it be organising repairs, informing the police, advising third parties or replacing damaged or stolen goods,' Gorman says.

Churchill was the first motor insurer to set up its own national network of car crash repair centres.

Key to the company's customer philosophy is its internal motto, 'SYNN', which stands for: 'Say yes, not no.'

'For example, up to 20 per cent of our calls asking for a motor quote are deemed too high a risk by our computer system, which will generate a "no" quote,' Gorman says.

'But our staff won't automatically accept the computer's verdict. They are empowered to query this, look further and try to find a valid reason for saying yes.'

Staff can transfer calls from very high risk customers straight to Anglia Countrywide, a broker owned by Churchill that specialises in non-standard risks. This way 'we can help everyone who phones'.

Churchill's other successes include a Plain English Society Crystal Award for its literature and a British Standard award for service.

fields.headline: Stuck in house of horrors...
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.body:
I bought a terraced house in Salford in 1992 with a £29,000 100 per cent mortgage from Abbey National. The area has never been desirable but began to decline and I soon went into negative equity. Now large numbers of properties are empty.

Recently there has been a spate of arson attacks on neighbouring houses, so my house stands beside three empty and burnt ones. It is completely unsaleable and I feel vulnerable. Even students are advised not to rent here. How can I get out of this situation while minimising my losses? And what is my insurance position if my house stands empty?
CP, Salford

 Abbey National says your house seemed a sensible buy when its valuer priced it for a home loan. Now the bank agrees that the area has deteriorated.

Abbey told me that it is willing to discuss your problems, without realising that you have already tried to talk but found no one who would help - unless you stopped paying the mortgage. I have asked Abbey again, this time for the name of someone who is briefed about your situation and understands that you do not intend defaulting on the loan.

Your insurer may exclude cover for vandalism and theft if you left the house empty. Do nothing without telling your insurer.

Trade relations: Standards line

I provided my local Trading Standards department with information about a firm with which I had problems. I asked how many complaints they had received about this com pany but they refused to tell me, saying that to do so would put them at risk of legal action from the trader.
MW, Rochester

 Exactly what trading standards officers can say to the public is bound by the Data Protection Act, although they can use their discretion if they believe someone is an exceptional nuisance. They sometimes issue press releases to name and shame traders causing serious problems when they believe it is in the public interest.

But they have to be careful about releasing statistics. They might, for example, receive many complaints about one company that are all unfounded or even malicious; publishing this would give the wrong impression.

When you have lodged a complaint and your trading standards department investigates, they should tell you the outcome, even if this was to do nothing. But even then they would still not necessarily tell you everything they knew about that trader.

However, if they had taken court action, this puts information in the public domain and then they can tell you what happened. And if you were planning a civil action against the firm yourself, they should provide information from their files to help your case.

Blessed to give: Charity taxation

I have followed the tax rules for giving to charity but was confused to read that a £10 gift from a basic-rate taxpayer is worth £12.30 to the charity. Surely, if £10 represents 77 per cent of the gross amount, 100 per cent is £12.98 and a £10 gift is worth £12.98 to the charity?
SM, London

 The new Gift Aid rules abolish the £250 minimum needed to attract tax relief. The gross amount is the gift plus the tax relief: if you give £10, the income tax you paid when you earned that money was £2.30 so the gross amount equals £12.30.

If the £10 comes from a higher-rate taxpayer, the charity still reclaims £2.30 and the donor can reclaim the difference between basic and higher-rate tax (17 per cent) through the tax return. You could send this £1.70 to the charity as a fresh donation - the charity can again reclaim 23 per cent (40p) and you 17 per cent.

Share prices: Woolwich worry

I have 248 shares in Woolwich which I received when it became a bank. For the first two years, they did quite well and, I believe, were worth around £4,000 but recently they have dropped to about £2,800. My wife and I bought a car jointly last December and now I owe her £2,000. I need to cash my Woolwich shares to pay her but thought I would hang on until just before I am due to receive the dividend, when I understand that share prices tend to increase. Am I right?

If my wife agrees, I could leave the shares in Woolwich and hope that they build up over the next two or three years.
MF, London

 You have seriously miscalculated the Woolwich share price and never were as rich as you thought. The share price peaked at £4.30, making your 248 holding worth £1,066.40 at best. Banks are out of favour at the moment and now they are worth around £3 each, giving you £744.

So you will have to rethink your strategy. If your wife is prepared to wait, you might as well hang on to the shares for a few more years anyway. Or perhaps repay her a little each month out of your earnings.

Share prices may rise when they go ex-dividend: in theory buyers pay more because they, not the sellers, receive the next dividend payment. There is no guarantee that this will happen and, even if it did, you are trading a higher share price for missing the dividend.

Love Hertz? Debt did us part

I closed my Visa account with the Co-op Bank last August because someone I'd never heard of billed me for £230. The amount was eventually refunded by Visa, but now the amount has been billed again, although the account is closed. It turns out to be Hertz car rental, from whom I hired a car last May in France and paid for in full in advance. How can this happen?
JH, London

 Companies are entitled to put payments through credit card accounts after customers have left the premises, if customers still owe money. Sometimes this is done in error but closing the account does not wipe out any debt.

The Co-op says it did not refund the original £230 but put the money in suspension while it investigated your complaint. It has now heard back from Hertz which has provided evidence that, Co-op says, has convinced the bank that you did agree to the charge so Co-op is now billing you for the £230.

If you still dispute the payment, you will have to take it up with Hertz directly.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

webTitle: Dresdner RCM keeps its 37,000 pairs of eyes on the ball

fields.headline: Dresdner RCM keeps its 37,000 pairs of eyes on the ball
fields.trailText: For an unprecedented third year running, the winner of the Money Observer investment trust category - judged by the average net asset value return over five years - is Dresdner RCM Global Investors.
fields.body:
For an unprecedented third year running, the winner of the Money Observer investment trust category - judged by the average net asset value return over five years - is Dresdner RCM Global Investors.

The group has built up a strong investment process and backed this with good use of gearing. Its larger trusts have been in strong sectors such as Europe, the UK or International; only its Pacific Basin exposure has been through a small emerging markets trust.

Having 37,000 people keeping an eye out for investment opportunities undoubtedly helps the group stay ahead of the opposition. Dresdner's 'grassroots network' of contacts act as a sounding board for the group's industry-based research specialists. Simon White, who has headed investment trust operations since 1992, says it has been invaluable in alerting the group early to opportunities in technology-related sectors.

'In a fast-moving environment, it allows us to talk to those actually using the new technologies and avoid becoming either over-exuberant or missing the picture,' he says. 'It is a way of challenging analysts' perceptions.' Towards the end of last year, reveals White, the group was top-slicing many of its most successful holdings and reinvesting the proceeds in companies that had not yet caught the market's attention.

White claims Dresdner RCM is not dogmatically growth-oriented and has recently been assessing sectors such as oils and mining. What is not in doubt is that the group's focus on growth and early recognition of the telecoms revolution worked wonders for a number of its trusts last year. Charter European was well up in the European sector, and magnificent performances were posted by Brunner and Dresdner RCM Smaller Companies.

White says much of the credit is due to Stuart Fowler and his pan-European team.

Gearing has made a useful contribution to Dresdner RCM's success. Most of the larger trusts aim to maintain gearing at around 20 per cent, and Merchants took the chance to raise a £30 million debenture on very good terms last December.

The group has also done well because its largest trusts are in areas that have been buoyant over the past five years. Its lack of Far East exposure could become a disadvantage if Japan does as well as White expects.

However, the group has limited its recent trust launches to endowment policy trusts and one split-capital trust. White is wary of launching further splits given the high hurdle rates and complicated structures required to compete on yields.

fields.headline: Straight on narrow means
fields.standfirst: The system makes it very hard not to reoffend, former prisoner Mark Leech tells Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: MARK Leech learnt the finer points of credit card fraud in a borstal, or 'academy of crime', as they are known. 'The more time you spend in them, the more skills you acquire and the more criminally aware you become.'
fields.body:
MARK Leech learnt the finer points of credit card fraud in a borstal, or 'academy of crime', as they are known. 'The more time you spend in them, the more skills you acquire and the more criminally aware you become.'

Before going straight six years ago, Leech did time in 62 prisons. He was an angry prisoner, involved in riots, rooftop protests, fights and other kinds of trouble. Looking back, the 41-year-old chairman of the ex-offenders' charity, Unlock, sees that he was caught in a series of criminal Catch 22s.

Emotional deprivation was the start. Left to run wild as a child, he was sexually abused by the housemaster in a special school. 'To an eight-and-a half year old, the half hour's abuse seemed worth 23-and-a-half hours of feeling special. But at the age of 12, I walked into his flat one day and found him with another boy. In that second, my life changed completely.'

For the next 24 years he fought against authority - starting with petty theft. 'Money was a welcome by-product - but you're not motivated by money at that age. You're more motivated by doing something exciting which is criminal in nature.'

He recalls as typical his release from Winchester prison, aged 18, after 18 months for hotel burglary. 'I went to a hotel in Portsmouth with a cafe downstairs and miserable rooms upstairs. I had £21 as a discharge grant, which seemed like a fortune - the equivalent of a week's Income Support. When I went to the dole office to sign on, they told me I could not get any more money for two weeks. This is how the system works. My money was gone by the end of the first week and I needed to eat. So I burgled a hotel room while the people were downstairs.'

He lived off credit card fraud for a few days - but was caught and back inside within a fortnight. 'It's not easy to get a job with a criminal record. Far too often, people get so fed up being rejected that they get out the addresses of people they met inside, and they do a job.'

Like most other criminals, he says, he never felt guilt while stealing people's wallets or other belongings: 'Criminals very rarely have a conscience: if you did, you'd be racked with guilt.' Eventually, he ended up in a humane jail, Grendon Underwood in Buckinghamshire, where, in therapy and counselling, he analysed his criminality and set it aside. In 1994, he, actor Stephen Fry (another former prisoner and credit card fraud veteran) and others set up Unlock. A major campaign is to persuade the Benefits Agency to end the one-week Income Support shortfall that encourages so many to return to crime.

He also encourages financial institutions to give prisoners a second chance and allow them to open accounts. Nationwide is the best and most broad-minded, he says; Lloyds TSB is the worst. Another campaign is to prevent the disaster he expects will follow the start of the Criminal Records Agency by the end of this year - an easy way for employers to check on criminal records. Its effect will be to ban many ex-prisoners from getting honest work.

In his private life, things are improving - after the collapse of a four-year relationship, Leech is now living with someone again.

fields.headline: Coal close to £60m rescue
fields.trailText: The Government is close to agreeing an emergency aid package that could throw a lifeline to the 8,000 workers still employed in the British coal mining industry.
fields.body:
The Government is close to agreeing an emergency aid package that could throw a lifeline to the 8,000 workers still employed in the British coal mining industry.

The rescue plan, worth more than £60 million, has been promoted by Prime Minister Tony Blair and Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers and is due to be announced before the end of the month.

It would secure the immediate future of the Ellington colliery in the North East, which is scheduled to close at the end of the month with the loss of 400 jobs. It is thought Richard Budge, head of privatised operator RJB Mining - which owns the pit along with 12 others - has said he will keep it open for at least four years as part of the deal.

RJB's results, due at the beginning of March, were delayed by a month. They are expected to show losses of £130m.

The package follows months of lobbying by coalfield MPs, who met Blair in February to alert him to the dangers that imported coal - currently 30 per cent cheaper than UK mined coal - would destroy what is left of Britain's coal industry.

MPs told Blair and Byers that UK miners have made huge strides in productivity and efficiency - cutting production costs from £1.50 a gigajoule to £1.20 since privatisation in 1992.

They have pressed for temporary assistance, which would secure coal's future until changes in the energy market create greater opportunities.

Ministers and industry experts believe world prices for coal will rise, and that new trading arrangements for electricity, and changes to the way electricity is sent through an interconnector to France, will help UK coal secure markets.

Under the deal, aid could be paid to power stations to cover the difference between UK coal and imports. Alter natively, money could be paid to mining operators, or focused on individual pits.

Byers received a report on the options on Friday, which must now be agreed by other departments. It is not expected to be blocked: Byers is set to announce a deal before the Ellington deadline.

A DTI source said: 'This is likely to deliver a positive outcome for the industry.'

Barnsley MP Mick Clapham said: 'The fact that the Government is thinking positively about assistance for the coal industry is good for mining, good for quality jobs in mining and good for the industry. I am confident the Government has seen the value of a temporary package.'

webTitle: Once-great KIO set to sell off London assets

fields.headline: Once-great KIO set to sell off London assets
fields.trailText: The Kuwait Investment Office (KIO) is preparing to sell the rest of its industrial and property investments as part of a winding-down of most of its UK activities. The moves will gradually reduce the KIO, once one of the City's most powerful institutions, to a mere representative office in London.
fields.body:
The Kuwait Investment Office (KIO) is preparing to sell the rest of its industrial and property investments as part of a winding-down of most of its UK activities. The moves will gradually reduce the KIO, once one of the City's most powerful institutions, to a mere representative office in London.

The KIO is already selling three of London's leading private hospitals - the London Bridge, the Lister in Chelsea and the Devonshire in Marylebone - for up to £100 million. It is now understood to be considering selling Autobar, one of the UK's largest packaging companies, and more of its much-reduced St Martins property empire.

According to insiders, the KIO now possesses a portfolio of just $5-7 billion, and funds from sales are sent to Kuwait. That is a pale shadow of its former Eighties self. In its heyday, during the 1987 stock market crash, the KIO was powerful enough to snap up a 22 per cent stake in British Petroleum when the government's privatisation ran into trouble.

However, after the Gulf War in 1992, the KIO saw its Spanish investment empire, Grupo Torras, collapse with £2.5bn of debts amid allegations of fraud, corruption and political kickbacks. Last year it won a £300m civil action against former managers over the affair in the biggest corruption case to be brought in the English courts.

So far, however, legal costs have run to over £70m, insiders say, while less than £15m has been recovered. Two of the key defendants, - Sheikh Fahad al-Sabah and Khaled al-Sabah, both members of the Kuwaiti royal family - are taking the case to the Court of Appeal. Over recent months the KIO has been recalling Kuwaiti staff to the Middle East, while many senior British executives have also left. The Kuwait Petroleum Company, owner of the Q8 chain of petrol stations, is also understood to be winding down its London office for tax reasons.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: BP | Lastminute | Amvescap
fields.body:
Was it something we said? Our warning here was certainly timely given the setback over-hyped techno stocks finally suffered last week.

Don't be too lastminute.com, we said, about about buying back into 'old economy' basics, such as mining and oils, plus grossly undervalued specific shares in sectors like food and drink.

Well, over the week, blue chip mining shares leapt: Rio Tinto from 925p to 1033p, and Billiton from 242p to 297p.

Oils also staged a recovery, with BP advancing from 552p to 558p and Shell from 486p to 505p, to name but two. BP, of course, finally swallowed Burmah Castrol, a perennial bid favourite of ours and most of the market.

Meanwhile, shares in Lastminute.com ended the week at 392p compared with their 380p flotation price. Anyone who actually tried to sell their holdings late on Friday would have realised - guess what - the flotation price of 380p.

Tight holdings and even tighter share allocations mean the shares probably won't drop like a stone just yet.

But, when the techno cycle turns, you won't be able to sell at all. Because that's when the traders start marking down over-ramped stocks.

Pot-holers only
Moving from the stratospheric to the near subterranean, we notice that Sytner, the car dealer, is now trading on a prospective price-earnings ratio of just four times. If only rocket scientists can fathom many of these e-commerce 'opportunities', here it seems only potholers and cave-dwellers need apply.

True, the car market is going through the leanest and meanest of times, with demand hardly inspiring and the Competition Commission taking a close look at the whole of the market.

But Sytner is a business with a whacking great £500 million-plus of sales. And the firm is at the leading edge of consolidation, having just swallowed Ixion, which brings three Jaguar, two BMW, one Mercedes and five other dealerships on board.

House broker Charterhouse is forecasting profits this year of just £10m on sales of £530m, giving 26p of earnings.

At 114p, a discount to net asset value, the shares do not look to have much downside and may be a beneficiary of current market conditions.

Techno benefits
Amvescap, at 800p, was one of the beneficiaries of the techno-hiccup last week, as investors sought out oversold financial stocks. And so it should be.

The fund manager has an impressive track record, with results for 1999 once again coming in above expectations and showing a net inflow of £7 billion of funds in the past year.

At current levels, the shares are trading at just 1.9 per cent of estimated funds under management of £280bn this year. As broker Charles Stanley points out, that's far lower than the 2.4 per cent Amvescap has recently traded on and a shadow of the 3 per cent a takeover bid could bring. Using the lower figure gives a fair value of £10.10 for the shares, but a bid could bring £13.50 to £14.30, the broker thinks. Buy.

Due for a bounce
Rentokil Initial's fall from grace has been as spectacular as a bungee jump from one of the many of its cranes cluttering City skylines.

At 130p, following the dropping of the 20 per cent growth target, the shares now stand at a quarter of their value a year ago. Once again, this is an example of the market behaving like a flock of scatty sheep.

Nonetheless, with profit growth still strong, cash generation excellent and huge share buybacks on the cards, the shares should be due for a bounce.

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Horses for courses
fields.body:
Horses for courses

Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, was too busy to get to Cheltenham for the festival last week, which was a shame as his horse was running. Given Morgan's recent run of bad luck with tipsters, (share rather than racing variety) we don't blame him. Given the City Slicker scandal, we were wondering whether Morgan's horse was either the triumphant 'Looks Like Trouble' or the innocently named 'Pure Coincidence'. As it turned out the name of the mount is in fact Ledham, and his finish far down the field was a disappointment to both Morgan and one of his co-owners: James Hipwell - a fired City Slicker.

No gays please, we're Mail

Media event of the week has without a doubt been the 'gay picket' that descended on the Daily Mail's Kensington headquarters last week. Infuriated by the Voice of Middle England's stance on the scrapping of Clause 28, gay activists stormed the building in the hope that Mail editor Paul Dacre would come and dance at their end of the ballroom if only for a brief minute. But it was not to be: the feisty protesters discovered that the Mail's preposterous editorial line was physically reinforced as appalled Mail staffers attempted to eject them from the building. The unseemly struggle was broken up when Diary editor Nigel Dempster chased after the gay blades. Although pretending to fend them off, one or two protestors are sure they heard Dempster was shouting: 'Please PLEASE let me join you!'

Taking over the asylum

The tiny Scottish Island of Talentfree, which is playing host to Greg Dyke's ambitious 'Cast Off' project, has been thrust into the ferment of the asylum seekers debate. Thousands of BBC employees look set to be shipped out to the island in the wake of a radical 'restructuring', which new Beeb director-general Dyke is implementing. Locals however are up in arms at the thought of tribes of homeless and jobless middle managers swamping their territory. 'They accost you at the traffic light and ask for the price of a business rate mobile phone call in exchange for brushing your sheep - it's a real nuisance,' commented one of Talentfree's indigenous crofters. Home Secretary Jack Straw is promising that anyone caught trying to use a Corporate Amex Card in the local shop would be thrown immediately into jail.

Sergeant at arms

Could we be imagining things again? A Channel Four news bulletin last week had Elinor Goodman, its redoubtable political editor, doorstepping Ken Livingstone over his small extra curricular income in the form of fees for after-dinner-speaking engagements. But who was the shadowy figure holding the furry microphone boom? Could it be Goodman's new ITN colleague John Sergeant? It certainly looked like him.

Clearly many years of distinguished service at the BBC count for nothing in the cut and thrust of commercial telly - he may be the political editor, but he still has to hold the mike.
