fields.headline: Paper blows in windy city
fields.standfirst: The merged Times Mirror/ Tribune group has its sights set on cyberspace, writes  Melinda Wittstock
fields.trailText: On the face of it, the latest American media merger tells an old but all-too-familiar story: yet another family has relinquished control of a newspaper heirloom to a hard-driving multimedia rival. But Monday's merger between the Los Angeles-based Times Mirror newspaper group and Chicago's Tribune Company did take both the media world and Wall Street by surprise.
fields.body:
On the face of it, the latest American media merger tells an old but all-too-familiar story: yet another family has relinquished control of a newspaper heirloom to a hard-driving multimedia rival. But Monday's $8 billion merger between the Los Angeles-based Times Mirror newspaper group and Chicago's Tribune Company - to create America's third-largest newspaper chain - did take both the media world and Wall Street by surprise.

It might not have the romantic glamour of Friday's sale of the Hearst Corp-controlled San Francisco Examiner to the Fang family's San Francisco Independent, but the Times Mirror/Tribune deal has rocked the industry.

No one had thought Times-Mirror's Chandler family, which has controlled the flagship Los Angeles Times since 1882, would ever sell their stake in the name they built into a Californian institution. And no one had believed Tribune, which is fast evolving into what Wall Street calls a 'new media' company - with its mix of newspaper, TV and Internet investments - would take a second glance at a rival still restricting itself to the ink-and-tree trade.

Initially, investors weren't all that keen, seeing the deal as little more than a marriage of convenience between two survivors in a fading world. 'So one newspaper buys another: so what?' said technology and multimedia pundit Esther Dyson. Then Tribune began the spin: no, said chief executive John Madigan, this was all about the Web. And no, buying up a middling newspaper chain that includes the Baltimore Sun , Hartford Courant and Newsday on New York's Long Island was no joke. 'We think we're creating the premier multimedia company in America,' said Madigan, now heading the joint company.

The Tribune's larger plan, he said, was to leverage 'old media' and its prized newspaper content into 'new media' television and Internet outlets: 'We'll be taking local-market media companies and putting them together into a major national footprint.' Not only will the combined group be selling advertising nationally for its regional and city dailies, TV stations and websites, it will also find synergies in its soon to be 'multi-medial' newsgathering force.

Suddenly Wall Street liked what it was hearing. Big-city newspaper circulation is declining, classified advertising has been deserting US newspapers for the Internet, and the merger spelled new-found online muscle. Both firm's sites combined would draw 3.4 million hits a month, compared with 1.8 million for the New York Times and 1.2 million for USA Today .

It was statistics like these that concentrated minds in the aftermath of the AOL/ Time Warner merger and pushed an already bickering third generation of Chandler family controlling shareholders to seek out what Time-Mirror's now ousted chairman and chief executive had believed was unthinkable.

The Chandlers had finally lost patience with Mark Willes and his disdain for new media, his hollow promises of a massive circulation boost and the embarrassing national headlines resulting from his attempts to 'blow up' the wall between Times Mirror journalists and the papers' advertising departments.

A botched revenue-sharing deal last year between the LA Times and the Staples Center, a local sports arena that featured in a Sunday newspaper supplement, earned Willes a public rebuke from Otis Chandler, the 72-year-old former publisher. Chandler said the ethical lapse was 'the single most important threat to the future and growth of this great newspaper'.

A former General Mills executive known as 'the cereal killer' for his cost-cutting and closures, Willes should have seen the writing on the wall. But apparently, he did not: he found out about the secret merger talks two weeks ago. He was outfoxed by Thomas Unterman, Times Mirror's former chief financial officer and 'new media' convert, who went behind his back to set the Chandlers up with Tribune - securing a place on the merged com pany's board and a $2 million 'investment advisory fee'.

The ousting of Willes sweetened a bitter pill for journalists in the Times-Mirror stable: Schadenfreude is helping them cope with the loss of independence to the aggressive crowd from the Chicago Tribune and the inevitable redundancies to come from the heralded new multimedia synergies ahead.

Tribune has been ahead of the game in melding its media properties to boost its brand name and extend its reach.

It already has holdings in a range of leading e-companies, including Excite@home, iVillage and Replay networks. Its best investment was the $5 million it paid in 1991 for 10 per cent of AOL - now worth hundreds of millions.

But pundits wonder how successfully the combined company's 'old media' interests can work in the Internet domain. So far, Tribune's online investments have boasted a bigger payoff than its websites - most of which are extensions of its newspapers and TV stations, which have lost the company $30m a year for three years running.

The jury is still out on whether 'old media' giants will ever be able to make much money online. The venerable Washington Post , for one, has lost more than $100m on the e-edition it launched four years ago - despite last month attracting more hits to its site, and keeping them longer than any competitor. But even with a record 108.2 million hits in February, second only to MSNBC.com, the online partnership between Microsoft and NBC TV network,WashingtonPost.com has kept its parent company's earnings flat.

By the same measure, the Chicago Tribune 's dot.com edition ranks fifteenth in cyber-news traffic behind CNN, USA Today , the BBC and even the Drudge Report, which puts a question mark on its strategy's viability.

No traditional media player has yet exploited the potential of the Internet: AOL wants Time Warner, because even Goliath couldn't do it.

New Internet powers lack content. The success of wedlock between two old media giants will be measured in cyberspace.

No one had thought Times-Mirror's Chandler family, which has controlled the flagship Los Angeles Times since 1882, would ever sell their stake in the name they built into a Californian institution. And no one had believed Tribune, which is fast evolving into what Wall Street calls a 'new media' company - with its mix of newspaper, TV and Internet investments - would take a second glance at a rival still restricting itself to the ink-and-tree trade. Initially, investors weren't all that keen, seeing the deal as little more than a marriage of convenience between two survivors in a fading world. 'So one newspaper buys another: so what?' said technology and multimedia pundit Esther Dyson. Then Tribune began the spin: no, said chief executive John Madigan, this was all about the Web. And no, buying up a middling newspaper chain that includes the Baltimore Sun , Hartford Courant and Newsday on New York's Long Island was no joke. 'We think we're creating the premier multimedia company in America,' said Madigan, now heading the joint company. The Tribune's larger plan, he said, was to leverage 'old media' and its prized newspaper content into 'new media' television and Internet outlets: 'We'll be taking local-market media companies and putting them together into a major national footprint.' Not only will the combined group be selling advertising nationally for its regional and city dailies, TV stations and websites, it will also find synergies in its soon to be 'multi-medial' newsgathering force. Suddenly Wall Street liked what it was hearing. Big-city newspaper circulation is declining, classified advertising has been deserting US newspapers for the Internet, and the merger spelled new-found online muscle. Both firm's sites combined would draw 3.4 million hits a month, compared with 1.8 million for the New York Times and 1.2 million for USA Today . It was statistics like these that concentrated minds in the aftermath of the AOL/ Time Warner merger and pushed an already bickering third generation of Chandler family controlling shareholders to seek out what Time-Mirror's now ousted chairman and chief executive had believed was unthinkable. The Chandlers had finally lost patience with Mark Willes and his disdain for new media, his hollow promises of a massive circulation boost and the embarrassing national headlines resulting from his attempts to 'blow up' the wall between Times Mirror journalists and the papers' advertising departments. A botched revenue-sharing deal last year between the LA Times and the Staples Center, a local sports arena that featured in a Sunday newspaper supplement, earned Willes a public rebuke from Otis Chandler, the 72-year-old former publisher. Chandler said the ethical lapse was 'the single most important threat to the future and growth of this great newspaper'. A former General Mills executive known as 'the cereal killer' for his cost-cutting and closures, Willes should have seen the writing on the wall. But apparently, he did not: he found out about the secret merger talks two weeks ago. He was outfoxed by Thomas Unterman, Times Mirror's former chief financial officer and 'new media' convert, who went behind his back to set the Chandlers up with Tribune - securing a place on the merged com pany's board and a $2 million 'investment advisory fee'. The ousting of Willes sweetened a bitter pill for journalists in the Times-Mirror stable: Schadenfreude is helping them cope with the loss of independence to the aggressive crowd from the Chicago Tribune and the inevitable redundancies to come from the heralded new multimedia synergies ahead. Tribune has been ahead of the game in melding its media properties to boost its brand name and extend its reach. It already has holdings in a range of leading e-companies, including Excite@home, iVillage and Replay networks. Its best investment was the $5 million it paid in 1991 for 10 per cent of AOL - now worth hundreds of millions. But pundits wonder how successfully the combined company's 'old media' interests can work in the Internet domain. So far, Tribune's online investments have boasted a bigger payoff than its websites - most of which are extensions of its newspapers and TV stations, which have lost the company $30m a year for three years running. The jury is still out on whether 'old media' giants will ever be able to make much money online. The venerable Washington Post , for one, has lost more than $100m on the e-edition it launched four years ago - despite last month attracting more hits to its site, and keeping them longer than any competitor. But even with a record 108.2 million hits in February, second only to MSNBC.com, the online partnership between Microsoft and NBC TV network,WashingtonPost.com has kept its parent company's earnings flat. By the same measure, the Chicago Tribune 's dot.com edition ranks fifteenth in cyber-news traffic behind CNN, USA Today , the BBC and even the Drudge Report, which puts a question mark on its strategy's viability. No traditional media player has yet exploited the potential of the Internet: AOL wants Time Warner, because even Goliath couldn't do it. New Internet powers lack content. The success of wedlock between two old media giants will be measured in cyberspace.

webTitle: On finding your bra size - and exercising your cat...

fields.headline: On finding your bra size - and exercising your cat...
fields.trailText: If your children are wondering what they should do for a living in the next decade or two, just whisper two words in their ears: intellectual property (IP).
fields.body:
If your children are wondering what they should do for a living in the next decade or two, just whisper two words in their ears: intellectual property (IP). Even Presidents Clinton and Blair have tumbled to this, as witnessed by their well-intentioned but vacuous statement last week about patenting the human genome. But while the IP problems posed by genetic research lie some distance ahead, those posed by the Internet and the US Office of Trademarks and Patents are very real and present.

Most people assume you have to be clever to be awarded a patent. The database of US patents maintained by IBM and provided free on the Web suggests otherwise. James Gleick of the New York Times rummaged around in it and found things you just would not believe. US Patent 5,993,336, for example, asserts proprietary rights on 'executing a tennis stroke while wearing a knee pad'.

Then there is 'Method of Bra Size Determination by Direct Measurement of the Breast' (US 5,965,809). This includes 'initially measuring the user's chest or torso circumference with a flexible tape measure immediately below the breasts followed by the step of adding five inches to the measured number and incorporating conventional rounding-off procedures'.

My favourite, though, is a patent on a method for exercising a cat (US 5,443,036). 'A method for inducing cats to exercise,' it reads, 'consists of directing a beam of invisible light produced by a hand-held laser apparatus onto the floor or wall or other opaque surface in the vicinity of the cat, then moving the laser so as to cause the bright pattern of light to move in an irregular way fascinating to cats, and to any other animal with a chase instinct.' (I am not making this up.) So next time you play with your cat, remember that you are abusing someone else's intellectual property.

In the circumstances, Amazon's infamous 'One-Click' patent may seem almost respectable. But it has attracted widespread condemnation. Richard Stallman, the programmer who founded the Free Software Foundation and is ultimately responsible for the Open Source movement, has been campaigning for a boycott of Amazon because of the patent and the company's aggressive attitude towards defending it. His campaign made some headway with the hacker community, but was ignored by mainstream Net users.

But then it was revealed that Amazon had done something even more crass - it had patented its 'affiliates' programme. This is the ingenious scheme whereby if you put a link on your website to Amazon you get a small royalty on anything they sell as a result of people jumping from your site to theirs.

It's a neat idea and one from which many people have benefited, including this columnist. It fits beautifully with the co-operative ethos of the Net. But using the patent laws to clobber other people who might like to use the same idea is so outrageous that Amazon suddenly began to feel the heat. Internet publisher Tim O'Reilly set up a special website and wrote an open letter to Amazon's chief executive and presiding genius Jeff Bezos. Several hundred other people emailed Bezos to complain.

After several days, Bezos replied, with a message that was conciliatory in tone but gave nothing substantive away. 'Despite the call from many thoughtful folks for us to give up our patents unilaterally,' he wrote, 'I don't believe it would be right for us to do so. I also doubt whether our giving up our patents would really provide much of a stepping stone to solving the bigger problem.'

Sigh. Even Bezos doesn't get it. On the grounds that the poor sap will have to be taught a lesson, I've written to Amazon resigning from their affiliate programme. You could call it standing down for one's principles.

 john.naughton@observer.co.uk. For links and background material see www.briefhistory.com/footnotes/

fields.headline: Can men read?
fields.trailText: A survey carried out by the organisers of the Orange Prize for Fiction has found that men are narrow-minded when it comes to choosing books. They are put off by 'female reads', things with 'love' in the title and by soppy covers. Such inhibitions mean that only 2 per cent of the survey group would consider reading highly rated authors such as A.S. Byatt, Anne Tyler and Margaret Atwood. Ian McEwan's Enduring Love (take it from us, a solid masculine read) would be kept, if at all, under the mattress or in plain brown wrapping.
fields.body:
A survey carried out by the organisers of the Orange Prize for Fiction has found that men are narrow-minded when it comes to choosing books. They are put off by 'female reads', things with 'love' in the title and by soppy covers. Such inhibitions mean that only 2 per cent of the survey group would consider reading highly rated authors such as A.S. Byatt, Anne Tyler and Margaret Atwood. Ian McEwan's Enduring Love (take it from us, a solid masculine read) would be kept, if at all, under the mattress or in plain brown wrapping.

Women, on the other hand, as well as now playing football by the raucous coach load, read widely and open-mindedly, including books such as Nick Hornby's High Fidelity , marketed as blokeish. No doubt the Government will step in soon and order a boys' own literary hour. But, as that very male writer Samuel Johnson once said of women preachers (like a dog standing on its hind legs, he thought), the surprise is not what men are reading, but that they do it at all.

webTitle: Politicians have the best pension scheme in Britain

fields.headline: Politicians have the best pension scheme in Britain
fields.trailText: Politicians' careers may be precarious but when they retire they enjoy the benefits of the best pension scheme in the country.
fields.body:
Politicians' careers may be precarious but when they retire they enjoy the benefits of the best pension scheme in the country.

A survey by Bryn Davies, an actuary who specialises in advising trade unions, has awarded the Parliamentary Contributory Fund the highest score out of 275 schemes that he surveyed. Companies surveyed cover two-thirds of all occupational scheme members.

Davies scores schemes according to a range of benefits for new members and sets this against a target, or ideal scheme. The target scheme has a score of 100 per cent and the Parliamentary Contributory Fund scores 124 per cent.

Davies notes, however, that the list of top pension providers is dominated by private-sector companies, rather than public-sector organisations. The results challenge traditional pensions wisdom that final salary pension schemes, where pensions are linked to salary and length of service, usually provide better benefits than money pur chase schemes, where the outcome depends on stock market growth and annuity rates.

In second place, with a score of 123 per cent, is a BP scheme (the 5:45 Plan), followed by Glaxo Wellcome's money purchase scheme. Then come Schroders, the BAT Class C scheme, the Barclays Bank Retirement Investment Scheme, the Warner Lambert money purchase scheme, Marks & Spencer, the main tier Nationwide building society plan and in 10th place the HSBC Defined Contribution Scheme.

The list of schemes offering the poorest benefits according to Davies' scores includes a sprinkling of well known names, including Grandmet's Core Plan, BOC's Level 1 scheme and the National Freight Corporation First Tier Plan. All scored 55 per cent or less. In some cases the same employers have other pension plans that score more highly. BOC's level-two plan is ranked 105th, while NFC's second-tier plan for employees over 40 is ranked 158th.

webTitle: Rover jobs toll set to mount

fields.headline: Rover jobs toll set to mount
fields.standfirst:
'Up to 8,000' to go at Longbridge | Byers heard sale rumours last year | Dealers face wipe-out
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's biggest car factory could be stripped to a shell employing a mere 1,000 workers, a leading car industry expert and former Rover adviser warned this weekend.
fields.byline: Oliver Morgan, Joanna Walters  and Paul Farrelly
fields.body:
Britain's biggest car factory could be stripped to a shell employing a mere 1,000 workers, a leading car industry expert and former Rover adviser warned this weekend.

Estimates of total job losses in the wake of the Rover débacle are expected to soar, with a further 20,000 disappearing if the 300-strong UK dealer network collapses.

And the embarrassment to Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers is set to deepen: The Observer has learnt that he first heard of a possible deal between BMW and London venture capital firm Alchemy as long as six months ago. Byers confronted BMW, but the company denied it.

Warwick University's Professor Kumar Bhattacharyya, a former adviser to Rover, said he believed the bulk of the 9,000 workers at the Longbridge plant in Birmingham would not survive when Alchemy imposes its new sports car strategy. 'I can't see them having more than 1,500 people, but it could be as low as 1,000,' said Bhattacharyya. Longbridge is now estimated to support indirectly a further 50,000 West Midlands jobs.

Bhattacharyya was critical of Alchemy's 'confused' plans to convert Rover into a niche sports-car maker, and cast doubt on its stated aim of building 100,000 vehicles a year - only around a fifth of current Rover production.

BMW offloaded Rover to Alchemy in a shock deal last week, followed by the sale of Land Rover to Ford for £1.8 billion, which was seen as a desperate attempt to raise cash and bolster BMW's battered finances by covering the write-down on two years of Rover losses totalling £1.9bn.

Alchemy managing partner Jon Moulton said on Friday he wanted to imitate sports car maker Lotus. Rover would be renamed MG Cars and turned into a 'small- volume producer'.

It is feared that up to 20,000 people selling Rover cars in the UK could also lose their jobs if Alchemy ends mass production and the dealer network collapses.

A source close to the deal warned this weekend that all 3,000 Rover dealers in 42 coun tries around the world are under threat. 'God knows what's going to happen to the sales network, he said. 'Many of the overseas showrooms now sell all three marques: Rover, BMW and Land Rover. It's a real mess, but with our reduced sales there will have to be a lot fewer Rover dealers in future anyway.'

There are 320 franchised Rover dealers in this country; hundreds of leasing companies and second-hand car trader also rely on the brand.

Alan Pulham, director of the National Franchised Dealers' Association warned that if confidence in the brand collapsed, the 20,000 jobs involved in selling the cars in the UK would be threatened.

Other manufacturers have already been trimming their networks, making the chances of Rover dealers switching easily to other marques less likely.

Sources close to Rover's network said consumers began cancelling or postponing orders for cars within hours of hearing BMW was breaking up the company. Showrooms selling W-plate cars were deserted. One source said the value of second-hand Rovers was forecast to fall by up to 50 per cent.

Rover union leaders are believed to have ruled out a strike for fear of losing public support, but are considering organising demonstrations outside Britain's 150 BMW dealerships in a bid to persuade the German carmaker back to the negotiating table to sell Rover as a job lot.

Byers is meeting senior executives from BMW, Alchemy and Ford this week in an attempt to reverse the break-up of Rover. Under the outline deal signed last week, Alchemy will continue to build and market the existing Rover 75, 45 and 25 cars only for 'as long as they sell'. After that it will shrink production capacity and concentrate on building sports cars.

The Observer has discovered that although the Trade and Industry Secretary has said the first he knew of the Alchemy deal was when it was sewn up on Wednesday last week, he was in fact aware of reputed talks between BMW and Alchemy six months ago.

When he challenged the Munich carmaker, senior executives told him BMW was not interested in the venture capital firm and there was 'nothing on the table'.

A DTI source said questions had been asked in the department about Alchemy last autumn - but the rumours were discounted.

webTitle: Who's been looking at your CV?

fields.headline: Who's been looking at your CV?
fields.standfirst: Job-hunting in cyberspace? Look out for black holes, says  Mark Anstead
fields.trailText: Job hunters beware - if you are looking for work on the internet, check that the websites you use observe ethical standards of practice. If not, you could end up chasing vacancies that don't exist - or even find your CV landing on your own manager's desk.
fields.body:
Job hunters beware - if you are looking for work on the internet, check that the websites you use observe ethical standards of practice. If not, you could end up chasing vacancies that don't exist - or even find your CV landing on your own manager's desk.

The Department of Trade and Industry recently proposed changes to the Employment Agencies Act specifically designed to curb unethical practices among Internet recruiters. Concerns include websites copying vacancies from one another and fabricating jobs to attract CVs and the indiscriminate circulation of CVs potentially compromising a job hunter's position with his own employer.

But doubts remain about whether the proposed law, due for debate in Parliament later this year, will be enforceable. 'The changes in legislation are not enough,' says Dave Ferguson, chief executive of ethical online recruitment firm 1st-Wave.com. 'We have heard horror stories of candidates who lost their jobs because their CVs were submitted to their existing employer. The low cost of the internet has opened the door to the cowboys - but if they get prosecuted they'll simply wind down the company and start a new one.'

Under the current law an employment agency can freely circulate the CV of any workseeker as long as it is for the purpose of finding work, not selling the data. But internet recruiters often rely on little more than a basic keyword match before allowing employers to view the contents of their CV database, and even anonymous profiles can be recognised. The new legislation will make it a criminal offence for an agency to pass a CV to a candidate's current employer without the candidate's permission and the Government hopes this will force internet sites to introduce more advanced filtering technology.

Ferguson thinks the changes must go further. 'It's relatively easy to screen out certain recipients from receiving the data but that doesn't stop a CV being automatically spewed all over the web and falling into the wrong hands,' he says. 'Candidates should look for websites that guarantee they will not send CVs to any potential hirer without informing them who that hirer is. We simply must put the candidate in control of the whole process.' 1st-Wave.com's own web site, www.jobbox.net only matches candidates to specific jobs, and offers online assessment and testing with video interviewing soon to be introduced.

The industry may eventually see the emergence of a self-regulating body. Prior to that, a new Association of Online Recruiters is soon to be formed comprising an initial membership of job sites such as www.Cityjobs.com, www.jobsite.co.uk and People Bank. The Association will seek to promote higher standards of ethical practice within the industry although there is no direct compulsion for any recruiter to join.

Stephen Anderson, chief executive of Cityjobs.com, has had some of his own vacancies copied and posted on Compurecruit.com, a rogue online recruitment service operating from a small flat in Edinburgh. 'I think it happened to bolster the number of jobs in its database to attract more site visitors and increase advertising revenue,' he says. 'We know the vacancies were lifted from our database via the employment listings at Yahoo! UK & Ireland because they all carried Yahoo! reference numbers.'

Compurecruit is in breach of current regulations for advertising the vacancies without clearly stating it had no authority from the hirer. The new law will make it a criminal offence to advertise without specific authority, which the Government hopes will outlaw fictional vacancies as well.

Portals such as Yahoo!, Freeserve and MSN operate as internet publishers, and their career sections function in a similar way to classified advertisement listings in a national newspaper. A spokesman from Yahoo! denied that it had any legal responsibility to pursue action for the data theft on the grounds that the data was not owned by them but by the job agency posting it on their site.

Under the Advertising Standards code publishers are requested to check ads for truthfulness and honesty, a task made harder with the sheer volume of ads that electronic communication can produce. Some internet publishers, moreover, carried away on a wave of enthusiasm, may find controlling the quality of their data low on their list of priorities. The code is a self-regulating, rather than a legal standard, but the new Employment Agencies Act includes a section covering instances where more than one agent is involved in advertising a position (which has become common on the Web). Whether internet portals will also come under the jurisdiction of the new proposals is yet to be decided, proving how difficult it is to legislate then internet in practice.

'Portals are crossing the line from publisher to agent and it shows how mad the internet recruitment industry has become,' says David Bosdet, independent internet recruitment strategist. 'I am looking forward to the next stages in development which will put an internal market pressure on the industry. When job sites begin to offer interactive online assessment or video interviewing, then employers will start to demand those features as standard and cowboy operators, who can't afford to make the technology investment will find life more difficult.'

But internet recruiters often rely on little more than a basic keyword match before allowing employers to view the contents of their CV database, and even anonymous profiles can be recognised. The new legislation will make it a criminal offence for an agency to pass a CV to a candidate's current employer without the candidate's permission and the Government hopes this will force internet sites to introduce more advanced filtering technology. Ferguson thinks the changes must go further. 'It's relatively easy to screen out certain recipients from receiving the data but that doesn't stop a CV being automatically spewed all over the web and falling into the wrong hands,' he says. 'Candidates should look for websites that guarantee they will not send CVs to any potential hirer without informing them who that hirer is. We simply must put the candidate in control of the whole process.' 1st-Wave.com's own web site, www.jobbox.net only matches candidates to specific jobs, and offers online assessment and testing with video interviewing soon to be introduced. The industry may eventually see the emergence of a self-regulating body. Prior to that, a new Association of Online Recruiters is soon to be formed comprising an initial membership of job sites such as www.Cityjobs.com, www.jobsite.co.uk and People Bank. The Association will seek to promote higher standards of ethical practice within the industry although there is no direct compulsion for any recruiter to join. Stephen Anderson, chief executive of Cityjobs.com, has had some of his own vacancies copied and posted on Compurecruit.com, a rogue online recruitment service operating from a small flat in Edinburgh. 'I think it happened to bolster the number of jobs in its database to attract more site visitors and increase advertising revenue,' he says. 'We know the vacancies were lifted from our database via the employment listings at Yahoo! UK & Ireland because they all carried Yahoo! reference numbers.' Compurecruit is in breach of current regulations for advertising the vacancies without clearly stating it had no authority from the hirer. The new law will make it a criminal offence to advertise without specific authority, which the Government hopes will outlaw fictional vacancies as well. Portals such as Yahoo!, Freeserve and MSN operate as internet publishers, and their career sections function in a similar way to classified advertisement listings in a national newspaper. A spokesman from Yahoo! denied that it had any legal responsibility to pursue action for the data theft on the grounds that the data was not owned by them but by the job agency posting it on their site. Under the Advertising Standards code publishers are requested to check ads for truthfulness and honesty, a task made harder with the sheer volume of ads that electronic communication can produce. Some internet publishers, moreover, carried away on a wave of enthusiasm, may find controlling the quality of their data low on their list of priorities. The code is a self-regulating, rather than a legal standard, but the new Employment Agencies Act includes a section covering instances where more than one agent is involved in advertising a position (which has become common on the Web). Whether internet portals will also come under the jurisdiction of the new proposals is yet to be decided, proving how difficult it is to legislate then internet in practice. 'Portals are crossing the line from publisher to agent and it shows how mad the internet recruitment industry has become,' says David Bosdet, independent internet recruitment strategist. 'I am looking forward to the next stages in development which will put an internal market pressure on the industry. When job sites begin to offer interactive online assessment or video interviewing, then employers will start to demand those features as standard and cowboy operators, who can't afford to make the technology investment will find life more difficult.'

webTitle: Why on the buses beats on the make

fields.headline: Why on the buses beats on the make
fields.standfirst: Plumbers are more valued than entrepreneurs. And that says a lot about the state of UK plc, says  Simon Caulkin
fields.trailText: In the 'New Labour' economic trinity of incubators, enterprise and Cambridge, enterprise clearly represents the Holy Ghost. Tony Blair set out his stall in May 1998 by launching an IPPR report,  The Entrepreneurial Society,  at a Downing Street seminar. Since then the entrepreneurial spirit has (with the Prime Minister's blessing) infused the competitiveness White Paper: the DTI has set up the Small Business Services Agency and the Enterprise Unit to help spread the message to the economy as a whole.
fields.body:
In the 'New Labour' economic trinity of incubators, enterprise and Cambridge, enterprise clearly represents the Holy Ghost. Tony Blair set out his stall in May 1998 by launching an IPPR report, The Entrepreneurial Society, at a Downing Street seminar. Since then the entrepreneurial spirit has (with the Prime Minister's blessing) infused the competitiveness White Paper: the DTI has set up the Small Business Services Agency and the Enterprise Unit to help spread the message to the economy as a whole.

This is a change not just of style but of substance - a gamble on entrepreneurial growing businesses being able to reach parts of UK plc that the old-established company sector could not. In a week when Gordon Brown will certainly reiterate his belief in the new trinity, it is worth asking what that faith is based on. How important is entrepreneurship, and how well fitted are UK managers to remake themselves in the new mould?

First, entrepreneurship does matter. According to the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor (GEM), a comparative research study carried out by London Business School and Babson College in the US, there is a strong link between new firm start-up rates and measures of economic prosperity, particularly changes in GDP and jobs. So boosting the number of start-ups would probably add to both. 'There are no countries with high start-up rates and low levels of economic growth,' notes the report.

But how easy is it to start a company? Not very, is the answer. In the short term, dot.com mania has brought a flurry of entrepreneurial activity, but boosting entrepreneurship depends on deeper cultural and educational factors - and here the news is mixed. In the GEM study, the UK is in the middle of a 10-nation league, well behind the leading group of the US (an easy champion), Canada and Israel. It is on a par with Italy's levels, but ahead of Germany, Denmark, France, Japan and Finland.

That sounds OK; but, says the LBS's Dr Michael Hay, co-author of the report, there aren't really three groups but two: the three leaders and the rest. 'The UK is a long way from moving up into the top group,' notes the report. What's more, the gap can't be closed by more of the same old same old: fundamental change is needed, particularly in education.

This comes out clearly in the GEM analysis, which suggests that today's 'British disease' is an 'entrepreneurial deficit' stopping it exploiting its strengths. Thus, in early 1999, only a third as many respondents as in the US saw good opportunities for start-ups in the next six months - fewer than anywhere except Japan.

Poor peripheral vision for opportunities is accompanied by ill-developed entrepreneurial capacities. The UK scores dismally on skills, motivation and respect for entrepreneurial activity. On the last count, only Japan did worse (a finding underlined by a recent newspaper report that the Scots think entrepreneurs are less valuable economically than plumbers or bus drivers).

The e-commerce frenzy has brought to light other weaknesses. While the UK likes to think of itself as the venture-capital capital of Europe (in fact Germany is catching up), there is a chronic mismatch between fund seekers and providers. Malcolm Holt, managing director of matchco.co.uk, a start-up which aims to improve the fit, points out that 99 per cent of entrepreneurs fail to attract venture funding, while poor hit-rates increase their caution still further.

Frustratingly, the UK has much of the entrepreneurial infrastructure (a good science base, government support and a reasonable funding climate), but not the capacities to exploit it. Building them to the levels of the US or Canada will, says Hay, take years, even generations.

In the meantime, are the roots of the enterprise culture deep enough to survive a sustained stock market setback? Good question, says Hay. He believes attitudes are changing, and cites the serious momentum behind technologies other than e-commerce - mobile telecoms and genomics, for example. But this has yet to reach critical mass. He'd like to see more inducements for individuals and organisations (particularly universities) to take the plunge.

'The big deal about entrepreneurship in the US is that it's not a big deal,' he says. 'It's an ordinary subject of conversation over the supper table. There's still a long way before we get to that situation here.'

Europe fights back in dot.com battle

At a debate organised by Oracle to accompany the launch of www.2becom.com, billed as an online marketplace to help European Internet entrepreneurs get started, 67 per cent of an industry audience sided with the motion: 'This house believes that UK/European dot.coms will resist US dot.com colonisation.'

No one attempted to deny that Europe had lost the first, business-to-consumer (b2c), round of the e-commerce contest. What swayed the debate was the contention that the much bigger second round, business-to-business (b2b), would be different.

Making the case, Mark Suster, American chief executive of construction e-business www.build-online.com, noted that venture capital was pouring into Europe, the capital markets were rewarding start-ups, attitudes were changing, and computer and mobile penetration was up to speed. Meanwhile, US b2b start-ups were too busy fighting for US predominance to spend time and effort figuring out the differences between 15 European markets. European companies, on the other hand, have figured out how to combine technological scale with local scope, and adding the US market was a relatively simple step.

'We lost b2c,' summed up Suster. 'But I've got news: b2b is a whole different kettle of fish - and Europe.com can win it.'

webTitle: Banks braced for savaging in watchdog report

fields.headline: Banks braced for savaging in watchdog report
fields.standfirst: Lloyds TSB
fields.trailText: Banks are prepared for a damning report tomorrow on their charges and anti-competitive practices by Don Cruickshank, the former telecommunications watchdog appointed by the Government to investigate them.
fields.body:
Banks are prepared for a damning report tomorrow on their charges and anti-competitive practices by Don Cruickshank, the former telecommunications watchdog appointed by the Government to investigate them.

Cruickshank has already locked horns with the banks, condemning the charges planned by Barclays and others for use of cash machines by non-customers.

The report will reiterate his belief that banks should charge no more than 30p; Barclays planned a £1 charge.

There is a fear among smaller banks and building societies that the 'big four' plan to use their monopoly over cash machines to increase their stranglehold on the current account market, which they dominate. Those with large machine networks could pro mote free access to them as a selling point for current accounts.

Neil Walkling, a money policy officer at the Consumers' Association, said he believed the timing of the report's publication, one day before the Budget, indicated that Chancellor Gordon Brown planned to announce action in the Budget. He may refer the banks to the Competition Commission.

Cruickshank's report was commissioned by the Chancellor more than 18 months ago.

Walkling said: 'If the big banks can break up the cash machine network, that would suit them, because they have more machines than anyone else. No small player can come in and offer free access across the network.'

However, Cruickshank is expected to criticise the industry over several other aspects. They could, for example, be lambasted for the way they deal with small businesses.

One building society director said: 'I think he will hit banks hardest on small business charges. They are less than transparent and the market is concentrated on Lloyds TSB and Barclays.'

He predicted that the length of time it takes banks to clear cheques - three to four days - could also be attacked by Cruickshank.

One bank spokesman said: 'It's not going to be good news.'

Another said: 'We've got to take it seriously.'

But while the City also expects a robust report - Cruickshank was noted for his tough approach to the telecommunications industry - one analyst said it was difficult to say whether share prices would be hit as a result. There was no guarantee, he said, that Cruickshank's proposals would be implemented. He expected strong lobbying from the banks.

webTitle: Can they sack me for my drinking?

fields.headline: Can they sack me for my drinking?
fields.trailText: I have a bit of a drink problem. It doesn't happen often, but I have been merry on occasion after lunch. We have a new non-drinking, puritanical managing director - and I'm worried that they might do something horrible - like firing me. What is my position?
fields.body:
I have a bit of a drink problem. It doesn't happen often, but I have been merry on occasion after lunch. We have a new non-drinking, puritanical managing director - and I'm worried that they might do something horrible - like firing me. What is my position?

Many companies chose redundancy programmes and other pretexts to get rid of staff they do not like or approve of. An easy way out for a puritanical MD may be to skirt the drink issue completely but tell you that your job is being made redundant. You can appeal if you are made redundant and do not think the official reasons are fair - but don't be too hopeful.

If your employer decides to address the issue head on, your contract of employment is crucial. Your contract terms include any alcohol policy decided by the company.

Angus Council recently fell foul of its own rules, which laid down a procedure for assisting employees with drink problems - including specialist help. So when they sacked someone who went home early one day and ended up in a pub, they were deemed by an Employment Appeal Tribunal to have broken the terms of help which they had laid down. The tribunal said that the employee's dismissal would not have been unfair if there had been no alcohol policy in place.

 Legal advice from Lewis Silkin

webTitle: How to relate to your secretary

fields.headline: How to relate to your secretary
fields.standfirst: Get More From Work - and More Fun by Neasa MacErlean can be purchased online from BOL
fields.trailText: 1. Recognise that office workers are becoming increasingly dependent on secretaries and administrators. A bad relationship with your secretary can be an office death warrant. Unhappy secretaries can do things like telling people you are in the toilet when they ring for you, give you vital bits of information just five minutes before a meeting starts, forget to book your travel tickets and stack your meetings into very stressful timetables.
fields.body:
1. Recognise that office workers are becoming increasingly dependent on secretaries and administrators. A bad relationship with your secretary can be an office death warrant. Unhappy secretaries can do things like telling people you are in the toilet when they ring for you, give you vital bits of information just five minutes before a meeting starts, forget to book your travel tickets and stack your meetings into very stressful timetables.

2. Don't play the traditional macho role, never giving your secretary a 'thank you' or other kind word. Secretaries are rarely in it for the money (even top salaries hit only £25,000 in London) and like all human beings, they respond to encouragement. Letting them know what you like and don't like is vital. In this closest of workplace relationships, you need to work at getting on well.

3. Avoid the common mistake of becoming reliant on your secretary. Many bosses depend on assistants to operate their computer or cover up for long lunches. Don't let your secretary have complete control of who you see: this can lead to the 'priest's housekeeper' syndrome, in which the doorkeeper has power because she controls access to the great man.

4. Think through the controversial coffee-making question. 'It's a big no-no to ask your secretary to make coffee or tea,' says Jackie Campbell of Reed Employment. You probably need to discuss the issue. Some people will see it as a status and power issue. But they may be more amenable if you show your appreciation and are genuinely too busy.

5. Never shout at your secretary. It is a sign that you cannot deal rationally. Since subordinates find it hard to shout back, you are, in fact, pulling rank, and will become far less respected.

6. Ask your secretary to talk to you freely if he or she has concerns or ideas about how you organise your business. 'You've then got to listen,' says Patrick, who has had extremely successful working relationships with two secretaries. 'You mustn't shut them up or do nothing about what they say - though that can be tempting.'
